summary: The logic is simple: use a conservative default for takeoff and landing assumptions, and only grant credit for automatic thrust increases or special operations when the applicant proves their safety and reliability under Appendix I and dedicated approvals.
intent: CS 25.20 defines the baseline assumptions for the Flight (Subpart B) requirements for turbine-powered aeroplanes. By default, takeoff performance is shown without any post-failure thrust increase (no “thrust bump” after an engine fails), unless an approved automatic system is installed that meets the extra reliability and performance criteria in Appendix I. It also cautions that the basic Subpart B rules do not, by themselves, cover special operations such as automatic landings (autoland), approaches/landings below a 200 ft decision height (DH), or operations from unprepared (e.g., gravel) runways—these need separate investigation and approval. The objective is to set a conservative, common basis for performance and limitations, and to ensure additional system credit or special operations are only accepted after focused safety substantiation. Terms: ATTCS (Automatic Takeoff Thrust Control System) or APR (Automatic Performance Reserve) automatically increases remaining engine power after an engine failure on takeoff.
events: Regulatory change: FAA Amendment 25-62 (53 FR 34215, 1988) added Part 25 Appendix I for Automatic Takeoff Thrust Control Systems (ATTCS), requiring demonstrated reliability before crediting thrust increases after an engine failure; CS-25 mirrors this by pointing to Appendix I in 25.20(c).

Programme lesson: BEA’s Hawker Siddeley Trident achieved routine CAT III autoland in the mid‑1960s, leading to dedicated AWO (All Weather Operations) approval frameworks (e.g., CAT II/III approvals), showing that autoland and DH <200 ft are certified via special processes beyond baseline Subpart B.

Operational practice: Boeing 737‑200 “Gravel Kit” operations in Canada/Alaska were approved via specific modifications and AFM supplements, demonstrating that unprepared runway use requires separate substantiation outside the standard CS‑25 flight requirements.

summary: The logic is simple: prove with tests or equally reliable analysis that handling and performance are safe across all approved weights/CGs, altitudes, winds, and applicable icing conditions—including when relying on automation—and control test conditions so the results are valid.
intent: CS 25.21 defines how an applicant must prove a transport airplane meets all Subpart B (Flight) requirements across its intended operating envelope. It requires demonstration of controllability, stability, trim, and stall behavior at every approved combination of weight and center of gravity (CG) and at all operating altitudes, using flight tests or analyses of equal fidelity, with systematic coverage of probable combinations. Critical test parameters (weight/CG/inertia, airspeed, power, wind) must be tightly controlled so results are valid. If compliance depends on a stability augmentation system (SAS) or any automatic/powered system, those systems must meet the flight-control safety rules (CS 25.671/25.672). Winds used in performance tests must be referenced to a 10 m height. For icing, applicants must show compliance in Appendix C (classical icing) and, if applicable, Appendix O (supercooled large droplet, SLD) using defined ice accretions and normal ice-protection operation—or demonstrate a safe exit if not seeking all Appendix O conditions. Basic weight and CG limits cannot be relaxed for icing.
events: American Eagle Flight 4184 (ATR 72), Roselawn, Indiana, 31 Oct 1994: Encountered supercooled large droplet (SLD) icing causing aileron hinge-moment reversal and loss of control; the investigation drove creation of Appendix O and today’s requirements to demonstrate flight characteristics and safe exit in such icing. This event shows why CS 25.21(g) mandates specific icing envelopes and defined ice accretions for proving compliance.

Boeing 737 MAX accidents Lion Air 610 (2018) and Ethiopian Airlines 302 (2019): The MCAS stability augmentation, used to meet pitch characteristics, was vulnerable to single-sensor failure and not fully assessed across the envelope. These accidents demonstrate CS 25.21(e)’s intent that when compliance depends on automatic systems, they must meet CS 25.671/25.672 and be proven under representative conditions.

National Air Cargo Flight 102 (Boeing 747-400BCF), Bagram, 29 Apr 2013: Cargo shift drove the center of gravity far aft, causing a steep pitch-up and stall shortly after takeoff. The loss shows why compliance must be demonstrated over the full weight and CG range and why controllability and stall margins at aft CG are critical per CS 25.21(a) and (c).

summary: The logic is simple: define and publish the proven-safe combinations of weight, CG, and load distribution, and do not allow operations beyond what structure and flight tests have shown to be safe.
intent: Ensure the airplane is only operated within combinations of total weight and center of gravity (CG, the balance point) that have been proven safe for both structure and flight handling, including any additional limits on how loads are distributed (e.g., fore-aft, left-right, and along the wings). If safe operation depends on specific load patterns—such as fuel sequencing, lateral balance, or cargo placement that could be accidentally exceeded—those limits must be identified and published with the corresponding allowable weight/CG ranges. In practice, the approved envelope cannot be wider than: what the manufacturer chooses to publish, what structural tests/analysis support, and what flight performance and controllability testing under Subpart B demonstrate.
events: National Airlines Flight 102 (B747‑400BCF), Bagram 2013: multiple armored vehicles shifted aft on takeoff, driving the CG beyond limits and causing loss of control and a fatal crash. It shows why strict load distribution limits and securing methods must keep CG within the certified envelope.

Fine Air Flight 101 (DC‑8‑61F), Miami 1997: improperly secured pallets shifted aft at rotation, producing an out‑of‑limit aft CG, steep pitch-up, stall, and crash; falsified load paperwork masked the risk. It demonstrates that exceeding load distribution/CG limits quickly compromises controllability.

Programme lesson – Airbus A380 fuel management (Load Alleviation Fuel Management): Airbus documentation describes automatic fuel transfer and tank sequencing to control spanwise and longitudinal load distribution and wing bending moments, with AFM/FCOM limits on tank usage. This illustrates how certified load distribution limits are embedded in fueling/transfer procedures to keep the airplane within the proven envelope.

summary: The logic is simple: only publish weights you can prove safe for structure, handling, performance, and noise in all relevant conditions—never allow operation above those maxima or below those minima.
intent: Ensure manufacturers set and publish realistic maximum and minimum aeroplane weights for each phase of operation (ramp, taxi, take-off, en‑route, landing) that are actually proven safe for structure, handling, performance, and noise. Maximum weights cannot exceed what is demonstrated in tests and analysis (including environmental effects like high altitude/temperature and loading like center of gravity (CG), zero fuel weight (ZFW), and distribution). Minimum weight cannot be below what is shown to satisfy structural and flight requirements, guarding against issues at very light mass (e.g., controllability, stability, flutter). In short, declared weights such as maximum take-off weight (MTOW), maximum landing weight (MLW), and ZFW must be engineering‑demonstrated, not marketing claims, across real operating and environmental conditions.
events: Fine Air Flight 101 (DC-8F), Miami, 1997: Improperly loaded cargo drove the CG aft and the aircraft was overloaded, leading to loss of control immediately after take-off and a fatal crash; this shows why strict maximums tied to CG and weight distribution (including ZFW limits) must be established and respected.

National Airlines Flight 102 (B747-400BCF), Bagram, 2013: Heavy vehicles shifted aft on rotation, moving CG out of the certified envelope and causing an unrecoverable pitch-up; this demonstrates the need to certify and enforce weight/CG limits for real loading conditions and distributions, not just total mass.

United Airlines Flight 328 (B777-200), Denver, 2021: After an engine failure the crew jettisoned fuel to get down to the aircraft’s maximum landing weight before returning, illustrating that distinct certified maximum weights exist for different phases (take-off vs landing) and must govern operational decisions.

summary: The logic is simple: only allow CG ranges in service that have been structurally proven and flight-tested for each practicable loading/configuration, and never certify beyond the evidence.
intent: Set safe forward and aft center of gravity (CG) limits for every distinct, real-world operating condition (e.g., different payload distributions, fuel states, or configurations) so the airplane only operates where its structure has been substantiated and its handling, stability, and controllability meet the flight rules. The approved CG envelope must not exceed what was actually proven during certification: it can be no wider than the applicant’s proposed range, the structural substantiation, or the flight-performance/compliance evidence. This prevents hazards such as excessive rotation distance or inability to rotate (forward CG), pitch instability, tailplane/elevator saturation, stalls or tailstrikes (aft CG), and abnormal structural loads. In short, it translates certification proof into practical, operational CG limits for all realistic loading cases.
events: National Airlines Flight 102 (Boeing 747‑400BCF), Bagram, 2013: poorly restrained heavy vehicles shifted aft on takeoff, moving CG outside limits and damaging control systems, leading to loss of control and crash (NTSB AAR‑15/01). It shows why the operational CG envelope must reflect proven structural and flight-control margins for all realistic load conditions.

Fine Air Flight 101 (DC‑8‑61F), Miami, 1997: aft cargo shift created an excessively aft CG, causing premature rotation, stall, and crash shortly after liftoff (NTSB AAR‑98/06). It demonstrates how exceeding aft CG limits degrades stability/controllability and why clear, enforceable CG bounds are essential.

Airbus A380 flight‑test program (MSN001, 2005–2007): engineers used water‑ballast tanks to move CG to forward and aft extremes to show compliance and define the certified CG envelope (Airbus public flight‑test reports/media). This illustrates the rule’s requirement that in‑service CG limits are no wider than the structurally and flight‑tested extremes.

summary: The logic is simple: weigh the airplane in a standard, repeatable “always-carried-fluids” condition so all later loading and performance calculations use the same accurate baseline for weight and CG.
intent: Establish a precise, repeatable baseline for an airplane’s mass and balance. The rule requires determining the “empty weight” and its corresponding center of gravity (CG) by actually weighing the aircraft in a clearly defined condition that includes fixed ballast, all unusable fuel (fuel that cannot be fed to the engines), and full operating fluids (oil, hydraulic fluid, and other system fluids that are always carried), while excluding variable service items like potable and lavatory water. This ensures everyone—designers, certifiers, and operators—starts weight-and-balance (W&B) and performance calculations from the same accurate reference. A stable baseline prevents hidden errors that could shift the CG out of limits, compromise controllability, or degrade takeoff/landing performance, and allows reweighing to be done consistently over the aircraft’s life.
events: Fine Air Flight 101 (DC‑8‑61F), Miami, 1997: improperly loaded/unsecured cargo shifted aft on takeoff, driving the CG out of limits and causing a stall and crash. It shows that safe loading depends on correct CG calculations that begin with a known, accurate empty weight/CG baseline.

National Airlines Flight 102 (Boeing 747‑400BCF), Bagram, 2013: heavy vehicles shifted aft after rotation, moving CG beyond limits and leading to loss of control. The accident underscores that any divergence between actual mass/CG and calculated values is catastrophic, reinforcing the need for precise, repeatable baseline weight/CG data.

Boeing 787 early program (publicly reported overweight early airframes): several tonnes of unexpected empty-weight growth required revised performance and payload‑range planning. This program lesson shows why accurately determining and publishing empty weight and corresponding CG in a defined condition is essential for reliable AFM data and operator load sheets.

summary: The logic is simple: you may temporarily add secured weight to place the aircraft at precise weight/CG extremes so you can prove handling, stability, and performance compliance before final interiors or real payloads exist.
intent: This rule says it is acceptable to add temporary, removable weight (ballast) to a test airplane to prove it meets the flight rules in CS-25 Subpart B. The underlying objective is to let manufacturers safely and precisely simulate the full range of mass properties—especially extreme center-of-gravity (CG) and weight conditions—before the cabin is finished or real payloads are available. Using removable ballast makes controllability, stability, and performance tests repeatable at the exact weight/CG points required, without committing those masses to the final design. It implicitly relies on other rules for the safe installation and securement of ballast, while enabling credible, worst‑case demonstrations that the airplane flies safely across its certified envelope.
events: BAC One-Eleven G-ASHG (1963) – deep stall during stall testing with aft CG led to a fatal crash near Chicklade, UK. It underscored why certification must rigorously explore and document aft-CG handling—often achieved using removable ballast—to validate stall and stability margins.

National Air Cargo 747-400 (Flight 102), Bagram, 2013 – load shift drove the CG aft and the aircraft became uncontrollable after takeoff. The accident shows how critical correct mass distribution and securement are, reinforcing that any test ballast must be carefully placed and restrained when simulating CG limits.

Air Midwest Flight 5481 (Beech 1900D), Charlotte, 2003 – an out‑of‑limit aft CG combined with maintenance issues led to a stall after takeoff. It demonstrates the consequences of aft-CG conditions and why certification uses controlled, removable ballast to validate controllability at CG extremes.

summary: The logic is simple: cap propeller RPM and prevent excessively low blade pitch so that even with failures or worst-case power the engine and airframe stay within safe limits while still delivering required performance.
intent: Ensure that large aeroplanes with propellers operate safely and meet required performance by hard-limiting propeller rotational speed (RPM: revolutions per minute) and blade pitch angle. The rule requires a speed-governing device that cannot allow the engine/propeller to exceed the certified maximum RPM, and a reliably set low‑pitch stop so that, even if the governor fails and the blades drive to minimum pitch at maximum take-off power, the engine will not overspeed beyond a narrowly defined margin. These limits protect against hazardous thrust asymmetry, structural loads, noise, and potential uncontained failures, and they keep the propeller within the efficient range needed to meet performance rules (CS 25.101–25.125) for take-off, climb, and landing.
events: Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 2311 (EMB‑120, 5 Apr 1991, Brunswick, GA): A Hamilton Standard propeller control unit failure drove the left propeller toward an abnormally low blade angle, causing uncontrollable asymmetric thrust and a fatal crash (NTSB). This demonstrates why certification demands reliable governing and hard limits on low pitch to prevent hazardous thrust/overspeed states.

Luxair Flight 9642 (Fokker 50, 6 Nov 2002, near Niederanven): Inadvertent selection of ground/low‑pitch range in flight led to severe asymmetric thrust/drag and loss of control; subsequent actions included strengthening beta lock protections. This underscores the rule’s purpose to limit blade pitch to safe ranges under all operating conditions.

Loganair Saab 340B G‑LGNL (10 Jul 2014, serious incident; AAIB Bulletin 2/2015): An in‑flight propeller overspeed due to a governor malfunction was contained and the crew landed safely after shutdown. It illustrates the need for independent propeller speed limiting and correctly set low‑pitch stops so a governor failure cannot let RPM exceed approved limits.

summary: The logic is simple: set conservative, standardized conditions and real-world, executable procedures so published performance reflects installed thrust and average-crew execution, not idealized test conditions.
intent: CS 25.101 sets the ground rules for establishing and publishing transport airplane performance. It standardizes the atmosphere used (still air with defined relative humidity vs temperature), requires performance to be based on installed, approved engine power/thrust after installation losses and accessory/bleed loads, and ties configurations to real operating procedures. The applicant may choose configurations, but the takeoff, en-route, approach, landing, and go-around data must be built on procedures that average crews can consistently execute, using safe, reliable methods with realistic allowances for reaction and system delays. It also requires specific balked-landing/missed-approach procedures and mandates that accelerate-stop and landing distances be determined with brake assemblies at their fully worn limits. In short, it prevents optimistic performance by standardizing assumptions and ensuring the data reflect the thrust actually available and how crews actually operate.
events: Southwest Airlines Flight 1248 (2005, Chicago Midway) overran a snowy runway after a long flare and delayed reverse thrust deployment. This underscores CS 25.101(f)-(h): landing distances must be based on procedures average crews can execute with explicit allowances for realistic time delays.

Emirates Flight 521 (2016, Dubai) attempted a late go-around after touchdown; engine spool-up lag and execution delays led to a runway impact and post-crash fire. This demonstrates why CS 25.101(g)-(h) require defined balked-landing/missed-approach procedures and allowance for real crew and system delays.

Program lesson and rulemaking: CS-25 Amendment 25/18 added the requirement to determine accelerate-stop and landing distances with all wheel brakes at the fully worn limit. In-service data showed worn linings increase stopping distance, so this ensures certified distances do not rely on 'as-new' brake performance.

summary: The logic is simple: define a conservative 1‑g reference stall speed under worst‑case, standardised conditions—and keep it above any stall‑protection trigger—so all derived performance margins remain genuinely safe in service.
intent: Ensure every transport airplane’s performance is anchored to a conservative, repeatable reference stall speed that cannot be understated by test technique or automation. CS 25.103 defines V_SR (reference stall speed) from a standard 1‑g deceleration manoeuvre using controlled conditions: engines at idle/zero thrust if thrust would lower stall speed; proper propeller pitch; the exact configuration (flaps, gear, icing) relevant to the performance standard; the weight and centre of gravity giving the highest stall speed; and a steady, slow deceleration and trim range to avoid dynamic or biased results. It also requires a safety margin above any automatic nose‑down device (stick pusher) activation so that certification speeds are not set below the protection threshold. Acronyms: V_SR = reference stall speed; V_CLMAX = calibrated airspeed at peak lift coefficient in the prescribed manoeuvre; nzw = load factor normal to the flight path; q = dynamic pressure; W = weight; S = wing area.
events: BAC One‑Eleven G‑ASHG (1963 test accident, UK): The prototype entered a deep stall during stall testing, leading to industry adoption of stick shakers/pushers on T‑tail jets; CS 25.103(d) ensures V_SR is set above pusher activation to preserve a protective margin.

Colgan Air Flight 3407, DHC‑8‑402 Q400 (2009, Buffalo): Icing and low‑speed deceleration led to stall warning/protection with an improper pilot response; it illustrates why stall speeds must be defined and protected with standardised 1‑g methods and with ice configurations considered when used for performance.

American Eagle Flight 4184, ATR‑72 (1994, Roselawn): Supercooled large droplet icing caused a roll upset and loss of control, highlighting how ice accretion can raise stall speed and alter characteristics; CS 25.103 demands configurations (including ice) be represented when V_SR underpins performance.

summary: The logic is simple: define a realistic take-off configuration and environment, then conservatively compute speeds, distances, and climb paths—accounting for icing, wind, and slope—so average crews can safely go or stop on standard runways.
intent: Ensure manufacturers determine and publish take-off speeds, distances, and flight paths that a normal crew can achieve with conservative margins across the approved envelope (weight, altitude, temperature). Performance must be established for non-icing and, when icing measurably degrades lift or climb, with the most critical “take-off ice” accretion (per Appendices C and O), reflecting real-world ice effects on stall speed and climb. The data may not rely on exceptional piloting skill, must be based on standard runway surface conditions (dry and wet hard surfaces, with optional credit for grooved/porous friction course wet runways), and must include operational corrections for wind (limited headwind credit, increased tailwind penalty) and runway gradient. The objective is to provide reliable, conservative numbers that preserve stopping and climb margins, especially after a critical event like an engine failure during take-off.
events: Air Florida Flight 90 (B737-222), Washington National, 13 Jan 1982: Wing/engine icing contamination and improper anti-ice use led to a stall after liftoff and loss of climb capability. This illustrates why CS 25.105 requires performance determination with “take-off ice” when icing raises stall speed or degrades climb.

MK Airlines Flight 1602 (B747-244SF), Halifax, 14 Oct 2004: Incorrect take-off weight data produced wrong V-speeds/stab setting and a downwind take-off; the aircraft failed to rotate and a late reject overran fatally. It underscores the need for validated, conservative accelerate-stop/take-off distance data with proper wind and slope corrections within operational limits.

NASA/FAA Runway Grooving Programme (1960s–1970s): Research and airport trials showed grooved or porous friction course surfaces markedly reduce hydroplaning and improve wet stopping/acceleration. This evidence underpins CS 25.105’s allowance for separate wet-runway take-off data on grooved/PFC runways.

summary: The logic is simple: pick V1, VR, and V2 so that after the worst-timed engine failure you can still control the airplane, either stop within the runway or lift off without tailstrike or stall and meet the required OEI climb, with margins that tolerate realistic pilot/aircraft variations.
intent: Ensure take-off decision and safety speeds are chosen so the airplane can either stop safely or continue the take-off after a worst-case engine failure. The rule defines and links speeds: VEF (assumed engine-failure speed), V1 (go/stop decision speed including pilot recognition time), VR (rotate), VLOF (liftoff), V2MIN/V2 (minimum/selected climb speeds with one engine inoperative), VMU (minimum unstick), VMCG/VMC (minimum control speeds on ground/in air), VFTO (final takeoff climb speed), and VSR (reference stall speed). It sets lower bounds and relationships so take-off is controllable, tailstrike/stall margins exist, climb gradients are met OEI (one engine inoperative), a single VR works for both AEO (all engines operating) and OEI, and normal service variations (e.g., over-rotation, trim errors) don’t create unsafe characteristics. It also clarifies that non-icing VMC/VMCG/VMU may be used when setting icing-condition take-off speeds.
events: Gulfstream G650 flight test accident (Roswell, 2011): during aggressive rotation in VMU/field performance testing the aircraft stalled at liftoff and crashed. This underscores why CS 25.107 ties VR/VLOF to margins over VMU and requires tolerance to over-rotation so liftoff near the minimum unstick condition does not become unsafe.

Emirates Flight 407, A340-500 (Melbourne, 2009): incorrect weight entry led to insufficient thrust/speeds, tailstrike, and a marginal liftoff and climb. The event illustrates the criticality of correctly establishing and respecting VR/VMU/V2 relationships to avoid tailstrike and ensure OEI climb margins.

US Airways Flight 5050, B737-400 (New York–LGA, 1989): a high-speed rejected takeoff on a wet runway led to an overrun after a decision made near/above V1. This demonstrates why V1 must include realistic engine-failure recognition and pilot reaction time and be linked to accelerate–stop performance limits.

summary: The logic is simple: assume the engine fails at VEF, the pilot begins a reject at V1 with a realistic reaction delay, use conservative braking/friction (especially on wet runways) without depending on reverse thrust, and size the distance to the longer of the credible cases so the airplane can always stop on the runway.
intent: Ensure that, if a pilot rejects a takeoff at the decision speed (V1) — with the critical engine having failed at the engine‑failure speed (VEF) — the airplane can stop on the available runway (and any declared stopway) under conservative, real‑world conditions. The rule defines how to compute that accelerate‑stop distance on dry and wet runways, explicitly adding pilot reaction time (2 seconds), limiting credit to dependable deceleration sources (no reverse thrust credit on dry; tightly constrained credit on wet), and bounding wet‑runway braking with specified friction curves and anti‑skid effectiveness. It also requires demonstration of the worst‑case brake‑energy stop with worn brakes, keeps the landing gear extended, and demands correction factors when stopway surfaces differ. In short, the performance data published to crews must guarantee a safe stop for a timely reject without relying on exceptional skill or unreliable systems.
events: USAir Flight 5050 (Boeing 737-401, LaGuardia, 1989): A late rejected takeoff on a wet runway led to an overrun into Bowery Bay, underscoring that stopping after V1 on wet surfaces can exceed runway length and why rules bake in wet friction limits and a V1-based decision assumption (NTSB AAR-90/06).

Learjet 60, N999LJ (Columbia, SC, 2008): A high‑speed reject after tire failures due to under‑inflation resulted in an overrun and fatalities, illustrating the danger of rejecting above V1 and that reverse thrust and other means cannot be relied upon for dry‑runway credit unless proven safe and consistent (NTSB AAR-10/01).

American Airlines 383 (Boeing 767-323ER, Chicago O’Hare, 2016): After an uncontained engine failure, the crew rejected near high speed and stopped on the runway, with significant brake heating but within capability—demonstrating the value of the rule’s reaction time allowance and the certified high‑energy brake stop performance (NTSB AAR-18/01).

summary: The logic is simple: assume the worst engine fails at a defined speed, then prove the aircraft can lift off, reach and hold V2, and climb along a conservative, no‑tricks path (no early configuration or power changes, no ground‑effect boost), meeting minimum OEI gradients up to en‑route configuration—even with defined icing.
intent: CS 25.111 defines a single, conservative take-off flight path that all transport aeroplanes must be able to follow if the “critical engine” fails at VEF (the speed at which engine failure is assumed) and remains inoperative. From a standing start to 1 500 ft above the runway (or until the aircraft is cleaned up and reaches VFTO, the final take-off speed, if higher), the aeroplane must lift off, reach V2 (take-off safety speed) by 35 ft, maintain at least V2 to 400 ft, and achieve specified one‑engine‑inoperative climb gradients thereafter (1.2/1.5/1.7% for 2/3/4 engines) with a positive slope at all points. Only gear retraction and automatic propeller feathering are allowed before 400 ft; no pilot‑initiated thrust/configuration changes. The path may be demonstrated continuously or built from constant‑condition segments, but must be based on performance without ground effect and cross‑checked by flight tests to out‑of‑ground‑effect height. When required for icing, defined “Take‑off Ice” and “Final Take‑off Ice” accretions must be included. VR (rotation speed) is respected for nose‑wheel liftoff; gear retraction only once airborne.
events: TransAsia Airways Flight 235 (2015, ATR 72‑600, Taipei): After an engine failed just after liftoff, the crew shut down the remaining engine and let speed decay below V2, leading to a stall and river impact. This highlights why the certified OEI path requires maintaining V2 and avoiding configuration/power changes before 400 ft to preserve climb capability.

Air Florida Flight 90 (1982, Boeing 737‑222, Washington National): Ice contamination and mis-set thrust prevented the aircraft from achieving the required climb, resulting in a stall into the 14th Street Bridge. It underpins the rule’s inclusion of defined “Take‑off Ice” and “Final Take‑off Ice” drag in take‑off path performance to ensure a positive climb in icing conditions.

Emirates Flight 407 (2009, A340‑500, Melbourne): An erroneous low weight entry produced insufficient thrust and low V‑speeds, causing a late liftoff in ground effect and obstacle strikes before a safe return. This shows why the certified take‑off path must not rely on ground effect and must be validated by continuous demonstrations to keep obstacle clearance margins robust.

summary: The logic is simple: size the required runway using the longer of the OEI-to-35 ft path or 115% of the AEO-to-35 ft path (15 ft for wet distance but V2 by 35 ft), and limit clearway credit so the take-off run remains conservative and repeatable.
intent: This rule defines how to calculate the certified take-off distance and take-off run so operators choose runways with sufficient real-world margin. It ties the take-off path to CS 25.111 (which models the path with one engine inoperative, OEI) and requires using the longer of: the OEI distance to 35 ft height, or 115% of the all-engines-operating (AEO) distance to 35 ft, to guard against variation in technique and conditions. For wet runways it uses a 15 ft “screen height” for distance, but still requires achieving V2 (take-off safety speed) by 35 ft, reflecting degraded acceleration on wet surfaces. When a clearway (obstacle-free airspace beyond the runway) is used, the rule limits how much of it can reduce the take-off run by measuring to a midpoint between liftoff speed VLOF and 35 ft. In plain terms: publish conservative, repeatable distances that ensure obstacle clearance and adequate runway length in both dry and wet conditions, even with one engine out.
events: Emirates Flight 407 (A340-500), Melbourne 2009: incorrect weight in performance data led to a very long take-off roll, tailstrike, and barely clearing the end lights (ATSB AO‑2009‑012). It illustrates why certified distances need built-in conservatism (115% AEO and wet penalties) to protect against real operational variability and errors.

MK Airlines Flight 1602 (B747‑200F), Halifax 2004: miscalculated take-off performance and wrong stabilizer setting prevented normal rotation, resulting in an overrun and fatal crash (TSB Canada Report A04H0001). It shows the safety need for robust, conservative take-off distance definitions tied to liftoff and 35 ft screen height, not optimistic AEO techniques.

Comair Flight 5191 (CRJ‑100), Lexington 2006: the crew attempted take-off from a much shorter wrong runway and crashed after overrunning (NTSB AAR‑07/05). This underscores that using the correct, conservatively defined certified take-off distance versus actual available runway is critical to safe departure.

summary: The logic is simple: start the takeoff path at 35 ft at the runway end, then subtract a fixed climb margin (by engine count) or an equivalent acceleration shortfall to get a conservative “net” path used to ensure obstacle clearance with one engine inoperative.
intent: This rule defines a conservative, obstacle-clearance reference for takeoff. It says the takeoff flight path starts at 35 ft above the end of the takeoff distance and then converts the measured ("gross") path into a "net" path by subtracting a fixed climb-gradient margin (0.8% for twins, 0.9% for tri-jets, 1.0% for four‑engined) at every point. That subtraction accounts for real‑world variability (pilot technique, engine wear, atmospheric uncertainty) so the published path reliably clears obstacles even with one engine inoperative (OEI). Where the path includes a level acceleration segment, the same margin can be applied as an equivalent reduction in acceleration. The net takeoff flight path is the backbone for obstacle assessments, engine‑out procedure design, and dispatch performance. In short, it standardizes where the path begins, and how to conservatively adjust it, so operators and authorities share a common, safety‑buffered OEI takeoff profile.
events: Air Florida Flight 90 (1982, B737-222, Washington National): With iced wings and mis-set thrust, the aircraft failed to achieve expected climb and hit the 14th Street Bridge—showing why certified obstacle clearance relies on conservative net (not ideal gross) takeoff flight paths.

TransAsia Airways Flight 235 (2015, ATR 72-600, Taipei): An engine anomaly followed by shutdown of the operative engine led to loss of climb and a stall into a river—underscoring that obstacle clearance assumptions hinge on correct OEI handling and the certified net takeoff flight path.

Innsbruck (LOWI) engine‑out special departure procedures (Jeppesen 10‑7 pages for A320/B737 fleets): Operators design EOSIDs so the CS‑25 net takeoff flight path (with 0.8–1.0% reductions) avoids terrain, demonstrating the rule’s direct translation into real‑world obstacle‑clearance procedures in mountainous airports.

summary: The logic is simple: prove the airplane can still achieve the minimum climb gradients required by CS 25.119 and 25.121 at any approved combination of weight, altitude, temperature, and worst‑case CG for each configuration, not just under ideal conditions.
intent: Ensure the airplane demonstrably meets all required climb gradients (both all-engines and one‑engine‑inoperative) across its entire approved operating envelope—not just on a good day. CS‑25.117 forces compliance with CS 25.119 (landing/approach climb with all engines) and CS 25.121 (one‑engine‑inoperative climb segments) at every approved weight, altitude, and ambient temperature, and at the most unfavorable center of gravity (CG) for each configuration (e.g., flaps/gear settings). The aim is to guarantee obstacle clearance and controllability after takeoff, during go‑around, and en‑route engine‑out scenarios, and to prevent “cherry‑picking” benign conditions. In plain terms: if operators can dispatch the airplane at a given weight and to a given airport on a hot day, performance has already been proven to be safe even at the worst allowable CG.
events: MK Airlines Flight 1602 (B747‑200F, Halifax 2004) crashed after takeoff due to miscalculated weight/thrust data, leaving insufficient acceleration and climb capability. This proves the rule’s purpose because it shows climb margins are highly sensitive to weight and conditions, so certification must verify compliant climb across the entire approved envelope.

Fine Air Flight 101 (DC‑8‑61F, Miami 1997) suffered an aft CG from cargo shift, pitched up and stalled shortly after liftoff. This proves the rule’s purpose because testing at the most unfavorable allowable CG ensures climb performance and controllability are adequate even at the CG limit.

Airbus A350 XWB hot‑and‑high flight tests in Bolivia (La Paz/Cochabamba, 2014) publicly verified performance at extreme altitude and temperature. This proves the rule’s purpose because manufacturers must demonstrate compliant climb at the hot‑and‑high edges of the approved operating envelope before operations are allowed.

summary: The logic is simple: from a realistic go‑around start (idle thrust, landing configuration, VREF, and possible ice), the airplane must still achieve at least a 3.2% steady climb gradient using only the thrust available 8 seconds after power‑lever movement.
intent: Ensure a transport airplane can safely go around from a landing approach with all engines working, even when power was at idle, in both clean air and defined icing. The rule demands a minimum steady climb gradient of 3.2% in full landing configuration at VREF (the reference landing speed) using only the thrust or power available 8 seconds after the pilot advances the levers from flight idle to go‑around. It also requires this capability with “Landing Ice” accretion per Appendix C and, if applicable, Appendix O (supercooled large droplet icing). This models real engine spool‑up delay and the high drag of flaps/gear, assuring obstacle clearance and compatibility with missed-approach procedure gradients.
events: Asiana Airlines Flight 214 (B777-200ER, San Francisco, 2013): The crew initiated a late go‑around with engines at idle; spool‑up lag meant thrust arrived too late, and the aircraft impacted short of the runway (NTSB AAR-14/01). This illustrates why certification explicitly accounts for engine spool‑up delay and requires a guaranteed climb gradient after a defined 8‑second thrust-availability point.

ATR‑72 American Eagle Flight 4184 (Roselawn, 1994): Supercooled large droplet icing led to a roll upset and crash during approach, catalyzing regulatory action to address SLD icing (NTSB AAR-96/01). CS-25 now requires landing-climb performance in defined “Landing Ice” accretion (Appendix C/O), ensuring a viable go‑around despite ice-degraded lift/drag.

ICAO PANS‑OPS (Doc 8168) missed‑approach design assumes a 2.5% all‑engine climb gradient for obstacle clearance. The CS‑25 3.2% landing‑climb requirement provides margin in the high‑drag landing configuration and with realistic engine spool‑up delay so certified airplanes can safely follow published missed approaches.

summary: The logic is simple: even if the worst engine fails at the worst time, the aeroplane must still achieve defined minimum climb gradients at specified speeds and configurations (including certain icing cases) so it can clean up, clear obstacles, and continue safely.
intent: Ensure that a transport aeroplane can safely continue flight after the failure of its most critical engine by demonstrating minimum climb performance in defined phases. The rule sets required steady climb gradients with one engine inoperative (OEI) from lift-off with gear extended, through gear retraction at V2 (takeoff safety speed), to the end of the takeoff path at VFTO (final takeoff speed) on maximum continuous thrust, and during an approach/go‑around. It specifies the appropriate engine power settings (takeoff or maximum continuous), weights, and speeds, and requires checks in icing if ice accretion meaningfully degrades stall speed (VSR) or climb. Acronyms: OEI = one engine inoperative; VLOF = lift‑off speed; V2 = takeoff safety speed; VFTO = final takeoff speed; VSR = reference stall speed; CAS = calibrated airspeed; AMC = Acceptable Means of Compliance. The objective is obstacle clearance and controllability margin after an engine failure in the most demanding parts of flight.
events: Qantas Flight QF32 (A380, 2010): An uncontained No. 2 engine failure just after takeoff forced an OEI climb and cleanup before returning to Singapore. The crew maintained V2/engine‑out profiles, and the aircraft’s certified OEI climb capability enabled safe altitude gain and systems management, illustrating the rule’s purpose.

American Airlines Flight 191 (DC‑10, 1979): Engine/pylon separation at rotation also caused slat retraction and severe performance/handling loss, leading to a crash. The accident underscores why certification requires demonstrated OEI climb in the actual critical configuration and why later, more critical conditions along the path must be considered.

TransAsia Airways Flight GE235 (ATR 72‑600, 2015): After one engine flamed out after takeoff, the wrong engine was shut down and V2/EO climb was not maintained, resulting in a stall and crash. It highlights that the safety margin envisioned by CS‑25.121 depends on flying the prescribed OEI speeds/configurations to realize the certified climb gradients.

summary: The logic is simple: publish a conservative engine‑out en‑route climb path (including icing when it matters) based on worst‑case conditions and maximum continuous thrust so operators can plan routes and escape paths that still clear terrain after an engine failure.
intent: Ensure a large aeroplane can safely continue en-route after an engine failure (or two on 3/4‑engine types) with predictable, conservative climb capability. Manufacturers must compute a “net” flight path: the real climb performance reduced by fixed margins to cover uncertainties, pilot technique, and environmental variability. This is done at the worst centre of gravity, with the failed (critical) engine(s), the remaining engine(s) at maximum continuous thrust/power (MCT), a minimum speed not less than final takeoff speed (VFTO), and engine‑cooling set for hot‑day adequacy. It must also consider fuel/oil burn over the path. If en‑route ice accretion (Appendices C/O) materially raises stall speed (VSR) or degrades climb, separate icing net data are required. CAS means calibrated airspeed. The objective is to provide operators with conservative engine‑out drift‑down/escape paths and obstacle clearance that remain valid across weights, altitudes, and temperatures.
events: China Airlines Flight 006 (1985): A Boeing 747SP suffered a No. 4 engine flameout at ~41,000 ft and, after mishandling, descended ~30,000 ft before recovery. It shows that at cruise a heavy jet cannot maintain level flight with one engine out and must execute a controlled drift‑down along a precomputed engine‑out en‑route path—the performance CS 25.123 requires.

American Eagle Flight 4184 (1994, Roselawn ATR‑72): Encounter with supercooled large droplet icing caused a roll upset and crash. The accident led to Appendix O icing criteria and demonstrates how en‑route icing can raise stall speed and erode climb gradient, triggering CS 25.123(b)(2) to require separate net paths/speeds when icing penalties exceed thresholds.

Pan Am Flight 6 (1956): A Boeing 377 Stratocruiser lost two engines over the Pacific and could not maintain altitude, ditching near a Coast Guard cutter. This illustrates why certification demands two‑engine‑inoperative net climb data for 3‑ and 4‑engine aircraft, enabling realistic route planning and obstacle clearance when multiple engines are lost.

summary: The logic is simple: prove the airplane can land from 50 ft and stop on a standard dry runway with a stabilized approach at safe speeds, conservative wind assumptions, and reliable deceleration means—even if an engine‑dependent aid isn’t available—using normal pilot technique.
intent: Ensure manufacturers generate conservative, repeatable landing‑distance data that operators can trust when planning runway length. The rule defines how to measure the horizontal distance from 50 ft to a full stop using standard pilot techniques, a stabilized approach at not less than VREF (reference landing speed), and normal deceleration on a level, dry, hard runway. VREF must provide stall margin (≥1.23 VSR0, where VSR0 is the reference stall speed in landing configuration), meet VMCL (minimum control speed in landing configuration), and provide maneuvering margin; it must be increased if ice accretion raises the required speed by >5 kt. Braking and any supplemental deceleration (e.g., thrust reversers, propeller beta) must be safe, reliable, within limits, and yield consistent results without exceptional skill. Wind effects are treated conservatively (credit only 50% headwind and assess 150% tailwind). If a device depends on an engine and losing that engine would noticeably increase stopping distance, the distance must reflect that inoperative case or an equivalent compensation. The outcome is a predictable, safe baseline for certification and operations.
events: Air France Flight 358 (Toronto, 2005) landed long in a thunderstorm with a tailwind and overran the runway. It illustrates why landing data assume a stabilized approach to timely touchdown and require conservative wind corrections, because small deviations and tailwind rapidly erode stopping margin.

Lufthansa Flight 2904 (Warsaw, 1993) overran on a wet runway after a fast, tailwind landing, with delayed spoiler and reverse‑thrust deployment due to hydroplaning and system logic. This shows the need for deceleration devices to provide consistent, predictable performance and why certification distances are based on stabilized technique and conservative winds.

TAM Flight 3054 (São Paulo Congonhas, 2007) overran when one thrust lever remained at climb power, preventing proper spoiler/reverse deployment and leaving high residual thrust on a wet runway. It demonstrates how engine‑dependent devices and configurations can dramatically alter stopping distance, validating the rule’s requirement to account for such dependencies.

summary: The logic is simple: an airliner must remain predictably controllable with reasonable pilot effort, through all phases and likely failures or configuration changes (including icing and go‑arounds), without overstressing the airframe or demanding exceptional pilot performance.
intent: Ensure every large aeroplane can be safely controlled and manoeuvred through all normal flight phases (take-off, climb, cruise, descent, approach, go‑around, landing) and through credible upsets or changes (e.g., an engine failure, configuration changes, turbulence, icing) without requiring exceptional skill, attention, or strength from the crew. The aircraft must transition smoothly between conditions without risking structural over‑loads, with pilot control forces that are neither excessive nor so light that inadvertent overstress occurs. Controllability must be shown with the most critical ice accretions, including checks for force reversals and push/pull characteristics. Specific manoeuvring capability is required at defined speeds and bank angles, including engine‑out at V2 (take‑off safety speed) and WAT‑limited thrust (weight‑altitude‑temperature). For side‑sticks and EFCS (Electronic Flight Control Systems), force levels and load‑factor limits must provide suitable handling and protections. Go‑around assessments must consider crew workload and the risk of somatogravic illusion (false pitch sensations due to acceleration).
events: TransAsia Airways Flight 235 (ATR 72‑600, 2015, Taipei): following an engine flameout, the crew inadvertently shut down the remaining engine and lost control at low altitude with asymmetric thrust. The accident underscores why certification demands predictable engine‑out handling and adequate roll/yaw authority at V2 and during turns, so the aircraft remains controllable without exceptional skill under engine‑failure conditions.

American Eagle/ATR 72 Flight 4184 (Roselawn, 1994): supercooled large droplet icing caused aileron hinge‑moment reversal and abrupt roll, leading to loss of control. This event drove the Appendix O icing criteria and directly supports CS 25.143 requirements to demonstrate controllability in icing without force reversals and with proper push/pull characteristics.

Gulf Air Flight 072 (A320, 2000, Bahrain): during a night go‑around, somatogravic illusion contributed to inappropriate pitch inputs and a fatal descent. It illustrates why CS 25.143 requires evaluating go‑around handling for workload and spatial disorientation risk, ensuring the aircraft can be managed safely without exceptional skill.

summary: The logic is simple: the airplane must let pilots reliably command nose-down and control speed during low-speed, high-drag and thrust-transient phases (approach, configuration changes, and go-around) with reasonable forces and predictable behavior.
intent: This rule ensures a transport airplane’s pitch (longitudinal) control is strong, predictable, and not overly demanding around approach, landing, and go-around. From any speed between the trimmed approach speed and the stall warning, the pilot must be able to push the nose down and promptly accelerate, with flaps up/down, gear up/down, and engines at idle or go-around thrust. Configuration or thrust changes near 1.3×VSR1 must not require more than about 222 N (50 lb) of control force or unusual retrimming. Starting a go-around and retracting high-lift devices at low speeds must not cause altitude loss, exceed structural loads, or erode stall margin; if flap/slat controls have gates, they must correspond to safe go-around configurations and resist inadvertent movement. The airplane must display safe, manageable pitch and speed behavior through the whole go-around and level-off, with or without automation. VSR1 = reference stall speed in the relevant configuration, VSW = stall warning speed, VFE = maximum flap-extended speed.
events: BAC One-Eleven G-ASHG deep stall (22 Oct 1963): the prototype entered a deep stall during testing and crashed when the tailplane was blanketed, removing effective nose-down authority. This proves the rule’s purpose by showing that recovery near stall demands assured nose-down control and prompt acceleration capability in all configurations.

FlyDubai Flight 981, Boeing 737-800 (19 Mar 2016, Rostov-on-Don): during a night go-around the aircraft experienced large pitch excursions and trim mismanagement, leading to loss of control and impact. It illustrates why CS 25.145(f) requires predictable, controllable longitudinal and speed behavior during go-around, including with various automation combinations and without excessive forces.

Tatarstan Airlines Flight 363, Boeing 737-500 (17 Nov 2013, Kazan): a go-around degraded into excessive pitch changes and a steep dive, attributed to poor pitch/trim control during the transition. The accident underlines the need for benign, manageable pitch characteristics and preserved stall margin during go-around and level-off, even with deviations from ideal procedures.

summary: The logic is simple: even in worst-case asymmetric thrust and near-stall conditions, and at high speeds with all engines running, the airplane must have enough yaw and roll authority—within reasonable pilot effort—to turn, track, and recover safely.
intent: Ensure a transport aeroplane remains safely controllable in yaw (directional) and roll (lateral) during the most demanding, realistic conditions: with one engine inoperative (OEI) — or two on the same side for four‑engine types — at low speeds near stall (1.3 VSR1, the reference stall speed in landing configuration), worst centre of gravity, appropriate flap/gear settings, and with only reasonable pilot forces (rudder pedal ≤ 667 N/150 lbf). It must be able to yaw toward the operative engine, make modest heading changes toward the failed side, and perform 20° banked turns both into and away from the failed engine. With all engines operating, the airplane must have enough roll response to recover from gust‑induced upsets or initiate evasive manoeuvres up to VFC/MFC (the design maximum speed/Mach for controllability) without excessive control forces or travel. The goal is to prevent loss of control from asymmetric thrust or disturbances across the normal operating envelope.
events: TransAsia Airways Flight 235 (2015, ATR 72‑600): After an engine flameout at low altitude, mishandling created severe asymmetric thrust and a stall leading to loss of control; it highlights why certification demands strong, predictable yaw/roll authority and banked‑turn capability near 1.3 VSR1 with OEI.

El Al Flight 1862 (1992, Boeing 747‑200F): Loss of two engines on the same wing caused extreme asymmetry and controllability challenges before impact; it underscores the requirement for four‑engine aircraft to demonstrate controllability with two critical engines inoperative.

USAir Flight 427 (1994, Boeing 737‑300): A rudder system hardover led to an upset and rapid roll/yaw divergence, showing the safety need for robust lateral control and upset‑recovery capability with engines operating across the speed range.

summary: The logic is simple: set conservative, demonstrable minimum speeds that guarantee a pilot can keep the airplane straight and controllable after the worst likely engine failure—on the runway, after liftoff, and on approach—using normal forces and without unsafe attitudes.
intent: Ensure a transport airplane remains controllable after a worst‑case engine failure by defining minimum safe speeds for directional and lateral control in takeoff and landing phases. The rule sets how to determine VMC (minimum control speed in the air after liftoff), VMCG (on the ground during the takeoff roll), VMCL (on approach/landing with all engines initially operating), and VMCL‑2 (on approach/landing for 3+ engine airplanes when a second critical engine fails). Tests must reflect the most critical, realistic failure (including propeller states like windmilling or feathering), maximum operating thrust on remaining engines, worst center of gravity, and critical configurations, with limits on pilot workload: ≤5° bank, ≤667 N (150 lbf) rudder force, no need to reduce operating-engine thrust, no hazardous attitudes, and adequate roll authority. VMC must also be limited relative to stall reference speed (VSR) for margin. In short, these speeds anchor certification, procedures, and AFM speeds so crews can keep the airplane straight and controllable when asymmetry is greatest.
events: Gulfstream G650 flight‑test accident, Roswell, 2 Apr 2011 (NTSB): During single‑engine takeoff performance testing at low speed, the airplane stalled and rolled after rotation, underscoring how asymmetric thrust near the ground can overpower control when speeds are set too low. It illustrates why certification must rigorously establish and respect minimum control speeds and prohibit hazardous attitudes during recovery.

Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 2311 (Embraer 120), Brunswick, 5 Apr 1991 (NTSB): A propeller pitch control failure drove one prop to an abnormally low blade angle, creating extreme asymmetric drag and roll the crew could not counter near approach speed. This demonstrates the need to base VMCL/VMC on realistic post‑failure prop states and to forbid hazardous characteristics from propeller positions.

El Al Flight 1862 (Boeing 747‑200F), Amsterdam, 4 Oct 1992 (Dutch Safety Board): Loss of two engines on the same wing produced overwhelming yaw/roll asymmetry leading to loss of control. While structural damage dominated, the event illustrates the severity of same‑side multi‑engine loss that underpins the VMCL‑2 requirement for 3+ engine aircraft to ensure defined minimum controllable speeds during approach when a second engine fails.

summary: The logic is simple: the airplane must be trimmable and stay trimmed—without the pilot holding force—through all normal speeds, configurations, CGs, and engine-out cases so it remains controllable with acceptable workload.
intent: Ensure a transport airplane can be “trimmed” (set so it flies without the pilot holding constant control pressures) in pitch (longitudinal), roll (lateral), and yaw (directional) across the full operating envelope, including worst-case weight/center‑of‑gravity (CG) positions, speeds, and configurations—and with engine failures. After the pilot or autopilot trims, the airplane must continue to maintain that condition without further control input. This reduces workload, prevents pilot overexertion, and preserves controllability when asymmetric thrust or configuration changes demand large trim. Covered cases include speeds from 1.3 VSR1 (a stall‑reference speed) up to VMO/MMO (maximum operating speed/Mach), gear up/down (VLE = max gear‑extended speed), flaps up/takeoff/landing, climbs and power‑off glides, the critical engine inoperative at maximum continuous power on the remaining engines, and for 4+ engine airplanes, two engines inoperative en‑route. The rule thereby requires adequate trim authority, stability, and systems integrity.
events: Alaska Airlines 261 (MD‑83, 2000): Failure of the stabilizer trim jackscrew acme nut led to loss of pitch trim/control and a fatal crash; it illustrates why robust trim systems and the ability to maintain trimmed flight are safety‑critical.

Lion Air JT610 (2018) and Ethiopian ET302 (2019), Boeing 737 MAX 8: Repeated automatic nose‑down stabilizer trim (MCAS) at high speed created severe mis‑trim the crews could not overcome; it shows that trim authority/behavior across the speed range must not overwhelm the crew and must allow maintaining trim without continuous force.

Air Canada 143 “Gimli Glider” (Boeing 767, 1983): After dual engine flameout, the crew glided and landed successfully, relying on the airplane’s ability to be trimmed and remain stable through approach and gear extension; this demonstrates the necessity of reliable longitudinal trim in glide/approach conditions.

summary: The logic is simple: the aeroplane must behave predictably and give pilots clear, progressive control cues in pitch, roll, and yaw across normal operating conditions, and if flight tests expose gaps, add design measures to ensure safe stability and feel.
intent: This rule ensures a large aeroplane is predictably stable in all three axes: longitudinal (pitch), directional (yaw), and lateral (roll). It points to detailed criteria for static stability, then adds a catch‑all: if flight tests show any condition normally met in service where stability or control feel (the forces and cues a pilot senses on the controls) are not adequate for safety, the design must provide suitable stability and feel, including augmentation if needed. The aim is that the aircraft tends to respond in a steady, expected way to disturbances, and that pilots get clear, progressive control forces and cues that help them judge how close they are to limits and maintain control throughout the approved envelope and typical operating environments.
events: Boeing 737 MAX MCAS accidents — Lion Air JT610 (2018) and Ethiopian Airlines ET302 (2019): augmentation was added to meet longitudinal stick‑force/stability requirements at high angle of attack; its erroneous activation removed predictable pitch feel and stability cues, leading to loss of control, showing why static stability and control feel must be robust and transparent across service conditions.

BAC One‑Eleven prototype G‑ASHG deep stall (1963, flight test): the T‑tail jet entered a deep stall with poor longitudinal stability and ineffective control feel, prompting regulators to require devices like stick pushers on similar aircraft so pilots get unmistakable cues and restoring forces before stall.

ATR 72‑212A Flight 4184, Roselawn (1994): supercooled large droplet icing degraded lateral/directional stability and control, causing a roll upset and loss of control, illustrating the need to assess and ensure adequate stability and pilot cues in real‑world service conditions such as icing.

summary: The logic is simple: the airplane must naturally cue the pilot—pull to go slower, push to go faster—and, when you let go, it should tend to return toward the trimmed speed with forces that are neither too light nor too heavy.
intent: Ensure the airplane’s basic pitch behavior is intuitive and self-stabilizing in normal (unstalled) flight. With the aircraft trimmed to a speed (trim speed = the speed at which no steady push/pull is needed), pulling the control column must make it fly slower and pushing must make it fly faster, and when the pilot relaxes the force the airspeed must drift back close to the trimmed value. The rule sets quantitative limits: defined “return-to-trim” accuracy in climb, cruise, approach, and landing configurations (per CS 25.175) and a minimum stick‑force‑per‑speed gradient (at least 1 lbf per 6 kt) so forces aren’t so light that speed wanders or so heavy that control is fatiguing. It applies up to normal operating limits (e.g., landing gear/flap limit speeds or VFC/MFC) and above the minimum steady unstalled speed. A small steady offset is allowed after force release if it doesn’t demand exceptional pilot attention.
events: Boeing 737 MAX (Lion Air JT610, 2018; Ethiopian Airlines ET302, 2019): MCAS was introduced to achieve required longitudinal stability and stick‑force characteristics at high angle of attack; its malfunctions drove powerful nose‑down trim, producing non‑intuitive forces and speed excursions. These accidents show that meeting stability/feel requirements must yield predictable pull/push cues across the envelope without creating hazardous force reversals.

BAC One‑Eleven prototype G‑ASHG deep‑stall crash (1963): During stall testing the T‑tail jet entered a deep stall with inadequate longitudinal stability/recoverability, leading to loss of control. The event led to widespread adoption of stick pushers and stricter handling‑quality criteria, underscoring the need for clear, consistent longitudinal cues as speed approaches minimums.

Boeing 777 program handling‑qualities design (1990s): Boeing publicly described its C*U fly‑by‑wire law providing speed stability so that releasing the column returns the airplane toward trim speed with a defined stick‑force‑per‑speed slope. This program lesson illustrates industry practice to deliberately shape force gradients and trim‑return behavior to comply with CS 25.173 and reduce pilot workload.

summary: The logic is simple: the airplane must always push back with increasing, correctly directed stick force as you move away from trimmed speed, and tend to return toward that speed, in the key flight regimes.
intent: Ensure the airplane naturally “wants” to hold its trimmed speed and gives the pilot clear, increasing control-force cues when speed changes, across climb, cruise, approach, and landing. In plain terms: if you speed up from trim, you must feel an increasing push; if you slow down, you must feel an increasing pull, and when you let go the airplane tends to return toward the trim speed. This must be shown in worst-case weight and centre-of-gravity (CG) positions, with appropriate flap/gear and power. Acronyms: VSW = stall warning speed; VSR1/VSR0 = reference stall speed in approach/takeoff (1) and landing (0) configurations; VMO/MMO = max operating speed (airspeed/Mach); VLE = max gear-extended speed; VFC/MFC = max speed for demonstrating stability; “free return speed range” = the range over which the airplane, with controls released, naturally returns toward trim speed. The rule also caps control forces so the pilot is not overloaded.
events: Boeing 737 MAX Lion Air 610 (2018): MCAS was added to maintain required stick‑force stability at high angle of attack with flaps up, but a faulty AoA input led to repeated nose‑down trim and loss of control; it shows that meeting static longitudinal stability via augmentation must be robust and transparent to prevent hazardous pitch forces.

BAC One‑Eleven G‑ASHG test accident (1963): The prototype entered a deep stall during stall testing with little restorative pitch feel, driving industry adoption of stick pushers on T‑tail jets and underscoring the need for a positive stick‑force slope down to stall warning as required by this rule.

BEA Flight 548, Hawker Siddeley Trident (1972): After premature slat retraction the aircraft stalled and crashed; the stick pusher was overridden/inoperative, illustrating that at low speed the absence of strong, correctly directed pitch‑force cues can allow a deep stall, validating the requirement to demonstrate stable stick‑force gradients in approach/landing ranges.

summary: The logic is simple: the airplane must naturally oppose skids and wing drops and provide steady, proportional pedal and wheel feel—without any force reversals—throughout the approved speed/configuration range so pilots can arrest yaw/roll promptly and predictably.
intent: Ensure big airplanes naturally resist yaw and roll disturbances and give pilots predictable, proportional control feel in sideslip. The rule demands positive static directional stability (in a skid, with rudder free, the nose must yaw back toward coordinated flight) and non‑negative static lateral stability (in a sideslip, with ailerons free, the low wing tends to rise) across normal configurations and speeds. It also requires that aileron and rudder forces/deflections grow in a stable, proportional way with sideslip and never “reverse” (become unexpectedly lighter or oppose input) as sideslip increases. Acronyms: VSR1 = reference stall speed for the relevant configuration; VFE/VLE = max flap/gear extended speeds; VMO/MMO = max operating speed/Mach; VFC/MFC = design high‑speed for stability characteristics. “Rudder/aileron free” means controls are released to assess the airplane’s inherent stability. The goal is to prevent divergent yaw/roll, surprise control feel, and control‑trap behaviors that can lead to loss of control.
events: American Airlines Flight 587 (A300-600, 2001, Queens, NY): Aggressive rudder reversals after a wake upset led to vertical tail failure; the NTSB highlighted rudder pedal sensitivity/feel and pilot expectations of force buildup. This underscores CS 25.177(c)-(d)’s demand for proportional, non‑reversing rudder forces and predictable sideslip response.

USAir Flight 427 (B737-300, 1994, near Pittsburgh): A rudder PCU malfunction produced an uncommanded hardover, causing an unrecoverable yaw/roll departure. While a systems failure, it starkly illustrates the hazard when yaw response is opposite to pilot input, reinforcing the need for positive static directional stability and predictable rudder force trends.

Early swept‑wing jet certification (e.g., Boeing 707): Operators and AFMs mandated yaw dampers and accepted mild high‑speed spiral tendencies only when gradual and manageable; certification policy evolved accordingly. CS 25.177(b)(2) mirrors this lesson by allowing only gradual, easily recognizable, and controllable lateral divergence above VMO/MMO.

summary: The logic is simple: disturbances may start an oscillation, but the airplane must quickly calm itself and remain controllable with normal inputs across the approved speed range.
intent: Ensure the airplane naturally damps out any short-term “wobbles” without needing heroic pilot action. In pitch, the short-period oscillation (a quick nose-up/nose-down response) must be heavily damped whether the primary controls are held fixed or left free. In yaw/roll, any combined lateral–directional oscillation (Dutch roll: a coupled yawing and rolling motion typical of swept‑wing jets) must be positively damped with controls free and remain easily controllable with normal primary control use. These qualities must hold from 1.13 VSR (a reference stall speed margin) up to the maximum allowable speed for the current configuration. The rule aims to prevent uncomfortable or unsafe oscillations from persisting after a gust or maneuver, and to ensure pilots don’t need exceptional skill or large alternating rudder inputs to keep the aircraft under control.
events: Programme lesson – Boeing 707 introduction (late 1950s): Early swept‑wing jet testing and service experience revealed weak natural Dutch roll damping, leading to mandatory yaw damper systems for certification and dispatch, illustrating the need for positively damped lateral–directional oscillations.

American Airlines Flight 587 (A300-600), New York, 12 Nov 2001: Wake turbulence triggered lateral–directional motions and the pilot’s large alternating rudder inputs led to fin failure, underscoring that Dutch roll–type disturbances must be controllable with normal inputs and not demand exceptional skill.

Programme lesson – Regulatory requirement for operable yaw dampers (e.g., FAA Part 121/CS‑25 operations): Operational rules stemming from early jet experience require yaw dampers on swept‑wing transports, reinforcing CS 25.181’s objective that Dutch roll be positively damped in service, not just on paper.

summary: The logic is simple: deliberately stall the airplane in tough but realistic scenarios and verify the cues are clear and the recovery is reliable and repeatable.
intent: Ensure large aeroplanes show predictable, recoverable behaviour at the point of stall, with unmistakable cues to the pilot, across the most demanding but realistic conditions. The rule standardises how stalls are provoked (slow, controlled deceleration; also faster decel in turns), requires both low-power and high-power cases (power to hold level at 1.5 VSR1, where VSR1 is the reference stall speed at maximum landing weight with approach flaps and gear retracted), and mandates coverage of straight and 30°-banked turns, all approved flap/gear/speed-brake configurations, representative weights, and the most adverse centre-of-gravity (CG) for recovery. A valid stall is identified by natural, compelling cues (nose drop, strong buffet, or no further pitch increase at full aft stick), and recovery must be possible using normal techniques. In essence, it prevents hidden or irrecoverable stall behaviours (e.g., deep stalls) and assures that pilots get clear, natural deterrents and a straightforward recovery across the approved envelope.
events: BAC One‑Eleven G‑ASHG stall test accident (Chicklade, UK, 22 Oct 1963): during high‑angle‑of‑attack testing the T‑tail jet entered a deep stall and crashed, with minimal natural cues and no recovery available. This drove stringent stall demonstration/acceptability and stick‑pusher philosophies to ensure unmistakable indications and recoverable behaviour.

Colgan Air Flight 3407 (DHC‑8‑402 Q400, near Buffalo, 12 Feb 2009): the aircraft stalled on approach after an inappropriate pilot response to stick shaker, leading to loss of control. It underscores why certification demands clear cues and benign, recoverable characteristics in approach configurations and with power.

TransAsia Airways Flight 235 (ATR 72‑600, Taipei, 4 Feb 2015): after the wrong engine was shut down, the aircraft stalled in a turning climb and rolled off, striking a bridge. It highlights the hazards of turning stalls with power and the need to demonstrate predictable, recoverable turning‑flight stalls.

summary: The logic is simple: make the aeroplane stall in a docile, predictable, and recoverable way—no control reversals, no pitch-up surprises, and only modest roll/bank—so normal pilot inputs can prevent and recover from stalls.
intent: This rule ensures that when an aeroplane approaches and enters a stall (loss of lift when the wing exceeds its critical angle of attack), its behaviour remains predictable and controllable. Up to the stall, pilots must be able to command roll and yaw with normal, unreversed aileron and rudder inputs; there must be no sudden nose-up pitch “hook,” and the stick/pitch force must stay positive (requiring increasing pull to increase angle of attack) through the stall. The aircraft must allow prompt stall avoidance and recovery using normal controls. After the stall, roll/bank excursions must be limited—both in level and turning flight—with acceptable bank-angle limits that scale with how fast speed is decaying. In short, CS-25.203 (EASA—European Union Aviation Safety Agency—Certification Specifications for large aeroplanes) aims to prevent wing-drop, control reversals, deep-stall pitch-up, and excessive bank during recovery so pilots can reliably prevent and recover from stalls with ordinary skill.
events: BAC One‑Eleven G‑ASHG deep‑stall test accident (22 Oct 1963): the T‑tail jet entered an unrecoverable deep stall with pitch‑up and ineffective elevators, leading to the adoption of stick pushers and tighter stall behaviour requirements—exactly what CS‑25.203 seeks to prevent.

BEA Flight 548, Hawker Siddeley Trident (Staines, 18 Jun 1972): inadvertent slat retraction led to a stall and deep‑stall characteristics from which recovery was not achieved, prompting regulatory emphasis on stall protection and benign, recoverable stall characteristics.

Gulfstream G650 flight‑test accident, Roswell (2 Apr 2011): during aggressive low‑speed testing the aircraft experienced wing drop and loss of control near stall, leading to program changes to stall margins and test methods—illustrating the need to limit roll and ensure prompt, normal‑skill recovery.

summary: The logic is simple: give the pilot a clear, feelable/aural early cue of impending stall across all configurations and icing states—with enough speed/ AoA margin that, even with a brief human delay, a standard recovery will prevent the stall.
intent: Ensure pilots get an unmistakable, non-visual stall warning early enough, in all likely configurations and conditions (including icing and turns), to prevent an inadvertent stall even if the pilot reacts with a short delay. The rule defines minimum margins between the stall warning speed (VSW) and the actual stall or reference stall speed (VSR), requires the warning to persist until angle of attack (AoA) is reduced, and demands it work during realistic decelerations and load factors. Warning must be clear and distinctive (e.g., tactile/aural like stick shaker), not visual-only, and generally use the same means in icing as in non-icing. It must also cover abnormal high-lift device configurations likely to be used after failures, and account for ice accretions defined in Appendices C and O, including before the ice protection system is effective. Acronyms: AoA = angle of attack; CAS = calibrated airspeed; VSR = reference stall speed; VSW = stall warning speed.
events: American Eagle Flight 4184 (ATR 72-212A), Roselawn, 31 Oct 1994: Supercooled large droplet icing led to an abrupt roll upset and loss of control. The accident drove creation of Appendix O and tighter icing/stall margins, directly reflected in CS 25.207(e)–(h) requirements to demonstrate adequate stall warning and recovery time with defined ice accretions.

Colgan Air Flight 3407 (DHC-8-Q400), Buffalo, 12 Feb 2009: On approach in icing, stick shaker/pusher activated but improper pilot response led to a deep stall. It underscores why regulations require a strong, tactile warning and sufficient margin in turns and icing so that, if the pilot reduces AoA promptly, recovery is assured.

Air France Flight 447 (A330-203), Atlantic Ocean, 1 Jun 2009: After pitot icing and unreliable airspeed, the aircraft entered a high-altitude stall with intermittent stall warnings due to logic inhibitions. The crew’s confusion highlights the need for clear, continuous stall warning tied to AoA and for cues that remain until AoA is reduced, as required by CS 25.207(c).

summary: The logic is simple: the airplane and its brakes must not create a forward-tip (nose-over) hazard and must remain pitch-controllable on the ground, including through a bounce and during tailwheel takeoff attitudes.
intent: Ensure the airplane stays controllable in pitch while on the ground so it does not tip forward onto the nose or exhibit hazardous pitch behavior during braking, takeoff, landing, or a bounce. Brakes must apply torque smoothly so they do not induce a forward pitching moment that could lead to a nose-over. For tailwheel (tail-dragger) airplanes, the crew must be able to hold any desired pitch attitude on a hard (concrete) runway during the takeoff roll, up to the tail raised to the engine thrust-line level, at a representative high ground speed (75% of VSR1). VSR1 is the reference stall speed in the appropriate configuration (typically takeoff/approach) at 1 g; using 75% of VSR1 ensures controllability at substantial speed without requiring near-stall operation. Overall, the rule demands benign, predictable longitudinal behavior on the ground, including during rebound after a bounce.
events: FedEx Flight 14, MD‑11, Newark (31 July 1997): A bounced landing led to a pitch oscillation and severe nose‑down second impact, flipping the aircraft—showing why rebound behavior must be controllable to avoid an uncontrollable nose‑over tendency.

FedEx Flight 80, MD‑11F, Narita (23 March 2009): After a bounce, rapid pitch‑down and hard second touchdown caused structural failure and overturn, underscoring the need for benign longitudinal dynamics during landing rebound.

FAA AC 25‑7D Flight Test Guide (public guidance): Formalizes certification evaluations for brake ‘snatch’/maximum braking and bounce handling, institutionalizing the requirement to show no undue nose‑over tendency from braking or rebound in CS‑25/Part 25 testing.

summary: The logic is simple: the airplane must inherently hold a straight path and be steerable on the ground in crosswinds and with idle power, without needing brakes or exceptional pilot effort, so it won’t swerve or ground‑loop.
intent: Ensure large airplanes remain directionally stable and steerable on the ground so they do not swerve, veer off, or ground‑loop in crosswinds and during routine ground operations. The aeroplane must track straight without relying on engine thrust or brakes to keep aligned, be manageable by an average pilot (no exceptional skill), and have enough nosewheel/rudder authority for taxi, landing rollout, and takeoff ground runs. Crosswind capability is verified to at least a 90-degree crosswind of 20 kt (37 km/h) or 0.2×VSR0 (reference stall speed in landing configuration with idle thrust), whichever is greater, capped at 25 kt at ground-operating speeds, consistent with CS 25.237 demonstrations. The goal is to prevent runway excursions, gear overloads, and loss of control while rolling on the runway or taxiways.
events: Lufthansa A320 D-AIQP at Hamburg (1 Mar 2008): during a gusty crosswind landing (LH044), a sudden yaw/roll led to a left wingtip strike and go‑around; it shows how high crosswind gusts can rapidly challenge ground directional control, hence the need to demonstrate no uncontrollable swerve/ground‑loop.

Delta Air Lines Flight 1086, MD‑88, LaGuardia (5 Mar 2015): veered off Runway 13 on a snowy surface; NTSB found excessive reverse thrust reduced rudder effectiveness and directional control, illustrating why aircraft must retain inherent ground controllability without relying on thrust or brakes to hold centerline.

Air Canada Flight 143 ‘Gimli Glider’ (23 Jul 1983): a 767 landed deadstick after fuel exhaustion and maintained runway alignment without engine power, underscoring the requirement to be controllable in power‑off landings without using engine power to keep straight.
