summary: The logic is simple: design and prove the landing gear absorbs taxi‑induced bumps and vibrations so structural loads stay below damage thresholds on the roughest surfaces the airplane can reasonably encounter in service.
intent: Ensure the landing gear’s shock-absorbing system (tyres, oleo‑pneumatic struts, bogies, torque links, dampers) does not transmit damaging loads into the airframe or gear structure when the airplane taxis over realistically rough surfaces expected in normal operations. In CS-25 (Certification Specifications for Large Aeroplanes), this ground-handling criterion covers paved surfaces with joints, steps, ruts, patches, and other roughness that can occur at airports the aircraft is approved to use. Compliance requires that at expected taxi weights and speeds, the gear cannot bottom out, induce excessive vibrations (e.g., shimmy), or cause structural cracking, fastener fretting, or attachment overloading. The aim is structural integrity and continued airworthiness during routine taxiing, not passenger comfort: the aircraft must be tolerant to rough ground without harming itself.
events: Boeing 787 rough‑runway certification tests at Edwards AFB (2010): Boeing publicly demonstrated 787s running over roughness courses to validate landing‑gear and structural loads, illustrating the need to show the shock system prevents airframe damage on uneven pavement.

Airbus A350 XWB rough‑ground testing at Istres (2014): Airbus reported completion of rough‑runway and high‑energy ground handling tests during CS‑25 certification, demonstrating the design withstands realistic taxi surface irregularities without structural harm.

summary: The logic is simple: make the manufacturer prove safe directional and roll control in a defined 90° crosswind on a dry runway (≥20 kt or 0.2 VSR0, capped at a 25‑kt minimum), and also prove landing controllability with worst‑case icing accretions, with the clean takeoff value accepted for icing.
intent: Ensure each transport-category airplane can be safely controlled for takeoff and landing in significant crosswinds, including when ice is on the aircraft. The rule requires flight-test demonstration of a safe 90-degree crosswind (wind perpendicular to the runway) on dry runways for both takeoff and landing; this must be at least 37 km/h (20 kt) or 0.2 × VSR0 (20% of the 1‑g stall-reference speed in landing configuration), whichever is greater, but need not exceed 46 km/h (25 kt) as a minimum demonstration. For takeoff, the value established without ice also applies in icing. For landing, controllability must also be shown with the most critical icing accretions from Appendix C and O (including supercooled large droplets), per CS 25.21(g). These demonstrated crosswind capabilities are published to guide operational limits, training, and procedures.
events: Lufthansa A320 D-AIQP, Hamburg (1 Mar 2008): A landing attempt in severe, gusting crosswinds (reported gusts up to 47 kt) caused a left wingtip strike before a go‑around. It shows why a demonstrated crosswind envelope and procedures are essential to ensure controllability near the limits.

American Eagle Flight 4184 (ATR‑72), Roselawn, Indiana (31 Oct 1994): Supercooled large droplet icing caused an aileron hinge‑moment reversal and roll upset leading to loss of control. This drove adoption of Appendix O; requiring crosswind landing capability to be shown with critical ice accretions ensures controllability when icing degrades roll/yaw authority.

Boeing 777 certification program: The AFM publishes a 38‑kt maximum demonstrated crosswind (dry runway) from certification flight tests. This illustrates compliance with CS 25.237 and how a verified 90° crosswind value is established and communicated for operational use.

summary: The logic is simple: prove in flight that the airplane and its parts won’t vibrate or buffet in a way that hinders control, tires the crew, or harms the structure across the certified envelope, set speed limits accordingly, and define safe buffet margins so minor excursions aren’t dangerous.
intent: Ensure transport airplanes do not experience harmful airframe vibrations or aerodynamic buffeting that could jeopardize safety, comfort, or structural integrity in any likely operating condition. In flight, the aircraft and its components must be shown free of excessive vibration up to the demonstrated dive speed (VDF/MDF), and operating limits (VMO/MMO) must reflect those findings. In normal flight, including configuration changes, buffeting must not interfere with control, fatigue the crew, or damage the structure; only stall-warning buffet is acceptable. In cruise configuration, there must be no perceptible buffet up to VMO/MMO. For higher performance aircraft (MD > 0.6 or max altitude > 25,000 ft), manufacturers must determine the load-factor/speed/altitude/weight boundaries where buffet begins and show there is adequate operational margin, and that likely inadvertent excursions beyond those boundaries do not create unsafe conditions. This provides a usable, safe maneuvering envelope and protects against aeroelastic instabilities (e.g., flutter) and high-altitude “coffin-corner” buffet.
events: Lockheed L-188 Electra whirl-flutter breakups (Braniff Flight 542, 1959; Northwest Orient Flight 710, 1960): both aircraft suffered catastrophic wing separations from propeller-induced aeroelastic vibration. These accidents show how unchecked vibration can rapidly lead to structural failure, motivating today’s requirement to demonstrate freedom from excessive vibration up to dive speeds and to set conservative operating limits.

Pinnacle Airlines Flight 3701 (CRJ200, 2004): the crew climbed to FL410, encountered the narrow high-altitude buffet regime, stalled, and lost both engines before crashing. This illustrates why certification must chart buffet-onset envelopes and ensure normal operations retain adequate speed/load-factor margin and that inadvertent excursions beyond onset do not create unrecoverable conditions.

BAC One-Eleven G-ASHG flight-test accident (1963): during high-angle-of-attack trials the aircraft entered a deep stall with little natural buffet warning and became uncontrollable. The case drove adoption of stick shaker/pusher protections and underscores CS 25.251’s intent that buffeting in normal flight must not interfere with control, allowing only managed stall-warning buffet.

summary: The logic is simple: ensure that if a transport aeroplane drifts or is upset above cruise limits, it gives clear warning, keeps predictable control (no reversals or severe buffet), provides enough roll and benign speedbrake behavior, and retains required stability up to test‑proven dive speeds (with appropriate icing limits) so a normal crew can reliably slow back to VMO/MMO without overstressing the aircraft.
intent: CS 25.253 makes sure a large transport aeroplane stays controllable and recoverable if it inadvertently accelerates to high speed. After an effective overspeed warning, a pilot of average strength and skill must be able to return to a normal attitude and slow back to the maximum operating speed (VMO/MMO) without exceeding the demonstrated/ design dive speeds (VDF/MDF, VD/MD), structural limits, or suffering buffet that prevents control. The aeroplane must not exhibit control-response reversal in pitch, roll, or yaw up to VDF/MDF; it must retain enough roll authority to recover from lateral upsets; and speedbrake extension at high speed must not create excessive g, impairing buffet, or a strong nose-down pitch. The rule also defines the maximum speed for which stability requirements must be met (VFC/MFC), and provides lower limits in icing (e.g., up to 300 knots CAS) recognizing altered aerodynamics. In short, it safeguards against high-speed phenomena (Mach tuck, shock buffet, aileron buzz) and ensures intuitive, predictable controls for safe recovery.
events: China Airlines Flight 006 (1985, Boeing 747SP) suffered an upset after an engine flameout, rolled into a spiral dive, and accelerated to near M0.99 with about 4.8 g before recovery, causing substantial structural damage. It shows why the rule demands clear overspeed warning, predictable high‑Mach control behavior, and sufficient authority to recover without exceeding VDF/MDF or structural limits.

TWA Flight 841 (1979, Boeing 727) entered an uncommanded roll and high‑speed dive; the crew used speedbrakes and landing gear to arrest the descent and recovered after significant overspeed and buffeting, with airframe damage. This highlights the need for non‑surprising speedbrake effects, no control reversals, and adequate controllability for recovery from inadvertent high‑speed excursions.

BOAC Flight 911 (1966, Boeing 707-436) encountered severe clear‑air turbulence near Mount Fuji and broke up in flight due to extreme gust loads at cruise. The event underlines why certification must consider gust‑induced upsets and speed increases and require controllable, non‑debilitating buffet characteristics near VMO/MMO.

summary: The logic is simple: even if the stabiliser is mis-trimmed at high speed, the airplane must retain stable, monotonic control forces and enough pitch authority to pull out safely without excessive effort.
intent: Ensure that a large aeroplane remains safely controllable and predictably stable in pitch even when not properly trimmed at high speed. Out-of-trim means the stabiliser/elevator trim is set incorrectly so the pilot must hold a steady force on the control column. The rule requires that, from a normal cruise trim up to VMO/MMO (maximum operating speed/Mach), the aeroplane with a representative mis-trim (from 3 seconds of trim run or the maximum autopilot-sustained mis-trim) has: positive stick-force-per-g up to VFC/MFC (no “lightening up” when you pull for more g), no control-force reversals up to VDF/MDF (design dive speed/Mach), and enough pitch authority to generate at least 1.5 g at VDF/MDF with no more than 556 N (125 lbf) of pull. Tests must respect structural/buffet limits, but trim must still be usable under load. The intent is to prevent mis-trim—whether from pilot action, system faults, or autopilot—from creating unstable behaviour or excessive forces that could prevent recovery from an overspeed dive.
events: China Airlines Flight 006 (Boeing 747SP, 1985): The autopilot masked an engine-out by holding altitude, building a large pitch/roll mis-trim; upon disconnect the aircraft departed into a high-speed dive before recovery. It shows why designs must remain predictable and recoverable after autopilot-sustained mis-trim, exactly as §25.255 requires.

Alaska Airlines Flight 261 (MD-83, 2000): A failed jackscrew led to stabiliser runaway/jam, severe out-of-trim, and loss of pitch control culminating in a fatal dive. Though beyond normal mis-trim, it illustrates how trim system failures can rapidly overwhelm control and why certification demands minimum recovery authority and usable trim under load.

Lion Air 610 and Ethiopian 302 (Boeing 737 MAX, 2018–2019): MCAS repeatedly drove nose-down stabiliser trim, creating large out-of-trim and rapidly rising column forces at high speed. This demonstrates the hazard of automated systems inducing mis-trim and validates the rule’s aim for predictable forces and assured recovery capability in mis-trimmed conditions.

summary: The logic is simple: define realistic in-service loads, apply a safety margin, model how the whole aircraft actually carries those loads (including deflection effects), and prove the predictions with flight/test evidence.
intent: This rule sets the foundation for how structural loads are defined and substantiated on large aeroplanes. It distinguishes limit loads (the maximum loads expected in service) from ultimate loads (limit loads multiplied by a safety factor, typically 1.5) and requires all calculated loads to reflect real physics: every mass item’s inertia must be included and the aircraft must be in equilibrium. Load distributions must conservatively match reality, and the analytical methods used to predict them must be proven—by instrumented flight-load measurements unless the methods are already demonstrated reliable. If the structure deflects under load in a way that changes how loads are carried (aeroelastic or geometric nonlinearity), that redistribution must be included. In short, the rule ensures loads assumptions are realistic, conservative, validated by test, and include safety margin.
events: Northwest Orient Flight 710 (Lockheed L-188 Electra), 17 March 1960, suffered in‑flight breakup near Tell City, Indiana due to propeller whirl flutter that led to catastrophic wing failure. The accident showed how structural deflection and engine/propeller inertia can redistribute and amplify loads, underscoring 25.301’s requirement to account for deflection‑induced load changes and all masses in equilibrium.

American Airlines Flight 587 (Airbus A300-605R), 12 November 2001, lost its vertical stabilizer after aggressive alternating rudder inputs generated aerodynamic loads that exceeded the structure’s strength (NTSB AAR-04/04). This demonstrated that ‘limit loads’ must reflect real in‑service control inputs and that design, procedures, and training must prevent pilots from driving loads beyond those assumptions.

Boeing 787 program (June 2009): static ground testing revealed delamination at the wing‑to‑body join (side‑of‑body), prompting structural reinforcement before flight test. This program lesson highlights the need to validate load models and distributions by test and to ensure ultimate‑load capability with adequate safety margin.

summary: The logic is simple: if a system can change the loads, stiffness, or damping on the airframe, you must prove the structure can withstand both its normal actions and credible failures using Appendix K’s criteria.
intent: This rule ensures that any aircraft system that can change structural loads or stiffness—whether during normal operation or if it fails—is explicitly accounted for when showing the airframe meets strength, fatigue, and aeroelastic requirements (Subparts C and D). It covers systems such as electronic flight controls (fly‑by‑wire), load‑alleviation and envelope‑protection functions, high‑lift devices, spoilers/speedbrakes, thrust reversers, landing gear/brakes, and pressurization. Applicants must demonstrate structural safety with realistic system behaviors and credible failure conditions, not just a “bare airframe.” CS‑25 Appendix K provides the method: classify failure conditions by severity and probability, determine which must be included in limit/ultimate loads and flutter/stability analyses, and define margins or independence when the structure depends on active systems. The outcome is a structure whose integrity is preserved despite system actions, transients, or malfunctions.
events: Lauda Air Flight 004 (Boeing 767‑300ER, 26 May 1991): an uncommanded in‑flight thrust reverser deployment caused extreme asymmetric loads and breakup. It illustrates why reverser system failures must be included in structural load cases and aeroelastic assessments, not treated solely as handling‑qualities issues.

China Eastern Airlines Flight 583 (McDonnell Douglas MD‑11, 6 April 1993): inadvertent slat deployment at cruise produced violent oscillations and high g excursions, damaging the aircraft. It demonstrates that high‑lift system malfunctions can drive critical structural loads that must be covered in the substantiation envelope.

Turkish Airlines Flight 981 (McDonnell Douglas DC‑10, 3 March 1974): a cargo door system/latch failure led to explosive decompression, floor collapse, and control cable failure. It shows that pressurization and door systems interact with structure and that credible system failures must be part of structural design and compliance analysis.

summary: The logic is simple: design for the highest expected service loads, then prove the structure can survive 150% of them to cover uncertainties—unless the rule already gives the load at the ultimate level.
intent: This rule sets the basic safety margin for structural strength. It requires every “limit load” (the highest load expected in normal service) to be multiplied by a Factor of Safety (FoS) of 1.5, and the structure must carry that “ultimate load” without failure. The 1.5 FoS covers uncertainties in load prediction, material properties, manufacturing tolerances, load paths, dynamic effects, and modest in-service degradation. If a requirement already states loads as “ultimate,” you do not apply the 1.5 again, avoiding double counting. This anchor requirement underpins static strength substantiation: designers size structure to limit loads, and then prove it can survive 150% of those loads.
events: Airbus A380 static wing test (2006): The wing failed around 1.45× limit load—below the required 1.5—prompting reinforcement before full compliance; this demonstrates why the rule demands a clear 1.5 margin above limit loads.

Boeing 777 static wing test (1995): The wing sustained about 1.54× limit load before failing, validating compliance with the 1.5 factor and exemplifying how ultimate-load testing verifies the mandated safety margin.

American Airlines Flight 587, A300-600 (2001): Rapid rudder reversals produced side loads that exceeded design strength, leading to vertical tail separation; it underscores the distinction between limit and ultimate loads and why structures are not expected to survive beyond the 1.5 safety margin.

summary: The logic is simple: prove the structure won’t permanently deform at expected loads, won’t fail at required ultimate loads, and can safely tolerate real‑world dynamics—deformation, transient spikes, vibration, buffet, and control‑system‑induced oscillations—by test or credible analysis.
intent: Ensure the airframe is both strong and stiff enough to fly safely under all expected conditions and credible malfunctions. At “limit load” (the highest loads expected in service), the structure must not suffer harmful permanent set or cause unsafe interference. At “ultimate load” (typically 150% of limit), it must not fail and must sustain that load for at least 3 seconds unless realistic dynamic tests show equivalence; analyses must properly account for the deformations that occur. Designers must also consider transient stress spikes from rapid load application on flexible structures, withstand vibration and buffet up to design dive speed/Mach (VD/MD), including stalls and likely brief excursions beyond buffet onset, and tolerate forced structural vibration from flight‑control failures/malfunctions unless shown extremely improbable, handled per CS 25.302.
events: Airbus A380 wing static test (Toulouse, 2006) failed around 145% of limit load, short of the required 150% ultimate load sustainment, prompting wing reinforcement before certification; this demonstrates why CS 25.305 demands proof of ultimate strength with full deformation accounted.

American Airlines Flight 587 (A300‑600, 2001): rapid rudder reversals at high speed generated transient and amplified side loads that exceeded structural capacity, leading to vertical tail separation; this illustrates the need to consider rate‑of‑load application and dynamic stresses, not just static loads.

Lockheed L‑188 Electra whirl‑flutter accidents (Braniff Flight 542, 1959; Northwest Flight 710, 1960) saw catastrophic wing separations from severe aeroelastic vibration; these cases underpin today’s requirements to analyze and test for vibration/buffet tolerance up to VD/MD and account for forced structural vibrations.

summary: The logic is simple: prove the structure can take its worst loads without undue deformation or failure using validated analysis, and where analysis isn’t proven, test to limit and ultimate loads (with extra material factors if you rely on tests alone for single-load-path structures).
intent: Ensure every critical load case on the airplane’s structure is proven to meet strength and deformation requirements by using analysis only where it is known to be reliable for that specific design, and otherwise by testing to appropriate load levels. In simple terms: the structure must carry limit loads (the highest loads expected in service) without harmful permanent deformation, and ultimate loads (typically 1.5 times limit) without failure, as required by CS 25.305. “CS” means Certification Specification; “AMC” means Acceptable Means of Compliance. Analyses (including FEM) must be validated by relevant test evidence for the same or very similar structures; new or significantly changed designs need targeted tests. If compliance is shown by tests alone on single-load-path flight structure, material variability must be covered by applying correction factors unless multiple load paths provide redundancy and load redistribution.
events: Airbus A380 wing static test (2006): The full-scale wing failed around 146% of limit load, short of the 150% ultimate requirement, prompting local reinforcements and a successful retest. This shows why full-scale tests must verify ultimate strength and why failures below ultimate drive redesign, exactly as CS 25.307/305 intend.

Boeing 787 side‑of‑body reinforcement (2009): During ground static testing, strain data indicated risk of delamination and inadequate margins at the wing‑body join, leading to design changes before further testing and first flight. This illustrates that new composite structural concepts require analysis validated by test, as mandated by CS 25.307.

Boeing 777‑9 extreme‑load ground test (2019): A cargo door panel blew out during an ultimate pressurization/bending static test, leading Boeing to pause, investigate, and reinforce the test article. This underscores the need to demonstrate ultimate load capability via testing and to act on results before certification, aligning with CS 25.307.

summary: The logic is simple: search the whole operating envelope (altitude, speed, weight, CG, thrust) with compressibility and full force/moment equilibrium so the true worst-case loads on every structural part are identified and sized safely.
intent: This rule defines flight load factor (aerodynamic force normal to the aircraft’s axis divided by weight) and requires that structural loads be determined across the full approved operating envelope. That means accounting for compressibility (high-speed/Mach effects) at each speed, every critical altitude, all weights from minimum to maximum, and any allowable loading/center-of-gravity (CG) distribution in the Aeroplane Flight Manual (AFM). Enough points inside that envelope must be evaluated to ensure the real worst-case load is found for each structural part. Loads must be computed by putting all significant forces and moments in equilibrium using rational or conservative methods, including linear and angular (pitch) inertia, thrust effects, and moments from components like tails and nacelles, with thrust ranging from zero to maximum continuous. The objective is to prevent undersizing by ensuring no critical combination of speed, altitude, weight, CG, thrust, and maneuver/gust condition is missed.
events: BOAC Flight 911 (Boeing 707-436, 1966, near Mt. Fuji) suffered in-flight breakup after encountering extreme clear-air turbulence and gust loads. It shows why designers must search the envelope at relevant altitudes and weights—gust/maneuver loads can peak at specific conditions, so maximum structural loads must be captured conservatively across the envelope.

China Airlines Flight 006 (Boeing 747SP, 1985) entered a high-speed dive after an engine flameout and recovered at roughly 4.8 g with near-transonic compressibility, causing major structural damage. It demonstrates the need to balance linear and angular inertia with aerodynamic forces and thrust across the envelope to ensure structural margins under upset/manoeuvre loads.

American Airlines Flight 587 (Airbus A300-600, 2001) lost its vertical tail after rapid alternating rudder inputs generated loads beyond the fin’s strength. It underscores that component loads (e.g., tail surfaces) can be critical and must be included in the global equilibrium so worst-case flight loads are identified and the structure is properly sized.

summary: The logic is simple: drive the airplane’s pitch with the most severe but realistic control motions across the allowed speeds until the required limit g is reached, and show the resulting wing and tail loads remain within structural limits.
intent: CS 25.331 sets the symmetric (pitch-only) maneuvering load cases used to size and verify the airplane’s structure. It demands realistic pilot/control-system input rates, inclusion of the aircraft’s dynamic pitch response (its short-period mode), and analysis of both in-trim and out-of-trim conditions per CS 25.255. Engineers must check steady “balanced” points across the maneuvering envelope (CS 25.333) and specific dynamic pitch inputs: a sudden maximum nose-up at VA (design maneuvering speed) and “checked” pitch maneuvers between VA and VD (design dive speed) that reach the limit load factor n (positive) or 0 g (nose-down). Loads are considered until the center-of-gravity (c.g.) normal acceleration exceeds the positive limit n or the tailplane load peaks. Acceptable Means of Compliance (AMC) define input shapes tied to the undamped short-period frequency, and any system that can move the cockpit pitch control (e.g., a stick pusher) must be included. The aim is to ensure wings, tailplane, fuselage, and controls can withstand the worst credible symmetric pitch loads without failure.
events: China Airlines Flight 006 (Boeing 747SP, 19 Feb 1985): During recovery from an upset, the pullout reached about 5 g and caused structural damage, illustrating how aggressive pitch inputs can quickly generate extreme wing/tail loads. This underscores why CS 25.331 requires dynamic, rate-limited “checked” maneuvers tied to aircraft response to bound pitch loads up to the certified limits.

Qantas Flight 72 (Airbus A330-303, 7 Oct 2008): Faulty ADIRU data triggered abrupt nose-down commands leading to negative g excursions around cruise, injuring occupants. This shows that system-induced pitch inputs can occur away from 1 g and must be included in maneuvering load analyses, including the nose-down case to 0 g and consideration of system effects on cockpit control motion.

BAC One-Eleven prototype G-ASHG (22 Oct 1963): A deep-stall test accident led to adoption of stick pushers on T-tail jets, a system that can drive the control column forward abruptly. CS 25.331 explicitly requires accounting for such system-driven pitch inputs in loads, ensuring structures can tolerate sudden nose-down commands at various load factors.

summary: The logic is simple: define the safe combination of speed and g (the V–n envelope), design the structure to withstand every point inside it, and set the airplane’s operating limits so pilots never command manoeuvres outside it.
intent: This rule ensures that the airplane’s structure can safely withstand all pilot‑induced manoeuvres that are allowed by its operating limits across the full range of speeds. It requires defining a “V–n diagram” (airspeed V versus load factor n, where n is lift/weight in g’s) and showing that at every point inside that envelope the aircraft meets strength requirements (no permanent deformation at limit load, adequate margin to ultimate). The same envelope then anchors the published structural operating limitations (e.g., design manoeuvring speed Va, cruise Vc, dive Vd, positive/negative g limits) so pilots and systems do not command manoeuvres that would exceed structural capability. In short, the regulation ties structural design loads to the manoeuvres the aircraft may legally see in service, and ties those loads back to the flight manual limits.
events: American Airlines Flight 587 (2001, A300-600): the vertical tail separated after aggressive alternating rudder inputs generated side loads that exceeded the certified manoeuvring/yaw envelope. The accident drove industry emphasis on respecting manoeuvring limits and training on rudder use at higher speeds.

China Airlines Flight 006 (1985, B747SP): after an upset, recovery pulled very high g (reported near 4.8 g), causing substantial structural damage though the aircraft landed safely. It illustrates how severe pilot manoeuvres at speed can approach or exceed the manoeuvring envelope, with real structural consequences.

Boeing 787 static test programme (2009): delamination at the wing‑to‑body side‑of‑body joint was discovered during high‑load certification testing, prompting redesign before flight tests. This publicly documented programme lesson shows how manoeuvring‑envelope load cases drive structural sizing and verification of safe operating limits.

summary: The logic is simple: pick and relate cruise, dive, manoeuvre, gust, flap, and drag‑device speeds—expressed in EAS—with mandated margins so that foreseeable turbulence, upsets, pilot actions, and system behaviors cannot drive the airplane beyond structural limits or controllability.
intent: Set the basic design airspeeds that drive structural sizing so the airplane can safely withstand realistic turbulence, upsets, manoeuvres, and configuration changes without exceeding strength or controllability limits. All speeds are expressed as Equivalent Airspeed (EAS) because it directly represents aerodynamic load. The rule defines minimum values and relationships for: VC (design cruise), VD (design dive), VA (manoeuvring), VB (gust penetration), VF (flap) and VDD (drag devices), with conservative stall speeds (VS0/VS1). It requires margins for severe turbulence, instrument/production variability, and real upset dynamics (e.g., 7.5–15° nose‑down paths and 1.5 g recoveries), and accommodates high‑speed protection systems. It also ensures flaps and drag devices are designed for their recommended operating speeds with adequate margin, including when automatic limiting is installed. Overall, it ties operationally plausible accelerations and gusts to structural design speeds, preventing exceedance of limit loads in service.
events: BOAC Flight 911 (B707-436), 1966, broke up near Mt. Fuji after encountering extreme clear‑air turbulence; the structural failure underscored the need for conservative gust design and a defined VB/VC margin tied to reference gusts.

China Airlines Flight 006 (B747SP), 1985, suffered a high‑altitude upset and descended in a steep dive to near Mach 0.96 with significant overspeed damage; it illustrates why VD must cover realistic nose‑down upset profiles and 1.5 g recoveries with sufficient speed margin.

TWA Flight 841 (B727), 1979, entered a spiral dive, exceeded Mmo with loss of a slat and structural damage before recovery; the event demonstrates the necessity of robust VD/VA relationships and configuration‑change speed margins to tolerate inadvertent or upset‑induced overspeeds.

summary: The logic is simple: define conservative minimum positive and negative g‑limits for symmetric manoeuvres across speeds (with real pull‑up dynamics), and let applicants take credit for robust protections that make higher loads impossible.
intent: Set minimum “g” (load factor) levels the airplane must structurally withstand during symmetric manoeuvres (pull‑ups, steady turns, push‑overs) across the speed range, so pilots cannot inadvertently break the aircraft with normal manoeuvring. It defines the positive limit load factor n based on weight (but not less than 2.5g and not more than 3.8g), and the negative limit as at least −1.0g up to design cruise speed (VC), reducing linearly to 0g at design dive speed (VD). Pitch‑rate effects typical of real pull‑ups must be included, and if certified design features (e.g., protections) make exceeding certain g‑levels impossible, lower values may be used. In short, it preserves structural integrity under realistic manoeuvres without demanding strength for extreme, unattainable inputs.
events: China Airlines Flight 006 (1985, Boeing 747SP): After an upset, the recovery peaked near 5 g and caused substantial structural damage yet the airframe held. This shows why CS 25.337 requires strong positive manoeuvre capability and accounting for pitch‑rate effects during pull‑ups.

TWA Flight 841 (1979, Boeing 727): Following a high‑altitude upset, recovery imposed very high symmetric pull‑out loads with significant damage but no in‑flight breakup. This illustrates the need for transport aircraft to withstand large manoeuvring g‑loads without structural failure—exactly the purpose of CS 25.337.

Airbus A320 FBW certification (late 1980s): Airbus demonstrated Normal Law g‑limiting that caps load factor to about +2.5/−1.0 g clean (lower in landing config), and authorities accepted reliance on these protections in showing manoeuvre loads could not be exceeded. This exemplifies CS 25.337(d), which allows reduced assumed loads when design features make exceedance impossible.

summary: The logic is simple: model realistic vertical and lateral gusts/turbulence across speeds and altitudes with full aircraft dynamics and systems, then size the structure and engine mounts to the worst resulting limit loads.
intent: CS 25.341 makes manufacturers show, by dynamic analysis, that the airframe and engine attachments can withstand real atmospheric disturbances without permanent deformation (limit load). It covers two families of disturbances: discrete gusts (a short 1–cosine “bump” with a length H) and continuous turbulence (the random atmosphere, modeled with a von Kármán spectrum). The rule requires unsteady aerodynamics, all significant structural modes and rigid‑body motions, and any stability augmentation system (SAS) non‑linearities to be included. Design gust/turbulence intensities vary with altitude and speed: between VB (turbulence penetration speed), VC (design cruise), and VD (design dive), with reference velocities scaled by a flight‑profile alleviation factor Fg (based on typical operating altitude Zmo and weight ratios) and expressed in EAS/TAS as appropriate. Engineers must search a range of gust gradients (9–107 m) and speeds to find the critical response. For wing‑mounted engines, combined vertical and lateral gusts must be assessed to capture peak nacelle/pylon loads in all six degrees of freedom.
events: BOAC Flight 911 (Boeing 707‑436), 5 March 1966: in‑flight breakup near Mount Fuji after encountering severe mountain‑wave clear‑air turbulence, with investigators citing extreme gust loads and structural overstress. This underscores the need for dynamic gust criteria over multiple axes and altitude‑dependent reference velocities as in CS 25.341.

Braniff Flight 250 (DC‑9), 6 August 1966: entered a thunderstorm and suffered an in‑flight breakup attributed to structural overload from severe up‑/downdrafts. This illustrates the discrete, short‑length gusts the rule models with the 1–cosine profile and requires checking across VB to VC/VD and gust gradients.

United Airlines Flight 826 (B747), 28 December 1997: severe clear‑air turbulence at cruise caused one fatality and many injuries without structural failure. The event shows the prevalence of continuous turbulence aloft and supports the rule’s RMS/spectral approach and speed/altitude scaling for limit loads, including consideration of both positive and negative increments.

summary: The logic is simple: design and verify the airplane for manoeuvre, gust, fatigue, and flutter across the entire fuel/oil range—including zero fuel in the wings—allowing a limited reserve assumption but still proving critical zero-fuel cases.
intent: Ensure the airplane’s structure remains safe for all in-flight loadings across the full spectrum of fuel and oil quantities. Because fuel in the wing provides bending relief and damping, the most severe structural and aeroelastic conditions can occur when the wing is empty. This rule requires designers to check flight manoeuvre and gust loads with fuel/oil ranging from zero to maximum, allows a small “structural reserve fuel” assumption (up to 45 minutes per CS 25.1001(f)), and, if used, sets it as the minimum for load compliance. Even then, the wing must still be proven safe at zero fuel for a defined manoeuvre (+2.25 g), for specified gust/turbulence levels (at 85% of CS 25.341 values), and for fatigue and flutter/aeroelastic criteria. In plain terms: prove strength, fatigue life, and flutter margins when the wings are empty as well as full.
events: BOAC Flight 911 (Boeing 707-436, 1966) broke up in extreme mountain-wave turbulence near Mount Fuji; it underscores why certification demands demonstrated gust capability across conditions, including when wing fuel (which normally gives bending relief and damping) is minimal or absent.

China Airlines Flight 006 (Boeing 747SP, 1985) experienced an upset and over‑G recovery that caused substantial structural damage but a safe landing; it shows manoeuvre loads can approach structural limits late in flight after fuel burn-off, so compliance must cover minimal/zero-wing-fuel conditions.

Maximum Zero Fuel Weight (MZFW) limits published in type data (e.g., EASA TCDS EASA.A.064 for the A320 family) are an operational reflection of the zero‑fuel wing bending case, preventing excessive wing‑root bending when wing tanks are empty and mirroring CS 25.343’s zero-fuel load requirements.

summary: The logic is simple: when flaps/slats are out, size the wing and high‑lift system for defined manoeuvre and gust loads (including propwash), up to the applicable flap design speeds, and ensure a minimum landing‑config 1.5 g capability.
intent: Ensure the wing and all high-lift devices (flaps, slats, tracks, and attachments) can safely carry the loads they see when deployed in takeoff, approach, landing, and any approved en‑route use. With flaps out, the airplane faces different aerodynamics and higher sensitivity to gusts and power effects, so CS 25.345 defines the structural “limit loads” to consider: up to 2 g manoeuvres, standardized gusts (25 ft/s Equivalent Airspeed, using a 1‑cosine profile with gradient 12.5 times the wing chord), propeller slipstream at relevant power, and a head‑on gust case. For any en‑route flap use, the normal manoeuvre factors and gust/turbulence spectrum apply up to the selected flap design speed. Regardless, the airplane must also withstand at least 1.5 g at maximum takeoff weight in landing configuration. Analyses must be rational and include unsteady aerodynamics and the airplane’s rigid‑body motion (AMC = Acceptable Means of Compliance; EAS = Equivalent Airspeed).
events: TWA Flight 841 (Boeing 727, 1979): an inadvertent leading‑edge slat extension at high speed caused a violent upset and slat damage; this shows how high‑lift deployment drastically alters loads and why flaps/slats must be structurally assessed for manoeuvre and gust conditions (NTSB AAR‑81/08).

FAA AD 2019‑20‑11 and EASA AD 2019‑0176 (Boeing 737NG slat tracks): cracking due to manufacturing hydrogen embrittlement required urgent replacement; this underscores that slat/track load paths must reliably sustain takeoff/landing and gust loads defined by CS 25.345.

EASA Emergency ADs 2012‑0011 and 2012‑0024 (Airbus A380 wing rib‑foot cracking): cracks found near leading‑edge structure in service and testing drove inspections/mods, highlighting that repeated low‑speed, flap‑down and gust load spectra produce significant fatigue near high‑lift attachment areas that must be sized per CS 25.345.

summary: The logic is simple: size the structure for the worst realistic roll loads from both commanded manoeuvres and uneven gusts across the wings, accounting for wing twist, outboard mass inertia, control system characteristics, and yaw coupling at key speeds (VA/VC/VD).
intent: This rule ensures a large transport aeroplane is strong enough to withstand the asymmetric and transient loads that occur when it rolls—either because the pilot/automation commands roll or because an uneven vertical gust hits the wings. It requires designers to account for unbalanced aerodynamic moments about the centre of gravity (CG) and the inertia of major masses (like outboard engines) during roll accelerations, and to include the wing’s torsional flexibility (to capture twist/aileron effects). Defined roll cases must be checked at VA (design manoeuvring speed), VC (design cruise), and VD (design dive): for conventional controls by aileron deflection, and for fly‑by‑wire (FBW) by cockpit control movement and achieved roll rate. Both steady roll rate and maximum angular acceleration must be considered, including a worst case with no yaw correction (maximising sideslip) and a separate case with yaw correction. For gusts, the structure must also be sized for unsymmetrical vertical gust loading (100% of wing airload on one side, 80% on the other) derived from the CS‑25 gust model.
events: BOAC Flight 911 (Boeing 707‑436), 5 March 1966, broke up near Mount Fuji after encountering extreme mountain‑wave turbulence; the investigation attributed the breakup to severe gust loads and rapid attitude changes. Such unsymmetrical gusts can load the two wings very differently, illustrating why CS 25.349(b) requires asymmetric gust sizing (100%/80%) to protect against rolling gust conditions.

Braniff Flight 542 (Lockheed L‑188 Electra), 29 September 1959, suffered in‑flight breakup from propeller‑nacelle whirl flutter that induced catastrophic wing torsional/rolling oscillations. The accident shows how outboard engine masses and wing torsional flexibility can drive high roll angular accelerations, supporting CS 25.349’s emphasis on angular‑acceleration cases and torsional flexibility when sizing rolling loads.

EASA ED Decision 2021/015/R (AMC 25.349(a)) formalised FBW‑specific rolling conditions based on cockpit roll‑control motion (rather than surface deflection) and required analysis with and without yaw correction. This programme‑level clarification, applied on modern FBW programmes (e.g., Airbus/Boeing), proves the rule’s purpose: translate real pilot inputs and achieved roll rates into structural loads so wings and control systems are sized correctly.

summary: The logic is simple: size the vertical tail and lateral load path for the worst credible rudder-input sequence—sudden full-pedal yaw, inertial overswing, steady sideslip, and snap-back to neutral—limited by stops or pedal forces, from VMC to VD.
intent: Ensure the airframe (especially the vertical tail, rudder, and their attachments) can safely withstand the worst yaw loads a pilot or system can realistically create, from minimum control speed (VMC) up to design dive speed (VD). The rule defines a sequence of realistic rudder use cases: a sudden pedal input to the maximum achievable rudder deflection (limited by stops or by specified pedal forces that reduce with speed), the ensuing inertial overswing to a larger sideslip, holding maximum deflection at steady sideslip, and then a sudden return to neutral that reverses loads. It requires a rational/conservative distribution of the resulting unbalanced moments about the center of gravity through the structure, accounting for inertia (e.g., fuselage, fin, engines/pylons). For tail load computation, yaw rate may be taken as zero to simplify but remains conservative. In short, it sizes the lateral load path for abrupt rudder inputs and reversals across the full speed range.
events: American Airlines Flight 587 (A300-600, 2001, Belle Harbor): aggressive rudder reversals at high speed produced alternating side loads that exceeded the vertical tail’s ultimate strength, leading to fin separation; this demonstrates why CS 25.351 includes overswing and sudden return-to-neutral (load reversal) conditions with realistic pedal-force limits.

Northwest Airlines Flight 85 (B747-400, 2002, near Alaska): an uncommanded rudder hardover caused a large, sudden yaw and sideslip; the airframe withstood the loads and landed safely, illustrating the need to design for abrupt maximum rudder deflection and overswing across the speed envelope.

USAir Flight 427 (B737-300, 1994, near Pittsburgh): a rudder PCU malfunction led to an abrupt full rudder deflection, extreme yaw/roll, and loss of control; while not a structural failure, it underscores that full-deflection yaw events can occur suddenly and the structure must tolerate the associated sideslip loads addressed by CS 25.351.

summary: The logic is simple: design the fin, rudder, and control system to survive worst-case full rudder reversals and sideslip overswings at operational speeds so that even extreme inputs don’t cause structural failure.
intent: Ensure the vertical tail, rudder, and their control system are strong enough to withstand rapid, large rudder inputs and reversals that create the highest side loads on the fin during yaw maneuvers. The rule requires sizing to “ultimate” loads (limit loads with safety margin) from a sequence of full rudder pedal inputs and reversals at speeds from VMC (minimum control speed in the air) up to VC/MC (design cruise speed or the corresponding design Mach). It models real pilot actions in upsets (including overshoot in sideslip due to inertia) using a conservative 890 N (200 lbf) pedal force, with gear and speed brakes retracted and considering en‑route flap/slat use. Permanent deformation at these ultimate loads must not compromise continued safe flight and landing. In short, the airplane must not lose its fin or control authority when a pilot rapidly “stamps” and reverses the rudder at high dynamic pressure.
events: American Airlines Flight 587 (Airbus A300-605R), Belle Harbor, New York, 12 Nov 2001: rapid alternating full rudder inputs in wake turbulence at high speed led to vertical stabilizer separation (NTSB AAR-04/04). This showed that rudder reversals can generate fin loads beyond older assumptions, prompting explicit certification load cases and training limits.

USAir Flight 427 (Boeing 737-3B7), near Pittsburgh, 8 Sep 1994: a rudder PCU malfunction caused a hardover and loss of control (NTSB AAR-99/01). It demonstrated that full-deflection rudder events can occur abruptly in service and may include rapid opposing pilot inputs, underscoring the need to structurally tolerate such loads.

EASA CS-25 Amendment 25/22 introducing CS 25.353 (Rudder control reversal conditions): Europe codified explicit rudder-reversal and overswing sideslip load sequences after AA587. This regulatory change directly embodies the rule’s purpose—ensuring fin/rudder structures withstand ultimate loads from rapid reversals up to VC/MC.

summary: The logic is simple: size the mounts and nearby structure for the worst torque the engine or APU can impose—including transient spikes from acceleration, deceleration, or propeller control faults—while simultaneously carrying the applicable flight loads.
intent: Ensure that engine, pylon, and auxiliary power unit (APU) attachments and nearby structure can safely carry the twisting loads (torque) transmitted during both normal operation and worst credible transients. The rule sets minimum torque cases to combine with flight loads: takeoff and maximum continuous power for jets and turboprops, and adds specific transient cases for sudden engine/APU acceleration or deceleration due to malfunctions. For turboprops, it requires conservative multipliers on mean torque (1.25) and a higher factor (1.6 unless justified) for propeller control malfunctions (including quick feathering), which are known to create sharp torque spikes. For other turbine engines, the governing case is the maximum accelerating torque. The objective is to prevent structural failure or detachment of engines/APUs, preserve controllability, and contain secondary damage by designing mounts and adjacent airframe structure for these peak torque events.
events: Luxair Flight 9642 (Fokker 50, 2002): An uncommanded propeller pitch change into ground/beta range produced extreme asymmetric thrust/drag and rapid torque transients before impact; this illustrates why CS 25.361 requires a high turboprop malfunction factor (incl. quick feather) on mount torque loads.

Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 2311 (EMB-120, 1991): A propeller control unit failure drove one propeller to an improper low blade angle, creating large asymmetric loads and rapid engine/prop torque changes; it demonstrates the need to design turboprop structures for prop-control–induced torque spikes.

Air France Flight 66 (A380, 2017): An uncontained GP7200 fan hub separation caused an abrupt engine deceleration and abnormal loads, yet the pylon and mounts retained the engine and the aircraft landed safely; this shows why mounts must withstand sudden deceleration torque loads from engine malfunctions.

summary: The logic is simple: size the mounts, pylons, and surrounding structure to survive the worst short-duration engine-failure or bird-strike loads without losing the engine or control of the airplane, even if parts bend.
intent: Ensure the engine mounts, pylons, and the nearby airframe structure can withstand the worst transient loads and vibrations that occur when an engine suffers an internal failure (such as a fan/compressor/turbine blade breaking off, a shaft or bearing/bearing support failure) or when the engine ingests a bird, while the airplane is still carrying normal 1g (one times gravity) flight loads. These “ultimate” conditions are established by dynamic analysis that captures the short, high‑magnitude unbalance and shock loads. Some permanent deformation is acceptable, but it must not compromise continued safe flight and landing (the CS-25 objective that the aircraft can be controlled and landed safely). To provide adequate margin, the resulting ultimate loads are applied with a factor of 1.0 to mounts and pylons and a higher factor of 1.25 to adjacent supporting airframe structure to prevent cascading damage into the wing or fuselage.
events: Southwest Airlines Flight 1380 (2018, B737-700): a CFM56-7B fan blade fractured, causing an uncontained failure, severe vibration, and inlet breakup; the engine remained attached and the aircraft landed safely. This shows mounts/pylons and adjacent structure must tolerate blade-off dynamic loads and still permit continued safe flight and landing.

Qantas Flight 32 (2010, A380): an uncontained Trent 900 failure sent debris into the wing and systems while the engine/pylon remained attached and the crew returned to Singapore. It illustrates why adjacent supporting structure must endure extreme transient loads and damage without loss of control.

El Al Flight 1862 (1992, B747-200F): failure of pylon fuse pins led to separation of two engines, severe wing damage, and a fatal crash. This demonstrates the catastrophic consequences when pylon/adjacent structure cannot sustain abnormal loads, underscoring the need for robust margins mandated by CS 25.362.

summary: The logic is simple: size engine and APU mounts to withstand at least the worst yaw‑induced lateral load (with a hard minimum) as a standalone case so they don’t fail or detach in high‑sideslip or asymmetric conditions.
intent: Ensure that engine and auxiliary power unit (APU) mounts and their supporting structure can safely carry side (lateral) loads created by yawing flight, crosswinds, engine-out control, and sideslip without failing or allowing detachment. The rule sets a clear minimum: design for at least the worst lateral load factor seen in yaw conditions, but never less than 1.33 g lateral or one‑third of the basic maneuvering limit load factor from flight condition A (the standard symmetrical flight case in CS 25.333(b)). By allowing the side-load case to be treated independently of other flight conditions, the regulation provides a discrete, conservative sizing case for pylons and attachments. The objective is to prevent catastrophic engine/APU separations or pylon/wing damage when the aircraft experiences significant yawing or lateral acceleration, safeguarding structural integrity and essential systems routed through the pylon.
events: American Airlines Flight 191 (DC‑10‑10, Chicago, 1979): improper maintenance damaged the pylon/engine attach, leading to engine separation and loss of the aircraft. It underscores the catastrophic consequences of mount/pylon failure and why robust, independently‑substantiated side‑load capability is essential.

El Al Flight 1862 (Boeing 747‑200F, Amsterdam, 1992): fatigue and corrosion of pylon fuse pins allowed No. 3 engine to separate and strike No. 4, leading to structural failure and crash. The event shows that engine/pylon attachments must tolerate multi‑directional loads (including lateral) with adequate margins to avert separation.

American Airlines Flight 587 (Airbus A300‑605R, New York, 2001): aggressive rudder reversals produced very high yaw and sideslip loads, leading to vertical tail failure. It demonstrates that yawing conditions can generate large lateral accelerations affecting all attachments, validating the need to size engine/APU mounts to the maximum yaw side loads.

summary: The logic is simple: make the pressure vessel and all affected structures strong and damage-tolerant for normal differential pressures, include a 1.33 ultimate relief case, and ensure that sudden, credible decompression openings—from engine fragments or door/structure failures—do not deform or fail parts in a way that prevents continued safe flight and landing.
intent: CS-25.365 sets the safety objective for pressurized airplane compartments: the fuselage and attached structure must safely carry all expected internal pressure differences together with flight and landing loads, and must tolerate rapid depressurization events without losing the ability to continue safe flight and landing. It requires accounting for real external pressure distributions, stress concentrations, and fatigue from pressurization cycles. Structures must meet normal combined-load cases up to the pressure-relief setting, an ultimate case at 1.33 times that setting, and emergency cases from sudden openings caused by credible failures (including engine debris or door/structure failures) sized by a prescribed formula. Interior items—floors, bulkheads, partitions, and components—must resist the transient loads and avoid injuring occupants. Designers may credit fail-safe features and inter-compartment venting if analyzed conservatively. AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance) gives methods; CS (Certification Specifications) 25 defines the requirements.
events: Turkish Airlines Flight 981 (DC‑10, 3 Mar 1974): a cargo door failure caused an explosive decompression and cabin floor collapse that severed control cables, leading to loss of control; this shows why floors/partitions and control paths must withstand decompression loads and why inadvertent/failed closures must be considered (CS 25.365(e),(f),(g)).

Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (Boeing 737‑200, 28 Apr 1988): multi-site fatigue at lap joints led to a large fuselage tear and explosive decompression, yet the aircraft landed; this illustrates the need to account for external pressure distributions, stress concentrations, fatigue, and to maintain structural integrity under combined pressure and flight loads (CS 25.365(b)).

Southwest Airlines Flight 1380 (B737‑700, 17 Apr 2018): an engine fan blade fracture sent debris that broke a cabin window, causing rapid depressurization; this validates the requirement to withstand sudden pressure release from engine debris penetration and to preserve safe flight and landing (CS 25.365(e)(1)).

summary: The logic is simple: size the airplane to tolerate worst‑case asymmetric thrust/drag transients from a critical engine failure—using tested time histories and conservative pilot reaction/force assumptions—treating likely failures as limit loads and rare violent failures as ultimate loads, including a single prop‑drag‑limiter malfunction on turboprops.
intent: This rule ensures a transport airplane’s structure and controls can withstand the sudden, uneven (unsymmetrical) yawing and rolling loads that occur when the most critical engine fails, especially on turboprops. Designers must use realistic failure transients—how quickly thrust decays and propeller drag rises—proven by test/data for the exact engine–propeller combination, and must assume conservative pilot reaction timing and achievable control forces. For turboprops, failure due to fuel flow interruption between VMC and VD is a limit‑load case (no permanent deformation allowed), while more violent failures such as compressor–turbine disconnect or turbine‑blade loss between VMC and VC are treated as ultimate‑load cases (with safety factor, no failure). The analysis also considers a single malfunction of the propeller drag‑limiting system (e.g., autofeather/negative‑torque sensing), and allows pilot inputs to start no earlier than 2 seconds after failure or at peak yaw rate. Acronyms: VMC = minimum control speed with the critical engine inoperative; VC = design cruise speed; VD = design dive speed.
events: Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 2311 (EMB‑120, 1991): A propeller pitch control unit failure drove one propeller toward low/reverse pitch, creating extreme asymmetric drag and roll, and the aircraft crashed near Brunswick, GA (NTSB AAR‑92/04). It shows why structures and controllability must account for sudden prop‑drag spikes and realistic pilot reaction as required by CS 25.367.

Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 529 (EMB‑120, 1995): A propeller blade separated due to fatigue, causing severe vibration, thrust decay, and drag build‑up on one side before the prop could be controlled, leading to a crash near Carrollton, GA (NTSB AAR‑96/06). The transient yaw/roll loads validate the rule’s demand for time‑history‑based loads for the specific engine–propeller combination.

Luxair Flight 9642 (Fokker 50, 2002): An in‑flight propeller pitch control malfunction let one propeller enter reverse range on approach, producing massive asymmetric drag and a rapid roll‑off, ending in a crash near Luxembourg (official investigation report). It underscores the need to consider single malfunctions of prop‑drag‑limiting systems and to size for the resulting unsymmetrical loads.

summary: The logic is simple: size the engine/APU supporting structure for the worst prescribed maneuver, gust, and landing cases with the engine at maximum rpm, explicitly including gyroscopic moments, up to the positive limit load factor.
intent: Ensure the structures that hold engines and auxiliary power units (APUs)—mounts, pylons, and attachments—are strong enough to withstand all loads from prescribed maneuvers, gusts, and landings, including gyroscopic loads from the spinning engine cores and fans at the highest relevant revolutions per minute (rpm). Gyroscopic loads are the twisting moments generated when a spinning mass resists changes in its orientation during pitch, roll, or yaw; these moments add to aerodynamic and inertial loads on the mounts. The rule explicitly requires testing the pitch maneuver up to the positive limit maneuvering load factor so that worst-case combined loads are captured, preventing engine/APU structural failures, separations, fuel line ruptures, and resulting fires or loss of control.
events: American Airlines Flight 191 (DC‑10), Chicago, 25 May 1979: the No. 1 engine and pylon separated during takeoff rotation, leading to loss of control and a fatal crash. It demonstrates the catastrophic consequences of engine/pylon support failure under high-thrust, high-rate pitch conditions where gyroscopic and maneuver loads peak, validating the rule’s requirement to design mounts for such combined loads.

China Airlines Flight 006 (Boeing 747SP), Pacific Ocean, 19 Feb 1985: a severe upset and high‑g recovery caused substantial structural and engine/pylon damage documented by the NTSB. The event shows that rapid pitch/yaw at high engine rpm can impose large gyroscopic moments on struts, confirming why mounts must be designed for maneuver and gust cases with gyroscopic loads.

El Al Flight 1862 (Boeing 747‑200), Amsterdam, 4 Oct 1992: two engines separated after a pylon/attachment failure, leading to loss of the aircraft. The accident highlights the system‑wide hazard of engine support failure and the need to account for all contributing loads—including gyroscopic components—in design to prevent detachment under operational maneuvers.

summary: The logic is simple: if you permit a speed-control device to be used in cruise, you must show the airplane can withstand all prescribed maneuver and gust loads at the highest speeds and at every device position the system can actually produce.
intent: This rule ensures that if an airplane has speed-control devices (e.g., flight spoilers or drag flaps) intended for use in cruise/en‑route flight, the structure is proven safe for all required maneuver and turbulence load cases with those devices deployed at any allowed setting and speed. It ties these devices to the standard structural load envelopes: symmetric and yawing maneuvers, and vertical/lateral gusts and turbulence (referenced in CS 25.333, 25.337, 25.351, and 25.341). Because spoilers/drag flaps change lift, drag, and load distribution across the wings and tail, they can increase bending and torsion, especially in rough air. If there are automatic functions or load limiters, compliance must address the worst device positions and speeds the system permits, not just the pilot’s intended setting. In short, no “clean-wing” assumptions are allowed when the airplane is approved to fly en‑route with speedbrakes out.
events: BOAC Flight 911 (Boeing 707, 1966, near Mount Fuji): in‑flight breakup in severe clear‑air turbulence underscored how cruise gust loads can be extreme, supporting the need to size structure for turbulence with any permitted speed‑control device configuration.

China Eastern Airlines Flight 583 (MD‑11, 1993): inadvertent high‑speed slat deployment caused violent oscillations and injuries, illustrating how deploying lift/drag devices in cruise radically alters loads and stability—why structural analysis must cover such configurations.

Programme lesson — Boeing 787 and Airbus A350/A380: certified gust/load‑alleviation functions use spoilers/ailerons in cruise; certification required demonstrating margins for the full range of automatically allowed surface deflections and speeds, exactly the CS 25.373 concept.

summary: The logic is simple: size every control surface and its supports for the highest credible loads from manoeuvres, gust/turbulence, roll and yaw, including hinge-line forces, pilot input, tab effects, asymmetry and auxiliary surfaces, so nothing breaks or deforms in real operations.
intent: Ensure every control surface (ailerons, elevators, rudder, flaps, spoilers and tabs) and its attachments are sized for the worst loads they can realistically see in service. CS (Certification Specification) 25.391 directs designers to combine the defined manoeuvre loads (CS 25.331), gust and continuous turbulence loads (CS 25.341), rolling (CS 25.349) and yaw manoeuvre loads (CS 25.351) with specific contributors: forces parallel to the hinge line, pilot-applied effort, trim/tab effects, unsymmetrical surface deflections, and auxiliary surfaces. In plain terms, it is a cross‑reference “gateway” that says: don’t miss any load path or condition that can peak the loads on the surface, its hinge, actuators and supporting structure. “Limit load” means the maximum expected in service; structure must carry at least this without permanent deformation (with separate factors to ultimate strength elsewhere in CS‑25).
events: American Airlines Flight 587 (A300-600, 12 Nov 2001): rapid alternating rudder pedal inputs after wake turbulence generated high yaw loads, leading to vertical stabilizer separation. It shows why control surfaces/tail must be designed and limited for pilot-effort and yaw manoeuvre loads referenced by CS 25.391.

American Eagle Flight 4184 (ATR 72, 31 Oct 1994): wing icing altered aileron hinge moments, causing uncommanded aileron deflection and a roll upset. It demonstrates the need to account for hinge-line loads, tab/servo-tab effects, and unsymmetrical control surface loads in the design envelope.

China Airlines Flight 006 (Boeing 747SP, 19 Feb 1985): a spiral dive and recovery produced large control inputs and overspeed, causing significant airframe/control surface damage but the airplane held together. It underscores designing control surfaces and attachments for combined manoeuvre/gust/roll/yaw limit loads so structure survives extreme but credible conditions.

summary: The logic is simple: even without precise data, size every control surface hinge and bracket to carry a conservative inertia load along the hinge line (K×W), because turbulence, buffet, and rapid inputs drive in-plane forces that can otherwise crack or fail these supports.
intent: This rule makes sure control surfaces (like ailerons, elevators, and rudders) and the brackets that hold their hinges can withstand the surface’s own mass (inertia) loads acting along the hinge line during maneuvers, turbulence, buffet, or rapid control movements. In addition to aerodynamic forces that try to twist the surface about the hinge, the surface’s weight resists aircraft accelerations and creates forces parallel to the hinge axis that can crack or shear hinge fittings. When no detailed “rational” test/analysis data are available, CS 25.393 provides conservative minimum in-plane inertia loads by multiplying the surface weight (W) by a factor K: K = 24 for vertical surfaces (rudders) and K = 12 for horizontal surfaces (ailerons/elevators). This ensures hinge brackets, pins, and local structure are robust against dynamic, vibration, and buffet-driven in-plane loads that historically have caused service cracking and, in rare cases, structural failures.
events: Air Transat Flight 961 (Airbus A310-308, 6 Mar 2005) lost its entire rudder in cruise due to composite delamination; regulators issued emergency ADs mandating rudder inspections on A300/A310 fleets. The event showed how sudden dynamic loads are transmitted through rudder hinges/brackets, reinforcing the need to design for surface inertia loads along the hinge line.

American Airlines Flight 587 (A300-605R, 12 Nov 2001) suffered vertical tail separation after rapid full-rudder reversals at high speed. The investigation highlighted extreme, rapidly reversing loads passing through the rudder system and hinge axis during yaw accelerations, demonstrating why hinge-line-parallel inertial loads must be explicitly considered.

summary: The logic is simple: size every control system and its attachments for 125% of the worst hinge-moment loads in CS 25.391, but no higher than what pilots or powered devices can actually impose, and never lower than the minimum pilot force values in CS 25.397(c).
intent: Ensure the flight control system (columns, pedals, cables/rods, actuators, bellcranks, mounts, and the structures that support them and the hinged surfaces) is strong enough for the worst aerodynamic torque on each surface (hinge moment) in the CS 25.391 loading conditions, with a 25% margin for uncertainty and transients. “Hinge moment” is the aerodynamic twisting force trying to rotate a control surface about its hinge line. Designers may cap the sizing at the maximum loads that people (the pilots) or machines (autopilots, hydraulic/electric actuators) can actually impose, so they don’t over‑design for impossible forces—but they must never go below the minimum cockpit control forces defined in CS 25.397(c). In short, size the control system for real, worst‑case aerodynamic and actuation loads, with margin, bounded by human and actuator capability, and not less than specified minimum pilot forces.
events: American Airlines Flight 587 (A300-600, 2001): Rapid, large rudder reversals at high speed generated extreme hinge moments and tail loads, culminating in vertical stabilizer separation (NTSB AAR-04/04). This shows why control systems and their supporting structures must tolerate worst-case pilot‑commanded hinge moments and why assumptions about pilot force/authority are critical.

USAir Flight 427 (Boeing 737-300, 1994): A jammed rudder PCU servo valve caused an uncommanded full rudder deflection, producing large control-surface loads (NTSB AAR-99/01). It illustrates that powered devices can drive control surfaces to high loads, so designs must consider the maximum loads those devices can produce.

Alaska Airlines Flight 261 (MD-83, 2000): Wear and failure of the horizontal stabilizer jackscrew assembly led to loss of pitch control and structural overload of the stabilizer system (NTSB AAR-02/01). This underscores that the control system’s load path and supporting structure must be robust against the highest credible loads or their loss can be catastrophic.

summary: The logic is simple: size every control-system part to withstand the highest credible pilot inputs (and the effects of servos/autopilots) without damage, using defined force limits and application points, with special provisions for aileron wheels and side-sticks.
intent: This rule sets the standardized pilot force and torque assumptions engineers must use to size flight control systems and their attachments so they won’t deform or fail when a pilot pushes, pulls, or turns the controls in the most demanding, but realistic, situations. It says to apply those forces at the cockpit grips and react them at the control-surface horn, and to cap the air loads/deflections by what any pilot within these force ranges could produce (accounting for servo tabs, feel systems, and autopilots). Where hinge-moment data are solid, lower (two‑thirds) forces may be used for aileron/elevator sizing. It also addresses design subtleties: a single tangential load on aileron wheels (1.25× the couple) and specific limits for side-sticks, including separate, lower jam‑tolerance loads so the mechanism won’t be damaged if something jams. Overall, it harmonizes human capability with structural design limits to ensure safe, predictable control-system strength.
events: American Airlines 587 (A300-600, 2001): Rapid alternating rudder pedal inputs within the certified pedal-force envelope led to vertical tail failure from high aerodynamic loads, underscoring why regulations must bound assumed pilot forces and ensure control systems/structures are sized for extreme but plausible pilot inputs.

Airbus A320 fly-by-wire side-stick certification (late 1980s–1990s): JAA/FAA adopted explicit wrist-operated side-stick force criteria and jam-tolerance provisions (codified as JAR/CS-25 amendments, now CS 25.397(d)), demonstrating the need to define realistic side-stick loads and protect sensors/mechanisms from damage during jams.

Boeing 737 MAX accidents (JT610 in 2018; ET302 in 2019): Automatic trim commands drove large column forces and surface deflections, highlighting the requirement in CS 25.397(b) to consider the effects of automatic systems when relating pilot force to control-surface loads in the design of control load paths.

summary: The logic is simple: size and prove the dual control system to withstand two pilots pushing together or against each other, counting each pilot as 0.75 of the single‑pilot design force (or at least the CS 25.397(c) minima for opposing inputs), so the hardware won’t deform, bind, or fail under real dual‑input situations.
intent: CS 25.399 makes sure an aeroplane with dual controls (both pilots have their own yoke/column/wheel/pedals) is strong enough to cope when two people act on the controls at the same time. It covers two realistic cases: the pilots push in opposite directions (e.g., one pulls while the other pushes) and the pilots push the same way (both pull or both press a pedal). The required design forces come from CS 25.395 (control-system load cases based on pilot forces) and the minimum pilot forces in CS 25.397(c). Each pilot is assumed to apply 75% of the single‑pilot design force, which reflects that two people rarely reach absolute maximums simultaneously. The aim is to prevent structural damage, deformation, or jamming of columns, torque tubes, mixers, quadrants, cables, feel units, and stops during dual, possibly conflicting, inputs—including startle, training, or jam‑overpower scenarios.
events: Air France 447 (A330, 2009; BEA Final Report, 2012) recorded repeated “DUAL INPUT” warnings as both pilots made simultaneous, sometimes opposing, sidestick commands during the stall. This demonstrates that concurrent and conflicting pilot inputs occur in real operations, which CS 25.399 requires the control system to tolerate structurally.

Emirates Flight 407 (A340-500, Melbourne 2009; ATSB AO-2009-012) noted both pilots applied aft sidestick simultaneously during the late rotation, triggering “DUAL INPUT” alerts. It shows additive pilot inputs under stress are realistic, validating the need to size control systems for same-direction dual forces under CS 25.399(b).

Airbus A320-family programme practice: the FCOM/FCTM describe a “DUAL INPUT” aural alert and sidestick priority takeover to prevent simultaneous commands (documented in Airbus flight crew manuals). This programme design lesson acknowledges the inevitability of dual inputs and reinforces why certification demands the underlying control system be robust to two-pilot loads.

summary: The logic is simple: size every secondary control and its linkage to survive worst-case human muscle input (per the specified force/torque limits) without damage or loss of function.
intent: This rule ensures that secondary controls (non-primary flight controls) like wheel brakes, spoilers/speedbrakes, trim/tabs, flaps, stabilizer trim wheels, and landing gear controls are structurally sized for the maximum forces a pilot could realistically apply in urgent or abnormal situations. It standardizes the pilot input loads to be used for compliance: for cranks/wheels/levers a force derived from handle radius with lower/upper bounds, a fixed torque for twist controls, and applicant-justified values for push–pull controls, applicable even when the pilot’s force is slightly off-axis (within 20 degrees). The goal is to prevent control handles, linkages, cables, and stops from failing or deforming when a pilot instinctively yanks, twists, or stamps on them, while avoiding unrealistic over-design by bounding the assumed human inputs.
events: Southwest Airlines Flight 1248 (2005, B737-700, Chicago Midway): NTSB reported the crew applied maximum manual braking during a contaminated-runway overrun; pedals and linkages must tolerate full-stomp loads without structural failure, exactly the case CS 25.405 addresses.

American Airlines Flight 1420 (1999, MD-82, Little Rock): In the thunderstorm landing and runway overrun, investigators documented aggressive manual braking and speedbrake commands, illustrating the need for secondary controls to withstand emergency-force inputs without breaking or binding.

Boeing 737 MAX manual trim wheel forces (2018–2019; JATR/FAA reviews): Investigations highlighted very high pilot effort needed to move the stabilizer by trim wheel at speed, underscoring why rules bound expected pilot forces and require the trim mechanism to endure those loads safely.

summary: The logic is simple: when pilot force is the limiting factor, assume the trim tab is helping and size the control surface and hinges for the loads that result from that assisting tab deflection in the relevant worst‑case trimmed conditions.
intent: Ensure structural design of control surfaces realistically accounts for the helper effect of trim tabs when pilot strength, not hydraulics, limits the loads. In conditions where a human’s maximum stick/rudder force governs the attainable control deflection (e.g., manual or degraded modes), the tab will be set to assist the pilot and can materially increase hinge moments and surface loads. Therefore, designers must include the worst‑case assisting tab deflections: for the elevator, those needed to trim anywhere in the positive flight envelope (i.e., normal operating speed/altitude range per CS 25.333(b)); for aileron and rudder, those needed to trim critical asymmetric power/loading (e.g., engine‑out), with allowance for rigging tolerances. This avoids under‑ or over‑estimating loads, leading to correct sizing of hinges, skins, and attachments, and prevents flutter or overstress driven by tab effects.
events: 2011 Reno Air Races – North American P‑51D “The Galloping Ghost” (NTSB AAR‑12/01): failure of the left elevator trim tab led to a sudden pitch‑up and very high g, showing that trim tabs can dominate elevator hinge moments and surface loads; design and analysis must capture tab‑assisted load cases.

FAA AD 2001‑08‑14 (de Havilland DHC‑8 Series 100/200/300): mandated replacement/inspection of elevator servo‑tab control rods to prevent freeplay‑induced flutter and structural failure, evidencing how tab condition/deflection governs control‑surface loads that must be considered in design and maintenance.

Air Midwest Flight 5481 (Beech 1900D), Charlotte, 2003 (NTSB AAR‑04/01): elevator mis‑rigging and out‑of‑tolerance settings increased trim/pilot force demands and altered achievable control, underscoring why regulations require allowances for rigging tolerances when determining tab‑assisted design loads.

summary: The logic is simple: make the tabs and their linkages strong and stable enough to handle the worst credible deflection and speed combinations—especially when a pilot fights a mis-set or opposing tab—so they don’t fail, jam, or flutter and compromise control.
intent: This rule ensures that all types of control-surface tabs—trim tabs (used to relieve pilot control force), balance tabs (used to reduce hinge moments), and servo tabs (small tabs that move to drive a larger surface)—are structurally strong and stable under the worst combinations of use they can realistically see in flight. Tabs must tolerate the full range of tab settings, primary control positions, and speeds achievable without exceeding the airplane’s overall flight load limits, including when a pilot is actively opposing a mis-set or runaway tab up to the maximum allowable pilot forces defined in CS 25.397(b). It also requires that balance and servo tabs be sized for deflections consistent with the loads on the primary surface, and that servo tabs account for possible opposition from trim tabs. The objective is to prevent structural failure, jamming, or flutter of the tab or its linkages that could lead to loss of control.
events: 2011 Reno Air Races, P‑51D “Galloping Ghost” (NTSB AAR‑12/01): the left elevator trim tab failed at high speed, causing a sudden pitch‑up, extreme g loads, and loss of control. It shows how a trim tab can see very high aerodynamic and pilot‑opposed loads, and why tabs must be designed for worst‑case combinations of speed, deflection, and opposition.

FAA Airworthiness Directives on Boeing 737 elevator tabs (2000s): multiple ADs required inspections and tight free‑play limits on elevator tabs to prevent flutter and potential loss of control. These actions demonstrate that tabs must have sufficient stiffness/strength and controlled free‑play to withstand high‑speed loads without aeroelastic instability.

FAA ADs on DC‑9/MD‑80/MD‑90 elevator/servo-tab systems: repetitive inspections and component replacements were mandated to address hinge/rod‑end wear and free‑play that could lead to flutter. This program history underscores the requirement that balance/servo tabs be designed for deflections and loads consistent with the primary surface, including interactions with trim tabs.
