summary: The logic is simple: make sure control surfaces and all connecting parts (locks, stops, linkages) can survive worst‑case 65‑knot ground winds during taxi or parking—locked or unlocked—using conservative load factors and sensible pilot‑force limits for upstream components.
intent: EASA CS-25.415 ensures that flight control surfaces and their linkages can safely withstand strong winds while the aircraft is on the ground. Designers must size the surfaces, hinges, stops, locks, and intervening control system parts for a 65‑knot (33.44 m/s) gust from any direction during taxi or parking, with controls either locked or unlocked. Loads may be treated as static using a defined hinge‑moment equation with prescribed K-factors, then increased with safety factors to account for system dynamics (transient spikes) unless a justified analysis shows lower transients. When controls are locked, the surfaces, locks, and the parts between them must carry the resultant loads; if no locks, the surfaces and nearest stops must do so, including any impact loads. For taxi with locks off, downstream components to the surface must meet gust loads, while upstream components toward the cockpit are not required to exceed specified pilot force limits per CS 25.397(c). AMC means Acceptable Means of Compliance; CS means Certification Specification.
events: Gulfstream G‑IV N121JM, Bedford, MA (May 31, 2014; NTSB AAR‑15/03): the aircraft attempted takeoff with the gust lock engaged and crashed, underscoring the critical role of gust‑lock systems and, in CS 25.415(f)–(g), the need to design locks, stops, and intervening linkages to robustly react control loads when engaged on the ground and to make their function unambiguous.

summary: The logic is simple: because real airflow often hits the tail unevenly, design the empennage and its supports to withstand worst‑case asymmetric manoeuvre, gust, and buffet loads so strength and controllability are preserved.
intent: CS 25.427 makes sure the empennage (the tail surfaces—horizontal tailplane and vertical fin) is strong enough when the airflow and loads are not symmetric from left to right. In real flight, lateral gusts, yawing/rolling manoeuvres, propeller slipstream, and aerodynamic interference from the wing and fin can load one side of the horizontal tail more than the other, or hit a T‑tail from the side. The rule sets a clear asymmetric load split for the horizontal tail (100% on one side, 80% on the other) based on existing manoeuvre and gust cases (CS 25.331 and CS 25.341(a)), and requires accounting for buffet (unsteady, turbulent airflow per CS 25.305(e)). For configurations with significant dihedral or a tailplane mounted on the fin, it also requires considering gusts from any lateral direction at right angles to the flight path. The objective is to prevent structural failure or deformation that could impair controllability under realistic, skewed airflow conditions.
events: American Airlines Flight 587 (Airbus A300-600, 2001): aggressive alternating rudder inputs in wake turbulence produced extreme lateral/yaw loads that tore off the vertical fin; it underscores the need to size empennage for unsymmetrical loads from yaw manoeuvres and lateral gust/wake effects.

Air Transat Flight 961 (Airbus A310-300, 2005): the composite rudder separated in flight due to structural degradation, revealing the fin–rudder system’s exposure to complex, dynamic and potentially asymmetric empennage loads; this illustrates why design and evaluation must include unsymmetrical and buffet conditions.

Boeing/Airbus post-AA587 programme actions: full-scale vertical tail static tests and revised guidance on lateral/directional manoeuvre loads (e.g., FAA/industry updates following the NTSB AA587 investigation) validated margins and analysis methods; this programme experience shows the necessity of explicitly accounting for asymmetric empennage load cases in certification.

summary: The logic is simple: if you add tip fins or winglets, you must include their aerodynamic interaction and worst-case asymmetric gust/manoeuvre loads in the supporting structure’s design so nothing is under-strength.
intent: Ensure that any add-on vertical surfaces at the tips of wings or tailplanes (for example, winglets or end-plate fins) are fully accounted for in structural load calculations. These auxiliary surfaces change airflow and load paths on the main supporting surface (the wing or horizontal tail), especially during pitch, roll, and yaw manoeuvres and when encountering gusts from any direction perpendicular to the flight path. The rule also forces designers to consider realistic unsymmetrical side loads when there are vertical surfaces both above and below a horizontal surface (e.g., split winglets or tailplane end-plates) by applying a conservative 100% load to one side and 80% to the other. In short, it prevents underestimating loads caused by aerodynamic interference and asymmetric gusts so structure and attachments are strong enough.
events: Aviation Partners Boeing 737 Blended Winglets STC ST01219SE required extensive wing structural reinforcements and new gust/manoeuvre load substantiation because the winglet changed wing aeroelastic and side-load behavior; this shows why the rule demands including winglet–wing aerodynamic influence in all load cases.

737NG Split Scimitar Winglet certification (ST01716SE) added a lower ventral strake below the wing tip, creating vertical surfaces above and below the wing and driving asymmetric tip loads and structural changes; this directly reflects CS 25.445(b)’s 100%/80% unsymmetrical loading requirement.

Airbus A320 Sharklet retrofit (EASA-approved circa 2012) required a strengthened “Sharklet wing” and full revalidation of gust/roll/yaw loads due to winglet–wing interaction; this program lesson proves auxiliary surfaces can materially increase loads on supporting structures and must be included in design.

summary: The logic is simple: size the flaps, their drives, and supports for the worst loads they can see in service, especially the short, high loads that occur while changing flap settings and speeds, so nothing breaks or jams when you need them most.
intent: Ensure the wing flaps, their drive mechanisms, and the structures that carry them are strong enough for the worst aerodynamic and inertial loads they will ever see, including while moving between positions. CS 25.345 defines the critical high-lift device load conditions (e.g., gusts, maneuvers, asymmetric lift, and speeds with flaps extended). This rule adds that transient loads during flap motion (deploying or retracting at or near limiting speeds) must be captured, because those brief transitions can be the most severe. The aim is to prevent structural failure, deformation, or jamming of flaps that could jeopardize control, performance, or safe landing/takeoff.
events: TWA Flight 841 (Boeing 727, 1979): An outboard leading-edge slat extended at high speed and subsequently failed during attempted retraction, causing a severe upset. Although involving slats, it illustrates how high-lift device transitions can generate extreme transient loads that can tear structures apart if beyond design/operational limits—underscoring why flap systems too must be designed for critical transition loads (per CS 25.345 and CS 25.457).

summary: The logic is simple: because slats/slots/spoilers create complex, hard‑to‑predict loads, you must measure those loads in tests and use that data to size structures and actuators safely.
intent: Ensure structural and system loads for “special devices” that alter airflow—like slots, slats, and spoilers—are based on measured test data, not only analysis. These high‑lift and lift‑dump devices create complex, highly unsteady flows, transients (during deploy/retract), and aeroelastic effects that are hard to predict accurately. Using empirical data (from flight tests, wind‑tunnel, or calibrated component tests) allows correct sizing of structures, hinges, actuators, and supports validation of worst cases (gusts, buffet, asymmetric or off‑schedule operation). The aim is to prevent structural failures, loss of control, or unexpected fatigue driven by real aerodynamic loads.
events: TWA Flight 841 (Boeing 727-31, 23 Apr 1979): An inadvertent leading-edge slat extension at high speed caused a violent upset and severe damage to the slat/wing before recovery. The event showed that off‑nominal slat loads and transients can be extreme and must be characterized with test data to ensure adequate structural and actuator margins.

China Eastern Airlines Flight 583 (McDonnell Douglas MD‑11, 6 Apr 1993): Accidental movement of the slat/flap handle led to slat deployment in cruise, triggering severe oscillations, injuries, and structural damage. The incident highlighted complex dynamic and aeroelastic loads from leading‑edge devices that exceed simple predictions, underscoring the need for test‑derived load data.

summary: The logic is simple: model ground forces and aircraft inertia in equilibrium and pick the worst credible CG positions so the landing gear and structure are proven strong enough, while allowing minor lateral imbalance to be managed by loading instructions.
intent: Ensure the aircraft’s structure and landing gear are designed and analyzed for realistic ground contact scenarios by treating ground contact forces as external loads and balancing them with the aircraft’s linear and rotational (angular) inertia. Engineers must pick the most critical centers of gravity (CG: the point where the aircraft’s mass is balanced) across forward, aft, vertical, and lateral positions within the certified range to find the worst loads in each gear element. Small lateral CG shifts from random passenger/cargo or fuel imbalance can be ignored if they raise main gear loads by no more than 3% and the flight/weight-and-balance instructions keep loading within those limits. This sets the foundation for all subsequent detailed ground load cases and gear geometry use.
events: FedEx 80 (MD‑11F), Narita 2009: A hard, bounced landing induced high vertical and roll/angular inertia loads, leading to gear and structural collapse; it illustrates why limit ground loads must be balanced with inertia realistically to capture worst touchdown conditions.

Southwest 345 (B737‑700), LaGuardia 2013: A nose‑first touchdown overloaded the nose gear, which collapsed rearward; it shows how CG position and pitch inertia can shift loads between gear elements and why worst‑case CGs must be selected in ground load analysis.

Airbus A380 landing gear drop test program (mid‑2000s certification): Full‑scale drop tests and analytical substantiation used maximum weights and critical CG‑derived conditions per CS‑25 Subpart C to validate gear energy absorption and load paths, exemplifying the CS 25.471 equilibrium and critical‑CG approach.

summary: The logic is simple: assume credible worst‑case touchdown rates and attitudes, include realistic lift, dynamics, and tyre–runway friction, and prove the gear/airframe can take those loads with validated tests.
intent: Set realistic, conservative assumptions for the worst credible landing so the structure and landing gear are proven safe. It defines touchdown attitudes, maximum sink (descent) rates at both design landing weight and at the higher takeoff weight, limits how much lift you may credit at touchdown, and requires that dynamic effects (tyre spin‑up, gear spring‑back, whole‑aircraft motion, and any significant structural vibration) are included in the loads analysis. It also requires validating landing‑gear dynamics by drop tests and caps the tyre–runway friction used in analyses so designers don’t assume unrealistically high grip. In short, it standardizes the landing cases and analysis methods so all large airplanes meet the same, evidence‑based landing load capability.
events: FedEx Flight 80 (MD‑11F), Narita 2009: a hard, bounced landing led to catastrophic structural failure; investigators highlighted the aircraft’s dynamic bounce and pitch response, illustrating why landing‑load rules must capture rigid‑body dynamics, spin‑up, and spring‑back effects.

Southwest Airlines Flight 345 (B737‑700), LaGuardia 2013: a nose‑first touchdown overloaded the nose gear beyond design and it collapsed, underscoring why the rules define landing attitudes, descent‑rate limits, and require validated dynamic gear behaviour for credible cases.

Boeing 777 certification program (early 1990s): full‑scale main‑gear drop tests at prescribed sink rates were publicly documented and used to correlate analysis models, demonstrating the requirement in CS 25.473/25.723 to validate landing‑gear dynamic characteristics by test.

summary: The logic is simple: if your aeroplane has standard tricycle or tailwheel gear and is landed using normal technique, use CS 25.479–25.485; otherwise, derive suitable loads by specific analysis or test.
intent: This clause sets the scope of the standard ground‑load rules in CS‑25 (Certification Specifications for Large Aeroplanes, by EASA – the European Union Aviation Safety Agency). It tells designers and regulators that the detailed landing and ground‑handling load cases in CS 25.479 to 25.485 are only intended for aeroplanes with conventional landing gear layouts (either tricycle: main gear plus a nosewheel; or taildragger: main gear plus a tailwheel) and when crews use normal landing techniques (main wheels touch first, appropriate flare, standard crosswind method). If an aeroplane has an unusual gear configuration or is intended to be operated differently, the applicant must use other rational analyses or tests to establish the correct loads.
events: Southwest Airlines Flight 345 (Boeing 737‑700), New York–LaGuardia, 2013: a nose‑first touchdown collapsed the nose gear, illustrating that CS‑25 landing load cases assume main‑gear‑first, normal technique and that abnormal technique can exceed those assumptions.

Lufthansa A320 D‑AIPW, Hamburg, 2008 crosswind incident: a pronounced one‑wheel touchdown and wingtip scrape risk highlighted why CS 25.483 (one‑wheel landing) and CS 25.485 (side‑load) conditions exist for conventional tricycle gear.

FedEx Flight 80 (MD‑11F), Narita, 2009: a hard, bounced landing in gusty crosswinds led to gear/structural failure and rollover, underscoring that when sink rates and attitudes depart from normal technique, loads can exceed the standard CS‑25 ground‑load envelope.

summary: The logic is simple: define conservative touchdown speeds, attitudes, and combined vertical/drag/side-load cases so the landing gear and nearby structure can safely absorb realistic level-landing loads, including crosswind drift and near-simultaneous nose/main contact.
intent: CS 25.479 defines the touchdown load cases the landing gear and its supporting structure must safely withstand in a level landing. It sets realistic but conservative forward-speed conditions around stall speed (VS0) in true airspeed (TAS), including hot-day/high-altitude effects and, if approved, higher speeds from tailwind landings. It requires assessing the two key attitudes for nose-wheel aeroplanes (main wheels first with the nose just clear, and near-simultaneous main/nose contact) and the level attitude for tail-wheel types. Beyond vertical loads, it mandates combined drag (longitudinal) and side loads to cover braking/rolling friction and lateral drift in crosswinds, with specified minimum load combinations and assumed shock absorber/tyre deflections, acting at the wheel axle. The objective is to ensure the gear and attachments are robust against the most likely touchdown load combinations seen in normal operations, including drift, crosswind, and small tailwind effects, without structural failure.
events: Southwest Airlines Flight 345 (B737-700), New York–LaGuardia, 22 July 2013: a nose-first touchdown led to nose gear collapse (NTSB AAR-15/01), illustrating why certification evaluates high nose-gear loads when near-simultaneous main/nose contact can occur.

FedEx Flight 80 (MD‑11), Tokyo–Narita, 23 March 2009: a hard, bounced landing in gusty crosswinds led to roll-over and gear failure (JTSB final report), demonstrating the need to size for combined vertical and lateral drift loads at touchdown.

JetBlue Flight 292 (A320), Los Angeles, 21 September 2005: the nose wheels were locked 90° to track; after main-gear touchdown the nose gear sustained large drag/side loads without collapsing (NTSB incident report), showing the importance of combined vertical-plus-drag design in level-landing conditions.

summary: The logic is simple: size the landing gear and nearby structure for a near‑stall, nose‑up touchdown where the main wheels first take both vertical impact and runway drag, at attitudes limited by stall or ground clearance.
intent: Ensure the landing gear, its attachments, and supporting structure can withstand a touchdown made in a nose‑up (tail‑down) attitude near stall speed. The rule defines the forward speed to use (the true airspeed at VS0 in standard and hot‑day/altitude conditions) and how to set the airplane’s attitude: for nose‑wheel types, use the stalling angle or the maximum pitch that still keeps all parts except the main wheels clear of the ground; for tail‑wheel types, assume a three‑point contact with a conservative tail‑wheel load direction. Vertical and longitudinal (drag) ground reactions are applied at the main wheel axle centerline, consistent with the general landing conditions in CS 25.473. The objective is to capture the worst realistic combination of vertical impact and runway drag loads in a tail‑down touchdown so the gear and structure do not fail or cause hazardous energy paths.
events: Asiana Airlines Flight 214 (Boeing 777-200ER), San Francisco, 6 July 2013: arriving low and slow in a tail‑low attitude, the airplane struck the seawall and the main gear separated under extreme combined vertical and longitudinal loads; this illustrates why certification must substantiate tail‑down touchdown loads near VS0 with realistic drag at the axle.

FedEx Flight 80 (McDonnell Douglas MD‑11F), Narita, 23 March 2009: a high‑sink, nose‑high landing and bounce produced severe ground reactions leading to main gear collapse and breakup; it highlights the need to size the main gear and attachments for peak vertical and drag loads in tail‑down landings.

Boeing 787 landing gear drop‑test program (public Boeing/FAA materials, circa 2009–2011): drop‑tests provided data for vertical energy absorption and spin‑up/drag characteristics at the axle line, underpinning compliance analyses of tail‑down landing cases per CS 25.481 at near‑VS0 forward speeds.

summary: The logic is simple: assume a level touchdown on one main gear, apply the same ground reactions as the standard level-landing case on that side, and show that airplane inertia rationally or conservatively balances the unbalanced loads without overstressing the structure.
intent: Ensure the airframe and landing gear are strong enough when only one main landing gear leg touches down first. In this “one-gear” case, the airplane is assumed level, contacting the runway on a single main gear, and the ground reaction on that side must be the same as in the standard level-landing case (CS 25.479(d)(1)). All resulting unbalanced forces and moments (roll, yaw, torsion) must be carried by the airplane’s mass and structure using a realistic (rational) or deliberately conservative analysis. This addresses real operations like crosswind landings, uneven runways, bounce/skip touchdowns, or partial gear malfunctions, ensuring the wing, fuselage, gear attachments, and keel/beams can tolerate the asymmetric loads without failure.
events: Lufthansa A320 wing strike at Hamburg (1 Mar 2008, D-AIQP): during a strong crosswind approach, initial contact occurred on one main gear and a gust-induced roll led to a left wingtip strike and go-around. The event shows how one-gear touchdowns create large asymmetric loads that the structure must safely absorb, validating the need for this design case.

SAS Dash 8 Q400 landing gear collapses (e.g., Flight 1209, Aalborg, 9 Sep 2007): a main gear failed and collapsed on landing, producing immediate asymmetric ground contact, veer, and wing contact. This illustrates the high unbalanced loads from one-side support and the necessity to size structure and attachments for such conditions.

FedEx Express Flight 80 MD-11 crash at Narita (23 Mar 2009): a hard landing and bounce led to asymmetric subsequent touchdowns, rapid roll, and wing strike. The dynamics demonstrate how one-gear contact and inertia coupling can generate severe unbalanced loads, underscoring the requirement to analyze and withstand this case.

summary: The logic is simple: size the main gear and its attachments to survive a pure, asymmetric side-load combined with half the vertical landing load, representing realistic crosswind/drift touchdown forces without longitudinal drag.
intent: Ensure the main landing gear, its attachments, and supporting structure can safely withstand the sideways (lateral) forces that occur during ground contact, especially in crosswind or drift-on touchdowns. The rule defines a conservative, asymmetric side-load case on the two main gears, combined with a portion of the vertical landing load, to reflect real touch-down physics (tire cornering forces, weathervaning, and asymmetric wheel loading). By assuming no drag (longitudinal) load in this case and applying the load at the tire–runway contact point, the regulation isolates and sizes the structure for worst credible lateral loads so the gear does not collapse or tear the airframe during crosswind landings, veers, or runway excursions.
events: Lufthansa A320 D-AIQP Hamburg crosswind incident (1 Mar 2008): a strong gust during touchdown caused significant lateral loading and a wingtip strike; the event illustrates the large side forces that can occur at the main gear in crosswind landings, which this rule requires structures to tolerate.

American Airlines Flight 1420, MD-82, Little Rock (1 Jun 1999): after landing in a severe thunderstorm with strong crosswinds, the aircraft overran and the left main gear collapsed; the side loads during the excursion underscore why main gear and attachments must be designed for substantial lateral reactions.

Boeing 777 certification practice (1990s): the 777’s main gear allows crabbed landings via truck yaw to reduce tire side forces and structural side loads, and high crosswind demonstrations were conducted; this design and testing approach exemplifies compliance with the CS-25.485 side-load case.

summary: The logic is simple: if a landing bounces and the gear shoots to full extension, design the wheels, linkages, and attachments—and the supporting structure—to survive a 20 g top‑out hit in the direction they move.
intent: This rule makes sure the landing gear and the structure that holds it can withstand the rebound phase of a landing, when the airplane briefly leaves the runway and the gear rapidly re-extends. “Unsprung weights” are the parts not cushioned by the shock absorber (wheels, axles, brakes, torque links, etc.); “sprung parts” are the shock strut and airframe isolated by the oleo. During a bounce the unsprung mass can “top out” (hit the end of travel), producing a sharp, high-rate load as parts strike stops or snubbers. CS-25 (EASA Certification Specifications for Large Aeroplanes) requires designers to analyze that case using a conservative 20 g (20 times gravity) load on the unsprung mass, applied in the actual direction those parts are moving at top-out. The goal is to prevent failures of torque links, top-out stops, retraction actuators, and attachments that could lead to gear collapse, loss of directional control, brake line ruptures, or unsafe go-arounds.
events: FedEx Flight 80 (MD‑11, Narita, 23 Mar 2009): The aircraft bounced on landing, recontacted with high vertical acceleration, and overturned; the JTSB found excessive sink rate and pitch inputs led to severe compression–rebound cycles of the landing gear. This shows why gear and attachments must tolerate violent rebound/extension loads, not just compression at touchdown.

China Airlines Flight 642 (MD‑11, Hong Kong, 22 Aug 1999): In strong crosswinds the aircraft bounced, rolled, and crashed; the Hong Kong CAD report details extreme landing loads during the bounce sequence. The event illustrates how rebound can drive damaging top‑out loads through torque links and stops, validating the need for explicit rebound design cases.

Boeing Flight Crew Training Manual – Bounced Landing Recovery (all models): Boeing instructs crews to execute a go‑around after a bounce to avoid structural damage and loss of control from subsequent rebound impacts. This operational guidance reflects the significant rebound/top‑out loads on landing gear that CS 25.487 requires designers to withstand.

summary: The logic is simple: check all defined ground-handling load cases at the maximum ramp weight with full weight on the gear (no wing lift) and with shocks/tyres at static setup so the structure is robust for towing, taxiing, turning, braking, and jacking.
intent: Ensure the landing gear and airframe can safely withstand all non-landing ground operations (taxi, towing/pushback, turning/pivoting, braking, jacking/support) at the heaviest condition used on the ramp. Engineers must analyze the specified CS 25.491–25.509 ground handling load cases with zero aerodynamic lift (i.e., the full aircraft weight is on the wheels) and with shock struts and tyres at their static (non-stroking) positions. This codifies a conservative, standardized basis so the structure is not under-designed by assuming any lift relief or dynamic strut travel during routine ground handling.
events: Airbus A340‑600 F‑WWCJ ground test accident, Toulouse (9 Nov 2007): during high‑power engine runs on the ground, the aircraft surged forward and struck a wall, collapsing the nose gear; it underscores that ground handling/roll loads at heavy weight with no lift can be severe and must be structurally accounted for.

EASA SIB 2009‑16R1 on towbarless towing vehicles (TLTV): issued after multiple nose landing gear damages across fleets, it highlights high torsional and side loads from towing/pivoting and the need to define and respect structural towing limits established from CS‑25 ground handling load analyses.

summary: The logic is simple: design and prove the aircraft can tolerate the worst reasonably expected runway and taxiway roughness at approved weights and ground speeds so bumps and surface irregularities don’t break the gear or airframe.
intent: Ensure that the airframe and landing gear of a large aeroplane are strong and durable enough to withstand the dynamic loads that occur during taxi, take-off roll, and landing roll when operating on real-world, imperfect pavements. In plain terms, at any approved weight and within normal ground speeds, the aircraft must safely handle bumps, joints, patches, and other roughness that can reasonably be encountered on runways and taxiways, without structural damage or loss of control. This protects against gear over‑stroke, shimmy, vibration, and fatigue spikes caused by surface irregularities. EASA (European Union Aviation Safety Agency) CS-25 (Certification Specifications for Large Aeroplanes) thus requires designing and substantiating loads at least as severe as those produced by the roughest surfaces expected in normal operation.
events: Programme/compliance lesson: Airbus A350 XWB conducted publicized rough‑runway taxi tests over cleated/irregular surfaces (circa 2013, Istres) to measure gear and structural loads for CS‑25 compliance; this demonstrates how manufacturers validate that ground‑roll loads from rough pavement are within design limits.

Industry/regulatory response: FAA AC 150/5380‑9A, 'Guidelines and Procedures for Measuring Airport Pavement Roughness,' was issued to address documented operational roughness that affected aircraft and passenger comfort; it shows that significant roughness is a real, routine exposure the design must be able to withstand.

Accident: Air France Flight 4590 (Concorde) in 2000 suffered a catastrophic take‑off roll event initiated by runway debris and tyre failure; while not a simple 'bump,' it illustrates that ground‑roll surface hazards can drive extreme loads and consequences, underscoring the need to account for severe ground‑roll conditions in design.

summary: The logic is simple: size the gear and structure for the worst realistic combination of vertical load and braking drag (μ = 0.8) plus the transient nose‑down pitch spike from sudden maximum braking, using conservative factors unless better data are substantiated.
intent: Ensure the landing gear and supporting structure can withstand the combined vertical and braking (drag) loads that occur when an aircraft is rolling on the runway and the brakes are applied, including the transient nose‑down pitch that happens when maximum braking is suddenly applied. The rule sets conservative vertical load factors (1.2 at design landing weight, 1.0 at design ramp/takeoff weight) and assumes a dry‑runway tire/runway friction coefficient of 0.8, unless a lower value is proven. For nose‑gear aircraft, it requires analysis of both: all wheels on the ground with no pitch acceleration, and mains only with the pitch moment resisted by angular acceleration. It explicitly adds the dynamic increment in nose‑gear load from sudden braking, using a formula with a default dynamic response factor f = 2.0 (unless a lower, substantiated damping/response is shown), based on the aircraft’s center of gravity (c.g.) geometry and damping. Tail‑wheel aeroplanes are treated similarly for mains. The aim is to prevent gear/structure overload, attachment failure, or fuselage damage during braked roll, rejected takeoff, or landing rollout.
events: Airbus A380 maximum‑energy rejected takeoff test at Istres (2006): public test videos and reports show abrupt max braking causing a strong nose‑down pitch transient and large gear loads, validating CS‑25’s need to combine μ≈0.8 drag with dynamic nose‑gear load increments (f up to 2.0).

Boeing 777 rejected takeoff brake‑energy certification test at Edwards AFB (mid‑1990s): documented certification demonstration shows significant forward pitch and nose‑gear load spikes upon brake slam, illustrating why the rule requires analysis of dynamic pitching loads during braked roll.

JetBlue Flight 292, A320, Los Angeles (2005): with the nose gear rotated 90°, the rollout involved sustained nose‑wheel friction and braking while supporting vertical loads; the intact gear/structure under combined drag and vertical reactions demonstrates the necessity of robust braked‑roll load design.

summary: The logic is simple: assume a steady turn that produces 0.5 g lateral while supporting 1.0 g vertical, and require every wheel and its attachments to carry a side reaction equal to half its vertical load without failure.
intent: CS 25.495 ensures large aeroplanes are structurally able to withstand the sideways (lateral) forces that occur during steady, low-speed ground turns made with nose-wheel steering or by asymmetric engine thrust. For certification, designers must assume a static condition where the aircraft experiences 1.0 g vertically (normal weight) and 0.5 g laterally (side acceleration) at the centre of gravity. Under this assumed turn, each wheel must react sideways with a load equal to half its vertical wheel load. The rule’s objective is to size and substantiate the landing gear, tires, wheels, axles, bogie/truck beams, trunnions, steering mechanisms, and their airframe attachments for predictable taxi/turn side loads so that sharp turns, tight ramp maneuvers, or single‑engine taxi do not lead to tire bursts, gear shimmy-induced damage, structural cracking, or gear collapse.
events: JetBlue 292 (A320, Los Angeles, 2005): The nose gear locked 90° sideways, forcing a landing with extreme tire scrubbing and lateral loads; the gear remained attached, illustrating why certification must cover substantial wheel side reactions on the ground.

EASA AD 2018-0194 (A330/A340 MLG bogie beam cracking): Mandated inspections due to fatigue cracks attributed to in-service ground maneuver loads, showing that repeated taxi/turn side loads drive landing gear structural design and maintenance limits in line with CS 25.495 assumptions.

summary: The logic is simple: design the tailwheel and its attachments to handle a lateral load as big as its vertical static load, applied in both castoring and locked/trailing conditions, so worst-case yawing side loads won’t damage the structure or cause loss of control.
intent: This rule sets the minimum structural loads that a tail-wheel (conventional-gear) transport must withstand when it yaws on the ground. It assumes a worst-case lateral (side) load equal to the static vertical load on the tailwheel and defines where that load is applied depending on the tailwheel configuration: fully castering/swiveling 90° (load through the axle) or locked/steered with a shimmy damper (side load at the tire–ground contact point). The purpose is to ensure the tailwheel fork, spring/strut, attachments, steering/lock mechanisms, shimmy damper, and aft fuselage structure can survive severe crosswind rollouts, incipient ground loops, and shimmy events without failure. In short, it formalizes conservative yawing ground-load cases so that tailwheel transports remain controllable and structurally safe during landing, taxi, and takeoff.
events: TSB Canada investigation (Buffalo Airways DC‑3C C‑GWIR, Yellowknife, Aug 2013) documented a landing runway excursion/ground loop with crosswind and tailwheel control issues, illustrating how large lateral tailwheel loads arise and why structures and locks/dampers must be designed for worst‑case yawing.

AAIB UK report (Douglas C‑47B “Dakota” G‑ANAF, Kemble/Cotswold Airport, 23 May 2011) describes a runway excursion after landing with directional control difficulties, demonstrating the high side loads transmitted through a locked/trailing tailwheel under crosswind and the need for robust load paths.

NTSB reports on DC‑3/C‑47 ground loops (e.g., multiple Alaska cargo operations in the 2000s) repeatedly note unlocked/ineffective tailwheel steering or shimmy leading to loss of directional control, reinforcing the requirement to size for lateral loads equal to vertical and to consider both castering (90°) and trailing positions.

summary: The logic is simple: size the nose gear and forward fuselage to survive the worst real ground scenarios—tight steering plus heavy vertical load and asymmetric braking—using friction-based side/drag limits (0.8) and a 1.33× vertical margin for steering, with loads properly carried through the CG.
intent: Ensure the nose landing gear (NLG), its attach structure, and the forward fuselage are strong enough to withstand realistic yawing and steering loads on the ground. The rule defines conservative side (lateral) and drag load components based on tire–runway friction (up to 0.8 times the vertical load), including the case of braking on only one main gear (asymmetric braking) that generates strong yaw moments. It allocates the resulting forces at the aircraft centre of gravity (CG, the balance point) and allows use of airplane inertia to carry unbalanced yaw if lateral tire force would exceed friction limits. It also requires that, at design ramp weight, the NLG be sized for the combination of full normal steering torque at any steering angle with a vertical reaction 1.33 times the maximum static nose load. Overall, it guards against structural failures during taxi, tight turns, pushback/towing, takeoff/landing roll, and asymmetric braking.
events: JetBlue Flight 292 (A320), LAX, 2005: The nose wheels locked 90° sideways, yet the airplane landed without catastrophic structural failure while the NLG absorbed extreme side loads and steering torque under high vertical load. This demonstrates why CS 25.499 demands the NLG and forward fuselage be sized for full steering-angle side loads combined with significant vertical reaction.

Southwest Airlines Flight 345 (B737-700), LGA, 2013: A nose-first touchdown overloaded the NLG, which collapsed, showing how severe vertical/drag loads can exceed the structure when not within the intended envelope. It underscores the need for robust nose-gear/forward-fuselage load paths for high ground loads from braking/yaw events addressed by CS 25.499.

FAA AD 2006-06-06 (A320-family Brake and Steering Control Unit), with corresponding EASA actions: Mandated modifications after multiple events of uncommanded 90° nose-wheel rotation. This program lesson confirms the rule’s purpose to consider full steering torque at any angle together with high vertical reactions so the gear/attachments sustain resulting yaw loads.

summary: The logic is simple: design the landing gear and its attachments to survive a tight-turn pivot on dry pavement with one side’s brakes locked, because that is the worst realistic side-load case the airplane may see on the ground.
intent: Ensure the landing gear, tires, brakes, and supporting structure can safely withstand the extreme side and torsional loads that occur if the airplane pivots around one main-gear leg with that side’s brakes locked on a high-friction surface. The rule defines a conservative ground case: full airplane weight (limit vertical load factor = 1.0), a high tire–pavement friction coefficient (0.8, approximating dry concrete), and static equilibrium with loads applied at the ground contact points. This forces designers to size gear components, attachments, and brake/tire capability for tight-turn or inadvertent locked-wheel conditions during taxi, pushback, or runway turnarounds, preventing gear damage, tire failures, or structural overload.
events: Airbus A380 Airport Planning Manual cautions against 180-degree turns and any pivot-like maneuver on narrow runways due to extreme tire scrubbing and main-gear side loads, and many airports restrict such turns for the A380. This demonstrates why CS 25.503 compels designers to account for worst-case pivot loads on dry, high-friction pavement.

Boeing Airplane Characteristics for Airport Planning (e.g., 747/777 ACAP) publish minimum turning radii and explicitly warn operators not to use locked-wheel turns or differential braking to pivot because it can overload gear and cause tire failures. These manufacturer limits reflect the high lateral loads embodied in the CS 25.503 pivoting load case.

FAA AC 20-97B (Aircraft Tire Maintenance and Operational Practices) documents in-service tire damage and failures from tight taxi turns and locked-wheel dragging on dry surfaces, advising crews to avoid such practices. This operational lesson underpins certifying gear and structure for the CS 25.503 pivoting side-load case.

summary: The logic is simple: size the landing gear and its attachments to withstand forward-directed brake forces that occur when stopping a backward-rolling airplane, using defined conservative limits and appropriate pitch balance assumptions.
intent: This rule makes sure the landing gear and its attachments are strong enough for the unusual case when braking forces act in the forward direction at the tire–ground contact patch. That happens when an airplane moves backward (e.g., during pushback or a powerback) and the pilot applies the wheel brakes, or in other rare operations that reverse wheel motion. The regulation defines how big those forward horizontal loads must be for design: take the lesser of 55% of the vertical wheel load or 1.2 times the nominal maximum static brake torque, applied at each braked wheel, with the aircraft in its normal three-point ground attitude. For tricycle-gear airplanes, the pitching moment from these forces is balanced by the airplane’s rotational inertia; for tailwheel airplanes, the combined ground reactions must pass through the center of gravity (CG). In plain terms, the gear must not be damaged when brakes are used to stop the aircraft while it’s rolling backward.
events: DC‑9/MD‑80 airline powerback programs (1970s–1990s) were documented by the NTSB/FAA to entail increased risk and maintenance loads, leading many U.S. carriers to ban powerbacks. Powerback requires braking while rolling backward, producing exactly the forward wheel reactions that CS 25.507 compels designers to cover.

Airbus and Boeing pushback procedures (e.g., Airbus FCOM/FCOM‑PRO and Boeing FCTM) explicitly direct crews not to apply brakes during pushback until the tug is stopped and the ground crew calls “set brakes.” This industry practice exists because braking during backward motion can impose large forward longitudinal loads on the main gear, the reversed‑braking case in this rule.

Military transport reverse‑taxi operations (e.g., C‑130) caution against heavy braking while moving backward in flight manuals and ground handling guidance due to high gear loads. These published cautions illustrate the significant forward tire forces and pitching moments that CS 25.507 requires the structure to tolerate.

summary: The logic is simple: size and check the landing gear, tow fittings, and surrounding structure against realistic forward/aft/side towing forces applied at the correct points, with defined magnitudes and reactions, so routine pushback/towing cannot overload or damage the aircraft.
intent: This rule makes sure a large aeroplane’s structure, landing gear, and tow fittings can safely withstand the forces applied during ground towing and pushback. It defines how to size and apply horizontal towing forces at the approved tow points, with a simultaneous 1.0g vertical weight on the wheels, and with tyres and struts at static (non‑shock) positions. It also prescribes realistic directions (forward, aft, and angled, including with steered/swivelled gear) and how these forces are reacted by the aircraft (at wheels and by inertia). The towing force magnitude scales with design ramp weight so the gear, fittings, and surrounding structure are not overstressed. In short, CS-25 (Certification Specification for large aeroplanes) 25.509 ensures towing and pushback do not cause structural failures, steering damage, or loss of control on the ramp. AMC = Acceptable Means of Compliance.
events: EASA Safety Information Bulletins on towbarless towing vehicles warn of multiple in-service occurrences of nose landing gear damage when towing loads/angles exceeded manufacturer limits; these bulletins emphasise respecting OEM tow load/angle limits and directly illustrate why CS 25.509 defines towing load cases and reactions.

Airbus Safety First articles on towbarless towing (summarising several events across A320/A330/A340 fleets) describe NLG structural and steering system damage from excessive side loads and over‑steer during ground moves; Airbus responded by clarifying allowable towing loads and angles, demonstrating the need for defined, conservative design towing loads.

IATA Airport Handling Manual (AHM) 910/913 revisions strengthened requirements for proper towbar shear pin ratings and aircraft-specific TBL approvals after reported towing/pushback damage events; ensuring the tow system fails before aircraft structural limits are exceeded aligns with CS 25.509’s intent to protect gear and tow fittings from overload.

summary: The logic is simple: design the multi-wheel gear and its attachments to withstand uneven wheel sharing—including one or two flat tyres—across landing, taxi, braked roll, and towing on flat or crowned runways, without structural failure or loss of control.
intent: Ensure that landing gear with more than one wheel per unit (including bogies/trucks and tandem struts) and the surrounding structure can safely carry uneven ground loads in real life. Designers must account for differences in tyre diameter (manufacturing, growth, wear), inflation pressure, runway crown (cross‑slope), aircraft attitude, structural deflection, and one or two deflated tyres during landing, taxi, ground handling, and towing. The rule prescribes how to distribute loads to wheels in these cases, including specific reductions for deflated-tyre cases (e.g., 60/50% factors) and requires considering truck see‑saw motion and braked‑roll loads that must not be underestimated on remaining inflated tyres. “Limit load” means the maximum load expected in service; the gear unit’s total load may be computed without shifting its load centroid for these cases. The objective is to prevent gear/attachment failures or unsafe handling when loads are not shared symmetrically.
events: JetBlue Flight 292 (A320), Los Angeles, 21 Sep 2005: the nose gear wheels were locked 90° to the runway, the tyres failed and the rims scrubbed, yet the nose gear and structure sustained extreme asymmetric ground loads, enabling a safe landing. This illustrates why CS 25.511 requires robust design for unsymmetrical wheel loads and deflated-tyre conditions.

British Airways Flight 2276 (B777-200), Las Vegas, 8 Sep 2015: after an uncontained engine failure and rejected takeoff, heavy braking led to multiple tyres deflating via fuse plugs on one main gear truck while the aircraft remained controllable and structurally supported. This demonstrates the need to size braked‑roll/taxi load distributions with deflated tyres as required by CS 25.511(e).

American Airlines Flight 383 (B767-300), Chicago O’Hare, 28 Oct 2016: a high‑energy rejected takeoff after an uncontained engine failure resulted in multiple main‑gear tyre deflations from heat and braking while the aircraft stayed upright for evacuation. The survivability of the gear under asymmetric vertical and drag loads validates the rule’s deflated‑tyre ground load requirements.

summary: The logic is simple: make the designated jacking and tie‑down points strong and well defined so the aircraft won’t fall off jacks or rip out moorings when subjected to realistic vertical and lateral loads during maintenance or high winds.
intent: Ensure an airliner can be safely lifted, supported, and secured on the ground without structural damage or loss of stability. The rule requires defined jacking and tie-down provisions that can carry conservative vertical and sideways forces at the worst combinations of aircraft weight and center of gravity (CG). “Limit load” is the maximum in-service load the structure must withstand without permanent deformation; jacking pads and nearby structure must be stronger still to tolerate localized loads and mishandling. If mooring (tie‑down) points are provided, they and the local structure must resist strong winds from any direction. The maximum allowable load for each jack pad must be clearly specified so maintenance can be done safely.
events: British Airways Boeing 787-8 G‑ZBJB (Heathrow, 18 Jun 2021): the nose gear collapsed on stand during maintenance after an incorrect ground lock pin configuration (AAIB Special Bulletin S1/2021), illustrating how ground/maintenance load paths can be severe and why robust, well‑specified support provisions and local structure are essential.

summary: The logic is simple: design the cabin, seats, and all heavy items to stay attached and not block exits under defined crash loads so people survive the impact and can get out fast.
intent: Ensure the airplane’s structure, seats, and heavy items protect people in survivable emergency landings on land or water, even if the airplane is damaged. Designers must show the aircraft can withstand specified acceleration (g) levels acting separately in each direction (up 3g, forward 9g, side 3–4g, down 6g, rear 1.5g), including with the landing gear retracted, when occupants use seats and belts correctly. Equipment, passenger-compartment cargo, and other large masses (e.g., galley inserts, auxiliary power unit (APU), fuselage‑mounted engines) must be located or restrained so they don’t injure occupants, puncture fuel systems, create fire hazards, or block escape routes; frequently removed items need extra margin. Seats and mass items must not deform under these loads in ways that slow evacuation. AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance) gives one way to show compliance; applicants may use equivalent methods.
events: US Airways Flight 1549 (2009 Hudson River ditching): The A320 sustained significant deceleration during a water landing, yet seats, galleys, and stowage generally remained in place and exits were usable, enabling a full evacuation. This shows why CS 25.561 demands restraint of masses and seat/structure integrity so occupants are protected and escape routes remain clear after a survivable landing.

LOT Polish Airlines Flight 16 (2011 Warsaw gear‑up landing): With the landing gear retracted, the 767 made a controlled belly landing and passengers evacuated with only minor injuries. This illustrates the requirement to design for wheels‑retracted emergency landings and specified inertia loads so the cabin remains survivable and egress is not impeded.

Adoption of the 16g dynamic seat standard (FAR/CS 25.562, late 1980s–1990s): Regulators raised seat crashworthiness after research and survivable accidents showed some 9g static‑design seats and attachments failed or deformed, injuring occupants and blocking aisles. This programme lesson underlines the intent behind 25.561 to keep seats and attachments from failing under crash pulses and to preserve evacuation paths.

summary: The logic is simple: prove through realistic dynamic tests that seats and belts keep occupants restrained and below injury limits while the seat stays attached and doesn’t hinder evacuation.
intent: CS 25.562 establishes dynamic crashworthiness requirements for aircraft seats and restraint systems so occupants can survive hard, but survivable, emergency landings. Each seat type must be dynamically tested with a 77 kg anthropomorphic test dummy (ATD) in two realistic impact pulses: vertical (downward) and forward (with slight yaw and seat-rail misalignment) to represent floor/fuselage deformation. Measured performance must keep body and strap loads within limits, ensure lap belts stay on the pelvis and shoulder straps (if installed) stay on the shoulders, limit head injury via the Head Injury Criterion (HIC ≤ 1000, based on head acceleration over time), and prevent excessive femur and spinal loads. Seats must remain attached and not deform to the point of impeding rapid evacuation. The core objective is to keep occupants restrained, conscious, and mobile after a survivable impact.
events: FAA 2005 “16 g seat retrofit” rule for Part 121 operators (compliance by 2009) required airline fleets to meet 25.562-like dynamic standards, reflecting research that stronger, dynamically tested seats reduce head/spine injuries; this programmatic action confirms the rule’s purpose of occupant protection in survivable crashes (see FAA Final Rule, 70 FR 56354, 2005).

Air France Flight 358, Toronto (2005): The TSB (A05H0002) reported a high-energy runway overrun with no fatalities; restraint systems generally functioned and seats remained attached, enabling rapid evacuation. This illustrates why CS 25.562 demands head-injury control (HIC), load limits, and seat-attachment integrity.

Asiana Airlines Flight 214, San Francisco (2013): NTSB AAR-14/01 found most belted passengers remained in their seats and survived, while some ejections/injuries occurred where occupants were unrestrained or seat rows detached amid floor deformation. The case underscores CS 25.562’s emphasis on belt retention, dynamic pulses, and attachment robustness under misalignment.

summary: The logic is simple: if you claim ditching capability, every structure that keeps water out or supports evacuation/survival must be proven—per CS 25.801(e)—strong enough to withstand water‑landing and flotation loads so it still works when needed.
intent: This rule simply ties any structure meant for water landings (ditching) to the ditching safety standard. If an applicant seeks ditching approval, all structural “ditching provisions”—for example watertight features, fuselage lower structure, ditching dams/plugs, liferaft or slide‑raft attachment points, lifeline anchorages, and related supports—must meet the strength criteria set in CS 25.801(e). The objective is to ensure these parts do not fail under water‑impact and flotation loads, keep water out long enough, and allow survival equipment and exits to function so occupants can evacuate and stay afloat. In short, the rule ensures structural robustness of ditching features is verified against the same assumptions and loads used for overall ditching safety.
events: US Airways Flight 1549 (A320), Hudson River, 2009: the fuselage stayed intact and slide/rafts and exits supported rapid evacuation while the aircraft floated. This shows robust ditching‑related structure and attachments can remain functional, which is exactly what CS 25.563 referencing 25.801(e) aims to assure (NTSB AAR‑10/03).

ALM Antillean Airlines Flight 980 (DC‑9), Caribbean Sea near St. Croix, 1970: several exits were at/under the waterline and raft access/deployment proved difficult, contributing to 23 drowning fatalities. It demonstrates ditching provisions must remain structurally accessible and effective above the waterline, reinforcing the need for strength‑compliant ditching features (NTSB AAR‑72‑6).

Ethiopian Airlines Flight 961 (B767), near Comoros, 1996: a high‑energy, banked ditching led to fuselage breakup and many fatalities. It underscores that ditching loads can be severe and only provisions substantiated to defined water‑impact loads have a chance to remain intact and usable (ICAO Circular 288, accident reports).

summary: The logic is simple: prove with analysis, testing, service data, and mandated maintenance that realistic flaws will be found before they threaten residual strength, and that even with such damage the structure can carry required loads for the LOV-defined life.
intent: Ensure transport airplanes do not suffer catastrophic structural failure over their service life by addressing fatigue, corrosion/environmental deterioration, and accidental/discrete-source damage. Applicants must identify principal structural elements (PSEs) and critical details, analyze and test them under realistic loads, temperatures, and humidity, and show damage tolerance: cracks or defects of credible size can be detected in time, their growth is understood, and residual strength meets required loads. The Airworthiness Limitations Section must include inspection thresholds/intervals and a Limit of Validity (LOV) supported by full-scale fatigue testing that precludes widespread fatigue damage (WFD), plus a Corrosion Prevention and Control Program (CPCP). If inspections are impractical, a safe-life approach with scatter factors may be used. Sonic fatigue must be assessed where relevant. For discrete-source events (e.g., bird strike), the airplane must be able to complete the flight with the damage, considering ultimate static loads and reasonable crew actions.
events: De Havilland Comet disasters (1954): three hull losses from fuselage rupture due to pressurization-cycle fatigue at square window corners. They led to full-scale pressurization fatigue testing and modern crack growth evaluation, exactly the kind of analysis-and-test-based fatigue substantiation CS 25.571 now requires.

Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (1988): a 737-200 suffered explosive decompression when multi-site fatigue cracking and corrosion at lap joints caused a large fuselage panel to fail. The event drove industry emphasis on widespread fatigue damage assessment, corrosion prevention/control programs (CPCP), inspection thresholds, and the establishment of LOVs—core elements in CS 25.571.

China Airlines Flight 611 (2002): a 747-200 broke up in flight after an improper 1980 tailstrike repair left a hidden crack that grew under repeated pressurization cycles. It illustrates why CS 25.571 demands consideration of initial defects/repairs, damage-tolerance inspections, and residual strength with realistic flaws.

summary: The logic is simple: provide a continuous, intentional path for lightning current and harden vulnerable materials so a strike cannot ignite fuel, destroy structure, or disable critical systems.
intent: Ensure a lightning strike cannot lead to a catastrophic outcome. That means the airframe and systems must safely conduct and dissipate lightning currents, prevent sparking or ignition in hazardous areas (like fuel tanks), preserve structural integrity, and avoid hazardous transients in wiring. For metal parts this is mainly done by robust electrical bonding (low-resistance connections) and structural design that tolerates direct attachment. For non‑metallic/composite parts (e.g., radomes, composite skins), designers must add protection such as conductive meshes/foils, diverter strips, shielding, and defined current return paths so the strike energy is routed harmlessly. The associated guidance (AMC) points to industry methods for zoning, analysis, test, and maintenance to verify these protections.
events: Pan Am Flight 214 (Boeing 707), Elkton, Maryland, 8 Dec 1963: a lightning strike ignited fuel vapors in a wing tank, causing an explosion and in‑flight breakup (Civil Aeronautics Board Accident Report, 1964). This tragedy drove stringent bonding and fuel system lightning protection, illustrating why CS 25.581 demands protection against catastrophic lightning effects.

LANSA Flight 508 (Lockheed L‑188A), Peru, 24 Dec 1971: reportedly struck by lightning leading to wing fuel ignition and structural breakup (Peruvian investigation; widely documented in public records). It shows how lightning can both damage structure and ignite fuel, reinforcing the need for controlled current paths and robust protection.

Boeing 787 certification (2007–2011): FAA/EASA issued Special Conditions for lightning protection of composite structure and fuel tanks, requiring features like expanded metal/copper foil, bonding, and current return networks (published in the Federal Register and EASA records). This program lesson shows regulators require proof that non‑metallic structures safely conduct and dissipate strike energy, mirroring CS 25.581 paragraphs (b) and (c).

summary: The logic is simple: if history shows a feature is dangerous you must not use it, and if any design detail is in doubt you must test it until you can prove it is safe for its intended use.
intent: This clause is a safety‑net in EASA’s CS‑25 (Certification Specifications for large aeroplanes). It prohibits including any design feature or detail that operational experience, incidents/accidents, or prior service data have shown to be hazardous or unreliable. If a design detail is novel, complex, historically troublesome, or otherwise in doubt, its suitability must be demonstrated by tests, not only by analysis or argument. The rule forces designers to learn from history, avoid repeating known failure modes, and to verify questionable parts and details (structural, mechanical, systems, or software) under realistic conditions before approval. The objective is to keep unsafe features out of service and require evidence‑based validation for anything uncertain.
events: 1954 de Havilland Comet structural breakups (BOAC Flight 781 and South African Airways Flight 201) traced to fatigue cracking from square‑corner windows. This proved that known hazardous details must be eliminated and that full‑scale pressure‑cycling tests are essential to establish the suitability of fuselage openings.

1974 Turkish Airlines Flight 981 (DC‑10) suffered explosive decompression from a cargo door that could appear latched yet open under load; a near‑miss in 1972 (American Airlines Flight 96) had already exposed the latch design vulnerability. It shows that once experience identifies an unreliable design detail, it must be redesigned and verified by test before further service.

2013 Boeing 787 lithium‑ion battery thermal runaways (JAL 787 at Boston and ANA Flight 692 diversion) led to a fleet grounding. As a novel, questionable design detail, the battery system’s suitability had to be re‑established by extensive containment and venting tests under FAA/EASA special conditions before return to service.

summary: The logic is simple: only use materials in safety-critical parts if you can prove by experience or tests that they meet controlled specifications and will retain their required properties in the real operating environment.
intent: Ensure any material used in parts whose failure could affect safety is proven to have the properties assumed in design and to keep those properties in real service. Proof must come from prior service experience or testing, and the production material must conform to approved specifications (controlled composition, processing, inspection) so the as-built strength and other critical properties match the design data. The rule requires explicit consideration of in-service environmental effects—temperature, humidity, fluids, corrosion, UV, ageing, and similar—so materials do not degrade faster or differently than assumed. In short, it prevents unproven or poorly controlled materials from entering safety-critical applications by demanding evidence of suitability, adherence to spec, and durability under the airplane’s operating conditions. (AMC = Acceptable Means of Compliance.)
events: United Airlines Flight 232 (1989, DC‑10): a titanium fan disk fractured due to a hard‑alpha inclusion from inadequate material quality and inspection, showing why strict material specifications, process control, and verification are essential for safety-critical parts.

Swissair Flight 111 (1998, MD‑11): flammable metallized Mylar (MPET) insulation covering contributed to an uncontrollable in-flight fire, demonstrating that material selection must establish not just strength but also durability and flammability performance under heat/smoke environments.

Air Transat Flight 961 (2005, A310): in-flight loss of most of the composite rudder due to disbonding and moisture‑related degradation led to inspections and design/manufacturing reviews, underscoring the need to prove composite durability and environmental resistance, as guided by dedicated AMC for composites.

summary: The logic is simple: only use controlled, approved, and adequately tested manufacturing and assembly methods that consistently deliver the properties the design relies on.
intent: This rule ensures that the way parts are made is as safe as the way they are designed. Manufacturing and assembly processes (including how raw materials are specified, handled, and transformed) must reliably produce the required strength and other properties every time. Any “special process” that can change properties and is hard to fully verify on the finished part (for example heat treatment, welding, adhesive bonding, composite layup/curing, friction stir welding, or additive manufacturing) must be performed to approved process specifications tied to approved material specifications and controlled design data. When a new fabrication method is introduced, it must be proven by a test program that is representative of the actual aircraft application, so the method’s repeatability and durability are demonstrated before use.
events: Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (1988, Boeing 737-200): An explosive decompression originated at cold-bonded fuselage lap joints where disbonding and multi-site fatigue developed; investigators linked the early “cold-bond” manufacturing method and execution to inadequate durable joint properties, underscoring the need for tightly specified and validated bonding processes.

Japan Airlines Boeing 787 battery fire (JA829J, Boston, 7 Jan 2013): The NTSB found cell defects and insufficient manufacturing process controls for the lithium‑ion batteries contributed to thermal runaway; this showed that new fabrication/assembly methods require approved process specs and representative qualification to ensure consistent safety.

Airbus A380 wing rib feet cracking (2012, EASA AD 2012-0013): Cracks discovered in wing rib feet were traced to manufacturing/assembly-induced stresses and material/process interactions, prompting inspection and redesign; the case demonstrated that fabrication and assembly methods must be controlled and shown to deliver consistent structural strength and durability.

summary: The logic is simple: for any critical removable fastener, use two independent locks that won’t be defeated by rotation or the operating environment, so the fastener cannot back out and degrade flight controls or structural safety.
intent: Ensure that any removable fastener (bolts, screws, nuts, pins) whose loss could jeopardise safe flight or required controllability is positively retained by two independent locking means, and that both the fastener and its locks continue to work in the real operating environment (vibration, temperature, fluids, corrosion). Prohibit relying solely on friction-type self-locking nuts on joints where the bolt rotates in service, because rotation can defeat friction locks; require a positive, non-friction secondary lock (e.g., castellated nut with cotter pin, lockwire, tab washer, safety clip). In plain terms: critical fasteners must not come loose, and their locking must survive heat, cold, fuel, oil, and vibration. Acronyms: CS = Certification Specification; AMC = Acceptable Means of Compliance.
events: British Airways Flight 5390 (1990, BAC One-Eleven): The captain’s windscreen blew out after maintenance installed undersized/incorrect screws, illustrating how improper fastener selection/retention can fail under pressure and vibration—exactly what redundant, environment-tolerant locking aims to prevent.

British Airways A319 G‑EUOE fan cowl door loss (Heathrow, 24 May 2013): Unlatched/removably secured doors detached after take-off, leading to fuel leak and fire; subsequent EASA ADs and design changes improved positive locking/indication—demonstrating the need for robust, error-resistant secondary retention on critical removable closures.

United Airlines Flight 811 (1989, B747 cargo door failure): The door’s latching/locking system allowed an apparent-locked but insecure condition and opened in flight; the accident showed that critical closures require positive, redundant locking resistant to loads and environmental effects, mirroring the intent of dual-locking for critical fasteners.

summary: The logic is simple: keep contaminants and moisture from attacking or accumulating on the structure (and let them escape if they get in), and shield wear areas, so the airframe keeps its designed strength over its life.
intent: CS-25.609 (Certification Specifications for Large Aeroplanes) requires that every structural part of a transport airplane be designed and maintained so it does not lose strength during service from weathering (sun, temperature, moisture), corrosion (chemical/electrochemical attack, including galvanic corrosion), or abrasion (wear/erosion). It also requires designers to provide ventilation and drainage wherever needed so water and contaminants cannot be trapped in cavities, where they would accelerate hidden damage. The objective is durable, maintainable structure that retains its load-carrying capability between inspections in all operating environments by selecting suitable materials, finishes and sealants, adding sacrificial/wear protections, controlling dissimilar-metal couples, and using drains/vents. This requirement underpins corrosion prevention and control programs (CPCP) and long-term structural integrity.
events: Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (1988, Boeing 737-200) suffered explosive decompression and roof loss due to multi-site fatigue cracking exacerbated by corrosion and disbonding in cold-bonded fuselage lap joints (NTSB AAR-89/03). The salty, high-cycle environment and moisture ingress degraded the joints over time, proving the need for robust corrosion protection and environmental sealing to preserve structural strength.

Air Transat Flight 961 (2005, Airbus A310-300) lost most of its composite rudder in flight; the investigation found manufacturing defects compounded by moisture ingress and bondline disbonding in the honeycomb rudder (TSB Canada report A05F0047). Subsequent ADs mandated inspections, sealing, and drain/vent provisions, demonstrating why protection, drainage, and ventilation are critical to prevent hidden water damage in composite structures.

SAS Bombardier Q400 landing gear collapses (2007: SK1209 Aalborg, SK2748 Vilnius, SK2867 Copenhagen) were traced to corrosion-induced fatigue cracking in landing-gear components following moisture ingress (final reports by Danish and Swedish accident authorities). The groundings and mandated inspections/coating improvements show why gear structures must be protected from corrosion and designed to shed and vent trapped moisture.

summary: The logic is simple: design physical access or validated NDI so maintainers can perform timely inspections, lubrication, adjustments, and replacements—including on wiring—at the required intervals to keep the aircraft airworthy.
intent: CS 25.611’s objective is to build maintainability into the airplane so safety‑critical items can actually be inspected, serviced, and replaced throughout the aircraft’s life. It requires practical access to principal structural elements (load‑bearing parts whose failure would seriously affect structural integrity) and to control systems, plus means for adjustment and lubrication. When direct visual inspection is not feasible, non‑destructive inspection (NDI) may be used only if its effectiveness is shown and the procedures are captured in the Instructions for Continued Airworthiness (ICA) required by CS 25.1529. Electrical Wiring Interconnection Systems (EWIS—wiring, connectors, clamps, and bundles) must also be accessible per CS 25.1719 so they can be inspected and maintained. In short, the design must make scheduled and on‑condition maintenance doable at the specified intervals, not just theoretically possible.
events: Alaska Airlines Flight 261 (2000) lost control after the MD‑83 horizontal stabilizer jackscrew failed due to inadequate lubrication and wear. The case underscored that critical control system components must be readily serviceable and their inspections practicable at the mandated intervals. It illustrates why the rule demands accessible means to lubricate and inspect control systems.

Swissair Flight 111 (1998) suffered an in‑flight fire initiated by arcing in wiring above the cockpit, leading to loss of the MD‑11. The aftermath drove comprehensive EWIS initiatives requiring better segregation, support, and inspection access. It demonstrates why wiring must meet explicit accessibility provisions (CS 25.1719) for effective inspection and repair.

Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (1988) experienced explosive decompression from multi‑site fatigue cracking in fuselage lap joints that eluded prior inspections. The industry responded with enhanced access and non‑destructive inspection (e.g., eddy current) of hidden structural elements at appropriate intervals. This shows the need for either direct access or proven NDI with documented procedures to detect damage in principal structural elements.

summary: The logic is simple: base design on statistically conservative, environment-appropriate material allowables (A- or B-basis), unless each item is individually proof-tested or the Agency approves otherwise, so variability cannot undermine structural integrity.
intent: CS 25.613 ensures the strength values used in airframe design are conservative, statistically sound, and representative of real production materials and service environments. Material properties must come from enough tests of material made to approved specifications, and designers must select “design values” that minimise failure risk: A-basis (99% of the population covered with 95% confidence) for single-load-path critical parts, and B-basis (90%/95%) for redundant structure. Environmental effects (e.g., temperature, moisture) within the aeroplane’s operating envelope must be included, especially for essential structure, so hot/wet or cold/dry knockdowns are applied where significant. Higher values are allowed only with premium selection (item-by-item proof testing) or if the Agency (EASA, European Union Aviation Safety Agency) approves another basis. The aim is to prevent structural failures caused by material variability, processing, and environment by anchoring design to verified, statistically derived allowables.
events: 1988 Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (B737-200): explosive decompression from lap-joint failure after cold-bond adhesive degraded and multiple-site fatigue cracks grew in a hot, humid, marine environment. It demonstrated that environmental conditions can erode joint/material strength below assumed values, validating CS 25.613’s mandate to use statistically conservative, environment-appropriate design allowables.

2012 Airbus A380 wing rib feet cracking: in-service cracks in 7449 aluminium rib feet led to EASA AD 2012-0011 requiring inspections and modifications. The programme lesson was that material strength at stress concentrations and process variability must be captured by conservative, statistically supported design values and knockdowns.

Boeing 787 composite primary structure certification: regulators required a CMH-17-based building-block test program to derive A- and B-basis allowables, including hot/wet moisture–temperature effects, before accepting design strengths. This shows CS 25.613’s purpose that design values must come from robust statistical databases reflecting real environmental conditions, not nominal coupon numbers.

summary: The logic is simple: if strength is uncertain or likely to degrade, increase the safety factor (using the highest applicable special factor) or apply other rigorous controls until integrity is assured.
intent: This rule tells designers to add extra safety margin to structural parts whose true strength is not well known, may degrade in service, or varies because of manufacturing or inspection uncertainty. The baseline “factor of safety” in CS 25.303 (normally 1.5 on loads) must be multiplied by the highest relevant “special factor” from CS 25.621–25.625 (e.g., casting, bearing, or fitting factors) for those parts. If multiplying by a special factor is not the right way to ensure integrity, the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) expects other measures (such as tighter process controls, proof testing, 100% inspection, life limits, or redesign). In short, when uncertainty or deterioration risk exists, either raise the margin or impose other robust controls so the structure remains safe throughout service.
events: American Airlines Flight 191 (1979, DC‑10): Maintenance-induced damage to the pylon attach structure led to a catastrophic engine separation on takeoff, illustrating how uncertainty and deterioration in critical fittings demand either higher margins or alternative controls.

Boeing 737NG pickle fork cracking (2019; FAA AD 2019‑20‑02/EASA ADs): Unexpected cracking in fuselage frame-to-wing-attach ‘pickle fork’ fittings, attributed to variability and service conditions, showed why fittings with uncertain strength require special factors and intensified inspection.

Airbus A380 wing rib foot cracks (2012; EASA AD 2012‑0013): Cracking in wing rib feet due to material/manufacturing issues demonstrated that parts with appreciable variability need added safety margins or other corrective measures to ensure structural integrity.

summary: The logic is simple: the less you can prove and inspect a casting’s quality, the more design margin you must add (via a higher casting factor), with critical parts demanding the most rigorous proof or margin.
intent: Structural metal castings can hide defects (porosity, inclusions, hot tears) and show more variability than wrought parts. CS 25.621 ensures that when cast parts carry aircraft structural loads, designers either: add extra strength margin (a “casting factor”), or prove by strict process qualification, non-destructive inspection (NDI), coupon testing, and static tests that the casting behaves like wrought material. Critical castings (whose failure could prevent safe flight/landing or seriously injure occupants) get the highest scrutiny. The rule scales required inspections and test quantities with the chosen casting factor, and relaxes requirements only for features under bearing stress and for non-structural fluid-system castings. NDI methods referenced include visual, liquid penetrant (LPI), and radiography (RT); process monitoring uses coupons cut from prolongations and, by sampling, from critical areas of production parts.
events: Boeing 777 titanium structural casting qualification: Boeing and suppliers documented using process qualification, 100% LPI/RT, coupons from each pour, and static tests to justify a 1.0 casting factor for large Ti investment castings (e.g., SAE/ASM papers on 777 Ti castings), showing how robust controls can replace added margin.

Airbus A350/A380 structural titanium castings: Airbus and casting suppliers (e.g., PCC Structurals, Doncasters) publicly describe wrought-equivalent variability demonstrations with coupon testing and 100% NDI for pylon/door/gear-related castings, illustrating the rule’s path to CF=1.0 through process control and inspection.

Regulatory programme lesson: FAA AC 25.621-1 (mirrored by EASA AMC 25.621) was issued in response to historical in-service problems with structural castings, codifying the mapping between inspection/testing rigor (LPI/RT, coupons, static tests) and allowable casting factors, which is exactly what CS 25.621 implements.

summary: The logic is simple: if a joint has clearance and will vibrate or experience impact, increase its bearing design margin to handle the extra local stresses and wear from normal relative motion, unless a bigger special factor already controls.
intent: This rule ensures that any joint or part designed with a clearance (a free fit between a pin/bolt and a hole, or a roller in a track) and exposed to vibration or impact loads is sized with extra margin for the local bearing contact stresses. "Bearing" here means the compressive contact stress between mating parts; repeated micro‑slip causes pounding, fretting, hole ovalization, and fatigue cracking. The required "bearing factor" is an added design factor to cover these effects of normal relative motion in service, unless another larger special factor (e.g., casting factor or a control-system special factor) already applies and governs. In practice this targets pins/lugs, hinges, rollers, actuator rod-ends, engine mounts, landing gear and control-surface attachments, where even small free play under cyclic loads can rapidly degrade joints.
events: American Airlines Flight 191 (DC‑10, 1979): the left engine/pylon separated after fatigue of the aft pylon attach structure, exacerbated by prior damage and service loads at the lug/pin interfaces; it illustrates how clearance‑fit attach points under vibration/fretting need robust bearing margins and controls (NTSB AAR‑79‑17).

El Al Flight 1862 (B747‑200F, Amsterdam 1992): fatigue-fractured pylon fuse pins allowed both right engines to separate, with investigations noting corrosion/fretting and cyclic loads in the pin‑lug joints; this highlights the vulnerability of clearance‑fit pinned attachments to vibration-induced bearing/fatigue damage and the need to account for such motion in design (Netherlands Aviation Safety Board report 92‑11).
