These findings drove industry practices such as fuselage "ice shields" near the prop disc and window qualification by ice‑block impact tests, directly mirroring CS 25.875’s intent.

summary: The logic is simple: keep every part at the same electrical potential and provide reliable paths for charges to bleed off so they can’t shock people, spark in fuel vapours, or disrupt avionics.
intent: Ensure the airplane has an electrical bonding and static charge control design that prevents dangerous build-up of electrostatic electricity. Bonding means electrically connecting components to the airframe so they stay at the same potential, and static control means giving charges a safe path to bleed off. The objectives are to avoid three hazards: electrical shock to people, ignition of flammable fuel vapours (e.g., in tanks or during refuelling), and interference with onboard electrical/electronic systems (EMI/EMC issues, including precipitation static). The rule allows compliance by proper bonding of parts or any other acceptable means that safely dissipates charge so the airplane, people, and systems are not endangered.
events: Philippine Airlines Flight 143 (Boeing 737-3C9), Manila, 11 May 1990: the center wing tank exploded during refuelling, killing 8. Investigators concluded a flammable vapour ignited likely from electrical arcing in tank wiring; it demonstrates why strict bonding/ESD control is vital to prevent sparks around fuel vapours.

TWA Flight 800 (Boeing 747-131), off Long Island, 17 July 1996: a center wing tank explosion destroyed the aircraft. NTSB found ignition of a flammable vapour likely from a wiring short; the resulting SFAR 88 programme tightened bonding, shielding, and static/EMI protections in and around fuel tanks to eliminate ignition sources.

FAA SAFO 06003 (2006) on precipitation static documented significant operator events of radio/nav interference when static dischargers were missing or bonding degraded. This pattern shows the need for effective bonding and static wicks to dissipate charge and protect installed electronics from p-static.

summary: The logic is simple: install and integrate the powerplant and its control/safety systems per approved instructions, ensure continued safe operation and access for maintenance with proper electrical bonding, assess their risks under CS 25.1309, and handle rare burst/debris hazards with specific dedicated design measures rather than generic probability goals.
intent: Ensure the entire powerplant installation (engines/propellers, their controls like FADEC/thrust reversers, and any systems that influence their safety) is designed, installed, and maintained so it stays safe and reliable between scheduled inspections. It must follow the engine/propeller manufacturer’s installation instructions, meet all Subpart E requirements, be accessible for inspection/maintenance, and be electrically bonded to prevent arcing/lighting/static hazards. The installation’s functions are assessed under CS 25.1309 (system safety), but three extreme hazards—engine case burn-through/rupture, uncontained rotor failure, and propeller debris release—are excluded from 25.1309(b)’s probability targets because they are controlled by specific, dedicated requirements and analyses (per associated AMCs). Overall, the rule defines scope, obliges disciplined integration, and focuses on continued safe operation and maintainability.
events: United Airlines Flight 232 (Sioux City, 1989): An uncontained fan-disk burst on a DC‑10 severed all hydraulics, leading to loss of flight controls and a crash-landing. It demonstrates why uncontained rotor failures must drive specific installation segregation/criteria and are treated outside CS 25.1309(b)’s generic probability framework.

Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 529 (EMB‑120, 1995): A propeller blade separation caused severe vibration and structural damage, leading to a crash during an emergency landing. It highlights propeller debris and sustained imbalance hazards, validating CS 25.901(c)’s special treatment and the need for robust installation and inspection provisions.

United Airlines Flight 328 (B777‑200, 2021): A PW4077 fan blade fractured, the nacelle shed parts and the engine experienced extreme imbalance, yet the airplane landed safely. It shows the value of compliant installation design, segregation/bonding, and dedicated blade‑out/imbalance criteria (e.g., AMC 25‑24) to contain effects and preserve aircraft safety.

summary: The logic is simple: use engines proven against FOD/ice, install and isolate them so one engine mishap can’t cascade, let crews stop dangerous rotation, protect against turbine rotor-burst/fire and overspeed, and guarantee in‑flight restart with independent ignition power.
intent: Ensure the engines and their installation on large transport aeroplanes provide proven protection against known hazards and allow safe continuation of flight after an engine problem. If an engine is not certified to EASA CS-E (Certification Specifications for Engines), it must show equivalent safety on foreign object debris/damage (FOD) and ice ingestion via tests or service history. Engines must be installed and isolated so one engine’s failure or fire cannot take out other engines or essential systems, nor force immediate crew action. Crews must be able to stop a hazardous windmilling engine (e.g., via feathering on turboprops), with fire-resistant components forward of the firewall. Turbine installations must minimise the effects of rotor-burst or case burn-through, and engine controls (e.g., FADEC) must prevent overspeed/overtemperature that threatens rotor integrity. Finally, engines must be restartable in flight within a defined altitude/airspeed envelope, with an independent electrical power source for ignition if all engines have stopped.
events: United Airlines Flight 232 (1989, DC‑10, Sioux City): an uncontained No. 2 engine fan‑disk failure severed all three hydraulic systems, leading to loss of normal control and a crash landing. This shows why CS 25.903(b) and (d)(1) demand system/engine isolation and rotor-burst hazard minimisation so a single engine failure cannot disable the aeroplane.

British Airways Flight 9 (1982, B747 near Jakarta): volcanic ash caused flameout of all four engines; after descending, the crew successfully restarted multiple engines and landed safely. This demonstrates the need for a defined restart envelope and assured in‑flight restart capability per CS 25.903(e).

Air Transat Flight 236 (2001, A330 over the Atlantic): fuel exhaustion led to dual engine flameout; the ram‑air turbine powered essential buses, enabling ignition and restart attempts and aircraft control during the glide to Lajes. This illustrates CS 25.903(e)(3)’s requirement for an engine‑independent electrical power source to support ignition when all engines have stopped.

summary: The logic is simple: if you count on automatic extra thrust after an engine failure at takeoff, you must prove the system is reliable, well‑annunciated, and safe per Appendix I before getting any performance credit.
intent: This rule ensures that if an aircraft uses an automatic system to increase power or thrust on the remaining engine(s) when an engine fails during takeoff (an ATTCS), the system meets stringent design, reliability, and performance criteria in Appendix I. ATTCS stands for Automatic Takeoff Thrust (or Power) Control System, sometimes called APR/ATPCS/ATR/“thrust bump” in industry. Because manufacturers may rely on this automatic thrust increase to meet one‑engine‑inoperative (OEI) takeoff and climb performance (and to claim higher takeoff weights or shorter distances), the regulation demands the system trigger only when needed, be highly reliable, clearly annunciated, and have safe failure modes. It ties system design, flight/crew procedures, and performance credit together so that safety is not degraded if the automation fails or misfires.
events: Regulatory history – Adoption of Part 25 Appendix I (ATTCS): FAA/EASA created Appendix I in the mid‑1980s to allow performance credit for automatic thrust/power‑reserve systems only if they met defined reliability, annunciation, and failure‑safety criteria; this codifies the rule’s purpose to tie automation design to performance credit.

TransAsia Airways Flight 235 (ATR 72‑600), Taipei, 2015: After a flameout, the ATPCS correctly increased power on the live engine and autofeathered the failed prop, but pilot misidentification led to shutting down the good engine and loss of control (Aviation Safety Council Taiwan, Final Report). It shows why ATTCS functions must be robust and clearly annunciated and why their use is bounded by defined crew procedures—the core aim of Appendix I.

Bombardier DHC‑8‑400 (Q400) program use of APR/ATPCS: Certification allowed OEI performance credit with automatic power‑reserve only after demonstrating arming logic, reliable failure detection, annunciation, and inoperative procedures per Appendix I (reflected in AFM limitations and TCDS notes). This program lesson illustrates the rule’s intent: no operational credit without a proven, reliable automatic thrust increase system.

summary: The logic is simple: keep the engine/propeller within the propeller’s certified limits, ensure the pitch‑control system meets propeller reliability standards, and design the aeroplane so a thrown blade or hub failure cannot cause catastrophic damage or loss of control.
intent: Ensure that any propeller installed on a large aeroplane is operated only within the limits for which it was certificated, that its blade pitch control system meets dedicated propeller standards, and that the aeroplane design mitigates the rare but severe consequences of a blade or hub failure. The rule ties engine power and shaft speed to the propeller’s certified envelope (preventing overspeed/over‑torque), demands reliable, fail‑safe pitch control hardware, and requires protection of structure and critical systems from blade fragments and extreme unbalance loads. The objective is to prevent loss of control and avert aeroplane‑level hazards from a single propeller failure. Acronyms: EASA (European Union Aviation Safety Agency); CS‑25 (Certification Specifications for Large Aeroplanes); CS‑P (Certification Specifications for Propellers); AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance).
events: Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 529 (EMB‑120, 21 Aug 1995): a Hamilton Standard propeller blade fractured from fatigue, separated, and caused severe unbalance and damage leading to a fatal crash—demonstrating why designs must minimise hazards from blade release and unbalance (CS 25.905(d)).

Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 2311 (EMB‑120, 5 Apr 1991): an uncommanded propeller pitch change from a propeller control unit malfunction led to loss of control on approach, illustrating the need for robust, compliant blade pitch control systems (CS‑P 420 referenced by CS 25.905(c)).

Regional Express Saab 340B VH‑NRX near Sydney (17 Mar 2017): the right propeller separated in flight after a propeller gearbox shaft failure; the safe landing underscored both the hazard of released propellers and the value of airframe/system protection to prevent catastrophic outcomes (CS 25.905(d)).

summary: The logic is simple: measure blade vibration on the actual installation across the operating envelope and keep it within proven safe limits—or redesign/limit operations until it is.
intent: Ensure that propeller blades on transport-category airplanes do not experience harmful vibratory stresses in normal service. The rule requires that actual blade vibration stresses be established on the installed airplane—either by strain‑gauge measurement or by validated comparison with a similar installation—and then shown to stay below limits proven safe for continuous operation. Those safe limits come from propeller certification testing and vibration evaluations (EASA CS‑P 530/550, i.e., Certification Specifications for Propellers). If stresses are too high, the design or operating envelope must be changed (e.g., damping, blade/engine mount changes, or restricted RPM ranges). The aim is to prevent high‑cycle fatigue cracks and blade failures that can cause severe imbalance, secondary structural damage, and loss of the aircraft.
events: Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 529 (EMB‑120, 21 Aug 1995) suffered an in‑flight Hamilton Standard propeller blade separation from undetected corrosion‑induced fatigue, leading to catastrophic imbalance and crash (NTSB AAR‑96/06). It shows how blade fatigue—exacerbated by vibratory stress—can be fatal and why certification demands demonstrated safe vibration margins for continuous operation.

Lockheed L‑188 Electra breakup accidents (Braniff Flight 542, 1959; Northwest Flight 710, 1960) were traced to propeller/engine whirl flutter exciting the wing, causing structural failure (Civil Aeronautics Board reports). These tragedies underline the need to validate installed propeller vibratory behavior on the airplane, not just component strength in isolation.

Programme lesson: Modern turboprop certifications perform strain‑gauged blade vibration surveys per CS‑P 530/550 and, when needed, translate findings into AFM and instrument markings with restricted RPM 'avoid ranges' on tachometers. This illustrates how measured stress data are turned into operating limits when redesign is impractical, directly implementing the rule’s intent.

summary: The logic is simple: always keep the propeller safely away from the ground and the airframe—even with heavy weight, worst CG, unfavourable blade pitch, compressed or deflated gear—while providing extra structural clearance to prevent contact and harmful vibration.
intent: Ensure a propeller never strikes the ground or the aeroplane structure in realistic worst-case conditions. Designers must show adequate margin at maximum weight, with the most adverse centre of gravity (CG), and with the propeller at its most adverse blade pitch (e.g., low/flat or reverse), considering landing gear compression. The rule demands minimum ground clearance in critical taxi/take-off attitudes and still-positive clearance if a critical tyre is completely deflated and the strut is bottomed. It also requires minimum radial and longitudinal clearances between propeller blades/spinner and nearby structure, plus extra margin to avoid harmful vibration. The aim is to prevent prop strikes, debris release, structural damage, or cabin penetration, and to limit vibration-induced fatigue and noise by guaranteeing physical separation under tolerances, flex, and dynamic effects.
events: SAS Flight 1209 (DHC-8-402 Q400), Aalborg, 9 Sep 2007: a main landing gear collapse on landing led to propeller blades striking and penetrating the fuselage; this illustrates the severe consequences of prop–airframe contact and why explicit structural and ground clearances (with gear deflection considered) are mandated.

Empire Airlines Flight 8284 (ATR 42-300), Lubbock, Texas, 27 Jan 2009: after a hard, iced landing the main gear collapsed and both propellers struck the runway, causing significant airframe damage; this shows how reduced clearance due to gear compression/deflation can rapidly lead to prop strikes, underpinning the requirement for minimum and positive clearance even with a flat tyre and bottomed strut.

summary: The logic is simple: if you want approval to fly in icing, you must show your propeller and nearby parts won’t accumulate dangerous ice in Appendix C and O conditions—or that you can safely and reliably remove it—and any flammable de-icing fluid must meet the engine compartment fire-protection rules.
intent: This rule ensures that any large transport airplane approved to fly in icing has a reliable way to stop dangerous ice building up on the propeller system and nearby parts that could hurt engine performance. It requires ice protection to work in all regulatory icing atmospheres: Appendix C (typical supercooled small droplets) and Appendix O (supercooled large droplets, SLD). That includes propeller blades, spinners, and related accessories whose icing can cause severe vibration, thrust loss, or engine ingestion issues. If the de-icing method uses a combustible fluid (e.g., alcohol-based systems), the installation must also meet the fuel/flammable-fluid fire-protection rules in CS 25.1181–25.1185 and CS 25.1189. In short, prove the propeller/associated parts will not accumulate hazardous ice in Appendix C and O, or safely remove it, without creating fire risk.
events: American Eagle Flight 4184 (ATR‑72, Roselawn, 1994): the crash in supercooled large droplet (SLD) icing led regulators to recognize hazards beyond Appendix C and to add Appendix O; this underpins CS 25.929’s explicit requirement to be effective in both Appendix C and O icing envelopes.

EASA CS‑25 Amendment 25/18: EASA formally incorporated Appendix O (SLD) into CS‑25 after industry/accident history, ensuring ice‑protection assessments include SLD; CS 25.929’s reference to Appendices C and O reflects this programmatic lesson.

NASA/FAA Tailplane Icing Program (TIP, late 1990s–2000s): flight and wind‑tunnel tests showed propeller ice accretion and shedding can create severe vibration and downstream icing, validating the need for effective propeller/spinner de‑icing and timed cycling logic to prevent hazardous accumulations.

summary: The logic is simple: design reversers so they either cannot create reverse thrust hazards in flight or, if used in flight, remain safe even with failures, and make any malfunction default to a controllable, low-thrust state.
intent: Ensure thrust- or pitch-reversing systems (on jets and propellers) cannot create hazardous conditions. If a jet’s reverser is intended for ground use only, either prove the airplane can still fly and land safely if a reverser deploys in flight, or show via a system safety assessment (per CS 25.1309(b), which sets acceptable failure probabilities) that such deployment is sufficiently improbable. If a reverser is approved for use in flight, it must be safe in normal operation and with foreseeable failures. Any malfunction must default the engine to no more than idle thrust (unless higher forward thrust can still be controlled using aerodynamic controls alone). For propellers, no single failure may cause unwanted reverse under expected conditions; compliance can be by analysis and/or tests, aligned with propeller rules (CS-P 70). Failures of structural elements with extremely remote probability need not be considered.
events: Lauda Air Flight 004 (Boeing 767-300ER, 26 May 1991): An uncommanded in‑flight thrust reverser deployment led to structural breakup and loss of the aircraft. This tragedy demonstrates why CS 25.933 demands either continued safe flight after an in‑flight reversal or extremely low likelihood of such deployment, and fail‑safe limits on thrust in malfunctions.

Luxair Flight 9642 (Fokker 50, 6 Nov 2002): Inadvertent selection of reverse/beta in flight led to a rapid loss of control and a fatal crash; subsequent actions strengthened flight‑idle stops and interlocks. This shows the need for propeller systems to prevent unwanted reverse from any single failure or handling error, as required by CS 25.933(b).

Douglas DC‑8 in‑flight reverse certification and operations: The DC‑8 was approved for limited in‑flight reverse thrust under strict procedures and envelope limits, validated by flight test and AFM/Type Certificate data. This program lesson illustrates CS 25.933(a)(2): if reversers are intended for use in flight, the design and demonstrated operation must not create unsafe conditions, even with credible failures.

summary: The logic is simple: only install thrust reversers that have passed the engine-level safety tests and fail‑safe criteria in CS‑E 890 so they cannot create hazardous conditions on the airplane.
intent: Ensure that any thrust reverser fitted to a turbojet engine on a large airplane has already been proven safe by meeting the engine certification tests and criteria in CS‑E 890 (EASA Certification Specifications for Engines). The objective is to prevent hazardous effects such as inadvertent in‑flight deployment, asymmetric or partial deployment, loss of directional control on landing, or structural/containment failures. By referencing CS‑E 890, EASA (European Union Aviation Safety Agency) requires robust design features (e.g., locks, logic interlocks), reliability tests, failure‑mode assessments, and demonstrations that the system either cannot deploy in flight or, if it does, will not produce a hazardous condition. This avoids duplicative rules and ensures consistent, engine‑level safety evidence before installation on transport airplanes.
events: Lauda Air Flight 004 (Boeing 767-3Z9ER), 26 May 1991: an uncommanded in‑flight deployment of the left engine thrust reverser led to loss of control and a fatal crash in Thailand. This tragedy drove industry and regulators to mandate robust locks, interlocks, and demonstrations preventing or mitigating in‑flight deployment—precisely the thrust reverser safety evidence required by CS‑E 890 and referenced by CS 25.934.

TAM Airlines Flight 402 (Fokker 100), São Paulo, 31 Oct 1996: the right engine thrust reverser inadvertently deployed shortly after liftoff, causing loss of control and a fatal crash. It shows how reverser malfunctions can be catastrophic in critical phases, underscoring the need for stringent engine‑level reverser testing and fail‑safe design that CS‑E 890 requires before installation.

summary: The logic is simple: design propeller pitch/drag controls so no single fault can let a prop create more drag than the aircraft is designed to tolerate, typically by defaulting to feather/coarse pitch and locking out reverse in flight.
intent: This rule ensures that turboprop aeroplanes are protected against hazardous propeller drag if a propeller control/drag-limiting system fails. Drag-limiting systems (for example, feathering/auto‑feather, negative‑torque sensing (NTS), and in‑flight beta/reverse lockouts) must be designed so that any single failure or malfunction—during normal or emergency operations—cannot let the propeller create more drag than the aeroplane was structurally and controllability‑wise designed to handle under CS 25.367 (loads/handling with engine-out or asymmetric power). Excessive drag from a windmilling, flat- or reverse‑pitch prop can rapidly degrade performance, yaw/roll the aircraft, and jeopardize controllability. Therefore, systems must be fault‑tolerant or fail‑benign (e.g., default to feather/coarse pitch), and only extremely remote failures of structural elements within the drag‑limiting system can be excluded from consideration.
events: Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 2311 (EMB‑120RT), 5 Apr 1991, Brunswick, GA: a propeller control unit failure drove one propeller toward flat/reverse pitch, creating extreme asymmetric drag and loss of control; NTSB AAR‑92/04 shows how a single system failure can produce catastrophic prop drag.

Luxair Flight 9642 (Fokker 50), 6 Nov 2002, near Luxembourg: inadvertent in‑flight selection of ground range put one propeller into reverse, generating massive drag and roll; the investigation led to beta‑lockout/interlock improvements to prevent in‑flight reverse and the associated drag excursions.

Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 529 (EMB‑120), 21 Aug 1995, near Carrollton, GA: a propeller blade separation caused severe drag and controllability problems; although a structural failure, it underscores why certification fixes a maximum prop‑drag assumption and why other single failures in drag‑limiting systems must not allow exceeding it.

summary: The logic is simple: prove in flight that the installed engine and inlet won’t stall, surge, flame out, or vibrate dangerously anywhere you’re allowed to operate, including during emergency manoeuvres and transients.
intent: Ensure that, when a turbine engine is installed on a transport aeroplane, its real‑world, installed behavior has no dangerous operability traits anywhere inside the approved operating envelope. In flight tests, the engine must not exhibit hazardous compressor stall (airflow breakdown), surge (violent flow reversal/oscillation), flameout (loss of combustion), or damaging vibration during normal and emergency operations, including rapid thrust changes, bleed/anti‑ice transitions, high angle of attack, sideslip, crosswinds, and precipitation exposure as permitted by limitations. The inlet system must not distort airflow in a way that induces harmful engine vibration. The intent is to prevent loss of thrust or engine damage from predictable manoeuvres or conditions, and to confirm benign, recoverable behavior with appropriate protections (e.g., continuous ignition, FADEC schedules) and crew procedures before certification.
events: TACA Flight 110 (Boeing 737-300, 1988): Both CFM56 engines flamed out after severe rain/hail ingestion, forcing a dead-stick landing on a levee near New Orleans; this drove engine and procedure changes (e.g., automatic continuous ignition in heavy precipitation) and illustrates why CS 25.939 demands in‑flight verification of flameout/surge resilience.

Southern Airways Flight 242 (DC-9-31, 1977): Dual JT8D flameouts from intense rain/hail caused loss of thrust and a fatal forced landing, underscoring susceptibility to water-ingestion–induced stall/surge and the need for tighter operability demonstrations aligned with this rule.

Scandinavian Airlines Flight 751 (MD-81, 1991): Ice shed from contaminated wings was ingested, causing repeated compressor stalls and severe thrust loss on both JT8D engines before a crash-landing, showing how distorted/contaminated inlet flow can trigger hazardous stall/surge and reinforcing the requirement to assess installed engine operability and inlet effects.

summary: The logic is simple: if you add movable intake or exhaust hardware, you must prove the engine–airframe system stays controllable with normal pilot effort in all schedules and credible failures, without flirting with limits.
intent: Ensure airplanes with variable-geometry inlets or exhausts (including thrust augmentation like afterburning or variable-area nozzles and thrust reversers) are compatible with the engine and the airframe so the combined system behaves safely. The inlet–engine–exhaust system must operate correctly across all engine speeds, power settings, and configurations requested for approval, and the dynamic effects of operating or malfunctioning these systems must not degrade aircraft controllability or require extraordinary pilot skill or strength. Any transients (yaw, pitch, roll, buffet, surges) from configuration changes or failures must not push the airplane toward exceeding structural or operational limits, and required pilot forces must remain within CS 25.143(d–f). In short, the design and its control laws must tame the aero–propulsive interactions so pilots can handle the airplane normally, even with credible malfunctions.
events: Lauda Air Flight 004 (Boeing 767-300ER, 26 May 1991): an uncommanded thrust reverser deployment in climb produced extreme asymmetric drag and loss of control, showing that exhaust-geometry malfunctions can create uncontrollable transients unless the system is made fail-safe and benign.

TAM Flight 402 (Fokker 100, 31 Oct 1996, São Paulo): inadvertent thrust reverser deployment after takeoff led to severe yaw/roll and a fatal crash, underscoring the need to evaluate reverser/inlet failure dynamics and ensure the aircraft remains controllable within normal pilot strength limits.

summary: The logic is simple: prove by analysis and test that the engine and its associated systems keep working safely for the worst negative‑g and duration expected in flight, so brief negative g never creates a powerplant hazard.
intent: Ensure that during brief negative accelerations (negative g, i.e., forces that make fuel/oil move “upward” away from pickups) within the approved flight envelope, the engine and any powerplant‑related systems (fuel, oil, nacelle, controls, APU, propeller/rotor) do not suffer a hazardous malfunction. The aim is to prevent outcomes like multiple‑engine flameout, loss of lubrication, uncontained failure, fire, or uncontrollable thrust/propeller conditions caused by fuel or oil unporting, pump cavitation, venting/foaming, or inlet/flow disturbances. Compliance must be shown for the worst negative‑g level and the longest duration that can reasonably occur per the maneuver/turbulence envelope (CS 25.333), not just for a momentary blip. This keeps the airplane safe during upsets, turbulence, and push‑over maneuvers that can produce brief negative g in service.
events: Qantas Flight 72 (A330, 2008): Two uncommanded pitch‑downs produced brief negative g (reportedly approaching −0.8 g); engines continued to operate, illustrating that real‑world upsets can impose negative g and powerplants must tolerate it without hazardous malfunction (ATSB AO-2008-070).

Lufthansa Flight 1829 (A321, 2014, near Bilbao): Anomalous alpha‑protection activation led to abrupt pitch‑downs and brief negative g; while engines were unaffected, the event shows negative g can arise from system faults within the envelope, underscoring the need for CS 25.943 robustness (EASA AD 2014-0266; BFU/airline reports).

Airbus A310 ZERO‑G (Novespace) program: Publicly documented modifications to fuel/oil systems were required to sustain 20–25 s zero‑g parabolas, demonstrating that standard transport designs are intended for only brief negative/zero g—exactly why CS 25.943 ties compliance to the greatest expected duration (Airbus/Novespace publications).

summary: The logic is simple: if you use fluid injection to get extra thrust, the system must always deliver the right flow, resist freezing and leaks, and carry enough fluid for the approved operation with structural and drainage margins.
intent: This rule covers any thrust or power augmentation that injects a fluid into the engine (for example, water or water–methanol used on some older turbojets/turbofans or turboprops to boost take-off thrust). It ensures the system reliably delivers the correct flow and pressure whenever it is used, that freezing of the fluid cannot damage the aircraft or degrade performance, and that tanks, vents, and drains are structurally sound and functional under all conditions. Tanks must tolerate vibration, loads, and internal pressure with margin, include effective venting and a small expansion volume to prevent inadvertent overfill/thermal expansion issues, and have proper drains if the fluid can freeze. Finally, the available fluid quantity must be sufficient for the approved procedures and performance, accounting for maximum approved flow rate, ambient temperature effects on engine output, and other consumption variables.
events: Programme lesson — Early Boeing 707 and Douglas DC‑8 water‑injection operations: FAA type design records and flight manuals document specific water‑injection flow/pressure and minimum onboard quantities required for rated take‑off thrust. This shows why CS 25.945 demands proven flow delivery and sufficient tank capacity sized to the approved procedures.

Programme lesson — Boeing 727 water‑injection (ADI) procedures: Boeing 727 Flight Crew/Systems manuals describe a water‑injection system with low‑flow indications and crew requirements to reject take‑off if proper flow/pressure is not achieved, and specify water–methanol mixes and post‑use draining to prevent freezing. This illustrates the rule’s emphasis on guaranteed flow, freezing resilience, and compliant drains/venting.

Programme lesson — Pratt & Whitney JT3C/JT8D service guidance on water/methanol systems: manufacturer documents and service bulletins address winterization, venting, expansion space, and drainage to prevent line/tank damage or flow loss due to freezing. This underpins CS 25.945 requirements for tank strength, vent effectiveness, expansion space, and drains when the fluid can freeze.

summary: The logic is simple: guarantee continuous, adequate fuel flow and pressure to the engines—even with aerated, water‑laden, and iced fuel—so the engines don’t roll back or flame out during any expected operation or maneuver.
intent: This rule’s purpose is to make sure the fuel system always delivers enough fuel, at the right pressure, for the engines to run properly in all realistic conditions and maneuvers. It also requires the system to tolerate some air getting into the fuel (from sloshing, pump transitions, or low fuel) without causing an engine flameout (loss of combustion). Finally, it demands that the system keep working when the fuel contains dissolved and free water and then gets very cold, so that ice crystals or ice accretions do not block filters, heat exchangers, or pump inlets. In short, the system must be robust to low fuel states, transients, and fuel icing so thrust is maintained whenever the engine is allowed to operate.
events: British Airways Flight 38 (Boeing 777‑200ER, 17 Jan 2008, London Heathrow): after long cold soak, ice crystals from water‑saturated Jet A‑1 accumulated and then restricted fuel flow through the fuel–oil heat exchanger, causing both engines to lose thrust on approach (AAIB Report 1/2010). It shows CS 25.951(c)’s purpose: the fuel system must sustain flow/pressure with water and icing present so engines don’t roll back or flame out.

Programme lesson and corrective action: FAA AD 2008‑21‑01 (with parallel EASA ADs) mandated Rolls‑Royce Trent 800 FOHE redesign after in‑service rollback events from ice‑restricted fuel flow revealed by BA38. This embodies CS 25.951’s intent by forcing design changes that ensure sustained fuel delivery with cold, water‑laden fuel.

summary: The logic is simple: prove with analysis and representative testing that the fuel system works across all probable conditions, and show that any likely heat‑exchanger failure involving fuel cannot make the airplane unsafe.
intent: Ensure the airplane’s fuel system is proven to work safely in all expected, real-life conditions by doing a rigorous analysis and any tests the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) deems necessary, using either the actual aircraft system or a representative test rig. It also requires that if a heat exchanger that uses fuel as one of its fluids (e.g., a fuel‑oil heat exchanger, FOHE) fails in any likely way, the failure must not create a hazardous condition such as loss of thrust, fire, fluid cross‑contamination, or uncontrolled leakage.
events: British Airways Flight 38 (Boeing 777-200ER, 17 Jan 2008, Heathrow): Dual engine rollback from ice restricting the Rolls‑Royce Trent 800 fuel‑oil heat exchanger led to FOHE redesigns and added cold‑soak/ice testing—exactly the kind of analysis and representative testing CS 25.952(a) compels to prevent hazardous loss of thrust.

Japan Airlines Boeing 787 JA829J fuel leak at Boston Logan (7 Jan 2013): A faulty fuel valve/logic allowed substantial ramp fuel spillage, prompting ADs and system updates—underscoring the need to validate fuel system operation with real or representative hardware across plausible scenarios per CS 25.952(a).

summary: The logic is simple: don’t let any single failure, leak, fire, blockage, or isolation action in the fuel system take down more than one engine’s fuel supply.
intent: Ensure that a failure, leak, fire, blockage, or crew action affecting the fuel supply for one engine cannot simultaneously deprive any other engine of fuel. In plain terms, each engine must be able to get fuel through its own segregated path, or the applicant must show by another acceptable means that a single fault cannot knock out multiple engines. This traces to CS 25.903(b), which requires engine installations to minimize hazards to the airplane: fuel is a key hazard path, so lines, pumps, filters, valves, and controls must be arranged so a single failure or isolation action doesn’t cascade. Crossfeed may exist for abnormal use, but it must not create a single point that can starve multiple engines. EASA (European Union Aviation Safety Agency) Certification Specifications (CS) demand either true physical independence or an equivalent level of safety demonstrated by analysis, test, and protective features.
events: Air Transat Flight 236 (A330, 24 Aug 2001): A maintenance-induced fuel leak on the right side, combined with crossfeed, drained fuel from both sides, leading to dual engine flameout and a deadstick landing at Lajes. It shows why systems must be arranged so one-side leaks or actions cannot starve all engines, reinforcing the need for independent feeds and safeguarded crossfeed logic.

British Airways Flight 38 (B777, 17 Jan 2008): Ice crystals in fuel caused restriction in both engines’ fuel-oil heat exchangers, leading to thrust rollback on both engines short of Heathrow. It illustrates how common-mode vulnerabilities in fuel delivery can disable multiple engines, underscoring the rule’s intent to prevent multi-engine loss from a single cause and to require design mitigations.

Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 4 Nov 2010): An uncontained engine failure severed fuel lines and caused multiple fuel system warnings, yet isolation and segregation measures kept other engines supplied and the aircraft landed safely. It demonstrates why independent engine fuel feeds and effective shutoff/isolation are critical to preventing cascading loss of thrust.

summary: The logic is simple: design the fuel system so lightning cannot ignite vapours even with a single failure, and then lock in and maintain those protective features with mandatory configuration controls and inspections.
intent: Ensure fuel tanks and all connected fuel-system parts cannot ignite from lightning. The rule requires designs to prevent catastrophic ignition of fuel vapours from direct or swept lightning attachment and from lightning-induced electrical surges, even when combined with a credible single failure. It defines what a “critical lightning strike” is, broadens “fuel system” to include structures and penetrations into tanks, and sets a very high safety target (extremely improbable). To make the protection durable in service, it mandates Critical Design Configuration Control Limitations (CDCCLs) and Airworthiness Limitations—mandatory inspections, tests, and replacement intervals—so that bonding, shielding, sealants, fastener treatments, surge vent devices, and other lightning-protection features are preserved throughout the aircraft’s life.
events: Pan Am Flight 214 (Boeing 707, 1963): A lightning strike ignited fuel vapour in a wing tank, causing in‑flight breakup near Elkton, Maryland; this directly drove tougher fuel tank lightning bonding and vent/flame arrestor standards, illustrating why CS 25.954 demands prevention of lightning-caused ignition.

TWA Flight 800 (Boeing 747-131, 1996): A center wing tank explosion from an internal ignition source (wiring/energy transient) led to SFAR 88 and the adoption of CDCCLs/ALIs to preserve ignition-prevention features; this underpins CS 25.954(d)’s requirement to control and maintain lightning-protection features over the life of the aircraft.

EASA AD 2020-0068 (Airbus A350): Disbonding/cracks in expanded copper foil on composite wings reduced lightning strike protection, with risk of fuel tank ignition; the mandated inspections and repairs show why CS 25.954 requires continuing airworthiness controls to keep lightning-protection features effective.

summary: The logic is simple: size, arrange, and prove the fuel system so each engine always receives the required flow and pressure—without pilot intervention—even when a tank empties, a pump fails, or a flowmeter is blocked, and prove it with near-empty tanks using both main and emergency pumps.
intent: Ensure every engine always gets enough fuel, at the pressure its engine type certificate (TC) specifies, during all intended operations and manoeuvres, even with low fuel, component failures, or transient conditions. Demonstrations must be done near “empty” (only unusable fuel plus what is needed for the test), first with the main pumps and then with the emergency pumps substituted, to prove redundancy. If a fuel flowmeter exists, the system must still pass with the meter blocked (using its bypass) to show a failure cannot choke the engine feed. Where an engine can draw from more than one tank, the design must automatically prevent any interruption of that engine’s feed when one supplying tank runs dry, without flight crew action, provided another tank that normally feeds that engine has usable fuel. AMC means Acceptable Means of Compliance.
events: British Airways Flight 38 (Boeing 777-200ER, 17 Jan 2008): Ice crystals in cold-soaked fuel restricted the fuel–oil heat exchanger, causing both engines to roll back on short final. The event drove design changes and shows why regulations demand proven fuel flow/pressure margins under adverse, real-world conditions and line restrictions.

Delta Air Lines Flight 18 (Boeing 777-200, 13 Nov 2008): A Trent 800 experienced thrust rollback in cruise due to fuel-ice accumulation similar to BA38, leading to ADs mandating FOHE modification. It reinforces that the fuel system must reliably deliver required flow under cold-fuel, high-demand conditions.

Post–TWA Flight 800 aftermath (Boeing transport fleet, from 1996 onward): FAA/EASA ADs introduced automatic center-tank pump shutoff and revised feed logic on several Boeing models. This ensured that when a center tank depletes, feed automatically reverts to wing tanks without crew action, preventing transient starvation consistent with CS 25.955(b)(2).

summary: The logic is simple: if you can pump fuel into another tank in flight, you must guarantee that any overfill is harmlessly vented or stopped before it can pressurize and damage the tank structure.
intent: This rule ensures that when fuel can be moved between tanks in flight, the tanks and their venting/transfer hardware are designed so an overfill cannot damage the structure. In plain terms: if a pump or transfer valve keeps sending fuel into a tank that is already full, the system must automatically limit or safely relieve the pressure/volume (via vents, surge tanks, and automatic shutoffs) so the tank, wing skins, or stabilizer tanks are not overstressed. CS-25 (Certification Specifications for Large Aeroplanes) and EASA (European Union Aviation Safety Agency) require that vent systems keep tank pressure within safe limits during any transfer scenario, including failures or crew error. The intent is to prevent structural deformation, cracking, or rupture from hydraulic overpressure or liquid hammer during inadvertent overfill, and to route overflow harmlessly to surge tanks/vents rather than into primary structure.
events: Industry programme lesson – SFAR 88/JAA–EASA Fuel Tank Safety reviews (circa 1999–2009): Fleet-wide assessments identified overfill/overpressure scenarios from fuel transfer and refuel operations, prompting design changes like surge tank capacity checks, vent/float-valve improvements, and automatic transfer cutouts—exactly the protections CS 25.957 demands.

Airbus A330/A340 Horizontal Stabilizer (trim) tank overfill/venting AD campaign (multiple EASA ADs in the mid‑2000s to early 2010s): In-service events showed that transfer logic or vent issues could overfill the HTP tank and vent fuel; regulators mandated FCMC software and vent system modifications to avoid overpressure and structural risk, illustrating the need for robust venting during transfers.

ATR 72 family – fuel vent/overflow incidents leading to EASA ADs on vent/float valves and surge tank arrangements: Service history documented fuel spillage via vents and potential tank pressurization during transfer/refuel; mandated modifications improved venting and overflow management to protect structure, aligning with CS 25.957’s intent.

summary: The logic is simple: determine, with an intact system, the fuel level where the engine first misbehaves under worst normal feed conditions and call everything below it unusable so crews don’t plan on it.
intent: This rule ensures that only fuel that can actually reach the engines in real flight is counted as usable. For each tank, the manufacturer must flight-test the system and find the minimum fuel at which the engine first begins to stumble, surge, or lose pressure when the airplane is flown in the most demanding yet normal attitudes and manoeuvres (pitch, roll, yaw/sideslip, accelerations) expected in service. Anything below that point is declared “unusable fuel.” The test assumes a healthy fuel system (no component failures), so the unusable quantity reflects true system/geometry limits like slosh, unporting of pickups, and aeration. The result is published so dispatchers and pilots, and the Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM), never plan on fuel that can’t be delivered.
events: Tuninter Flight 1153 (ATR 72-202, 6 Aug 2005): a mis-installed fuel-quantity indicator led to takeoff with insufficient usable fuel; both engines flamed out and the aircraft ditched. The case underscores why certification and operations must distinguish clearly between fuel that is truly deliverable versus what an indication or total quantity might suggest.

FAA AC 25-7D (Flight Test Guide for Transport Category Airplanes) explicitly prescribes establishing unusable fuel by flying worst-case attitudes/manoeuvres until the first evidence of engine malfunction. This programme guidance operationalizes CS/FAR 25.959’s purpose: to prevent reliance on fuel that cannot be delivered in real flight conditions.

CS 25.1585 and AFM practice require publishing usable fuel quantities that exclude the unusable fuel established by CS 25.959. This ensures dispatch and in-service fuel management never plan on fuel that will unport or aerate during takeoff, approach, or manoeuvres.

summary: The logic is simple: keep the entire fuel feed path positively pressurised with hot fuel so it cannot boil, or prove it by a worst‑case hot‑fuel climb showing no vapour lock or malfunction.
intent: CS-25.961 (EASA Certification Specification for Large Aeroplanes) ensures that, in hot weather, the fuel system always delivers liquid fuel to the engines without interruption. Hot fuel can boil and form vapour bubbles (“vapour lock”), causing pump cavitation, loss of pressure, engine surges, or flameout. The rule requires the applicant to show the fuel system is kept positively pressurised from tank outlets to each engine under all intended operations, or to prove it by a hot‑fuel climb test to the aeroplane’s maximum operating altitude with prescribed power settings and conditions (e.g., fuel at least 110 F, full-fuel weight). Tests may be flown or done on the ground with realistic hot‑day simulation. The safety objective is simple: protect engine feed integrity in heat by preventing vapour formation and fuel system malfunctions.
events: Boeing 787 hot‑weather testing at Yuma, Arizona (publicly reported by Boeing in 2010–2011) exposed the aircraft to ambient temperatures above 110 F to verify systems including fuel feed during ground soak and climbs. Demonstrating stable engine operation without pump or pressure anomalies directly shows compliance with the hot‑fuel, no‑vapour‑lock intent of CS 25.961.

Airbus A350 XWB hot‑weather trials at Al Ain, UAE, in 2014 (public Airbus reports) included ground hot‑soak and flight climbs in temperatures above 40 C. The absence of fuel system malfunctions during these tests illustrates the rule’s purpose: proving that hot fuel will not vapour‑lock and interrupt engine feed.

FAA AD 2002‑24‑51 and subsequent directives for Boeing 737 center tank fuel pumps addressed pump cavitation/overheat when inlet pressure was insufficient, conditions aggravated by fuel vapour. This programme lesson underlines why transport fuel systems must maintain positive pressure to keep pumps flooded and prevent vapour formation and malfunctions — exactly what CS 25.961 seeks to ensure in hot conditions.

summary: The logic is simple: design and install fuel tanks so they don’t fail, leak, or feed a fire under operational loads or foreseeable survivable crash/tear‑away/debris scenarios, while remaining inspectable and protected against pressure and fire.
intent: CS-25.963 ensures that fuel tanks and their installations are robust and crashworthy so fuel does not become an ignition source or fire feed in otherwise survivable events. It requires tanks to withstand operational loads, vibration, and inertia; flexible liners to be suitable; integral tanks to be inspectable/repairable; and installations to resist rupture, crushing/scraping, and tear‑away of engines or landing gear. It adds debris tolerance (tyre/wheel fragments, uncontained engine or APU [auxiliary power unit] failures, runway debris), fire-resistant access covers, and failsafe pressure control for pressurised tanks. The overarching aim is to prevent hazardous leakage and post‑accident fire by prescribing performance‑based load cases and protective features around wings, fuselage, and engines. (EASA = European Union Aviation Safety Agency; CS = Certification Specifications.)
events: Air France Flight 4590 (Concorde), 25 July 2000: a tyre burst launched debris that ruptured a wing fuel tank, releasing fuel that ignited and led to loss of the aircraft. This illustrates why CS 25.963(e)(1) demands resistance (by analysis/test) to tyre/wheel and runway debris penetration to avoid hazardous leaks and fire.

Qantas Flight 32 (Airbus A380), 4 Nov 2010: an uncontained engine failure sent fragments through the wing, puncturing systems and causing significant fuel leaks that were contained without catastrophic fire. This event shows the need for fuel tank/installations tolerant to engine/APU debris and controlled leakage paths per CS 25.963(e)(1).

British Airways Flight 38 (Boeing 777), 17 Jan 2008: a short landing with gear collapse and engine separations resulted in no major post‑crash fire, aided by frangible mounts and tank/structure that did not rupture. This outcome demonstrates CS 25.963(d)(4)–(5) intent to prevent fuel spillage and fire during ground scraping and engine/gear tear‑away in survivable accidents.

summary: The logic is simple: prove by representative pressure, slosh, and vibration tests (or analysis where allowed) that the installed fuel tank will not leak or fail under the worst loads it will ever see in service.
intent: This rule ensures that the aeroplane’s fuel tanks, as installed, can withstand all realistic loads without failing or leaking. It requires proof (by test or analysis) that tanks tolerate internal pressure from vent/ram air, transient pressures from fuel slosh during acceleration and roll, and severe vibration representative of service. Special rocking-and-vibration tests address metallic tanks with large flat panels that could oil-can or crack, and non-metallic tanks must be proven at elevated fuel temperature to capture material softening/creep. Pressurised tanks must withstand their maximum on-ground and in-flight pressures. The intent is to prevent structural failure or leakage that could lead to fuel starvation or fire. Acronyms: EASA = European Union Aviation Safety Agency; CS = Certification Specification; AMC = Acceptable Means of Compliance; kPa = kilopascal; psi = pounds per square inch.
events: Air France Flight 4590 (Concorde), 25 July 2000: runway debris punctured the wing tank and fuel spray ignited, causing a fatal fire; Concorde was retrofitted with Kevlar tank liners to better resist rupture and spray, underscoring the certification goal of keeping fuel contained under severe loads.

NASA SP-106 “Liquid Sloshing Dynamics” (Abramson, 1966) and follow-on FAA/NASA research showed that acceleration and roll can create transient pressure spikes and impact loads on tank walls; this evidence underpins codified slosh/rocking and vibration tests like those in CS 25.965 to prevent leakage from dynamic fluid loads.

summary: The logic is simple: support and protect the tank to prevent wear and leaks, keep heat and ignition sources away, ventilate adjacent bays so vapors cannot build up, and seal tanks away from people.
intent: This rule ensures fuel tanks are installed so they do not leak, chafe, or overheat, and that any fuel vapors cannot collect or reach passengers. Tanks must be structurally supported so fuel weight does not concentrate loads, with non‑absorbent padding and smooth surfaces to avoid wearing through tanks or liners. If a flexible “bladder” liner is used, it must be supported so it never has to resist fuel hydrostatic loads. Spaces next to tanks (dry bays) must be ventilated so minor leaks do not let fumes build up or create pressure changes with altitude. Tank locations must comply with the flammable‑fluid fire‑protection rules (CS 25.1185(a)), keeping tanks away from designated fire zones and hot outlets. Engine nacelle hot‑air/exhaust outlets may not double as tank walls. Finally, tanks must be sealed off from crew/passenger areas by fuel‑ and fume‑proof barriers to protect occupants.
events: TWA Flight 800 (1996, Boeing 747‑131): the center wing tank exploded from ignition of fuel vapors, with heat from air‑conditioning packs contributing to a flammable environment; this drove fuel‑tank safety reforms and illustrates why tank installations must minimize heating, manage vapors, and segregate tanks from ignition sources.

Thai Airways International Flight 114 (2001, Boeing 737‑400): an explosion of the center wing tank while parked at Bangkok was linked to a fuel‑air mixture ignited by electrical wiring, exacerbated by pack heating under the tank; it underscores the need for tank placement away from hot outlets and for ventilated adjacent spaces to prevent fume accumulation.

China Airlines Flight 120 (2007, Boeing 737‑800): a loose slat‑track bolt punctured the right wing tank after landing, causing a large fuel leak and fire; it demonstrates why tank installations must avoid chafing/contact with hardware and provide protective, smooth interfaces that prevent wear‑through and leakage.

summary: The logic is simple: always leave at least 2% ullage and make it impossible to fill it during normal ground fueling so heat-driven expansion or fueling surges don’t push fuel out of the tank or overload the structure.
intent: Ensure every transport-category airplane fuel tank has a minimum empty volume (ullage) equal to at least 2% of its capacity to safely absorb fuel thermal expansion and fueling surges. This prevents liquid fuel from being forced into vents or out of the tank in normal ground attitude, avoiding structural overpressure, hazardous spillage on the wing/ramp, fire risk, and environmental contamination. The rule also requires that, in routine ground conditions, crews and ground staff cannot inadvertently fill that ullage. For pressure fueling systems, the automatic level control, shutoff, and surge/vent provisions used to meet CS 25.979(b) can be used to show this requirement is met.
events: EASA SIB 2009-35R1 (Precautions during aircraft refuelling/defuelling) was issued after multiple ramp fires where fuel vapour from spills/overfills ignited, often from APU exhausts; it highlights why preventing inadvertent overfill and maintaining expansion space reduces spillage and ignition hazards.

summary: The logic is simple: trap water at a defined low point, make sure it gets there, and give crews a secure, accessible way to drain it so engines don’t ingest it.
intent: The rule ensures fuel tanks handle unavoidable water contamination safely. A sump (a low point in the tank) must be large enough to collect free water, the tank geometry must let hazardous water flow to that sump on the ground, and there must be an accessible drain to remove it completely and safely. The drain must discharge clear of the airplane and have a positive locking feature (manual or automatic) so it cannot leak or open unintentionally. The objective is to keep water from reaching engines or pumps, preventing power loss, fuel icing blockages, corrosion, and microbial growth, while enabling routine ground sampling/draining by maintenance and flight crews.
events: British Airways Flight 38 (B777-200ER, London Heathrow, 2008; AAIB Report 1/2010): Ice crystals formed from small amounts of water in Jet A‑1 accumulated and later restricted the fuel‑oil heat exchanger, causing thrust rollback—showing why robust water management (collection, drainage, and prevention of carry‑over) is critical from the tank onward.

FAA Advisory Circular AC 20-125 “Water in Aviation Fuels” (1985): Summarizes industry experience with power‑loss events from water contamination and recommends design and operational controls, including tank low‑point sumps and accessible drains—directly supporting CS 25.971’s requirements.

UK CAA CAP 748 “Aircraft Fuel Uplift and Quality Control” (current): Documents service occurrences and prescribes low‑point sampling/draining at aircraft and fuel installations, demonstrating the operational reliance on accessible sump drains to keep water out of aircraft fuel systems.

summary: The logic is simple: contain fuel at the tank, drain any spillage away from the airframe, seal the cap, and bond the aircraft to the refueler so a static spark cannot ignite vapors during refueling.
intent: This rule ensures fuel only goes where it belongs (inside the tank) and that refueling does not create fire or structural hazards. It requires: physical arrangements that stop fuel from entering the airframe or compartments; drains in any recessed filler “well” so spilled fuel is led safely away from the aircraft; a cap that seals tightly so fuel and vapors cannot leak or siphon; and an electrical bonding point so the aircraft can be connected to the refueler to equalize static electricity and prevent sparks. In plain terms: keep fuel contained, keep any spillage off the airplane, and remove ignition sources at the filler.
events: TWA Flight 800 (1996, Boeing 747-131): The center wing tank explosion drove SFAR 88/CS-25 ignition-prevention philosophy, reinforcing why fuel interfaces (including filler points and caps) must not permit vapor release or electrical energy that could ignite fuel.

NFPA 407 and FAA AC 150/5230-4B (Airport Fuel Storage, Handling, Training, and Dispensing): These widely adopted standards mandate aircraft–refueler bonding and proper drainage of fueling wells, reflecting lessons from multiple documented ramp refueling fires caused by static discharge and pooled fuel.

JIG Standard 1 and IATA IFQP procedures: Industry programs require bonding before opening the cap, continuous nozzle–filler contact, and verification of cap integrity, explicitly targeting spills and static-spark ignitions at filler connections that CS 25.973 is designed to prevent.

summary: The logic is simple: let tanks breathe without leaking, siphoning, or over/under-pressurizing, keep ice/dirt and fumes out, place outlets safely, and stop external flames from entering the tank long enough to protect people.
intent: This rule ensures each fuel tank can “breathe” safely and predictably in all normal conditions, and that its vent system does not create new hazards. Tanks must vent from the expansion space so pressure stays within safe limits during flight, rapid climbs/descents, and refuelling/defuelling. The vents must resist blockage by dirt, water, or ice; be routed and drained to avoid water traps; and be arranged to prevent fuel siphoning overboard. Airspaces of tanks that share outlets must be interconnected to equalize pressure. Vent and drain outlets must be located so spilled fuel is not a fire hazard and fumes cannot enter occupied areas. Critically, vents must include protection (e.g., flame arresters) that prevents external flames from propagating into the tank vapour space for at least 2 minutes 30 seconds, buying time for evacuation and firefighting. AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance) 25.975(a)(7) details acceptable test methods for this flame-propagation protection.
events: TWA Flight 800 (Boeing 747-131, 17 July 1996): A center wing tank fuel–air explosion destroyed the aircraft, driving SFAR 88 and the FAA’s fuel tank flammability reduction rule; it underscores why regulations demand robust explosion prevention, including blocking flame paths such as vents.

Emirates Flight 521 (Boeing 777-300, Dubai, 3 Aug 2016): After a crash landing and evacuation, a fuel tank explosion occurred minutes later during the post‑crash fire, killing a firefighter; this illustrates why vent systems must delay flame ingress from external fires to provide evacuation and response time.

FAA Final Rule, Reduction of Fuel Tank Flammability in Transport Category Airplanes (73 FR 42444, 21 July 2008): Post‑TWA 800 programmatic action mandated explosion‑prevention measures (e.g., inerting, ignition source control) and reinforced scrutiny of vent systems, demonstrating the regulatory aim that vents must not become an ignition propagation path.

summary: The logic is simple: put a big, easy-to-clean screen at each tank outlet so debris stays out of the fuel system and, even if the screen partly clogs, the engines still get enough fuel.
intent: Ensure every tank feeds clean, unobstructed fuel to the engines and pumps by stopping debris at the tank outlet with a large-area, maintainable screen. The rule requires a strainer (at the tank outlet or booster pump) that blocks any foreign object debris (FOD) that could reduce flow or harm components, with enough open area (≥5 times the outlet line area) and diameter (no smaller than the outlet) to minimise pressure drop even if partly fouled. It also mandates access to “finger strainers” for inspection and cleaning so contamination (sealant slivers, microbial sludge, loose hardware) can be removed before it migrates downstream and causes pump cavitation, filter clogging, or engine flameout. In short, it is a flow-assurance and maintainability requirement to keep fuel delivery reliable.
events: Boeing 737 MAX fuel-tank FOD findings (2020): Boeing paused deliveries after discovering foreign object debris in multiple stored aircraft fuel tanks. The incident shows debris can remain in tanks and migrate; outlet strainers and required accessibility provide an immediate barrier and a maintenance path to remove FOD before it damages pumps or restricts flow.

British Airways Flight 38, Boeing 777-200ER (Heathrow, 2008): Both engines rolled back due to fuel-flow restriction when ice crystals clogged the fuel–oil heat exchanger. Although the restriction occurred downstream, it demonstrates how any upstream blockage can cause severe power loss—exactly why CS 25.977 mandates large-area outlet strainers to prevent solids from initiating flow restrictions.

FAA SAFO 18015 (2018) – Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) contamination events: Multiple business jets experienced engine power loss after DEF-contaminated fuel formed crystals that clogged fuel filters. These events underscore the hazard of particulate contamination blocking fuel paths and the need for effective, maintainable strainers at the tank outlet to intercept debris and support timely inspection/cleaning.

summary: The logic is simple: prevent overfilling and hazardous leaks, detect/indicate shutoff failures, and make the fuelling/defuelling plumbing strong enough to survive real surge/suction loads so spills, fires, and structural damage don’t happen.
intent: Ensure that pressure fuelling and defuelling on large aeroplanes are inherently safe, spill‑resistant, and structurally robust. The rule requires: fail‑safe manifold connections so a failed fuel entry valve cannot discharge hazardous amounts of fuel; an automatic high‑level shutoff in each tank that can be function‑checked (“pre‑check”) before every fuelling and that clearly indicates any shutoff failure at the fuelling station; design features that prevent system damage if the shutoff does fail; and fuel/defuel plumbing strong enough to withstand twice the maximum likely operating pressures, including transient “surge” or “water‑hammer” loads with any combination of valves intentionally or inadvertently closed. It also requires similar strength margins for defuelling, including protection against excessive suction (negative pressure). Overall, it aims to prevent overfill, spills, fires, environmental releases, and structural damage during high‑rate pressure fuelling/defuelling.
events: Air India Express B737-800 at Muscat (2017): A fire broke out during refuelling and passengers were evacuated; reports cited fuel on the apron as a key hazard, underscoring why automatic shutoff, failure indication, and containment of hazardous quantities are critical.

Pegasus Airlines B737-800 at Istanbul Sabiha Gökçen (2012): A refuelling‑phase fire on the stand drew emergency response; media and airport reports highlighted fuel present on the ramp, illustrating the risk from overfill/valve failures and the need for robust shutoff and leak‑prevention measures.

Industry lesson – hydrant pressure surges: JIG/API fuel standards and airport safety bulletins document multiple incidents where rapid valve closures created surge (“water‑hammer”) loads that damaged hoses/couplers; CS 25.979(d)/(e) codifies designing aircraft fuelling/defuelling plumbing to withstand 2× these surge/suction loads.

summary: The logic is simple: remove ignition sources, reduce the time fuel vapours are flammable, and lock those protections into maintenance so an explosion cannot occur over the aircraft’s life.
intent: Keep fuel tanks from ever exploding. The rule requires you to eliminate ignition sources inside tanks (including under failures, ageing, and manufacturing variation), keep the fuel vapour environment non‑flammable as far as practical, and then preserve those protections for the life of the fleet through locked‑down maintenance controls. It sets a clear temperature margin below the fuel’s auto‑ignition point, demands design and failure‑tolerance so a single fault (or credible combinations) can’t create a spark or hot surface, and caps fleet‑average flammability exposure at very low levels unless you can prove a tank blast would not prevent safe flight and landing. Where needed, Flammability Reduction Means (FRM), such as nitrogen inerting, must meet dedicated performance rules, and Critical Design Configuration Control Limitations (CDCCLs) plus specific inspection/replacement intervals must be embedded in the Instructions for Continued Airworthiness (ICA) so maintenance and alterations don’t erode safety. Acronyms: FRM = Flammability Reduction Means; CDCCL = Critical Design Configuration Control Limitation; ICA = Instructions for Continued Airworthiness; FQIS = Fuel Quantity Indicating System.
events: TWA Flight 800 (Boeing 747‑131), 17 July 1996: An explosion of the center wing tank destroyed the aircraft; NTSB found ignition of a flammable fuel‑air mixture, likely from FQIS wiring arcing, with heat from air‑conditioning packs increasing flammability. This tragedy directly drove the modern fuel tank safety rules to eliminate ignition sources, manage tank temperatures, and reduce flammability exposure.

Philippine Airlines Flight 143 (Boeing 737‑300), 11 May 1990: A ground explosion of the center wing tank at Manila killed and injured occupants; investigators concluded ignition of flammable vapours in a near‑empty tank, likely from electrical arcing associated with tank systems. It highlighted how low‑fuel, heated center tanks and degraded wiring can create catastrophic ignition—precisely what CS 25.981 targets.

FAA SFAR 88 (2001) and the EASA Fuel Tank Safety program: Regulators mandated design reviews and issued widespread ADs introducing CDCCLs, Airworthiness Limitations, wiring/pump modifications, and—in many cases—nitrogen inerting. This programme lesson shows that design plus disciplined maintenance controls are both essential to sustain the no‑ignition/low‑flammability intent of CS 25.981.

summary: The logic is simple: design pumps so a failed positive-displacement unit can be bypassed and ensure each engine has an immediate alternate pump so fuel flow is never interrupted by a single pump failure.
intent: CS-25 (EASA Certification Specifications for Large Aeroplanes) 25.991 ensures that no single failure of a fuel pump can interrupt fuel flow to an engine. It does this in two ways: (1) any positive displacement (PD) pump in the aircraft fuel system must have a bypass so, if it seizes or is stopped, fuel can flow around it instead of being blocked; and (2) each engine must have an immediate alternate source of pressurised fuel (an emergency pump or another main pump) if a main pump fails. A PD pump moves a fixed volume per revolution and can act like a plug when failed; a bypass is a parallel path (often via a check/relief valve) that lets fuel continue to the engine. The fuel injection pump that is part of the engine is excluded because its failure modes are managed under engine certification. The intent is uninterrupted, safe fuel delivery despite a single pump failure.
events: TWA Flight 800 (Boeing 747-131, 1996) – the center wing tank exploded, with the NTSB concluding an electrical short likely ignited vapors via wiring associated with fuel tank systems and pump circuits; subsequent ADs mandated pump auto-shutoff and dry-run protections. This illustrates why fuel pump failure modes must be inherently safe and not jeopardize fuel delivery, reinforcing CS 25.991’s focus on benign pump failures and alternate supply paths.

Qantas Flight 32 (Airbus A380, 2010) – an uncontained engine failure damaged parts of the fuel system, yet redundant pumps and crossfeeds kept the remaining engines supplied and the aircraft landed safely. The event demonstrates the safety value of immediate alternate fuel feeding capability after a single component/pump loss, as required by CS 25.991.

summary: The logic is simple: support and route fuel lines to resist vibration and loads, provide flexible approved hoses where things move, keep heat‑sensitive hose away from hot zones, and ensure lines can deform without leaking—so fuel stays inside the system and away from ignition sources.
intent: Keep fuel from leaking and igniting by making the airplane’s fuel lines and fittings mechanically and thermally robust, and tolerant of movement. Lines must be firmly supported against vibration and the loads from fuel pressure and manoeuvres; where parts can move relative to each other (e.g., wing-to-pylon, engine-to-airframe), connections must include designed-in flexibility using suitable, approved hose assemblies. Flexible hoses must be appropriate for the specific use and not degraded by the high temperatures found around engines or after heat soak when an engine is shut down. Inside the fuselage, fuel lines must accommodate reasonable structural deformation without leaking. In plain terms, the rule aims to prevent fuel spray or pooling from cracked, chafed, overheated, or overstressed lines—major precursors to fires—across all normal and foreseeable operating and maintenance conditions.
events: Air Transat Flight 236 (A330-243, 2001): Investigators (GPIAA with TSB Canada) found mis-installed hydraulic lines chafed the right engine fuel feed tube, causing a fatigue crack and massive fuel leak that led to dual engine flameout. It shows why fuel lines must be properly supported/isolated from relative motion and use suitable flexible connections to prevent chafing and rupture.

British Airways A319 G-EUOE (BA762, London Heathrow, 2013): AAIB found unlatched fan cowl doors detached on takeoff and struck the left engine, rupturing a fuel pipe and causing a spray fire on hot engine surfaces. It illustrates the need for approved, heat‑resistant fuel pipes/hoses and robust routing/protection in high‑temperature engine zones to prevent leakage and ignition.

Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 2010): ATSB reported an uncontained engine failure severed multiple fuel and hydraulic lines in the left wing/pylon, producing significant fuel leaks that had to be managed with system isolation and crew actions. The event underscores why design rules demand flexible, well-supported, and suitably rated lines and fittings to withstand loads, vibration, and thermal effects and to limit hazardous leakage.

summary: The logic is simple: design and protect nacelle and fuselage fuel components so that a belly landing doesn’t rupture them and dump fuel that could catch fire.
intent: This rule aims to keep fuel from spilling and igniting if a large airplane has to land with the landing gear retracted (a wheels-up or belly landing) on a paved runway. It requires fuel system parts located in engine nacelles (the housings around engines) and inside the fuselage to be placed, shielded, and/or designed so they won’t be crushed, abraded, or torn open during the slide. The referenced CS 25.721(b) defines the standardized loads and conditions for such a landing. In plain terms: make sure fuel lines, pumps, filters, valves, drains, and fittings near the belly and nacelles are protected or will shut off so that enough fuel cannot leak out to create a fire hazard.
events: LOT Polish Airlines Flight 016 (B767-300ER), Warsaw, 2011: a full wheels-up landing produced sparks but no fuel-fed fire, with reports noting no significant fuel leakage. This demonstrates how protected nacelle/fuselage fuel systems and effective shutoff/containment prevent a fire in a belly landing.

SAS Flight 1209 (Dash 8 Q400), Aalborg, 2007: right main gear collapsed and the aircraft slid on the nacelle/wing, with a post-landing fire on the right side linked to fuel leakage. It shows how ground contact in the nacelle area can damage fuel components and why protection against rupture and spillage is essential.

Ryanair Flight 4102 (B737-800), Rome Ciampino, 2008: severe bird strike led to a hard landing, gear collapse, and nacelle/belly scraping with no major post-landing fuel fire. The absence of a fuel-fed fire underscores the value of locating and shielding fuel components to withstand runway contact.

summary: The logic is simple: mount and brace each fuel valve so that neither valve operation nor flight g‑loads are carried by the attached fuel lines, preventing cracks and leaks.
intent: This rule’s goal is to prevent fuel leaks and fires by making sure each fuel valve (devices that start/stop or route fuel, such as engine shutoff, crossfeed, and jettison valves) is mounted in a way that keeps mechanical loads out of the attached fuel lines. Loads can come from operating the valve (manual or motor torque) or from “accelerated flight conditions” (g-forces during maneuvers, turbulence, takeoff/landing, and gusts). If those loads get transmitted into rigid tubes, fittings, or hoses, they can crack, loosen, or chafe, leading to leaks, engine flameout, or fire. Proper independent support and restraint of the valve isolates the plumbing, preserves sealing integrity, and reduces fire hazards and fuel starvation risks. Paragraph (a) is reserved; paragraph (b) captures the core requirement to support the valve so lines don’t carry those loads.
events: El Al Flight 1862 (Boeing 747-200F, Amsterdam, 1992): engine/pylon separation tore fuel lines, feeding a post-crash fire; investigators highlighted the vulnerability of fuel plumbing to structural and inertial loads, underscoring the need to isolate and robustly support fuel components so lines don’t carry loads.

Qantas Flight 32 (Airbus A380, 2010): an uncontained engine failure severed/ damaged fuel lines in the pylon and wing, causing significant leaks; subsequent design and service actions improved routing/support and shielding of fuel components, illustrating why components must be mechanically supported to protect attached lines from local loads and vibration.

EASA airworthiness directives in the early 2010s for Airbus A320-family addressing cracking of engine low‑pressure fuel shutoff valve support brackets required inspections and reinforcements because bracket failures could transmit loads to rigid tubes and cause leaks; this program experience directly reflects the CS 25.995 intent to keep valve and flight loads out of the lines.

summary: The logic is simple: put a robust, maintainable, properly supported filter near the tank to catch sediment and water before sensitive engine components, and size it so the engine keeps working even with worse‑than‑normal fuel contamination.
intent: Ensure each engine receives clean, uninterrupted fuel by mandating a primary strainer/filter between the tank and the engine’s first sensitive component (fuel metering unit or engine-driven pump). The filter must be easy to drain and clean, have a sediment trap/drain for water and debris, be mounted so it does not overload or crack fuel lines, and be sized so that engine operation is not impaired even when fuel contamination (particle size/density) exceeds the engine’s allowable limits in CS‑E (EASA Certification Specifications for Engines). In short, the rule prevents contaminants (dirt, metallic swarf, microbial sludge, water/ice) from reaching and disabling critical engine fuel components, while ensuring maintainability and structural integrity of the installation.
events: British Airways Flight 38 (Boeing 777‑200ER, 17 Jan 2008): both engines rolled back on approach when ice crystals from cold‑soaked fuel restricted flow at the engine fuel‑oil heat exchanger; subsequent ADs/Mods increased fuel‑system tolerance to contamination, underscoring the need for upstream filtration/robust capacity so contamination does not impair engine operation (CS‑25.997(d)).

NTSB Safety Recommendations A‑09‑11 through ‑13 followed two Boeing 777 single‑engine rollback events in 2008 (e.g., Delta Air Lines Flight 18 and American Airlines Flight 268) attributed to fuel‑borne ice restricting fuel flow; regulators and OEMs implemented design and maintenance changes that highlight the requirement for fuel system components to tolerate contamination and remain functional.

summary: The logic is simple: give the system safe, lockable low‑point drains to purge contaminants, and place/protect them so any discharge is away from the airframe and won’t spill or rupture in a belly landing.
intent: Keep fuel clean and prevent fires or leaks by requiring low-point drains and filter drains that can be safely used and that won’t dump fuel onto the airplane. CS‑25 (Certification Specifications for Large Aeroplanes) requires sump and strainer drains so water, ice, and debris can be removed from tanks and lines; each drain must discharge away from any aircraft part, be positively locked closed so vibration or error can’t open it, be easy to operate for maintenance or sampling, and be located/shielded so a gear‑up (wheels‑retracted) landing doesn’t shear it off and spill fuel. The aim is both contamination control (reliable engine fuel) and fire risk reduction (no pooling on hot or sparking areas).
events: LOT Polish Airlines Flight 016 (2011, Boeing 767) performed a full gear‑up landing in Warsaw without a post‑landing fuel fire; the absence of significant spillage highlighted the value of locating and protecting fuel low‑point hardware so it isn’t torn open in a belly landing.

All Nippon Airways Flight 1603 (2007, DHC‑8‑400) suffered a gear collapse at Kochi and a subsequent fire fed by leaking fuel; the event illustrates how fuel system components vulnerable to ground contact or rupture can drive fire risk, underscoring why drains must be protected and discharge clear of hot/abrasive surfaces.
