TACA Flight 110 (1988, Boeing 737‑300) made a power‑off landing on a levee with no post‑landing fire and no hazardous fuel leakage reported, demonstrating how robust, protected fuel system low points and drains help prevent spillage in abnormal landings.

summary: The logic is simple: only fit fuel-dump gear if needed to meet immediate-return climb performance, and if fitted it must jettison enough fuel quickly and safely under worst conditions without creating fire, contamination, controllability, or reserve-fuel risks.
intent: Ensure that large transport airplanes either do not need a fuel-dump system (because they can safely return and climb after an immediate turn-back at maximum takeoff weight), or, if they do need one, that the system can rapidly dump enough fuel within 15 minutes and do so safely. The rule demands flight-test proof that fuel dumping creates no fire risk, that fuel discharges well clear of the airplane, that fumes don’t enter the cabin or systems, and that the airplane remains controllable while dumping in worst-case conditions (power-off glide, one‑engine‑inoperative climb). It also protects against human error or failures by requiring shutoff capability at any time, warning placards if high‑lift devices affect dump plumes, single-failure tolerance (no dangerous asymmetry or inability to dump), and safeguards against dumping below the reserve needed to go around and then cruise 45 minutes at 10,000 ft. References: CS 25.119 (all-engines landing climb) and CS 25.121(d) (one‑engine‑inoperative approach climb).
events: LOT Polish Airlines Flight 16 (Boeing 767-300ER, Warsaw, 1 Nov 2011) had no fuel jettison system and held to burn fuel before a gear‑up landing. This illustrates the rule’s allowance to omit jettison if the airplane’s performance and reserves can be met without it, shifting the operational mitigation to fuel burn-down.

Delta Air Lines Flight 89 (Boeing 777-200, LAX, 14 Jan 2020) dumped fuel at low altitude with high‑lift devices deployed, dispersing fuel over populated areas and prompting FAA SAFO 20003 on proper fuel‑dump procedures. It underscores the requirement to assess/placard configuration effects on dump plumes and ensure dumping does not create hazards or controllability issues.

Swissair Flight 111 (MD‑11, near Halifax, 2 Sep 1998) began dumping fuel for an overweight landing while managing an in‑flight fire; the time-critical situation highlighted the operational need for rapid, controllable fuel jettison. It supports the rule’s 15‑minute jettison capability and the requirement that dumping not impair control or introduce additional hazards.

summary: The logic is simple: give each engine its own oil supply and make that supply large and cool enough to cover worst-case flight duration and consumption, with extra margin for safe circulation.
intent: Ensure each engine has its own self-sufficient oil system that reliably delivers enough oil, at safe temperatures, for the entire time the airplane must be able to operate in its most demanding conditions. This prevents a single oil system failure or contamination from disabling multiple engines, and it avoids engine damage from oil starvation or overheated oil. The rule also forces designers to size usable oil quantity based on the airplane’s endurance and the engine’s maximum approved oil consumption in those conditions, plus extra margin to keep oil circulating and pickups covered. In plain terms: don’t share oil between engines; keep the oil cool and plentiful enough to protect bearings, gears, and seals for as long as the flight profile demands, with a buffer for real-world variability.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 2010): A fractured Trent 900 oil feed stub pipe caused a massive oil leak, fire, and uncontained engine failure; independent oil systems confined the event to one engine, underscoring why oil systems must be self-contained and robust (EASA AD 2012-0177/FAA AD 2012-06-23 addressed the oil pipe issue).

CF34 regional jet fleet oil-loss events (late 1990s–early 2000s): Multiple in-flight shutdowns from oil filter bowl leakage/separation prompted FAA AD 2003-07-08, demonstrating how oil system integrity and margin are critical to prevent rapid oil depletion and engine failure.

ETOPS policy (FAA AC 120-42B/42C): Requires monitoring of engine oil consumption and sufficient oil quantity for the maximum diversion time, effectively operationalizing CS 25.1011(b)’s premise that usable oil capacity must cover worst-case endurance plus a circulation margin.

summary: The logic is simple: design, vent, and protect the oil tank so oil can expand and flow at all temperatures without spillage or blockage, and ensure you can isolate it in a fire unless the external system is fireproof.
intent: This rule ensures oil tanks on large airplanes are installed and built to keep oil flowing reliably while preventing leaks, over‑pressurisation, contamination, and avoidable fire hazards. It requires oil tanks to meet the same installation safety principles as fuel tanks (e.g., fire protection and safe location), provide dedicated expansion volume (so heated or aerated oil doesn’t overflow), be impossible to overfill inadvertently, seal tightly at the filler, and drain any spillage away from the airframe. Tanks must be vented from the top of the expansion space and routed to avoid water condensation and icing blockages. Outlets must prevent foreign object ingress and avoid restrictive screens that could starve oil flow in cold, viscous conditions, and a shut‑off valve is required at the tank outlet unless the external oil system is fireproof, to help isolate leaks in a fire. Flexible liners must be proven suitable. In short, EASA (European Union Aviation Safety Agency) CS (Certification Specification) 25.1013 aims to maintain oil supply and contain oil as a combustible fluid under all conditions.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (Airbus A380, 4 Nov 2010): A manufacturing defect in a Trent 900 oil feed pipe allowed oil to escape and ignite, leading to an uncontained engine failure—demonstrating why oil systems must prevent leaks and be fire‑protected/isolatable.

EASA Safety Information Bulletins on improperly latched engine oil filler caps (2013 onward): issued after multiple in‑flight shutdowns across fleets due to oil loss from unsecured caps, underscoring the need for oil‑tight caps and filler/drain designs that prevent spillage into the airframe.

summary: The logic is simple: build and test oil tanks to withstand vibration, g‑loads, realistic pressure, and hot oil so they don’t leak or burst and create fire or engine‑failure hazards.
intent: Ensure the aircraft’s oil tanks are structurally robust and leak‑free under real operating stresses. The tanks must survive vibration (engine/airframe shake), inertia loads (g-forces from manoeuvres, turbulence, and landings), and internal fluid loads (sloshing, pressure pulsations) without failure. Because turbine-engine oil systems can be pressurised and operate at high temperature, the regulation tailors proof tests to oil-specific conditions: use hot oil (121°C/250°F) as the test fluid and raise the proof pressure to at least 5 psi above the tank’s maximum operating pressure for pressurised tanks (or at least 5 psi for non-pressurised tanks). By cross‑referencing CS 25.965 (fuel tank test philosophy) and adapting it, the rule aims to prevent oil leaks, tank ruptures, and resulting engine fires or loss of lubrication that could cause engine failure or fire hazards.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 2010): A mis-manufactured oil feed stub pipe on a Rolls‑Royce Trent 900 fractured, spraying hot pressurised oil that ignited and contributed to an uncontained engine failure (ATSB AO‑2010‑089). It shows why oil‑containing hardware must endure pressure, vibration and temperature without leaking, and why proof testing with hot oil and proper margins is critical.

summary: The logic is simple: make oil lines and vents strong and fire-safe, and route breather discharge so it can neither freeze and block, ignite, blind the pilots, nor be sucked into the engine.
intent: This rule ensures that any part of the oil system that can leak, vent, or be exposed to fire is built and routed to prevent fires, loss of visibility, or engine ingestion hazards. Oil lines must meet the same robustness and compatibility standards as fuel lines (strength, vibration, temperature, and fluid compatibility per CS 25.993), and, when located in a “designated fire zone” (areas like engine or APU compartments where fire is credible), they must be fire-resistant and properly protected (per CS 25.1183). Oil breather lines—which vent pressure and oil mist from tanks/gearboxes—must be routed to avoid water condensation low points that can freeze and block the vent, must discharge where any oil mist cannot ignite or contaminate the pilots’ windshield, and must never vent into the engine air intake, where oil ingestion can cause performance anomalies or smoke.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (ATSB AO-2010-089): A fractured Trent 900 oil feed pipe led to an internal oil fire and uncontained engine failure, prompting emergency EASA ADs—demonstrating why oil lines and fittings in fire zones must be built and protected to stringent fire-resistance and integrity standards.

summary: The logic is simple: keep oil flowing and debris contained under all conditions, warn the crew early if filtration is degrading, and design any bypass so it doesn’t flush contaminants into the engine.
intent: Ensure every turbine engine’s oil system has robust, full‑flow filtration that won’t jeopardise lubrication if it clogs, and that gives timely warning before a loss of protection. The filter/strainer must handle worse‑than‑normal contamination (per CS‑E engine limits), and if it has a bypass, oil must still flow at the required rate with the element fully blocked without sweeping trapped debris downstream. If no bypass is used (except at the tank outlet), the installation must tie into the cockpit warning system required by CS 25.1305(c)(7) so crews are alerted. In short: prevent oil starvation and secondary damage from debris, and provide clear indication so the crew can manage the flight and maintenance can correct the condition before it becomes hazardous.
events: Eastern Air Lines Flight 855 (L‑1011, 1983): Maintenance errors left chip detector O‑rings out, oil leaked away, and all three engines lost oil pressure, forcing an emergency landing; it starkly shows that any interruption of lubrication is catastrophic, so filtration must never block oil flow and crews must get clear warnings.

Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 2010): A fractured oil feed stub pipe led to an oil-fed fire and uncontained engine failure; the subsequent contamination and system upset illustrate why bypass paths must be located to avoid sweeping debris into critical bearings and why cockpit indications are essential for managing oil system anomalies.

summary: The logic is simple: provide an easy-to-use drain for maintenance, and make sure it can’t accidentally open in flight, so oil doesn’t leak out and cause an engine failure or fire.
intent: Ensure the oil system can be drained safely for maintenance without creating hazards, and prevent any inadvertent opening or loosening of drain points in service. In plain terms: aircraft engines need a way to empty oil (for servicing, contamination removal, or preservation) that technicians can reach and use safely, while the drain device itself must have a secure "positive lock" (a mechanical means that cannot vibrate or creep open) in the closed position. This protects against oil leaks that could lead to engine oil starvation, overheating, or fires, and avoids spills that endanger people, the aircraft, or the environment.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 2010): An oil feed pipe fractured, causing an internal engine oil fire and an uncontained engine failure; it underscores how any uncontrolled oil release can rapidly escalate, reinforcing the need for reliably secured oil closures like drains (ATSB AO-2010-089).

summary: The logic is simple: make the oil cooler strong enough for real loads and keep its ducts out of any fire plume so the cooler can’t rupture or feed a nacelle fire.
intent: This rule ensures oil coolers (radiators) and their airflow ducts in transport aircraft are robust and fire‑safe. First, the cooler must withstand the real loads it will see—engine vibration, aircraft inertia (g‑loads), and internal oil pressure—without cracking or bursting. Second, its cooling‑air duct must be positioned so that, if an engine‑bay fire occurs, flames exiting normal nacelle openings cannot hit the cooler directly. Oil is a combustible fluid; a weakened or flame‑impinged cooler can rupture and spray hot oil, rapidly escalating a nacelle fire. Meeting this intent protects continued engine operation or safe shutdown, limits fire propagation, and complements the broader fire‑protection standards in Subpart E (e.g., containment and flammable‑fluid control).
events: Qantas Flight 32 (ATSB AO-2010-089, 2010): An oil feed stub pipe manufacturing defect on a Trent 900 led to an internal oil fire and uncontained engine failure, illustrating how oil-fed fires can quickly escalate and why oil-system components, including coolers and their ducts, must be robust and shielded from flame impingement.

summary: The logic is simple: you must be able to isolate oil like any other fire fuel source, still feather a prop if needed, and mount/mark the valve so it can’t be mis-set or damage the oil lines.
intent: Ensure the airplane can quickly and reliably stop the flow of engine oil when needed (e.g., for fire protection), without compromising essential safety functions, and without creating new hazards. Oil shutoff valves must meet the same fire-zone shutoff criteria as other flammable fluid shutoffs (CS 25.1189), propeller aircraft must still be able to “feather” the propeller (turn blades edge‑on to the airflow to cut drag) even if oil is shut off, and the valves must have clear detents/indices and be mounted so operating forces and g‑loads are not transmitted into attached oil lines (to prevent leaks/cracks).
events: Programme lesson – ATR 72/42: The FCOM/AFM describes that pulling the engine fire handle closes the engine oil shutoff valve, while an emergency feathering system with its own reservoir/pump still feathers the propeller. This shows compliance with CS 25.1025(b): oil isolation for fire does not remove the ability to feather and reduce drag.

Programme lesson – DHC‑8 Q400: Bombardier training/system manuals describe electric/accumulator‑assisted feathering that remains available even after the engine oil shutoff valve is closed by the fire handle. This demonstrates the design intent to maintain feather capability with oil isolated, satisfying CS 25.1025(b).

Accident – Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 2010): An internal oil feed stub pipe failure on a Trent 900 led to an oil‑fed engine fire and uncontained failure (ATSB AO‑2010‑089), prompting ADs to address oil system hazards. It underscores why oil is treated as a flammable fluid requiring robust shutoff means per CS 25.1189 and why valves and lines must be durable and properly supported.

summary: The logic is simple: give the feathering pump its own guaranteed clean oil supply and prove it will feather the prop even after an oil-system failure.
intent: Propeller “feathering” turns the blades edge-on to the airflow to cut drag after an engine failure. This rule ensures that, if a feathering system uses engine oil, there is a dedicated reserve of oil trapped in the tank so the propeller can still feather even after a major oil-system failure (e.g., a leak or line rupture). That trapped oil must be reserved solely for the feathering pump, the ability to feather with it must be proven (you can ground‑run using an external oil source to keep the engine lubricated while using the trapped oil to feather), and the system must be protected against sludge or contamination that could block valves or lines. In short, the aircraft must always be able to feather a propeller when needed, regardless of oil loss or dirty oil, to avoid the extreme drag of a windmilling prop and preserve controllability.
events: KLM Cityhopper Flight 433 (Fokker 50, Amsterdam, 4 Apr 1994): after a spurious low oil pressure warning, the crew reduced power but did not feather; during go-around the drag from the windmilling prop contributed to loss of control and crash (Dutch Safety Board report). This illustrates why dependable, readily available feathering is critical to minimize drag after an engine problem.

FAA AD 2002-17-18 (Hartzell Propeller Inc. governors): mandated overhaul/replacement due to contamination/corrosion that could prevent proper pitch control, including failure to feather. This shows how sludge/foreign matter in oil-governed feathering systems can defeat feathering, aligning with CS 25.1027(d)’s contamination-prevention intent.

summary: The logic is simple: the airplane must keep engine parts and fluids cool enough in every phase—including after shutdown—so nothing overheats, degrades, or ignites.
intent: Ensure the engine installation has enough ventilation and heat management so all powerplant parts and fluids (fuel, oil, hydraulics) stay within their approved temperature limits during all ground and flight operations and during heat soak after a normal shutdown. This prevents damage, loss of performance, vapor lock, oil/fuel coking, spurious overheat warnings, and fire risk from hot surfaces. The rule applies to turbine and piston powerplants, including nacelles, cowlings, and accessory bays, and covers worst-case ambient conditions, prolonged taxi/holds, high-bleed use, and the post‑shutdown period when residual heat can spike component and fluid temperatures.
events: Airbus A320neo PW1100G early in-service experience (2016–2018): OEM/operator bulletins introduced minimum idle cool‑down times to mitigate hot‑soak rotor bow and thermal distress; this shows why designs and procedures must control temperatures even after shutdown.

Southwest Airlines Boeing 737 tailpipe fire at John Wayne Airport (June 2016, widely reported video): residual fuel ignited in a hot engine core after shutdown, and crews used dry‑motoring to ventilate and cool—illustrating the need for post‑shutdown cooling provisions.

British Airways A319 G-EUOE, London Heathrow (24 May 2013): an unlatched fan cowl led to a fuel leak that ignited on hot engine surfaces, underscoring why installations must limit surface temperatures and manage nacelle ventilation to reduce ignition risk.

summary: The logic is simple: prove by test (or approved correction) that in worst-case hot weather the engine and powerplant components never exceed temperature limits in any critical ground or flight condition.
intent: Ensure engines and all powerplant systems (oil, fuel, coolers, nacelle bays, APU) stay within temperature limits in the hottest credible conditions. Applicants must prove this by testing under the most critical ground and flight scenarios, using a defined “hot‑day” atmosphere (at least 37.8°C/100°F at sea level with an ISA-like lapse rate to the tropopause). If testing can’t be done at those hot conditions, measured temperatures must be corrected to the defined maximum ambient using a prescribed method, and the corrected values must not exceed limits. This prevents overheating that can lead to fluid breakdown, pump cavitation/vapor lock, bearing distress, and fire risk. For winterized installations intended only for cold climates, a lower maximum ambient may be chosen, reflecting their operational envelope.
events: Programme lesson – Airbus A350 XWB hot‑weather testing (Al Ain, UAE, 2014): Airbus publicly tested the A350 in +40–50°C conditions to validate engine, nacelle, and systems temperatures and margins. This demonstrates why CS 25.1043 requires hot‑day testing/corrections to show all powerplant temperatures remain within limits.

Programme lesson – Boeing 787 hot‑weather testing (Yuma, Arizona, 2010): Boeing conducted dedicated hot‑day trials to verify propulsion and systems thermal behavior and compliance. This shows regulators expect proof that cooling is adequate under defined high‑ambient conditions or by corrected data.

Operational event – Phoenix extreme heat flight cancellations (June 2017): Several U.S. operators cancelled flights at PHX when OAT approached 48°C (118°F), highlighting how extreme ambient temperatures challenge aircraft limits and certification envelopes. It illustrates why CS 25.1043 defines a maximum ambient model and requires showing temperature compliance against it.

summary: The logic is simple: test cooling in each critical flight phase from realistic, worst-case starting conditions, then keep going until temperatures level off or a limit is hit, so you know the system truly copes with real thermal loads and lags.
intent: This rule tells manufacturers exactly how to flight-test the airplane so its engines and powerplant areas (nacelles, accessories, and engine fluids like oil, hydraulic fluid, and any coolant) stay within temperature limits in all critical phases: takeoff, climb, cruise (en-route), and landing. It operationalizes CS 25.1041 (the general cooling requirement) by defining realistic, worst-case test configurations and when a temperature is considered ‘stabilized’ (changing less than 1 °C per minute). It also requires starting each phase from representative entry conditions (including heat-soaked or ground-idle states) and continuing the test until temperatures either stabilize, the phase ends, or a limit is reached. In plain terms, it ensures cooling is proven under the toughest, real-world heat loads and thermal lags so engines and nearby components won’t overheat or exceed limits during normal operations.

summary: The logic is simple: make sure the engine always gets steady, clean air while the intake is kept isolated from fires and protected against fuel, water/slush, and debris, and prove the intake hardware won’t fail hazardously when real-world ingestion happens.
intent: This rule ensures each engine’s air intake (the duct and inlet that feed airflow to the engine) reliably delivers the right amount and quality of air in all certified conditions, so fuel metering and mixture stay correct regardless of valve positions. It keeps the intake separated from fire-prone areas: intakes must not open into the engine cowling unless a fireproof barrier isolates them. It also requires designs that prevent hazardous ingestion of flammable fluids (like leaked fuel), runway spray (water/slush), and other foreign objects during taxi, take-off, and landing. Finally, if intake parts could be harmed by foreign objects, they must be proven—by tests or analysis—to tolerate the engine ingestion conditions of CS-E 790 (rain/hail ingestion) and CS-E 800 (bird ingestion) without failing in a way that creates a hazard. FOD means foreign object debris/damage.
events: Air France Flight 4590 (Concorde), Paris 2000: a tyre burst after striking runway debris led to fuel fire and loss of thrust as debris and flames were ingested; it shows why designs must minimise ingestion of foreign matter during the take-off roll.

US Airways Flight 1549 (A320), New York 2009: multiple Canada geese were ingested, causing dual engine flameout; it underlines the need for bird-ingestion tolerance and for intake components to survive CS-E 800-type ingestion without creating additional hazards.

British Airways A319 G-EUOE, London Heathrow 2013: unlatched fan cowl doors departed, leading to a nacelle fuel leak and engine fire; it illustrates the hazard of flammable fluid release near the intake and the need for segregation and prevention of fuel entering the intake airflow.

summary: The logic is simple: prove the engine and inlet (with anti‑ice on) won’t let ice build or shed in ways that cause power loss, damage, or flameout across all relevant icing environments—including ground snow—while defining any necessary run‑ups and limits for safe operation.
intent: Ensure that turbine engines and their inlets (air intake systems) can safely operate in icing, both in flight and on the ground, when all ice‑protection is ON. With protection operating, there must be no hazardous ice accretion on the engine, intake, or upstream airframe that would degrade operation (power/thrust loss, temperature exceedance), damage the engine, or cause stall/surge/flameout or loss of controllability. Compliance must cover the full power range (including idle), the classical icing envelope (Appendix C), supercooled large drops/SLD (Appendix O), and ice‑crystal icing/HIWC (Appendix P), plus falling/blowing snow on the ground. The rule also requires a 30‑minute ground‑idle demonstration in prescribed icing/snow, with defined periodic run‑ups and bleed use, and mandates documenting the resulting operating procedures/limits in the AFM so crews can manage risk.
events: Scandinavian Airlines Flight 751 (MD‑81, 27 Dec 1991, Gottröra): Clear ice detached from the wings after takeoff and was ingested by both engines, causing severe surges and power loss leading to dual engine failure; it illustrates why intake/engine systems must tolerate or prevent upstream ice shedding that can destabilize engines.

High Ice Water Content (ice‑crystal) power‑loss events (2000s–2010s): Multiple transport jets (e.g., CF34, PW4000, GE90 fleets) experienced high‑altitude rollbacks/surges in tropical convection due to ice‑crystal icing, prompting FAA SAFO 09004 (2009) and the adoption of Appendix P; this history underpins the rule’s explicit coverage of ice‑crystal conditions to prevent rollbacks or flameouts.

Air Florida Flight 90 (B737‑200, 13 Jan 1982, Washington National): With engine anti‑ice OFF in snow, inlet/EPR probes iced and indicated false high thrust, resulting in an actual thrust shortfall and crash; this demonstrates the need for effective intake anti‑ice and validated ground procedures to avoid hazardous power loss or mis‑set.

summary: The logic is simple: make intake/air ducts strong, fire-resistant where needed, flexible where things move, and inherently safe if a hot, high-pressure bleed duct fails.
intent: Ensure engine intake and aircraft air-duct systems remain safe under abnormal loads, fire, motion, and failures. Inlets must be strong enough to withstand pressure oscillations from engine surge (a compressor stall event that sends violent pressure pulses upstream) without collapsing or breaking. Any duct located in a “fire zone” (areas like the nacelle where an extinguishing system is required) must be fire-resistant to avoid feeding or spreading a fire. Ducts between components that can move relative to each other (engine-to-nacelle/airframe, thermal expansion, vibration) need flexible features to prevent cracking and leaks. For bleed air (hot, high‑pressure air tapped from the engine compressor for anti‑ice, pressurization, etc.), a rupture anywhere from the engine port to the aircraft user must not create a hazard—achieved by safe routing, insulation/shielding, overheat/leak detection, isolation/relief, and controlled discharge paths.
events: Boeing 737 Classic strut/nacelle overheat events: multiple in-service bleed-air leaks damaged structure and systems, prompting FAA AD 2004-10-14 to inspect/modify ducts and check valves; this shows why a bleed-duct rupture must create no hazard.

Airbus A320-family wing anti-ice hot-air leaks led to EASA directives and Airbus service bulletins to inspect/replace cracked piccolo tubes/manifolds (e.g., 2010s EASA AD actions); these events show hot bleed leaks can thermally damage wing/slat structure, underscoring the need for safe routing, insulation and leak detection.

Concorde development testing reported intake instability/engine surges producing severe pressure pulsations and panel loads (widely documented in Flight International’s Concorde coverage), illustrating why intake structures must tolerate surge loads without structural failure.

summary: The logic is simple: keep hot exhaust and its by-products away from people, flammable fluids, and vulnerable structure by smart routing, shielding, and cooling so nothing catches fire, nobody breathes CO, and pilots can still see at night.
intent: Ensure exhaust gases and hot exhaust parts from engines and APUs (auxiliary power units) are routed, shielded, and cooled so they cannot ignite leaked fuel, oil, or vapours; cannot introduce carbon monoxide (CO) into any crew or passenger area; and cannot create pilot-disabling glare at night. Components exposed to exhaust heat must be fireproof and separated from non-engine structure, and exhaust outlets must be located away from fuel vents/drains. Ventilation or insulation must prevent local hot spots on exhaust parts and shrouds. In short, the rule prevents fires, fume/CO exposure, thermal damage, and visual impairment arising from exhaust flow and temperatures.
events: British Airways A319-131 G-EUOE (London Heathrow, 24 May 2013): Unlatched fan cowl doors departed, rupturing a fuel pipe and causing fuel to spray onto hot engine areas, leading to a nacelle fire (AAIB S5/2013). It illustrates why exhaust-system-adjacent hot surfaces must be shielded/segregated from any flammable fluid leaks (CS 25.1121(b),(c),(g)).

China Airlines Flight 120, Boeing 737-800 (Naha, 20 Aug 2007): A slat downstop punctured the right wing, causing a major fuel leak that was most likely ignited by hot engine parts or the APU exhaust, destroying the aircraft (JTSB Final Report). It highlights the hazard of fuel near hot exhaust flows and the need to ensure exhaust discharge does not threaten flammable fluid vents or drains (CS 25.1121(b),(d)).

summary: The logic is simple: build exhaust ducts from suitable high-temperature, corrosion-resistant materials, support them for vibration and loads, and add flexible joints so thermal expansion and relative motion don’t crack the system and leak hot gas.
intent: EASA CS-25.1123 ensures the integrity of engine and APU exhaust ducting on large aeroplanes. Exhaust pipes run at extreme temperatures, are exposed to corrosive by-products, vibrate with the engine/airframe, and must accommodate thermal growth and relative movement between the engine, mounts, and airframe. The rule’s objective is to prevent cracks, separations, or leaks of hot exhaust that could ignite flammable fluids, overheat or weaken nearby structure, allow toxic gases into occupied areas, or degrade engine performance. It requires heat- and corrosion-resistant materials, adequate supports to withstand vibration and inertia loads, and flexible features (e.g., bellows, slip joints) where components move relative to each other, so the system remains intact throughout the operating envelope.
events: United Airlines Flight 608 (Douglas DC-6, 1947): An in‑flight fire traced to the cabin combustion‑heater installation led to the DC‑6 fleet grounding and redesign, highlighting how hot exhaust/combustion ducting integrity and placement can cause catastrophic fires if materials, support, and expansion tolerances are inadequate.

summary: The logic is simple: design and place powerplant controls so they can be positively selected, stay where set, resist fire when needed, and clearly tell the crew both what was commanded and what actually happened so errors, creep, and hidden failures don’t endanger the aircraft.
intent: This rule ensures flight crews can control engines and related systems safely and reliably. It requires powerplant controls (throttles, fuel and hydraulic shutoff/crossfeed/reverser valves, etc.) to be deliberately placed and marked so they are not bumped or misused; to be strong, rigid, and suitable for their application; and to hold settings without creeping from vibration or loads. Any part of a control that must work during a fire and sits in a fire zone must resist fire so the crew can still shut down and isolate an engine. For flight deck powerplant valve controls, the crew must be able to positively select a function and get clear feedback of the selected position and an alert if the valve does not move as commanded. EASA (European Union Aviation Safety Agency) CS-25 (Certification Specifications for large aeroplanes) and associated AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance) give the detailed design/human‑factors standards underpinning these objectives.
events: Lauda Air Flight 004 (Boeing 767, 1991): an uncommanded in‑flight thrust reverser deployment due to a malfunctioning control valve led to loss of the aircraft; regulators and industry added additional locks and cockpit disagree indications for reverser/valve position. This illustrates the need for positive valve control selection and clear indication when a valve does not achieve the commanded position.

Qantas Flight 32 (Airbus A380, 2010): an uncontained engine failure severed wiring so some fuel/hydraulic shutoff valves did not close when commanded, and ECAM displayed valve‑position disagree/failed indications guiding crew actions. This shows why crews must be warned when a valve fails to respond and why control elements in fire zones must remain operable and fire‑resistant.

British Midland Flight 92 – Kegworth (Boeing 737‑400, 1989): the crew shut down the wrong engine, influenced by misleading cues, prompting emphasis on clearer engine identification and control/indication design. This underscores the need for unambiguous arrangement and marking of powerplant controls to prevent mis‑selection or inadvertent operation.

summary: The logic is simple: give pilots clear, immediately responsive, individual and collective engine control with guarded shutoff positions and properly controlled auxiliary-fluid systems so thrust can be set or removed without errors or delays.
intent: Ensure pilots can control each engine independently and together, with immediate, predictable response, and without accidentally shutting an engine down. For every engine, the throttle (power/thrust control) must be arranged so one engine can be adjusted alone or all engines can be moved together with one hand. Controls must be positive (clear, direct, and responsive). Any auxiliary fluid-injection system not part of the certificated engine (e.g., water/methanol or alcohol/anti-ice) must have proper flow control. If a throttle incorporates fuel shutoff, it must have a guarded idle stop and require a distinct, separate action to move into cutoff to prevent inadvertent shutdown. This reduces human-error hazards, supports workload management, and maintains safe thrust control in normal and emergency situations. (EASA = European Union Aviation Safety Agency.)
events: British Midland Flight 092 (Kegworth, 1989, Boeing 737-400): the crew shut down the wrong engine after a fan failure amid ambiguous cues; this underscores the need for unambiguous, separately controllable, ergonomically arranged engine controls to avoid inadvertent or wrong-engine shutdown.

United Airlines Flight 232 (Sioux City, 1989, DC-10): with all hydraulics lost, the crew used differential thrust to fly the aircraft, showing why engine controls must be positive and immediately responsive to provide reliable control when they are the last available means.

Luxair Flight 9642 (2002, Fokker 50, Niederanven): inadvertent in‑flight selection of ground range due to an improperly secured stop system led to loss of control, highlighting the necessity for robust locks/stops and distinct actions to prevent hazardous lever movement into shutdown/ground ranges.

summary: The logic is simple: give crews clear control of each engine’s ignition, a fast way to shut all ignition off, and guard against accidental operation—except on turbine ignitions where ready access for rapid selection of ignition is prioritized.
intent: Ensure the flight crew has positive, independent control of each engine’s ignition (spark) system, can shut off all ignition quickly when needed, and is protected from accidental switch movement that could undesirably change ignition status. Ignition means magnetos/spark for piston engines and exciters/igniters for turbine engines. The rule requires a control for each engine’s ignition circuit, either a grouped arrangement that can be actuated together or a single master control to cut all ignition rapidly (e.g., for fire/fuel-leak hazards or to secure the aircraft). To avoid inadvertent engine shutdowns or unwanted sparking, the grouped or master controls must be guarded or interlocked—except turbine-engine ignition switches where continuous ignition is not required, where easy, immediate access to turn ignition on is operationally more important than guarding.
events: British Airways Flight 9 (1982, Boeing 747 near Jakarta): All four engines flamed out in volcanic ash and were later restarted using published relight procedures that included commanding ignition. This illustrates why crews need immediate, positive ignition control on each engine and the ability to select ignition rapidly.

Southern Airways Flight 242 (1977, DC‑9 in severe hail/rain): Both engines flamed out; the crew attempted relights, and the accident helped reinforce using continuous ignition in severe precipitation to improve flame stability. This underscores the need for readily accessible ignition controls to enable continuous ignition or quick relight attempts.

US Airways Flight 1549 (2009, A320 Hudson River ditching): Following dual bird‑strike flameouts, the crew executed dual‑engine relight attempts using the start/ignition controls per checklist. This shows why having simple, fast ignition/master controls is essential to any chance of engine relight in time-critical emergencies.

summary: The logic is simple: give the crew clearly located, distinct controls to adjust each propeller alone or all together and to synchronize them, so they can’t confuse them with throttles and can quickly manage thrust and vibration safely.
intent: Ensure pilots can positively, intuitively, and safely manage each propeller’s rotational speed (RPM) and blade angle (pitch) on multi‑engine airplanes. The rule demands a distinct control for each propeller, grouping that enables both independent adjustments and simultaneous action across all props, and a built‑in means to synchronize propellers to minimize beat‑frequency vibration, noise, and structural loads. It also standardizes human‑factors layout by placing propeller speed/pitch controls to the right of, and slightly below, the throttles so they are hard to confuse under workload. In plain terms, it prevents wrong‑lever errors, supports quick symmetric or asymmetric thrust management, and reduces vibration‑related fatigue and discomfort.
events: Luxair Flight 9642 (Fokker 50, 2002): In‑flight reverse was inadvertently selected on one propeller due to control/gating vulnerability, leading to loss of control and a crash near Niederanven, Luxembourg (AAIU Luxembourg Final Report). This underscores the need for unmistakable, well‑positioned prop/pitch controls relative to throttles to prevent wrong‑lever selections and hazardous asymmetric prop states.

Braniff Flight 542 (1959) and Northwest Flight 710 (1960), Lockheed L‑188 Electra: Prop‑rotor whirl flutter caused catastrophic structural failure (CAB investigation), highlighting how prop‑induced vibratory loads can be destructive. Mandating propeller synchronization capability and precise RPM control reduces beat frequencies and vibration that can excite structural modes.

TransAsia Airways Flight 235 (ATR 72‑600, 2015): After an engine flameout, the crew retarded the opposite engine’s power and subsequently feathered the wrong propeller, causing fatal asymmetric thrust and a stall (ASC Taiwan Final Report). Clear, grouped per‑prop controls that support unambiguous separate versus simultaneous actions help mitigate such human‑factor errors.

summary: The logic is simple: make feathering a deliberate, unmistakable action on the correct propeller only, and design controls so they cannot be moved into feather by mistake during normal flight.
intent: This rule aims to prevent accidental shutdown or drag-producing misconfiguration of a propeller during normal flight. On multi‑engine turboprops, “feathering” rotates a propeller’s blades edge‑on to the airflow to cut drag after an engine failure; doing it to the wrong prop, or by mistake, can instantly remove needed thrust and jeopardize control. Therefore, each propeller must have its own clearly distinct feathering control, and any lever that can command feather (e.g., a pitch, speed, or condition lever) must be gated, guarded, or interlocked so it cannot be moved into feather unintentionally during normal operations.
events: TransAsia Airways Flight 235 (ATR 72‑600, 2015, Taipei): After a flameout on one engine, the captain mistakenly retarded and shut down the operating engine, moving its condition lever to fuel‑shutoff and feathering the good prop; the aircraft stalled and crashed. This shows the catastrophic consequences of an incorrect or inadvertent feather/shutoff selection and the need for clear, guarded, prop‑specific controls.

Luxair Flight 9642 (Fokker 50, 2002, Niederanven): The crew inadvertently moved the power levers into the ground range in flight, causing extreme drag and loss of control. While not a feathering action, it underscores why lever gates/locks are essential to prevent unintended propeller pitch selections during normal flight—the same design philosophy mandated by CS 25.1153(b).

Flybe BE331 (DHC‑8‑402Q, G‑JECP, 2017, Belfast City): An uncommanded feather due to a propeller control fault shortly after takeoff forced a return and emergency landing (AAIB report). The event highlights how a feathered prop dramatically affects performance, reinforcing the need for designs that minimize any possibility of inadvertent feather selection by the crew.

summary: The logic is simple: physically gate and electronically inhibit reverse/beta selection in flight unless within a certified safe envelope, make the protection highly reliable, and clearly warn the crew if the protection is lost or the control is moved toward reverse when it shouldn’t be.
intent: Keep reverse thrust or propeller reverse/beta from being used in flight unless specifically approved, because doing so can cause immediate loss of control or severe damage. The rule requires a guarded, two-step control action (a physical lock/stop) that only becomes available at flight idle; a system interlock that prevents both accidental and deliberate selection outside the approved in‑flight operating envelope (the set of speeds/altitudes/conditions where it’s safe); very high reliability of that interlock; and clear cockpit cautions if the protection is lost or if a control is moved toward reverse while still outside the approved envelope. In short, design out inadvertent selection, block intentional misuse, and alert the crew if protections degrade.
events: Lauda Air Flight 004 (Boeing 767-300ER, 26 May 1991): an uncommanded in‑flight deployment of a thrust reverser led to structural breakup and loss of the aircraft. The catastrophe drove industry-wide enhancements to in‑flight reverse inhibitions and demonstrates why selection outside the safe envelope must be prevented and not overrideable.

TAM Flight 402 (Fokker 100, 31 Oct 1996): a thrust reverser on one engine deployed shortly after takeoff, causing uncontrollable asymmetry and a fatal crash in São Paulo. This shows the need for robust locks, interlocks, and warnings to prevent both inadvertent and intentional selection when airborne.

Luxair Flight 9642 (Fokker 50, 6 Nov 2002): inadvertent selection of reverse on one propeller during approach led to asymmetric thrust and loss of control near Luxembourg. The accident illustrates why mechanical baulks, beta lockouts, and explicit cockpit cautions are essential to block reverse/beta selection outside the approved in‑flight envelope.

summary: The logic is simple: make fuel-dump a clearly guarded, two-step, and well-separated action so it can’t be triggered by mistake or confused with fire-fighting controls when seconds matter.
intent: This rule makes sure the fuel jettison (fuel dump) control on large aeroplanes cannot be accidentally used and cannot be confused with fire-fighting controls. Fuel jettison rapidly discharges fuel overboard so the aircraft can land below maximum landing weight; it is inherently hazardous because it creates flammable vapour clouds and environmental exposure. By requiring a physical guard (a cover or two-step arming) and separating it from fire extinguisher or fire-fighting controls, the rule reduces the chance that, under stress, a pilot or maintainer triggers fuel dump by mistake or reaches for the wrong control during a fire. CS-25 is EASA’s Certification Specifications for Large Aeroplanes; this clause is about safe cockpit control design and human factors during emergencies.
events: Delta Air Lines Flight 89 (B777-200, 14 Jan 2020): the crew jettisoned fuel shortly after take-off and fuel fell on schools and neighborhoods near LAX, causing injuries (NTSB docket and FAA reports). It underscores that fuel dumping has serious hazards and must never occur inadvertently—hence guarded, deliberate controls.

Swissair Flight 111 (MD-11, 2 Sep 1998; TSB Canada Report A98H0003): amid an in‑flight fire, the crew initiated fuel dump while workload rapidly escalated before a fatal crash. The case illustrates that in fire emergencies any control confusion or delay is critical; keeping fuel‑dump controls distinct and separated from fire-fighting controls helps prevent human-error misselection.

Human factors/certification guidance (FAA AC 25.777-1B and EASA AMC 25.777): mandates guarding of emergency controls and functional segregation to avoid misselection; modern types (e.g., B747/777, A340) implement guarded, two-step jettison on the overhead, remote from fire handles. This programmatic design practice evidences the rule’s intent to prevent inadvertent operation and confusion with fire controls.

summary: The logic is simple: use only approved, sealed accessories on the engine’s intended mounts, keep sparking electrics away from any fuel/oil, and include a means to disconnect or stop any failed accessory without jeopardizing the engine.
intent: Ensure that any accessory attached to an engine (generators/IDGs, hydraulic and fuel pumps, cabin superchargers on legacy types, etc.) is specifically approved for that engine, mounted only on the engine’s designed pads/brackets, and sealed so fluids (especially engine oil) cannot cross-contaminate. Electrical items that can spark or arc must be located and protected so they cannot ignite fuel, oil, or vapors if these escape into the nacelle/pylon. If a remote, engine-driven accessory could become dangerous by continuing to spin after a malfunction (e.g., seizure, overheat, internal failure), the design must provide a disconnect or shear feature to stop that accessory’s rotation without compromising the engine’s continued safe operation. The overarching goal is to reduce fire/explosion risk, prevent fluid contamination–induced engine failures, and keep propulsion available after accessory problems.
events: TWA Flight 800 (1996, B747-131): An electrical arc ignited fuel-air vapors in the center wing tank, leading to an explosion; while not in the nacelle, it cemented industry rules to segregate and shield arcing sources from flammable fluids/vapors, directly underpinning requirements like CS 25.1163(b).

Boeing 787 ZA002 flight-test fire (2010, Laredo, TX): An electrical arc and fire in the P100 panel produced significant smoke and system damage; this public, well-documented event illustrates how arcing equipment can rapidly escalate into a fire, reinforcing the need to keep such equipment isolated from any flammable fluids in powerplant areas.

Programme lesson – IDG/EDP disconnects and shear features (Airbus and Boeing fleets): Pilot-operated Integrated Drive Generator (IDG) disconnects and engine-driven pump (EDP) shear couplings, documented in FCOMs/AMMs and required procedures (e.g., disconnect on IDG overheat), exemplify CS 25.1163(c)’s intent to stop a malfunctioning, engine-driven accessory from rotating without impairing engine operation.

summary: The logic is simple: keep engine ignition powered at all times from at least one automatic source, size and isolate the system so other electrical faults or fires cannot take it down, warn the crew if a critical battery is draining, and treat ignition as an essential load so engines keep burning or can be relit when needed.
intent: Ensure turbine-engine ignition always has reliable electrical power so engines keep running and can be relit in adverse or failure conditions. Because turbine igniters are electrically powered, the rule requires an automatically available generator as an alternate to the battery, adequate capacity for concurrent loads, and design that covers failed generators, depleted batteries, and low generator speed. Ignition wiring must be independent of unrelated circuits and not be jeopardised by another engine’s fire zone (unless fireproof), so a single fault or fire cannot disable ignition. The crew must be warned if an ignition‑critical battery is being continuously discharged. Finally, ignition on turbine aeroplanes is defined as an essential electrical load—i.e., equipment that must remain powered after failures or on standby/RAT/APU power—to preserve engine operation and relight capability.
events: TACA Flight 110 (1988, B737-300): Both engines flamed out in severe rain/hail and could not be relit before a deadstick landing on a levee near New Orleans. The investigation drove procedures and design emphasis on continuous ignition and reliable electrical supply for relight, underscoring why ignition must be treated as an essential, independently powered load.

Garuda Indonesia Flight 421 (2002, B737-300): Dual flameout in extreme precipitation led to a forced river landing after unsuccessful relight attempts. The case reinforced the need for assured, continuously available ignition power and procedures (continuous ignition in heavy rain) so relight capability is maintained.

Air Transat Flight 236 (2001, A330-200): After fuel exhaustion and dual engine flameout, the RAT powered essential buses; the crew achieved a relight of one engine near landing. This demonstrates why ignition is classified as an essential electrical load that must remain powered from standby sources even after multiple failures.

summary: The logic is simple: if you mount a gearbox and shafts to take power off the engine but they aren’t engine-certified, you must test and analyse them to engine-level standards and verify they can withstand misalignment and torsional loads in service.
intent: Ensure that any accessory gearbox (and its connecting shafts and transmissions) installed on a transport aeroplane, when that gearbox is not part of the engine’s own type certificate, is proven to be as robust as an engine-certified unit. The rule ties the airframe-installed gearbox and driveline to key engine standards and tests from CS-E (Certification Specifications for Engines), including vibration, endurance, and integrity requirements. It also requires engineers to analyse real-life installation effects such as misalignment from mounting tolerances/thermal growth and torsional loads from connected accessories (generators, pumps), so that drivetrain failures, oil leaks, fires, or engine shutdowns are prevented.
events: Airbus A400M TP400-D6 propeller gearbox (PGB) issues (2016–2018): EASA issued multiple ADs mandating inspections and limits after planet gear cracking in the PGB, highlighting how endurance and torsional stresses in gear trains can drive failures without rigorous vibration/load assessment and testing (e.g., EASA AD series addressing TP400-D6 PGB planet gear cracking).

Rolls-Royce RB211 accessory drive shaft failures on Boeing 757 fleets (various AAIB/service reports): In-flight shutdowns occurred when the external radial drive shaft to the accessory gearbox sheared due to misalignment/torsional effects, illustrating the need to evaluate real installation misalignment and drivetrain torsion and to meet engine-grade gearbox requirements.

summary: The logic is simple: identify every place where ignition sources and flammable fluids coexist, label it a designated fire zone, and then require robust isolation, detection, shutoff, drainage, and extinguishing so a fire is contained and rapidly suppressed.
intent: This rule’s purpose is to explicitly define which parts of the powerplant are “designated fire zones” so they must receive the full suite of fire-protection measures. EASA (European Union Aviation Safety Agency) uses CS (Certification Specifications) and AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance) to set and explain these requirements. By listing the engine power and accessory sections, combined compartments, combustion heaters, and specific hot sections of turbine engines that contain flammable fluid or gas lines, it ensures no hazardous area is overlooked. Once designated, those zones must comply with the related CS-25 fire rules (e.g., materials, isolation, detection, extinguishing, drainage, and shutoff provisions) to prevent, contain, detect, and extinguish fires before they threaten structure, systems, or occupants.
events: British Airways Flight 2276 (B777-236ER, Las Vegas, 8 Sep 2015): An uncontained GE90 failure ruptured lines and triggered a fuel-fed nacelle fire; detection and fire-extinguishing actions, along with nacelle firewalls and shutoffs, limited spread (AAIB Report 1/2018), illustrating why engine compartments are designated fire zones.

American Airlines Flight 383 (B767-323ER, Chicago O’Hare, 28 Oct 2016): A CF6-80C2 uncontained failure caused a severe nacelle fire; the crew relied on defined fire-zone protections—warnings, fuel/hydraulic shutoffs, and extinguishing—to suppress it (NTSB AAR-18/01), proving the need to treat these sections as designated fire zones.

Korean Air Flight 2708 (B777-300, Tokyo Haneda, 27 May 2016): Uncontained GE90 failure led to an engine fire and evacuation; the JTSB final report documents nacelle fire detection/extinguishing actions, underscoring why turbine hot sections with flammable lines are classified as designated fire zones.

summary: The logic is simple: treat the areas just behind the firewall and any pylon sections with flammable lines as if they were fire zones—ensure leaks can be shut off, contained, drained, and ventilated—so a nacelle event cannot ignite hidden bays or the wing/strut, even though those bays need no detectors or extinguishers.
intent: Make the ‘cold’ spaces just aft of the engine firewall and any part of the engine pod/strut (pylon) that carries flammable fluids (fuel, oil, hydraulic fluid) behave like fire zones in terms of protection. In plain terms: even though these areas are outside the engine’s main fire area, they must meet the same design rules for materials, routing, isolation/shutoff, drainage, ventilation, and fire containment used in designated fire zones, because leaks or failures there can still feed a serious fire. A firewall is a heat/fire-resistant barrier that separates an engine fire zone from the rest of the aircraft; a nacelle is the engine housing; an engine pod attaching structure is the pylon/strut that mounts the engine. Detection/extinguishing equipment is not required inside the pylon itself, but all other fire-protection measures apply. Where retractable landing gear shares that bay, show compliance with the gear retracted (the worst enclosed condition).
events: American Airlines Flight 383 (B767-323ER, Chicago O’Hare, 28 Oct 2016): an uncontained engine failure severed the main fuel line, driving a fuel-fed fire under the wing and around the pylon (NTSB AAR-18/01). It shows why lines and structure behind the firewall/pylon must be protected, isolatable, and arranged to limit fire spread.

British Airways Flight 2276 (B777-236ER, Las Vegas, 8 Sep 2015): an uncontained GE90 failure led to a severe nacelle and underwing fire after high-energy debris breached fuel/oil systems (AAIB Report 1/2018). This demonstrates the need for shutoff, fire-resistant routing, and containment in nacelle/pylon areas beyond the firewall.

Qantas Flight 32 (A380-842, 4 Nov 2010): an uncontained Trent 900 failure fractured lines and wiring in the pylon/wing dry-bay, causing fuel leaks and multiple system failures (ATSB AO-2010-089). Effective isolation and fire protection in the pylon/dry-bay limited ignition risk, illustrating why these bays must meet fire-zone design rules even without detectors/extinguishers.

summary: The logic is simple: keep flammable-fluid hardware in fire zones tough enough and arranged so that a fire won’t make it leak, spread, or knock out essential systems.
intent: This rule ensures that anything carrying flammable fluids (fuel, oil, hydraulic fluid, etc.) in engine fire areas or designated fire zones (like engine nacelles and APU compartments) can survive a fire long enough to prevent leaks, ignition, or knock-on damage. "Fire resistant" means it can withstand a severe flame for a limited time without failing; "fireproof" is a higher standard for longer exposure. Lines, fittings, tanks, and supports in fire zones must meet these standards, and be located or shielded so that any leak will not ignite. If any component in a fire zone could, when exposed to fire, spread the fire or disable essential systems, it must be fireproof. Items already approved as part of a type-certificated engine, and low-risk vents/drains, are excluded. The intent is to contain fires where they start, prevent leaking fluids from feeding them, and protect critical systems so the crew can keep control.
events: British Airways Flight 762 (A319, G‑EUOE, London Heathrow, 24 May 2013): Unlatched fan-cowl doors detached and damaged the right engine, fracturing a fuel pipe and causing a nacelle fire; the AAIB found a significant fuel leak feeding the fire, underscoring the need for robust, shielded fuel lines in fire zones to prevent ignition of leaked fuel.

American Airlines Flight 383 (B767-323ER, N345AN, Chicago O’Hare, 28 Oct 2016): An uncontained CF6 engine failure punctured fuel/hydraulic systems and led to a large, fuel-fed nacelle/wing fire; NTSB findings highlight the importance of fireproof components and shielding to prevent fire spread to other airplane regions and protect essential services.

Qantas Flight 32 (A380, VH‑OQA, Singapore, 4 Nov 2010): An uncontained engine failure damaged oil and hydraulic lines and produced an engine fire warning; the ATSB documented multiple flammable-fluid leaks and system degradations, illustrating why lines in fire zones must be fire‑resistant/fireproof and routed to avoid fire-induced loss of essential functions.

summary: The logic is simple: keep flammable fluids out of fire-prone spaces, and where they must be present, isolate them, provide spacing from firewalls, and ensure nothing nearby can soak up leaks and feed a fire.
intent: Prevent fires in engine/APU areas from being started or sustained by fluids that burn. A “designated fire zone” is a space where fires are most likely (for example, engine nacelles or APU compartments). If any tank or reservoir for flammable fluids or gases (such as fuel, engine oil, hydraulic fluid, alcohol) must be in such a zone, its design, materials, plumbing, and shutoff valves must make it as safe as if it were outside that zone. There must be a small air gap to the firewall/shroud to reduce heat conduction and structural damage, and any nearby materials that could soak up leaked fluid must be non‑absorbent or treated so they cannot wick fuel and keep a fire burning.
events: American Airlines Flight 383 (Boeing 767-323ER), Chicago O’Hare, 28 Oct 2016: an uncontained right-engine failure led to a fuel-fed fire on the wing and nacelle (NTSB DCA17FA021). It shows why systems carrying flammable fluids near engine fire zones need robust isolation and shutoff so a single failure does not create or sustain a major fire.

British Airtours Flight 28M (Boeing 737-236), Manchester, 22 Aug 1985: an engine failure produced a severe nacelle/underwing fire that was fed by fuel and rapidly compromised the aircraft, leading to 55 fatalities (AAIB Report 8/88). The accident underscores the need to prevent leaks and accumulation of flammable fluids and to limit combustible/absorbent materials in and around engine fire zones.

Qantas Flight 32 (Airbus A380), Singapore, 4 Nov 2010: a fractured oil feed pipe in a Trent 900 caused an uncontained engine failure and nacelle fire (Australian ATSB AO-2010-089). It demonstrates why oil tanks, lines, and controls within designated fire zones must use robust materials and effective shutoff to avoid a leak sustaining a fire.

summary: The logic is simple: drain leaked fluids safely, ventilate to avoid vapour build-up without importing or exporting fire, and control airflow so the extinguisher can actually work.
intent: Ensure that any compartment classified as a fire zone (such as engine nacelles, auxiliary power unit (APU) bays, and heater compartments) cannot accumulate flammable liquids or vapours and cannot spread fire. The rule requires complete and effective drainage so leaked fuel, oil, or hydraulic fluid does not pool or discharge to a hazardous location, and ventilation that prevents vapour build-up without importing flames or fluids from other areas. Vent and drain outlets must not create new hazards. Because airflow can dilute fire extinguishing agent, the design must either size the extinguishing system for worst-case airflow or give the crew a way to shut off forced ventilation to that zone (with limited exceptions), so the suppressant can reach and maintain an effective concentration.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (Airbus A380 VH-OQA), 4 Nov 2010: an uncontained engine failure ruptured oil systems and led to an oil-fed fire in the nacelle (ATSB AO-2010-089). It shows why fire zones need effective drainage/venting to prevent fluid pooling and vapour build-up, and why suppressant effectiveness depends on controlling airflow.

British Airways Flight 2276 (Boeing 777-236ER G-VIIO), Las Vegas 8 Sep 2015: a GE90 uncontained failure severed a fuel feed line, causing an intense fire around the nacelle/wing (AAIB Report 1/2018). The event underscores the need to route and drain flammable fluids so discharge does not create secondary hazards or let fire migrate into adjacent zones such as wheel wells.

FAA nacelle fire suppression research (e.g., DOT/FAA/AR-2003/26) showed that high ventilation flow in engine/APU bays rapidly dilutes Halon below extinguishing levels. That evidence underpins the rule to either size the agent for maximum airflow or provide crew means to shut off forced ventilation to the fire zone.

summary: The logic is simple: make it possible to rapidly and reliably stop flammable fluids from feeding an engine/APU fire—without harming other engines—using fire‑resistant, survivable, guarded valves that won’t leak or burst and can be reopened if needed.
intent: This rule ensures that any area where a fire could occur around engines or APUs (“designated fire zones”) can be quickly isolated from flammable fluids such as fuel, oil, hydraulic fluid, and de‑icer. It requires shut-off valves and their controls to be robust (“fireproof” or protected against fire effects), placed so they still work after engine or mount structural failures, and arranged so closing one engine’s supply does not deprive other engines of fuel. The system must not allow hazardous amounts of fluid to continue draining into a fire zone after shutoff, must prevent accidental activation, and must allow the crew to reopen a valve in flight if needed. Pressure relief must be provided so trapped fluid between valves doesn’t burst lines when heated. Exceptions exist only where components are integral to the engine or the oil system is entirely fireproof or outside engine fire conditions.
events: Qantas Flight QF32 (A380, 4 Nov 2010): An uncontained engine failure damaged wing wiring, and the crew could not shut down No. 1 engine with normal/fire controls after landing due to lost control of the fuel shutoff valve (ATSB AO‑2010‑089). This highlights why shutoff means and their controls must be fireproof/segregated and located to remain operable despite fire or structural damage (CS 25.1189(d),(g)).

British Airways Flight 2276 (B777, Las Vegas, 8 Sep 2015): A high‑pressure turbine failure led to a severe engine fire; pulling the fire handle closed the spar and engine fuel valves and isolated other flammable supplies while the other engine remained powered (NTSB DCA15FA185). This demonstrates the need for immediate, independent shutoff of flammable fluids to the affected fire zone without affecting the remaining engine(s) (CS 25.1189(a),(b)).

British Airways A319 G‑EUOE (Heathrow, 24 May 2013): Unlatched fan‑cowl doors damaged a fuel pipe, causing an engine fire; the crew’s use of fire controls stopped continued tank feed and the aircraft landed safely (AAIB Report 1/2015). This shows why designs must prevent hazardous quantities of fuel from continuing to flow or drain into a fire zone after shutoff (CS 25.1189(a),(e)).

summary: The logic is simple: keep any engine or heater fire fully contained where it starts by a sealed, fireproof, corrosion-resistant barrier so flames, hot gases, and fluids cannot spread to the rest of the airplane.
intent: CS-25.1191 requires any place where fire can start in flight (engines, APUs/heaters, and hot sections of turbine engines) to be physically isolated from the rest of the airplane by a barrier. That barrier—a firewall, shroud, or equivalent—must be truly fireproof (able to withstand a severe fire), sealed so flames, hot gases, fluids (fuel, oil, hydraulics), or even airflow cannot pass through in hazardous amounts, and durable against corrosion so it works for the aircraft’s life. The goal is straightforward: if a fire starts in a powerplant bay, it must be contained and starved of paths to spread to critical structure, systems, or the cabin. EASA (European Union Aviation Safety Agency) uses CS (Certification Specification) terms like “fireproof” and requires proper fittings/grommets at every penetration so the barrier remains intact.
events: British Airways 2276 (Boeing 777-236ER, Las Vegas, 2015): An uncontained GE90 engine failure led to a severe nacelle fire, yet the fire did not penetrate the fuselage and passengers evacuated successfully (AAIB Report 2/2018). This shows why robust firewalls and sealed penetrations are essential to prevent an engine-bay fire from spreading into occupied areas.

Qantas Flight 32 (Airbus A380, 2010): A Trent 900 uncontained engine failure caused a significant nacelle fire and fluid leaks, but the fire was contained and did not propagate into the fuselage (ATSB AO-2010-089). The event illustrates the value of isolating the hot sections and engine compartments so a serious powerplant fire does not compromise the cabin or systems bays.

British Airtours Flight 28M (Boeing 737-236, Manchester, 1985): After a rejected takeoff due to engine failure and fire, flames and toxic smoke rapidly entered the cabin through structural openings, contributing to 55 fatalities (AAIB Report 8/88). The tragedy underscores why barriers must be fireproof and sealed—preventing hazardous flame, gases, and airflow from migrating from the engine area into the fuselage.

summary: The logic is simple: make nacelle and cowling structures strong, flame-tolerant, and secure so that fires stay contained and doors don’t open or depart, even if one latch or hinge is wrong or fails.
intent: Ensure engine cowlings and nacelle skins are structurally robust, resist heat and flames, and are secured so they neither open nor fail in flight, and so a fire cannot spread to more hazardous areas. In plain terms: the panels around the engine must withstand vibration, aerodynamic and inertia loads, have proper drainage/ventilation, be “fireproof” (able to withstand intense flame for a specified time) where flames or hot exhaust can impinge, and “fire-resistant” where appropriate, and must isolate any fire within its designated engine fire zone. The design must prevent a fire from burning through into other regions (e.g. wing, fuselage), protect critical areas during both flight and ground operations, and include a retention/verification system that tolerates a single latch/hinge failure or a single improper fastener and still keeps the cowling closed with an obvious, reliable preflight check.
events: British Airways A319 G-EUOE, London Heathrow (24 May 2013): both fan cowl doors left unlatched detached on takeoff, causing fuel leak and engine fire (AAIB Report 2/2015). This showed the need for cowling retention tolerant of single-point human error and for clear preflight-secure verification (CS 25.1193(f)).

Southwest Airlines 3472 (2016) and 1380 (2018) Boeing 737-700: fan-blade-out led to nacelle inlet/cowl structural failures and debris that damaged the fuselage/window (NTSB). These events underscored the requirement that nacelle structures withstand operational loads and avoid creating additional hazards if damaged (CS 25.1193(a), (e)(1)).

American Airlines 383, Boeing 767-300, Chicago O’Hare (28 Oct 2016): uncontained CF6 failure led to a severe nacelle/pylon fire on the ground with fuel-fed flames (NTSB AAR-18/01). It highlighted the need for fireproof nacelle/cowling in flame-impinged areas and prevention of fire spread to critical zones, especially in ground operations (CS 25.1193(e)(3)(ii)).

summary: The logic is simple: put an extinguisher in every fire-prone powerplant zone, prove it reaches effective agent concentration in worst-case airflow, provide two shots for re‑ignition, and ensure nacelles get simultaneous coverage across all protected zones.
intent: CS 25.1195 ensures that any “designated fire zone” (areas like engine nacelles, APUs, and other compartments with flammable fluids) has a fire-extinguishing system that actually puts out a fire in real flight conditions. It requires proving, by flight or realistic simulation, that the extinguishing agent’s amount, discharge rate, and distribution will achieve an effective concentration under the worst ventilation (“critical airflow”) and will minimize re‑ignition. Most zones must have two effective discharges (“two shots”) to cope with re‑ignition or an initially ineffective shot; a single-shot system is allowed only for fuel‑burning heaters and similar equipment. For nacelles with multiple protected zones, the system must be capable of protecting all such zones simultaneously. An exception exists for combustor, turbine, and tailpipe sections if you can show a fire originating there can be controlled by procedures (e.g., fuel cutoff and motoring) without a dedicated extinguisher.
events: British Airways Flight 2276 (B777-236ER, Las Vegas, 2015): An uncontained engine failure caused a severe right engine nacelle/wing fire; the crew discharged both engine fire bottles and ARFF completed extinguishment (NTSB AAR-19/01). It illustrates why CS 25.1195 demands adequate agent quantity/distribution and two shots proven under high airflow, as internal systems must rapidly flood nacelle zones even when ventilation is extreme.

American Airlines Flight 383 (B767-323ER, Chicago O’Hare, 2016): An uncontained engine failure led to an intense nacelle/wing fire; the crew used both extinguisher discharges, and ARFF finished suppression (NTSB AAR-18/01). This underscores the need for robust, zoned nacelle suppression with multiple discharges and simultaneous zone protection to minimize re‑ignition and ensure coverage where the fire starts.

FAA Fire Safety nacelle suppression tests (DOT/FAA/AR-01/37, 2001): Flight/simulated tests measured Halon 1301 concentration in nacelles and showed high ventilation and poor nozzle placement can prevent reaching extinguishing concentration, making re‑ignition likely without sufficient agent or a second discharge. These programme findings directly support CS 25.1195’s requirement to prove, under critical airflow, that quantity, rate, and distribution are adequate.

summary: The logic is simple: use an agent that reliably extinguishes the expected fires and stays stable in its environment, and if it’s toxic, design the airplane so people can’t be exposed to harmful concentrations even if the system leaks or fires.
intent: Ensure that the fire-extinguishing chemical used in engine, APU, or fuselage-protected compartments will actually put out the likely fires there, will not break down or lose performance across the temperatures it sees in service, and will not poison or asphyxiate crew or passengers if it leaks or is discharged. If a toxic agent (for example, Halon 1301 or carbon dioxide) is used, the system and airplane must be arranged so harmful concentrations cannot reach occupied areas—even if a fault exists—unless tightly limited CO2 quantities are used or flight crew have protective breathing equipment. AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance) offers methods to show this with testing.
events: United Airlines Flight 608 (1947, DC‑6): Following a baggage-compartment fire, CO2 was discharged but smoke and gases spread, and the crew were overcome before an emergency landing, underscoring the need to both contain agents and prevent hazardous concentrations reaching occupied areas.

Pan Am Flight 160 (1973, Boeing 707‑321C freighter): A main-deck cargo fire led to CO2 discharge; the cockpit filled with smoke/fumes and the aircraft crashed short of Boston, highlighting risks from agent migration/asphyxiation and the importance of demonstrating safe concentrations for toxic agents.

summary: The logic is simple: keep the fire bottle safe from bursting, keep its agent reliably available and flowing when needed, and provide clear indication of its status.
intent: This rule ensures that built-in fire-extinguishing agent containers (the pressurized bottles that discharge Halon or equivalent into engines, APUs, and other protected bays) remain safe and effective across all operating conditions. It requires: a pressure-relief feature so a bottle cannot burst if it overheats or is over-pressurized; safe routing of any relief discharge so it cannot harm the airplane and cannot be blocked by ice or debris; cockpit/maintenance indication that a bottle has discharged or is under‑charged; thermal control so bottle pressure stays high enough to flow properly in cold conditions yet not so high that it blows early in hot conditions; and protection of the pyrotechnic squib (the cartridge that initiates discharge) from heat-related degradation. In short, the rule prevents bottle rupture or ineffective/no discharge and ensures the crew and maintenance know bottle status so they can rely on the system when a fire occurs.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (ATSB AO-2010-089, 2010): After an uncontained A380 engine failure and fire warning, one engine fire bottle did not discharge due to wiring damage, while the other did—highlighting the need for robust bottle health/pressure monitoring and positive discharge indication so crews know what agent is truly available.

American Airlines Flight 383 (NTSB, 2016, Chicago): Following a right-engine uncontained failure, the crew discharged engine fire bottles; reliable agent availability and indication are critical to suppress internal engine fires while responders fight external flames—illustrating why bottle pressure/temperature control and status indication matter.

Regulatory actions on installed bottles (multiple FAA/EASA ADs on Kidde/UTC/B/E Aerospace halon containers and squibs in the 2000s–2010s): In-service findings of leaking bottles, degraded pyrotechnic cartridges, and pressure‑relief issues led to mandated inspections, replacements, and life limits—demonstrating the need for pressure relief, temperature management, and verified discharge capability to prevent burst/no-discharge conditions.

summary: The logic is simple: pick materials that don’t react with the extinguishing agent, and make any suppression hardware in the engine bay fireproof so it still delivers agent in a real fire.
intent: Ensure the fire-extinguishing system itself never makes a fire worse and still works when a fire occurs. First, any materials used in the system (bottles, valves, pipes, seals, wiring, fittings) must be chemically compatible with the extinguishing agent (e.g., halons or their replacements), so they do not produce toxic, corrosive, or overpressure hazards. Second, any part of that system that sits inside the engine compartment must be fireproof—able to withstand a severe nacelle fire long enough to operate and deliver agent without failing or melting. In plain terms: the agent must not react with the hardware, and the hardware in the fire zone must survive a fire long enough to do its job.
events: ATSB AO-2010-089 (Qantas A380 QF32, 2010): Debris from an uncontained engine failure damaged nacelle systems; one engine fire bottle failed to discharge, likely due to wiring damage. It illustrates why engine-bay fire-extinguishing components and their interfaces must be robust and fireproof so suppression remains available in a fire-damaged environment.

FAA William J. Hughes Technical Center Halon Replacement Program and FAA AC 20-42D: Testing showed halogenated agents (e.g., Halon 1301) and some replacements can decompose to hazardous acids (e.g., hydrogen fluoride) and react with certain metals/elastomers. This led to strict materials-compatibility testing to ensure nothing in the system chemically reacts with the agent to create a hazard.

summary: The logic is simple: put quick, robust detectors in every fire zone so real fires are detected fast, faults are revealed (or detection persists), false alarms are avoided, and crews can verify system health in flight.
intent: Ensure engines and other powerplant fire zones have fast, reliable, and durable fire/overheat detection that promptly alerts the crew, keeps working under damage and vibration, avoids false alarms, and can be checked in flight. A “designated fire zone” is any compartment where a fire hazard exists (e.g., engine nacelle, auxiliary power unit); detectors must be “approved” and “quick acting” to meet a defined alarm time. The system must tolerate operational loads, and if a detector circuit in a fire zone is severed or shorted, it must either still detect adequately or warn the crew of the fault. Detectors must not be triggered by oil, water, or fumes, and components inside fire zones must be at least fire-resistant. Installation must prevent cross-zone false warnings unless zones are protected together. The system must meet European Technical Standard Order (ETSO) response-time criteria and comply with robust wiring/installation requirements for Electrical Wiring Interconnection Systems (EWIS).
events: British Airways 2276 (Boeing 777-200, Las Vegas, 2015): an uncontained high‑pressure turbine failure caused a severe engine/nacelle fire; the crew received an immediate right-engine fire warning and discharged extinguishers, enabling a prompt shutdown and successful evacuation (AAIB). This shows the need for quick‑acting, robust detection in engine fire zones to trigger timely crew action per CS 25.1203.

United Airlines 328 (Boeing 777-200, Denver, 2021): after a fan blade failure, a nacelle fire and heavy vibration occurred; the crew got an engine fire warning and discharged both bottles, with alerting surviving significant damage (NTSB).
