This illustrates why detectors and wiring must withstand vibration/damage and still warn the crew, as CS 25.1203 requires.

American Airlines 383 (Boeing 767-300, Chicago O’Hare, 2016): an uncontained engine failure led to a fuel‑fed fire; the fire‑detection system annunciated promptly, guiding the shutdown and discharge sequence during evacuation (NTSB). It underscores the requirement for reliable, fast detection in designated fire zones and compliance with approved response times.

summary: The logic is simple: show powerplant fire protection performance with the most realistic and representative evidence available—prefer full‑scale fire tests, but accept proven similarity, component tests, service experience, or analysis when they credibly cover the worst‑case conditions.
intent: This clause tells applicants how they must prove that the airplane’s powerplant fire protection meets CS 25.1181–25.1203. “Powerplant” covers engines, nacelles, Auxiliary Power Unit (APU), and associated systems (flammable-fluid lines, fire detection and extinguishing). The primary, most realistic proof is a full‑scale fire test. However, to avoid unnecessary or impractical full‑aircraft tests, EASA allows other rigorously justified evidence: tests on a similar engine/nacelle configuration, component‑level fire tests, in‑service experience on comparable designs, and technical analysis. The alternative methods must be representative of worst‑case fire threats and installation details to ensure an equivalent level of safety. In short, it sets a hierarchy of acceptable evidence so applicants can use validated similarity, targeted testing, field data, and analysis to demonstrate that fire zones are correctly identified, materials and systems are fireproof/fire‑resistant as required, and detection/suppression is effective.
events: British Airways Flight 2276 (B777-200, 8 Sep 2015, Las Vegas): an uncontained GE90 failure produced a severe nacelle fuel fire during the takeoff roll. It underscores why fire zones, shutoff, and extinguishing must be validated under realistic leaks/airflow—exactly the kind of evidence (full‑scale or well‑justified similarity/component tests) CS 25.1207 requires.

American Airlines Flight 383 (B767-300, 28 Oct 2016, Chicago O’Hare): an uncontained CF6-80C2 engine failure led to a rapid, fuel‑fed nacelle fire despite prompt bottle discharge. The NTSB’s findings illustrate the real conditions designers must prove against (fuel release, ventilation, hot surfaces), supporting the rule’s demand for representative testing or equivalent evidence.

JAL Boeing 787-8 APU battery fire (Boston, 7 Jan 2013): a thermal runaway and fire in the APU battery prompted a redesign whose certification relied on extensive component‑level fire/containment tests and analysis, leveraged across the 787 fleet. This exemplifies CS 25.1207’s allowance to show compliance using component tests, similarity, service experience, and analysis in lieu of repeating full‑scale aircraft fire tests.

summary: The logic is simple: pick the right equipment, label it clearly, install it only within its approved limits, and make the wiring meet EWIS rules.
intent: Ensure every piece of equipment on a transport aeroplane is fit for its job, clearly identified for correct use, installed only within its approved limits, and wired to modern safety standards. In plain terms: choose equipment that is appropriate for the intended function and operating environment; mark it so crews and maintenance can identify what it is, what it does, and any limits; install it exactly as the manufacturer’s limitations and instructions require; and make sure all Electrical Wiring Interconnection Systems (EWIS) comply with Subpart H to prevent wiring-related hazards. CS (Certification Specifications) 25.1301 is the foundational “baseline” for equipment function and installation, while AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance) 25.1301 explains practical ways to show compliance. It supports safe operation by preventing mis-selection or misuse through clear labeling, avoiding out-of-scope applications, and reducing wiring failures, fires, and interference through disciplined installation and qualification.
events: Air France 447 (A330, 2009): transient pitot probe icing at high altitude led to unreliable airspeed and loss of automation, prompting EASA ADs to replace certain probes. It shows equipment must be of a kind and design appropriate to its intended function and environment (25.1301(a)(1)).

Swissair 111 (MD‑11, 1998): in-flight fire traced to wiring arcing above the cockpit spread rapidly, driving major EWIS rulemaking in both FAA and EASA. It demonstrates why installations must meet robust EWIS standards to prevent wiring-related fires (25.1301(b), Subpart H).

Ethiopian Airlines 787-8 ET‑AOP Heathrow fire (2013): a lithium-battery ELT experienced thermal runaway, leading to ADs mandating removal/deactivation and design/installation changes. It underscores installing equipment only per its limitations and ensuring installation/wiring do not create new hazards (25.1301(a)(3) and EWIS considerations).

summary: The logic is simple: design flight-deck controls and displays so trained pilots can quickly find, understand, and use them under pressure with predictable results, clear feedback and mode awareness, and enough error tolerance to catch and recover from reasonable mistakes.
intent: Ensure cockpit systems and equipment that pilots use from their seats are designed from a human-factors perspective so trained crews can safely and reliably accomplish their tasks. That means controls exist for all needed actions, and the information to perform those actions is available, clear, unambiguous, and at the right precision. Controls and displays must be easy to reach and use consistent with task urgency and duration, and they must keep pilots aware of system effects and aircraft response to their actions. System behavior must be predictable and unambiguous, with clear mode/status indications, and it must allow pilots to intervene appropriately at any time. Designs should be tolerant of foreseeable pilot interaction errors (good-faith slips, lapses, or mode mistakes), helping crews detect, avoid, and recover from them; this does not cover pure stick-and-rudder skill errors.
events: Air Inter Flight 148 (A320), Strasbourg, 20 Jan 1992: the investigation highlighted potential confusion between flight-path-angle and vertical-speed selections due to similar knob/use and numeric formatting, contributing to a high descent rate and CFIT (BEA). This showed that mode interfaces must present information unambiguously and predictably so pilots cannot mistake units or modes—exactly what CS 25.1302 demands.

Turkish Airlines Flight 1951 (B737-800), Amsterdam, 25 Feb 2009: a faulty left radio altimeter caused the autothrottle to enter RETARD and throttle to idle; the crew did not recognize the mode/status change and airspeed decay (Dutch Safety Board). The accident demonstrated the need for clear, salient mode/status awareness and predictable behavior that enables timely pilot intervention.

Asiana Airlines Flight 214 (B777-200ER), San Francisco, 6 Jul 2013: the crew expected the autothrottle to hold speed while it was inactive in HOLD during FLCH SPD, leading to low energy on approach (NTSB AAR-14/01). This underscored that automation behavior and indications must be unambiguous and predictable, with cues that let pilots detect and correct errors promptly.

summary: The logic is simple: give each pilot an immediately viewable, complete set of essential instruments—plus clear overspeed cues and an independent attitude reference—so the airplane stays controllable and within limits even when systems fail.
intent: Ensure every transport airplane has a standardized, minimum set of flight and navigation instruments, clearly visible to each pilot, so the aircraft can be safely controlled, navigated, and kept within speed limits under all conditions, including failures. This includes core indications (airspeed, altitude, vertical speed, attitude/bank, turn/slip, direction/heading), basic situational aids (clock with seconds, temperature, magnetic compass), and specific protections at higher speeds/altitudes (a distinct aural overspeed warning at defined limits and a Mach meter when compressibility matters). It also requires an independently powered attitude system usable for at least 30 minutes after total generator failure to preserve controllability. Acronyms: VMO (maximum operating speed), MMO (maximum operating Mach number).
events: Birgenair Flight 301 (1996, B757) crashed after a blocked pitot tube led to grossly erroneous airspeed/Mach indications and pilot disorientation. The loss illustrates why reliable, cross-checkable basic flight instruments at each pilot station are essential to diagnose anomalies and maintain control.

China Airlines Flight 006 (1985, B747SP) entered a high-speed dive and exceeded VMO/MMO after an engine failure and upset; the crew recovered but the aircraft suffered structural damage. The case underscores the need for a distinct aural overspeed warning and clear airspeed/Mach indication to prevent or limit exceedances.

Air Transat Flight 236 (2001, A330) lost both engines from fuel exhaustion and continued on RAT/standby instruments to a successful dead-stick landing. It demonstrates the value of an independently powered attitude instrument that remains usable after total electrical generation loss.

summary: The logic is simple: give crews clear, reliable, failure-tolerant indications and alerts of any powerplant or fuel condition that could degrade thrust or starve an engine, so they can act before safety margins are lost.
intent: CS 25.1305 ensures the flight crew always has timely, unambiguous information and warnings about engine and fuel-system health so they can prevent loss of thrust/power, contain damage, and land safely. It mandates continuous fuel quantity displays (total and per tank), alerts for conditions that could starve an engine (misconfiguration, abnormal transfer, trapped fuel, leaks), and a low-fuel alert with at least 30 minutes of cruise endurance remaining, with alert/indication independence from a single failure. It also requires core engine condition instruments (oil quantity/pressure/temperature and fire warnings) and, for turbine engines, indicators for exhaust/gas temperature (EGT), fuel flow, rotor speeds (tachometers), starter operation, engine ice protection, filter contamination, fuel heating, and vibration. Turbojets need thrust (or a directly thrust-related parameter) indications that change with damage or deterioration, plus thrust reverser position indications; turboprops need torque and low blade-angle indications. Any fluid-based augmentation must have a functioning indicator. In short, the rule compels a comprehensive, failure-tolerant set of powerplant instruments and alerts tied to known hazards.
events: Air Transat Flight 236 (A330-200, 24 Aug 2001) suffered a maintenance-induced fuel leak, leading to fuel imbalance, low fuel, and dual engine flameouts over the Atlantic. The event underscores the need for integrated fuel quantity/transfer/leak alerts and early low-fuel warnings, as required by CS 25.1305(a)(2), to prevent undetected fuel-loss conditions from progressing to engine flameout.

Lauda Air Flight 004 (B767-300ER, 26 May 1991) crashed after uncommanded deployment of the left thrust reverser in flight. It directly demonstrates why CS 25.1305(d)(2) requires clear cockpit indication of reverser position (not in selected position and in reverse), enabling crews to identify and respond to reverser malfunctions promptly.

British Midland Flight 92 – “Kegworth” (B737-400, 8 Jan 1989) involved a fan blade failure and severe vibration; the crew shut down the healthy engine, misidentifying the failed one. The accident highlights the need for unmistakable, responsive thrust-related indications and vibration monitoring (CS 25.1305(d)(1) and (c)(9)) so crews can correctly identify the degraded engine during malfunctions.

summary: The logic is simple: build in independent, protected power, communications, and navigation paths so a single failure cannot leave the crew deaf, dumb, or blind.
intent: Ensure a transport aeroplane always retains the ability to power essential systems, talk to air traffic control, and navigate, even after a single failure. The rule requires: at least two independent electrical power sources (e.g., engine-driven generators, auxiliary power unit, or ram air turbine), proper electrical protective devices (circuit breakers/fuses per other CS-25 sections) to isolate faults, and two independent two‑way communication and two navigation systems with controls reachable from each pilot seat. Independence means one failure (including an antenna or a radio set) will not disable the other system; common antennas are allowed only if reliability is proven. The aim is continued safe flight and landing with robust fault containment and no single point of failure in power, communications, or navigation.
events: Swissair Flight 111 (1998, MD‑11): an in‑flight fire fed by arcing IFE wiring overwhelmed protections and led to loss of control (TSB A98H0003). This shows why robust electrical protective devices and segregation are essential to prevent faults from propagating, as required by CS 25.1307(c).

US Airways Flight 1549 (2009, A320): dual bird strike led to loss of engine‑driven generators, but the APU/RAT and multiple radios kept essential instruments and communications alive, enabling a successful ditching (NTSB AAR‑10/03). This demonstrates the value of having two or more independent electrical power sources and redundant comms per CS 25.1307(b), (d).

Qantas Flight 32 (2010, A380): an uncontained engine failure damaged multiple systems, but electrical protection and multiple independent sources isolated faults and preserved key radios and nav, allowing a safe return (ATSB AO‑2010‑089). This underscores the redundancy and independence criteria in CS 25.1307(b)–(e) to prevent a single failure from disabling critical communications and navigation.

summary: The logic is simple: classify how bad each failure could be, design so catastrophic outcomes can’t arise from a single fault and are extraordinarily unlikely even with combinations, make faults containable and obvious to the crew, and maintain the airplane so hidden faults don’t build up.
intent: CS 25.1309 is the cornerstone system-safety rule for large airplanes. It requires every installed system and piece of equipment to work as intended in expected environments, not endanger the aircraft or other systems, and meet risk targets that match the severity of possible failures. Catastrophic failure conditions must be extremely improbable and cannot result from a single failure; hazardous must be extremely remote; major must be remote; and hidden (latent) failures must be minimized and controlled. Designers must assess single and multiple failures, system interactions, and human factors, and must give timely, clear information to the crew to enable safe corrective action while minimizing crew error. Electrical Wiring Interconnection Systems (EWIS) are assessed under CS 25.1709, and Certification Maintenance Requirements (CMR) must be placed in the Airworthiness Limitations Section (ALS) to prevent latent risk accumulation. In short, it ties design, installation, alerts, probability targets, and maintenance together to ensure system-level safety.
events: Boeing 737 MAX MCAS accidents (Lion Air JT610, 2018; Ethiopian Airlines ET302, 2019): a single angle-of-attack sensor failure repeatedly triggered MCAS stabilizer commands without adequate redundancy, failure monitoring, or clear alerting, leading to loss of control. This shows why 25.1309 requires catastrophic conditions not result from a single failure and demands timely, unambiguous crew information.

Qantas 72, Airbus A330-303 VH-QPA (7 Oct 2008): an ADIRU malfunction injected erroneous data, causing abrupt uncommanded pitch-downs and injuries. This illustrates the need for cross-checking, robust fault monitoring, and system interaction analysis so a single unit’s failure cannot create a hazardous condition and the crew can manage it.

Swissair 111, McDonnell Douglas MD-11 (2 Sep 1998): an in-flight fire originating in the overhead area involving IFE system wiring and adjacent materials led to loss of the aircraft. This underscores 25.1309(a)(2) and later EWIS provisions: non-essential systems must not be a source of danger or adversely affect other systems, and installations must prevent and contain such hazards.

summary: The logic is simple: size and route power so essential equipment stays on for the likely time needed under normal and credible failure cases, using alternate sources and crew load-shedding when necessary, even with engines or major power paths lost.
intent: This rule ensures that any equipment needed to meet certification or operating rules (the “essential loads”) keeps working long enough and in the right combinations, even when parts of the power system fail. “Power sources” include engine-driven generators (prime movers), the auxiliary power unit (APU), batteries and ram air turbines (RATs); converters are AC/DC inverters/rectifiers; and the distribution system is the network of buses and feeders. Manufacturers must size capacity and design distribution paths so essential avionics, flight controls, lighting, communications and instruments remain powered with the system healthy, after loss of a generator, after specified engine-out conditions, and after a failure in any one supply or distribution path. The rule allows planned crew monitoring and load shedding to conserve power and focuses the most severe engine-out case for tri-/quad-jets. The objective is controlled flight and safe completion/landing despite credible power-system failures.
events: Air Canada Flight 143 (Boeing 767, 23 July 1983, the “Gimli Glider”) lost both engines from fuel exhaustion and relied on standby power and the RAT to maintain essential flight controls and instruments during a dead-stick glide and landing. This demonstrates the rule’s purpose: essential loads must remain powered for the required duration after loss of prime movers, via alternate sources and prudent load management.

Air Transat Flight 236 (Airbus A330, 24 August 2001) suffered dual engine flameout after a fuel leak and glided ~65 NM with a RAT supplying emergency electrical/hydraulic power to keep fly-by-wire and key avionics alive until landing at Lajes. This shows why capacity and distribution to essential buses, plus load shedding, must support continued controlled flight after generator loss.

US Airways Flight 1549 (Airbus A320, 15 January 2009) lost both engines to bird ingestion; the crew started the APU and the RAT deployed, preserving essential electrical/hydraulic power and instruments for the controlled ditching. This proves the need for alternate sources and distribution that keep essential loads available during severe engine-out scenarios.

summary: The logic is simple: brief negative-g conditions within the certified flight envelope must not by themselves cause any equipment to fail in a hazardous way, for as long as those conditions can last.
intent: Ensure that no aircraft equipment or system creates a dangerous condition simply because the airplane experiences brief negative accelerations (negative g or “weightless”/upward forces) that are allowed by the certified flight envelope. CS (Certification Specifications) 25.333 defines the maneuver and gust envelopes, including the negative-g range; CS 25.1315 requires applicants to show that, for the longest negative-g duration credibly expected, equipment will not malfunction in a way that could seriously endanger the airplane or occupants. This focuses attention on fluid-dependent systems (fuel, oil, and hydraulics) that can “unport” or cavitate; sensors and controls that can misread under reversed acceleration; and safety equipment (e.g., fire suppression, oxygen, waste/water) whose operation must not be compromised by negative g. Applicants typically demonstrate compliance by analysis and test that functions remain safe throughout the specified negative-g time.
events: United Airlines Flight 826 (B747-100, 28 Dec 1997) encountered severe clear-air turbulence that produced brief negative g, injuring passengers when they struck the ceiling; this shows airliners do see negative-g exposures in service, so systems must remain safe during them.

China Airlines Flight 006 (B747SP, 19 Feb 1985) suffered an upset with recorded near-zero and negative g and an engine flameout during the event; this illustrates that upsets impose negative accelerations and critical systems (fuel/oil/hydraulics) must tolerate them without creating additional hazards.

Alaska Airlines Flight 261 (MD‑83, 31 Jan 2000) experienced dives and inversion with documented negative-g excursions; it demonstrates that negative g can persist for several seconds in real events, so equipment must be shown safe for the maximum expected duration.

summary: The logic is simple: design and verify E/E systems so lightning cannot take away functions needed to keep flying and land, and make any upset self-correct quickly without creating new hazards.
intent: This rule ensures that aircraft electrical and electronic (E/E) systems are robust to lightning. For any function whose loss would be catastrophic (i.e., would prevent continued safe flight and landing), the system must continue to work during and after a lightning strike, and automatically return to normal operation quickly if it is transiently upset—unless immediate recovery would conflict with safety (e.g., a controlled lockout state). For functions whose failure would only reduce crew capability, the system must at least recover normal operation in a timely manner after lightning. In practice, applicants show immunity to the indirect effects of lightning (transient voltages/currents induced into wiring and equipment) through design (shielding, bonding, surge protection, grounding, segregation) and verification (analysis and tests per AMC 20-136 and RTCA DO‑160 Section 22). The goal is that lightning does not disable, corrupt, or delay essential functions and that any upsets clear without pilot intervention and without creating new hazards.
events: Aeroflot Flight SU1492 (Sukhoi Superjet 100), Moscow, 5 May 2019: a lightning strike after takeoff led to radio loss, autopilot disconnect, degraded flight-control laws, and electrical abnormalities; the return and hard landing ended in a fatal fire. This shows why systems must resist lightning-induced transients and automatically recover to preserve safe flight and landing.

Boeing 787 certification program (circa 2008–2013): regulators required extensive indirect‑effects‑of‑lightning demonstrations per AMC 20‑136/RTCA DO‑160 Sec 22 and added shielding/copper foils on the composite structure; critical systems (e.g., flight controls, engine controls) had to show immunity and automatic recovery. This programmatic lesson exemplifies CS 25.1316’s expectation for continued function and timely recovery under lightning exposure.

Pan Am Flight 214 (Boeing 707), Elkton, Maryland, 8 December 1963: lightning ignited a fuel tank, causing in‑flight breakup and 81 fatalities. Although focused on fuel safety, the catastrophe drove modern lightning zoning, bonding, and system‑level protection philosophy that also underpins today’s E/E lightning immunity and recovery requirements.

summary: The logic is simple: the more safety‑critical the function, the stronger the proven immunity and recovery to external RF fields it must have, demonstrated against standard HIRF environments and test levels.
intent: Ensure that critical aircraft electrical/electronic systems keep working, and quickly recover if upset, when exposed to strong external radio-frequency energy (“High‑Intensity Radiated Fields” or HIRF) from sources like ground, ship, or airborne radars and high‑power transmitters. The rule tiers the required immunity by consequence of failure: systems whose failure would prevent continued safe flight and landing must withstand severe HIRF environments (Appendix R, Environments I and II) and recover promptly; systems whose failure is hazardous/major must meet defined equipment test levels; and even lower‑criticality systems must meet a baseline level. Appendix R defines the threat levels and test methods, and AMC 20‑158 provides acceptable means of compliance. In plain terms, design, installation, and verification must ensure no unsafe degradation or latent damage during/after HIRF exposure.
events: 2021–2022 5G C‑band roll‑out: FAA AD 2021‑23‑12 and related directives, and EASA SIB 2021‑16, restricted operations because radio altimeters could be degraded by external RF transmissions. This highlighted that strong external emitters can corrupt critical avionics and reinforced the need for robust HIRF immunity and recovery.

Airbus A320 certification (1988): FAA issued Special Conditions for High‑Intensity Radiated Fields to address the novel digital fly‑by‑wire flight‑control system. This program lesson led to codified HIRF requirements (now §/CS 25.1317 and Appendix R) ensuring critical flight controls remain safe in high RF environments.

Boeing 777 certification (mid‑1990s): FAA Special Conditions required HIRF protection for electronic flight‑control and engine control (FADEC/EEC) systems. The requirement demonstrated regulators’ insistence that critical digital controls be immune to powerful external RF, shaping design shielding, bonding, filtering, and test practices.

summary: The logic is simple: find and rank cyber risks to safety, put in safeguards and isolation so deliberate electronic actions cannot degrade essential functions, and keep those safeguards effective through procedures and ICA for the aircraft’s life.
intent: This rule requires large airplanes to be protected against intentional unauthorised electronic interactions (IUEIs)—in plain terms, cyberattacks or malicious electronic interference—that could affect safety. Applicants must use a risk-based process to identify credible threats and attack paths, assess their potential safety impact, and implement mitigations so no unsafe condition can result. Because protection must endure over the aircraft’s life, applicants must also provide procedures and Instructions for Continued Airworthiness (ICA) so that security controls remain effective during operations, maintenance, software updates, and modifications, including third‑party changes. The rule recognises today’s highly connected aircraft (maintenance links, wireless services, passenger connectivity) and demands appropriate isolation, monitoring, and response measures proportional to safety risk.
events: FAA Special Conditions for Boeing 787 (Systems and Data Networks Security—Protection Against Unauthorized Access, 2007) required isolation between external/passenger networks and aircraft systems due to its highly integrated architecture. This shows that connected aircraft need formal security risk assessment and mitigations—the very process CS 25.1319 now mandates.

GAO report GAO-15-370 (2015) warned that modern transport aircraft connected to passenger Wi‑Fi and external networks could be vulnerable to remote exploitation if not properly segregated and protected. It demonstrates that intentional electronic access is plausible and must be assessed and mitigated as an airworthiness matter.

DHS ICS‑CERT Advisory ICSA-14-202-01 (2014) disclosed cybersecurity flaws in SATCOM terminals used on aircraft (e.g., hardcoded credentials, exposed management interfaces) that could be reachable from the internet if misconfigured. This illustrates that onboard equipment can have exploitable weaknesses, reinforcing the need for protections and continued-airworthiness procedures to maintain them.

summary: The logic is simple: put the instruments pilots need most where their eyes naturally look, keep them grouped and standardized, make each engine’s gauges obviously mapped to that engine, and ensure indications remain accurate and readable in all conditions.
intent: This rule ensures pilots can see and interpret essential flight, navigation, and engine information instantly, with minimal head/eye movement, using a standard, intuitive layout that supports correct scanning and decisions. It mandates the “basic T” arrangement—attitude indicator top‑center, airspeed left, altitude right, heading below—so primary cues are always in the same place, reducing scan time, errors, and disorientation. Powerplant instruments must be closely grouped and unambiguously tied to the correct engine (left engine indications on the left, right on the right), with vital parameters plainly visible to the responsible crewmember. It also requires the installation to avoid vibration that could damage or degrade instrument accuracy, and any instrument‑malfunction visual cue to remain conspicuous under all likely cockpit lighting conditions. Together, these provisions standardize cockpit layouts, prevent wrong‑engine or wrong‑parameter actions, and preserve readability so the crew can maintain control and manage failures.
events: British Midland Flight 92 (Kegworth, 1989): The crew shut down the wrong 737-400 engine after misinterpreting cues amid non-familiar instrument arrangements between variants; the AAIB found confusion over engine indications contributed, underscoring why 25.1321(c) demands clear, plainly visible, engine‑to‑indicator association.

TransAsia Airways Flight 235 (Taipei, 2015): Following a flameout on the right engine, the crew inadvertently retarded and shut down the operating left engine; investigators cited misidentification and inadequate instrument cross‑check, showing the need for unmistakable mapping and conspicuous, grouped powerplant indications per 25.1321(c).

Aeroflot‑Nord Flight 821 (Perm, 2008): The 737‑500 crew became spatially disoriented at night and misused the Western‑style attitude indicator; the MAK report cited poor instrument scan and interpretation, illustrating why the attitude indicator must be top‑center and primary flight instruments grouped to support rapid, correct scanning per 25.1321(b).

summary: The logic is simple: present the right alert at the right priority in a way that can’t be missed or misread, avoid false or distracting alarms, and allow the attention-getting part to be silenced once acknowledged while keeping the status visible.
intent: Ensure cockpit alerts reliably tell pilots what is wrong and what to do, without confusion or overload. Alerts must be prioritized by urgency (Warning = immediate awareness and action; Caution = immediate awareness then action; Advisory = awareness), be unmistakable under all conditions (including when many alerts occur), and disappear when the condition ends. Warnings and Cautions must grab attention through at least two senses (aural/visual/tactile), be acknowledgeable, and have attention-getting parts that can be suppressed when the alerting function itself fails. The design must minimize false and nuisance alerts, prevent inappropriate alerts, and provide a guarded means to silence a failed attention-getter with a clear indication that it’s suppressed. Visual alerts must use standard colors (red Warning, amber/yellow Caution, non-red/green Advisory) and limit red/amber/yellow use elsewhere so true alerts stand out.
events: Helios Airways Flight 522 (2005, Boeing 737-300): The cabin altitude warning horn, identical in sound to the takeoff configuration horn, was misinterpreted after the pressurization was left in manual, leading to crew hypoxia and loss of the aircraft. This shows why alerts must be intelligible and discriminable, with coding that makes the condition and required action unmistakable.

Lion Air Flight JT610 (2018, Boeing 737 MAX 8): A single failed angle-of-attack sensor triggered continuous stick shaker and multiple spurious alerts with no practical means to silence the attention-getting cue, contributing to crew overload. This demonstrates the need to minimize false/nuisance alerts and to provide a guarded means to suppress attention-getters caused by alert-function failures while preserving clear annunciation.

Qantas Flight QF72 (2008, Airbus A330-303): An ADIRU malfunction generated repeated warnings/cautions and contradictory cues during uncommanded pitch-downs, creating an alert flood. This underscores the requirement for alert prioritization, clarity under multiple simultaneous alerts, and robust designs to prevent or manage false alerts.

summary: The logic is simple: verify and bound airspeed errors and dynamics across the whole flight envelope—especially takeoff—and make the system robust against contamination and common‑cause damage so the IAS always changes in the right direction, quickly enough, and is trustworthy for pilot decisions.
intent: Ensure that pilots always get an accurate, stable, and sensible airspeed indication across all phases of flight, especially during takeoff, approach/landing, stall margins, and near maximum speeds. The instrument and its installation must be calibrated so indicated airspeed (IAS) relates correctly to calibrated airspeed (CAS), with tight error limits and predictable, monotonic behavior (no “wrong‑sense” changes). It must be specifically checked during the accelerate–go/stop regime (around V1 and up to V2) and designed so lag does not bias takeoff performance. The display must not cause undue difficulty during rotation and initial climb. The system must be robust against moisture, dirt, icing and other contamination, and duplicate sensors should be placed to avoid common‑cause damage (for example, a single bird strike). Acronyms: IAS = indicated airspeed; CAS = calibrated airspeed; V1 = takeoff decision speed; V2 = takeoff safety speed; VMO = maximum operating speed; VFE = maximum flap‑extended speed; VSR = reference stall speed; VDF = demonstrated dive speed.
events: Birgenair Flight 301 (Boeing 757, 6 Feb 1996, Dominican Republic): A wasp‑blocked pitot tube led to grossly erroneous IAS on the captain’s side, autopilot mismanagement, and a fatal stall. It shows why CS 25.1323 demands contamination‑resistant installations, credible IAS behavior, and robust cross‑checks.

Aeroperú Flight 603 (Boeing 757, 2 Oct 1996): Static ports were inadvertently taped over after maintenance, producing wildly misleading airspeed/altitude and multiple conflicting alerts until the aircraft crashed. It demonstrates the need for calibrated, predictable IAS/CAS behavior and protection against obstruction that causes “wrong‑sense” indications.

Air France Flight 447 (Airbus A330, 1 Jun 2009): Pitot probe icing caused unreliable airspeed, autopilot disconnect, and crew confusion culminating in a stall; regulators and industry mandated improved probes and UAS training. It underscores the requirement for airspeed systems resistant to moisture/icing and for indications that remain sensible near high‑speed and stall boundaries.

summary: The logic is simple: if a sensor sits in the airstream and feeds flight instruments, it must be protected (heated or equivalent) so it keeps working in heavy rain and all icing conditions the aircraft is certified to encounter.
intent: This rule ensures that every external sensor feeding the flight instruments (pitot and pitot‑static tubes for airspeed/altitude, static probes, angle‑of‑attack sensors, sideslip vanes, and temperature probes) keeps giving correct data when flying through severe weather. It requires heating or an equivalent protective means so these probes do not freeze, flood, or otherwise malfunction in heavy rain and the full range of certified icing environments. “Appendix C” covers classical supercooled droplets, “Appendix O” covers supercooled large drops (SLD), and “Appendix P” covers ice crystal/mixed‑phase icing. The linkage to CS 25.1420 clarifies how much icing capability the airplane must have (safe exit vs continuous operation vs all icing), and the probes must match that capability. The goal is to prevent unreliable or erroneous flight data (airspeed, altitude, angle of attack) that can lead to autopilot disconnects, flight envelope protection degradation, and loss of control.
events: Air France 447 (A330-203, 1 Jun 2009): Pitot probes iced by ice crystals in convective weather triggered unreliable airspeed, autopilot disconnect, and subsequent loss of control; this underscores the need for probes qualified and heated for ice-crystal/icing conditions (Appendices P/O/C).

XL Airways Germany Flight 888T (A320, Perpignan, 27 Nov 2008): Angle-of-attack sensors froze after water ingress from washing, producing erroneous indications and a fatal stall; this shows why external probes must resist water/heavy rain ingestion and freezing through heating and design features.

EASA AD 2009-0195 (and subsequent ADs) mandated replacing Thales AA pitot probes on A330/A340 after multiple high-altitude unreliable airspeed events in convective weather; the fleet-wide retrofit demonstrates regulators requiring more robust, heated probes tolerant of ice crystals and heavy precipitation, exactly what CS 25.1324 demands.

summary: The logic is simple: keep the static system clean, drainable, airtight, accurately calibrated, and fault‑tolerant so the airplane always “knows” the true outside pressure—and thus true altitude—under all configurations and conditions.
intent: Ensure that the airplane’s static pressure system—the external ports and plumbing that feed ambient air pressure to altimeters, air data computers, and vertical speed indicators—delivers accurate, reliable pressure to the instruments in all conditions. The rule demands ports be placed and protected to minimise errors from airflow, icing, moisture, or debris; that tubing be durable, well‑routed, drainable, corrosion‑protected, and leak‑free; and that the system’s airtightness be proven by a leakage test. It also requires approved, properly calibrated altimeters; defined accuracy across flap/speed ranges (VSR0/VSR1 are reference stall speeds with flaps extended/retracted); safe bypass of any correction devices if they fail; and source‑selection logic that prevents inadvertently blocking both primary and alternate static sources. In short, it prevents wrong altitude/airspeed due to contamination, icing, leaks, or mis‑selection.
events: Aeroperú Flight 603 (1996, B757): Maintenance tape left over the static ports led to grossly erroneous altitude/airspeed indications and loss of control into the Pacific; this starkly shows why static ports must be protected from foreign matter and the system’s integrity verified before flight (CS 25.1325(b)-(c)).

EASA SIB 2016-09R1 (and revisions): Issued after multiple events of unreliable airspeed/altitude from insect, moisture, or contamination of pitot/static ports, recommending strict use of covers, inspections, and drainage; it underscores the rule’s requirement to prevent blockage and maintain correct correlation with true ambient pressure, including in icing (CS 25.1325(b)-(c)).

14 CFR 91.411 and associated maintenance practices: Mandated post‑maintenance altimeter/static system leak tests and calibration checks reflect industry lessons that undetected leaks and water traps cause altitude errors; this programmatic requirement mirrors CS 25.1325(c)(2)’s proof test to ensure an airtight, properly drained static system.

summary: The logic is simple: if probe heat is off or not working, give an amber caution so the crew can act before icing disables critical flight instruments.
intent: This rule ensures that pilots are promptly warned if the heating on any external flight-instrument probe is not working normally. External probes include pitot tubes (airspeed), static ports (altitude/pressure), angle-of-attack (AOA) vanes, and total air temperature (TAT) probes. In icing or precipitation, these probes can quickly freeze and provide false data; a clear cockpit alert at the “Caution” level (amber attention, action required) is therefore required whenever the system is switched off or is selected on but not functioning. The objective is simple: prevent unreliable airspeed/altitude/AOA indications and the cascading flight-control/autopilot issues they cause by giving crews immediate awareness of probe heat status so they can restore or manage it before icing creates a hazard.
events: Northwest Airlines Flight 6231 (B727-200, 1974): The crew departed with pitot heat off; the pitots iced over, produced false airspeed, the aircraft stalled and crashed—demonstrating the need for a conspicuous cockpit alert when probe heat is off.

Birgenair Flight 301 (B757-200, 1996): A wasp-nest–blocked pitot tube led to unreliable airspeed and loss of control; while not a heater failure, it shows how fast loss of probe function becomes catastrophic and why any abnormal probe-system status must be flagged to crews.

FAA introduced 14 CFR 25.1326 (Pitot Heat Indication System) in the 1990s following NTSB recommendations from pitot-icing accidents; this regulatory precedent underpins CS 25.1326’s requirement for a caution alert when probe heat is off or malfunctioning.

summary: The logic is simple: prevent interference and limit error so the magnetic compass and any other heading displays remain accurate and usable when pilots need them most, including as a last-resort reference.
intent: Ensure pilots always have a trustworthy sense of aircraft heading. The rule requires the magnetic direction indicator (the standby compass) to be installed and compensated so airplane vibration and on‑board magnetic fields (from motors, heaters, wiring, ferrous structure) don’t distort it, and to keep its residual deviation in level flight within 10 degrees after a proper compass swing (compensation). It also requires any other direction indicators (e.g., gyroscopic/heading indicators, or IRS/INS-derived heading displays) to be accurate enough for safe navigation in normal and abnormal conditions. In short, isolate the compass from interference, verify its residual error is small, and ensure any alternate heading source is accurate for safe operation.
events: Varig Flight 254 (1989): The crew misinterpreted a heading in the flight plan and flew a grossly incorrect course, ultimately crash‑landing in the Amazon; this illustrates how critical clear, reliable and cross‑checked heading/direction indications are to safe navigation.

OEM programme lesson: Boeing 737NG and Airbus A320 FCOM/QRH procedures instruct crews to turn OFF windshield/window heat before using the standby magnetic compass because the heaters’ magnetic fields can corrupt compass readings; this operational mitigation directly reflects CS 25.1327(a)’s intent to minimise compass error from airplane‑generated fields.

Air Transat Flight 236 (2001): After dual engine flameout, the A330 crew relied on standby instruments to navigate and glide to Lajes; the need for a dependable magnetic compass and adequately accurate alternative heading sources in abnormal conditions underpins CS 25.1327(b)–(c).

summary: The logic is simple: keep automation predictable and clearly annunciated, let pilots instantly and safely override or disconnect it, and never let it command or conceal guidance that drives the airplane outside safe speed, load, or flight-path limits—even when something fails.
intent: CS 25.1329 ensures that the flight guidance system (FGS)—including the autopilot (AP) and autothrust/auto‑throttle (A/THR)—behaves predictably, is easy to disengage, and cannot drive the airplane or mislead the crew into unsafe flight. It requires quick, readily accessible disconnects for both pilots; minimal aircraft transients when modes engage/disengage; clear, unambiguous mode annunciation and control labeling to prevent mode confusion; and protections to keep speeds within a safe margin when the FGS is in use. The system must not impose unacceptable structural loads or hazardous path deviations, must react safely to pilot override, and must provide timely, distinct alerts when AP or A/THR disengage. It also demands safe behavior under malfunctions consistent with the general system safety rule (CS 25.1309), assuming pilots respond within a reasonable time.
events: Asiana Airlines Flight 214 (2013, Boeing 777-200ER, San Francisco): The autothrottle was in a mode (HOLD) that did not wake to protect speed, while the crew believed it would maintain Vref; airspeed decayed to stall on final. This proves the rule’s purpose for clear mode annunciations and speed-margin protection when flight guidance is in use (CS 25.1329(h),(i)).

Turkish Airlines Flight 1951 (2009, Boeing 737-800, Amsterdam): A faulty radio altimeter triggered autothrottle RETARD to idle on approach without adequate crew awareness, leading to a stall short of the runway. This illustrates why autothrust status/alerts, transparent mode behavior, and avoidance of guidance to unsafe speeds are required (CS 25.1329(h),(i),(k)).

China Airlines Flight 140 (1994, Airbus A300-600R, Nagoya): Inadvertent go‑around mode engagement produced strong nose‑up commands while the crew’s push inputs were effectively opposed, culminating in a stall and crash. This underscores the need for quick disengagement, safe pilot override without creating unsafe conditions, and controlled transients during mode transitions (CS 25.1329(a),(d),(l)).

summary: The logic is simple: give each required powered instrument a built‑in “power not OK” indicator, an obvious “data invalid—do not use” cue if external inputs are lost, and an independent backup power feed so one failure can’t remove the same display from both pilots.
intent: Ensure pilots never unknowingly rely on dead or unreliable powered instruments, and that a single power-source failure cannot deprive both pilots of the same critical information. Required powered instruments must self‑indicate when their input power at the instrument is inadequate (e.g., low voltage), must be capable of being powered from an alternate, independent source if one source fails, and must clearly flag on the instrument itself when external data feeds (sensors/computers) are lost or unreliable so the data is not used. The rule applies to standalone instruments and to integrated systems made of multiple remote units.
events: US Airways Flight 1549 (A320, 2009): After dual engine flameout, the ram‑air turbine automatically powered the essential buses, keeping critical flight displays and standby instruments alive for a controlled ditching on the Hudson. This demonstrates the need for alternate power to required instruments after a source failure (CS 25.1331(a)(2)).

AeroPerú Flight 603 (B757, 1996): Static ports left taped produced wildly unreliable air data from both ADCs, and the crew lacked an unambiguous “do not trust” cue on the displays amid conflicting warnings, leading to loss of control at night over water. The accident underscores why instruments must clearly warn when external sensor data is lost or unreliable (CS 25.1331(a)(3)).

Qantas Flight 72 (A330, 2008): An ADIRU malfunction injected spurious attitude/air data; the PFD showed flags and ADR fault messages, enabling the crew to identify and isolate the bad source before landing. This highlights the value of integral invalid‑data indications and independent sources so one fault does not compromise both sides (CS 25.1331(a)(2)–(3)).

summary: The logic is simple: keep each pilot’s essential flight instruments on independent sensors, computers, and power, and isolate extras, so that after any likely single failure one pilot still has airspeed, altitude, attitude, and direction to fly without extra action.
intent: CS 25.1333 makes sure the systems that drive the essential flight instruments required by CS 25.1303(b) — airspeed, altitude, attitude, and direction — are independent between pilot stations and protected from cascading failures. The objectives are: (1) after any single failure or any combination not assessed as extremely improbable, at least one pilot must still have enough reliable information to control the aircraft without needing to reconfigure anything, and (2) any additional or optional equipment connected to those operating systems must not be able to degrade the required instruments if it malfunctions. This leads to separate pitot-static sources, independent air data and inertial units, segregated power and wiring, robust data validation, and a truly independent standby set that stays available in electrical/avionics failures. It also enforces isolation and fault containment so add-ons cannot take down the basic flight instruments.
events: Birgenair Flight 301 (B757-225, 6 Feb 1996) crashed after the captain’s pitot tube was blocked, giving erroneous high airspeed while the first officer’s instruments remained valid. It shows why each pilot needs an independent air data chain and why one pilot must be able to control the aircraft using their own reliable instruments after a single-side failure.

AeroPerú Flight 603 (B757-23A, 2 Oct 1996) suffered taped-over static ports, producing unreliable airspeed/altitude on multiple systems and leading to loss of control. It illustrates the hazard of common-mode failures and the need for segregated sources and a truly independent standby set so one pilot retains usable information.

Air France Flight 447 (A330-203, 1 Jun 2009) experienced pitot icing, triggering unreliable airspeed and autopilot disconnect; despite valid attitude and heading, the crew lost control. It underlines the requirement that essential attitude/direction information remain available and support one-pilot control after air data failures.

summary: The logic is simple: don’t let sensing hardware introduce fire or engine-out hazards, and give crews clear, dependable readings of fuel, oil, and propeller state so they can manage the engines safely in all conditions.
intent: Ensure that powerplant instruments and the lines feeding them are both safe and reliable: flammable-fluid sensing lines (e.g., fuel/oil for pressure or quantity instruments) must be arranged so a failure cannot spray hazardous fluid, and any instrument that uses such fluids must not create a fire risk. Flight crews must always know the usable fuel in each tank (with “zero” calibrated at the unusable level), have protected sight gauges if used, and see oil quantity (including in-flight quantities when oil transfer/reserve systems exist). If a fuel-flow meter is installed, its failure must never choke off fuel to the engine (a bypass is required). For turboprops, required propeller blade-position indicators must directly sense blade angle and warn before entering the ground/beta range.
events: Tuninter Flight 1153 (ATR 72-202, 6 Aug 2005) ditched after fuel exhaustion because a wrong fuel quantity indicator (from an ATR 42) under-read the actual fuel onboard, leading to inadequate fuel for the flight. This shows why the rule demands correct, calibrated fuel quantity indication of usable fuel in each tank to prevent fuel starvation from misleading instruments.

Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 2311 (EMB-120, 5 Apr 1991) crashed after a propeller pitch control failure drove one propeller toward flat/reverse in flight, with limited cockpit awareness of actual blade angle. It illustrates the need for a direct-sensed turboprop blade-position indication that alerts before the blade goes below the flight low-pitch stop, enabling timely crew response.

Programme lesson: modern transport designs moved away from cockpit capillary lines carrying fuel/oil for instruments, using restrictor orifices at the source and remote electrical transducers in the nacelle/fire zones (see EASA CS 25.1337(a)(2) and CS 25.1183/AMC). This evolution, codified in regulation, prevents a ruptured instrument line from spraying flammable fluid and creating a cockpit or nacelle fire, directly reflecting the rule’s purpose.

summary: The logic is simple: size the system for all loads, isolate and protect it so single faults and transients can’t take out essentials or cause fire, give crews control and visibility, block bad ground power, and ensure an independent emergency source automatically keeps the airplane flyable to a safe landing.
intent: CS 25.1351 sets the baseline safety and performance goals for an airliner’s electrical power system. It requires sizing by an electrical load analysis and compliance with the system safety objectives in CS 25.1309. Power generation and distribution must be fault tolerant: sources must operate independently or together without harming each other; essential equipment must see correct voltage/frequency under all probable conditions; and switching/fault clearing must not disable essentials or create smoke/fire. Flight crews need rapid source-isolation controls and clear indications. If external (ground) power is used, interlocks must block wrong voltage, frequency, phase sequence, or polarity. Critically, unless total loss of normal generation is Extremely Improbable (≈10⁻⁹ per flight hour), an independent, high‑integrity alternate source (e.g., APU-driven generator or ram air turbine) must automatically power services needed for immediate safety, continued controlled flight, and approach/landing. AMC = Acceptable Means of Compliance; CS = Certification Specification; APU = Auxiliary Power Unit; RAT = Ram Air Turbine.
events: US Airways Flight 1549 (A320, 15 Jan 2009): After dual engine failure from bird strike, the RAT deployed automatically and powered essential flight controls, instruments, and radios, enabling a controlled ditching on the Hudson. This exemplifies 25.1351(d) that essential services must continue without crew action after loss of normal generation.

Air Transat Flight 236 (A330, 24 Aug 2001): Following fuel exhaustion and loss of both engine-driven generators over the Atlantic, the RAT and APU provided emergency electrical power to maintain fly-by-wire control and navigation for a deadstick landing at Lajes. It demonstrates the need for an independent, high‑integrity alternate power source sufficient to complete descent, approach, and landing.

Swissair Flight 111 (MD-11, 2 Sep 1998): An in-flight fire initiated by IFE wiring led to smoke and progressive electrical failures, culminating in loss of the aircraft. The accident underscores the rule’s requirements for protective devices, wiring segregation, and that faults/transients and wire bundle or panel fires must not disable essential loads or create smoke/fire hazards, nor defeat both normal and alternate power.

summary: The logic is simple: install, separate, control, and monitor electrical equipment, wiring, and batteries so that no single unit’s behavior, interference, or fault can create heat, gas, arcing, or disturbances that harm essential systems or the airplane, with robust bonding to keep currents in intended paths.
intent: CS 25.1353 ensures that all electrical equipment, controls, wiring, and batteries are installed so that one unit’s faults or electrical noise cannot disrupt or endanger essential systems. It requires electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) so that expected electrical interference (EMI) in the aircraft does not cause hazardous effects except with extremely remote likelihood. It ties the Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS) to specific design rules, and demands safe battery design/installation: cell temperature and pressure must remain safe during charge/discharge; no hazardous accumulation of explosive or toxic gases; no corrosive damage; and nickel-cadmium batteries must be protected against short-circuit heat and have automatic charge control and over-temperature or failure sensing with disconnect. Finally, on earthed (ground-return) systems, electrical bonding must provide reliable return paths in normal and fault conditions to prevent stray currents and arcing. Overall, the aim is to keep electrical power, wiring, and batteries from becoming sources of fire, fumes, interference, or cascading failures that threaten safe flight and landing.
events: Swissair Flight 111 (MD-11), 2 Sep 1998: arcing in in-flight entertainment wiring ignited metallized Mylar insulation, causing an intense fire and loss of the aircraft near Halifax. The tragedy drove stricter EWIS design/installation and arc-fault protections, illustrating why CS 25.1353 requires that electrical faults and interference not produce hazardous effects.

Boeing 787 battery incidents (JAL 787 at Boston, 7 Jan 2013; ANA Flight 692, 16 Jan 2013): lithium-ion main/APU batteries experienced thermal runaway with smoke and venting, grounding the fleet. The redesign with containment, venting, improved charge control, and monitoring exemplifies CS 25.1353(c) requirements to control temperature/pressure, manage gases, and disconnect on over-temperature or failure.

TWA Flight 800 (B747-100), 17 Jul 1996: a short circuit likely energized the center wing tank fuel quantity wiring, igniting a flammable fuel-air mixture and destroying the aircraft. It shows why electrical systems, wiring, bonding, and interference control must ensure a unit’s faults cannot create hazardous effects on other systems or the airframe.

summary: The logic is simple: if one electrical source or its feeder fails, the distribution must automatically or manually switch critical loads to an independent source through a separate path so those systems keep working.
intent: Ensure the airplane’s electrical power distribution can keep essential equipment running despite a failure of one power source. The “distribution system” means the power buses (common power bars that feed groups of loads), the feeders (wires/cables from sources to buses), and the protective/control devices (contactors, relays, circuit breakers) that route and protect power. When regulations or the design require two independent power sources for a system (for example, flight instruments, fly‑by‑wire controls, navigation/communication), the architecture must automatically switch to, or allow the crew to select, an alternate independent source with its own separate feeder so a single failure does not darken critical buses. The rule is about continuity of power and physical/electrical independence in the distribution paths, not just having two generators, thereby preventing common‑cause losses and enabling reliable automatic or manual reconfiguration after a fault.
events: US Airways Flight 1549 (2009, A320) lost both engines; the ram air turbine (RAT) automatically powered essential buses, preserving flight controls and instruments for a successful ditching. This shows why the rule requires an alternate source to be automatically provided when normal sources fail.

Air Canada Flight 143 “Gimli Glider” (1983, B767) suffered dual‑engine flameout from fuel exhaustion; standby electrical arrangements kept essential instruments powered throughout the glide and landing. It illustrates the need for the distribution system to maintain operation from an independent source when primary generators are lost.

TACA Flight 110 (1988, B737‑300) lost both engines in severe precipitation; the crew manually started the auxiliary power unit (APU) to restore electrical/hydraulic power and landed safely on a levee. This demonstrates the rule’s allowance for manual selection of an independent power source to keep essential systems operating after a primary source failure.

summary: The logic is simple: automatically and rapidly isolate any faulty electrical source or circuit, protect essential loads individually, and avoid using circuit breakers as switches so electrical faults can’t cascade into fires or system-wide failures.
intent: This rule ensures airplanes have automatic electrical protection so that wiring faults, short circuits, or generator malfunctions don’t escalate into fires, overvoltage damage, or cascading system failures. Protective devices (fuses, circuit breakers, generator controls) must quickly disconnect faulty sources and open circuits even if a pilot switch is left ON. Essential systems must have dedicated protection, and any fuse needed in flight must be accessible with adequate spares. Circuit breakers are not to be used as routine ON/OFF switches unless designed for that function, and auto‑reset breakers are only allowed within equipment if the feeder wires are separately protected. Overall, the aim is to contain electrical faults, preserve essential power, and minimise hazards to the aircraft.
events: TWA Flight 800 (1996): The NTSB found the center wing tank explosion was likely ignited by an electrical short that allowed energy into the fuel quantity indication system wiring. The accident underscored the need for robust fault isolation and protection to prevent stray or overvoltage energy from propagating into vulnerable circuits.

Swissair Flight 111 (1998): An in-flight fire was traced to arcing in wiring associated with the IFE system, with rapid fire growth behind the cockpit. The investigation drove industry changes on wire protection and strict policies against resetting or using circuit breakers as switches, reinforcing the requirement that CBs not be primary power controls and that faults be rapidly isolated.

Boeing 787 ZA002 Laredo test incident (2010): An electrical fault and fire in a power distribution panel led to loss of primary electrical power and an emergency landing. The event prompted design updates to improve fault isolation and circuit protection speed, illustrating the necessity of rapid de-energising of faulty sources and protection of feeders.

summary: The logic is simple: keep live electricity and hot surfaces away from human touch—or make them intrinsically safe—so no crew member, passenger, or maintainer can be shocked or burned during normal use or routine maintenance.
intent: This rule ensures people do not get hurt by aircraft electrical systems. First, the design must minimize the chance of electric shock to anyone who may legitimately touch or work around the airplane: flight crew, cabin crew, passengers, ground servicing staff, and maintenance personnel using normal precautions. That means no accessible live parts, proper insulation and guarding, shrouded connectors, interlocks, safe discharge of stored energy (capacitors), and clear labeling. Second, any part the flight crew must handle in normal operation (e.g., knobs, switches, panels, plugs) must not reach touch temperatures that could burn skin or cause a startle/reflex reaction that might lead to inadvertent control inputs. Together with bonding/lightning rules (CS 25.899), the aim is to make energized hardware and hot surfaces inherently safe to touch during use, servicing, and maintenance, including foreseeable faults.
events: NTSB Safety Recommendations A-07-38 through -41 (June 7, 2007) followed multiple Boeing 757/767 cockpit windshield heat terminal-block arcing fires; these showed that electrical components near the crew can become dangerously hot and must be designed/guarded to prevent burns or startle-induced inadvertent actions.

summary: The logic is simple: keep a crash/ditch‑resilient, independent power source for evacuation/communication/lighting, and make its wiring so benign and protected that it won’t start a fire in a damaged, fuel‑wet or water‑filled airplane.
intent: Ensure that after an emergency landing on land or water (a ditching), the airplane still has a dependable source of electrical power for the equipment needed to carry out emergency procedures—such as evacuation slides and their lights, emergency lighting, public address (PA), emergency locator transmitter (ELT), and essential communications. This supply must not rely on the normal generators that may be shut down or damaged, and must be arranged so its wiring and components are unlikely to ignite spilled fuel or combustibles, or spark in water immersion. In practice this means independent, low-energy, protected power sources (often local batteries) and crash/ditch‑tolerant circuit design, routing, and protection, so crews can evacuate and signal for help without creating a new fire hazard.
events: Air France 358 (A340), Toronto 2005: After a runway overrun and rapid post‑crash fire, emergency lighting and slide‑rafts functioned despite loss of normal power, enabling a full evacuation of 309 survivors. This shows the need for self-powered, protected emergency circuits that remain available and do not add ignition sources in a fuel‑rich environment.

US Airways 1549 (A320), Hudson River ditching 2009: With both engines lost and after water landing, evacuation relied on emergency lighting and slide/raft lighting and essential systems powered independently of the main generators. This demonstrates why aircraft must provide ditching‑resilient emergency electrical supplies to complete evacuation and survival actions when normal power is unavailable.

Programme lesson (modern types A320/A350/B787): Manufacturers adopted distributed, self‑contained emergency lighting power supply units with current‑limited, sealed batteries and segregated wiring to meet CS/14 CFR 25.812 and 25.1362. This practice proves the rule’s purpose by ensuring evacuation lighting remains available after generators are lost while minimizing post‑accident arcing or fire from damaged circuits.

summary: The logic is simple: test the electrical system with equipment and dynamics that behave like the real airplane—and fly it if needed—so you prove safe performance in both normal and failure conditions.
intent: Ensure the aircraft’s electrical power supply really works, in both normal and failed states, by proving it with realistic tests. CS means Certification Specification; AMC is Acceptable Means of Compliance. The rule demands representative testing of generators (including engine- and APU-driven sources), distribution wiring, and actual or accurately simulated loads, while also reproducing how the prime movers (engines/APU) dynamically react to electrical loading and faults. If any flight conditions (for example, high-altitude, high-Mach, or RAT deployment) can’t be credibly reproduced in the lab or on the ground, they must be flight-tested. The goal is reliable voltage/frequency, correct load sharing and shedding, fault protection, and stable operation so essential and critical systems keep working.
events: Boeing 787 ZA002 Laredo incident (9 Nov 2010): an electrical fire in the P100 main power panel caused loss of primary electrical power and an emergency landing (NTSB DCA11IA037). It exposed integration and fault-response weaknesses, showing why representative, fault-loaded testing of generators, distribution, and prime mover dynamics is essential.

Swissair Flight 111 (MD‑11), 2 Sep 1998: in‑flight fire originated with arcing in IFE wiring and spread, leading to loss of the aircraft (TSB Canada A98H0003). It demonstrated how wiring characteristics and fault currents can escalate without robust protections, validating the need for realistic system tests that replicate distribution wiring and fault conditions.

US Airways Flight 1549 (A320), 15 Jan 2009: dual engine flameout led to RAT deployment that powered essential buses during the ditching (NTSB AAR‑10/03). It underscores the requirement to verify emergency electrical supply performance in real flight conditions that labs/ground tests can’t fully replicate.

summary: The logic is simple: cabin electrical appliances must be installed and protected so that heat, faults, and spills cannot start a fire or damage other systems, and motors/transformers get their own overheat protection whenever normal circuit breakers aren’t enough.
intent: This rule ensures that cabin electrical equipment (like galley ovens, coffee makers, chillers, lavatory flush motors, and their transformers) cannot create smoke, fire, burns, or collateral damage—even if their power supply or control systems fail. Installations must contain heat, arcing, spills, and vapours; keep liquids away from other systems; and provide independent thermal protection for motors/transformers if standard circuit breakers are not enough. It ties to CS 25.1309 (system safety objectives for failures) and CS 25.1357 (circuit protection), requiring design and installation measures—such as thermal cut-outs, drip shields, segregation, drainage, and proper overheat controls—so domestic appliances remain fail-safe and do not jeopardize the aircraft. CS means Certification Specification; AMC means Acceptable Means of Compliance.
events: Swissair Flight 111 (1998, MD‑11): an in-flight fire initiated by arcing in a non-essential entertainment/power system led to loss of the aircraft, highlighting the need for robust protection and fail-safe design of cabin electrical equipment and power feeds (the very hazard CS 25.1365 aims to preclude).

Air Canada Flight 797 (1983, DC‑9): a cabin/lavatory fire led to 23 fatalities and spurred enhanced cabin fire protections, underscoring why installations of galley/lavatory equipment must minimise overheat, fire, and burn risks and contain smoke/heat sources.

Fleet AD actions on galley coffee makers/boilers (mid‑2000s onward, e.g., B/E Aerospace units): FAA and EASA issued Airworthiness Directives after multiple in‑flight smoke/overheat events, mandating thermal cutouts/control‑card changes—direct evidence of the need for dedicated thermal protection required by CS 25.1365(d).

summary: The logic is simple: give pilots clear, glare-free, reflection-free instrument lighting with dimming so they can read what matters in any lighting condition without distraction.
intent: Ensure pilots can always see and read the instruments, switches, and essential cockpit devices without being dazzled or distracted. The rule requires cockpit lighting to make all required items clearly legible under all expected conditions (day, night, cloud, bright sun), unless another reliable light source already does so. It also mandates installation that prevents direct light shining into the pilot’s eyes and prevents reflections on instrument faces, screens, or the windshield that could obscure information. Because ambient conditions vary widely, the system must include intensity control (dimming) unless it’s proven safe at full brightness in all conditions. The objective is practical human factors: preserve night adaptation, prevent veiling glare and reflections, and keep attention on flying by providing comfortable, readable illumination.
events: Eastern Air Lines Flight 401 (L‑1011), 1972, Everglades—crew fixation on a landing gear indicator light at night contributed to loss of situational awareness and CFIT (NTSB AAR‑73‑14). It underscores the need for cockpit indications to be immediately readable and non‑distracting, and for lighting ergonomics that support attention on primary instruments.

Programme/guidance lesson: EASA AMC 25.1302 and FAA AC 25.1302‑1 require design and test to avoid glare/reflections and to provide effective dimming for displays and controls. Transport‑category certification campaigns routinely identify and correct windshield/panel reflections with shielding and matte finishes, demonstrating the regulation’s focus on readability without glare.

Low‑visibility/HUD operations guidance: FAA AC 120‑28D and EASA AMC 20‑27 call for managing cockpit lighting brightness and preventing windshield glare during CAT II/III and HUD use. This shows why dimming and shielding are essential—excessive brightness or reflections can degrade external visual cues and pilot performance in critical phases.

summary: The logic is simple: give pilots enough controllable, independent, and well‑indicated landing light capability to see the runway at night without blinding themselves or unknowingly flying with lights extended.
intent: Ensure landing lights are effective for night operations without harming pilot vision, and that pilots can positively control and know the position of extendable lights. The rule requires approved landing lights to be installed so they don’t shine back into the cockpit (no glare), don’t cause “halation” (a blooming halo/reflection off moisture, scratches, or contaminants on windows that washes out outside visual cues), and provide adequate runway illumination at night. It also requires independent control of each light (to manage failures, heat load, or electrical faults without losing all lighting) and a clear cockpit indication when retractable/extendable lights are out, so crews can verify configuration and avoid overspeed/structural damage or unintended drag.
events: Programme lesson (Airbus A320 family): Retractable landing lights have explicit cockpit indication and published extension speed limits (e.g., 250 kt/M0.60) in the FCOM, reflecting service experience that overspeed or unknown extension state can damage light doors and create drag—hence the rule’s requirement for extension indication and independent control.

Operational reports (NASA ASRS): Multiple night approaches in snow/fog document severe halation/“whiteout” when landing lights illuminated precipitation, with pilots restoring usable external cues by switching some or all landing lights off—illustrating why the rule bans objectionable glare and halation.

summary: The logic is simple: put certified red/green/white lights in the standard places, far apart and durable, so others can reliably see your orientation and avoid you in the dark.
intent: Ensure every large airplane has a standardized, reliable navigation (position) light system so other pilots can instantly tell its heading and relative motion at night or in low visibility, reducing mid‑air and ground collision risk. The rule fixes the colors and locations (red on left, green on right, white to the rear), requires the lights to be spaced as far apart as practical for clear aspect cues, and demands use of approved (certified) lights. It also requires lenses/filters to be flame‑resistant and stable so color and brightness don’t degrade with heat, age, or normal use, preserving conspicuity and avoiding fire hazards. As a system, the installation must meet the detailed color, coverage, and intensity requirements in the associated sections so the cues are unambiguous from required angles.
events: Programme lesson – ICAO Annex 2 and Annex 8: International Standards prescribe red (left), green (right), and white (rear) navigation lights and coverage to convey aircraft aspect and right‑of‑way at night; CS‑25.1385 enforces that standard on large airplanes so the cues are consistent and unambiguous worldwide.

Accident – USAir 1493 and SkyWest 5569 runway collision, Los Angeles (1991, NTSB AAR‑91/08): At night the Boeing 737 crew did not visually acquire the Metroliner on the runway in time, highlighting how critical standardized, conspicuous exterior lighting is for detectability in darkness and supporting rigorous installation and performance requirements for position lights.

Programme lesson – FAA AC 20‑30B and TSO/ETSO‑C30 (Aircraft Position Lights): Regulators require use of approved lights and verification of color, intensity, and coverage after installation, demonstrating the need for certified equipment and correct placement to achieve the collision‑avoidance intent of CS‑25.1385.

summary: The logic is simple: make sure the red, green, and white position lights are continuously visible over defined angles so other pilots can instantly tell which way you’re pointed, with only a tiny, controlled allowance for unavoidable tail-light shadowing.
intent: Ensure the red (left), green (right), and white (rear) navigation/position lights are continuously visible over standard angular sectors so other pilots can reliably determine an aircraft’s orientation and relative course at night or in low visibility. The rule defines the exact visibility “dihedral angles” for left (L), right (R), and aft (A) sectors and requires unbroken light within them, harmonizing with international right‑of‑way rules that rely on red/green/white cues. Recognizing that the tail light can be partially blocked by structure, it permits a very small, tightly bounded obstruction (0.04 steradians within a 30° cone) only when the rear light is mounted as far aft as practical, preserving recognition without demanding impractical tail designs.
events: NTSB Safety Study SS-90/01, “Midair Collisions: Limitations of the See-and-Avoid Concept” (1990) found that night detection and orientation judgments rely heavily on unobstructed, standardized navigation light coverage; this supports the requirement for unbroken dihedral angles to prevent misrecognition.

FAA Advisory Circular AC 20-30B, Aircraft Position Light and Anticollision Light Installations, emphasizes compliance with defined dihedral angles and photometry; its guidance reflects service experience where mis-aimed or partially shadowed lights degraded recognition, reinforcing the need for the CS 25.1387 geometry.

Aviation Partners Boeing winglet retrofit programs (e.g., FAA STC ST02278SE for Blended/Split Scimitar Winglets) required demonstration that relocated wingtip navigation lights met the 110° left/right and aft coverage without structural shadowing; this shows the rule directly shapes design and installation to preserve continuous visibility.

summary: The logic is simple: guarantee other pilots see you clearly where they need to, and never so brightly in beam overlaps that your red/green/white signals become ambiguous.
intent: Ensure that an aeroplane’s navigation (position) lights—red on the left wingtip, green on the right, white to the rear—are bright enough in the right directions, consistently bright across vertical angles, and not so bright where beams overlap that they blur together and confuse an observer. Measurements must reflect real, installed performance: with lenses and colour filters fitted, at normal aircraft electrical voltage, and using the average luminous output of the light source. By standardising minimum intensities and limiting overlap maxima (in candela, cd), the rule makes an aircraft’s presence and heading unambiguous at night or in reduced visibility, supporting “see-and-avoid” and preventing mid-air conflicts.
events: EASA ED Decision 2021/015/R (CS-25 Amendment 27) added explicit percentage limits for overlap intensities (10% in Area A and 2.5% in Area B) to accommodate high-peak LED lights; this shows the rule’s purpose is signal clarity relative to the main beam, not raw brightness.

FAA AC 20-30B, “Aircraft Position Light and Anti-collision Light Measurements,” requires testing with lenses/filters installed and at normal system voltage using average luminous output; this mirrors CS 25.1389(a) to ensure certified intensity distributions match what other pilots actually see in service.

TSO-C30e (Aircraft Position Lights) and SAE AS8037 define beam patterns, colour, and overlap control used by transport programmes adopting LED nav lights; applicants demonstrate photometric grids to prove minima and controlled overlaps, preventing misleading colour blending that could obscure aircraft orientation.

summary: The logic is simple: set minimum brightness by angle so oncoming traffic sees strong red/green cues up to 110° and a bright white tail from 110°–180°, letting others detect you early and tell your heading.
intent: This rule sets the minimum brightness (in candela) and where it must be directed, around the horizontal azimuth, for aircraft navigation/position lights: red on the left wing, green on the right wing, and white at the rear (tail).
