Aging Transport Systems Rulemaking Advisory Committee (ATSRAC) inspections (1999–2000): FAA/ATSRAC and NTSB studies documented widespread wire chafing, clamp damage, and physical abuse, particularly in cargo holds, bilges, and above‑ceiling walkways used by maintenance (e.g., NTSB SS‑00/01; ATSRAC final reports). These findings directly led to the EWIS subpart and the requirement to protect wiring from baggage movement, people traffic, and servicing.

summary: The logic is simple: wherever flammable fluids or vapours might leak, treat EWIS as a potential ignition source and apply flammable-fluid fire protection measures so a leak cannot be ignited by the wiring.
intent: This rule ensures that the aircraft’s Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS)—all wires, connectors, splices, clamps, and related hardware—is treated as a possible spark or heat source wherever flammable fluids or vapours could be present due to leaks. Designers must therefore apply the flammable-fluid fire protection standard in CS 25.863 to EWIS in such areas, so that a leak of fuel, oil, or certain hydraulic fluids cannot be ignited by arcing, overheating, or hot surfaces on wiring. The aim is to prevent wiring faults from turning routine leaks or sprays into fires or explosions by using separation, shielding, drip protection, robust insulation, proper support and clamping, and appropriate circuit protection. In plain terms: don’t assume wiring is harmless—assume it can ignite leaked fluids and design accordingly.
events: TWA Flight 800 (Boeing 747-131, 1996): NTSB found the center wing tank explosion was most likely ignited by an electrical short that allowed energy onto FQIS wiring inside the tank, demonstrating wiring can ignite fuel vapours; this drove SFAR 88 and the modern treatment of EWIS as an ignition source.

EgyptAir Flight 667 (Boeing 777-200ER, Cairo 2011): An oxygen leak near the right-hand audio control panel combined with an electrical fault led to a severe cockpit fire on the ground; it shows how leaked oxidizer/fluids and EWIS faults can rapidly produce a fire, prompting ADs to modify oxygen and wiring installations.

SFAR 88 fuel tank safety reviews (FAA, 2001 onward) and resulting ADs (e.g., 737/747 fuel system wiring modifications) required rerouting, shielding, and protection of wiring near fuel tanks and lines to prevent ignition; this programme lesson codified the need to treat EWIS as an ignition source wherever flammable vapours or leaked fuel may be present.

summary: The logic is simple: isolate and harden engine EWIS so one wiring fault or engine failure/fire cannot cascade to other engines or critical functions, allowing continued safe operation.
intent: Make engine-related wiring (EWIS: all wires, bundles, connectors, clamps, and related parts) resilient and isolated so that a single wiring fault does not cripple other engines or force pilots into immediate corrective action. Any EWIS for engines or APUs must be arranged with redundancy and segregation, and routed or protected so that damage from an engine rotor burst (when rotating parts fail and throw fragments) or an engine fire that breaches the case cannot create new hazards. This aligns with engine installation safety goals in CS 25.903: no single failure with catastrophic effects, and protection against uncontained failures and fires. Practically, it drives independent power/control for each engine, physical separation of harnesses, use of fire- and heat-resistant materials, shielding, and routing outside rotor-burst zones so remaining powerplants stay safely operable.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 2010): An uncontained Trent 900 failure showered the wing/pylon with debris, damaging systems and wiring, yet segregation and redundancy allowed the crew to keep the other engines operable and land safely. It shows why EWIS near engines must be routed/protected against rotor-burst hazards so remaining powerplants remain available.

British Airways Flight 2276 (B777, Las Vegas 2015): An uncontained GE90 HPT/compressor failure led to a severe nacelle/wing-root fire that could threaten local wiring; protected, redundant fire-detection/extinguishing circuits enabled shutdown and evacuation. It underscores the need for fire-resistant, protected EWIS to minimize hazards when an engine fire damages wiring.

Lauda Air Flight 004 (B767, 1991): An in-flight thrust reverser deployment led to loss of the aircraft; subsequent ADs and design changes added independent locks and circuit protections, improving reverser control system wiring/logic segregation to prevent single-fault commands. This demonstrates the necessity for EWIS design that prevents a single component failure from creating hazardous powerplant behavior.

summary: The logic is simple: make the wiring that controls flammable-fluid shutoff valves survive a nacelle/APU fire so the crew can still close the valves and starve the fire.
intent: Ensure that the electrical wiring interconnection system (EWIS) that powers or controls every flammable-fluid shutoff device (for fuel, oil, hydraulic fluid) remains operable during an engine/APU/nacelle “fire zone” fire. In plain terms: the wires to the shutoff valves and cockpit controls must either be fireproof or routed/protected so a fire cannot disable the crew’s ability to stop the flow of flammable liquids, as required by CS 25.1189. This prevents a fire from burning through, shorting, or melting the control circuits that close engine/APU fuel spar valves or hydraulic shutoff valves, which could otherwise leave valves stuck open and feed the fire. It ties EWIS robustness directly to fire containment and isolation so that, even in a severe nacelle fire, crews can reliably cut off the fuel or other flammable fluids and stop escalation.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 2010): After an uncontained engine failure, the crew could not shut down one engine using cockpit controls due to damage to control systems/wiring, requiring external firefighting to stop it (ATSB AO-2010-089). This shows why shutoff control paths must be protected so damage or fire cannot defeat fluid isolation.

British Airways 2276 (B777, Las Vegas 2015): An uncontained right engine failure and nacelle fire was met by an abort and fire-handle pull; the system closed valves and enabled effective firefighting (NTSB DCA15FA185). It illustrates the safety benefit when EWIS to shutoff valves remains functional under fire, limiting fuel supply to the nacelle.

Swissair Flight 111 (MD-11, 1998): An in-flight wiring-initiated fire rapidly degraded systems and led to the modern EWIS rule set (TSB A98H0003). The accident underpins the need for fire-resistant/protected routing of critical wiring, including flammable-fluid shutoff controls, so a fire cannot disable them when most needed.

summary: The logic is simple: make manufacturers provide robust, EWIS-specific maintenance instructions and limits so operators can systematically find and fix wiring risks before they cause failures or fires.
intent: Require the applicant to create clear, EWIS-specific Instructions for Continued Airworthiness (ICA) so that wiring and related components can be safely maintained throughout the aircraft’s life. EWIS (Electrical Wiring Interconnection System) includes wires, connectors, splices, clamps, shields, and harnesses. The ICA must follow the general ICA rule (CS 25.1529) and Appendix H (H25.4 and H25.5), meaning it must define what to inspect, how to clean and protect wiring, repair criteria, mandatory inspection intervals and limitations, and any special tools/training. This ensures aging, contamination, chafing, heat, fluids, and vibration that degrade wiring are managed proactively, preventing arcing, smoke, fire, and hidden functional failures in critical systems.
events: TWA Flight 800 (1996, B747-131): NTSB found a center wing tank explosion likely ignited by an electrical short allowing energy into the fuel quantity indication system, highlighting how aging/contaminated wiring can become an ignition source—driving the need for rigorous EWIS ICAs.

Swissair Flight 111 (1998, MD-11): TSB Canada concluded an in-flight fire initiated by arcing in wiring (including IFE wiring) spread rapidly in overhead spaces, underscoring the necessity for defined EWIS inspection, cleaning, separation, and repair practices in ICAs.

Thai Airways International Flight 114 (2001, B737-400): Ground explosion of the center wing tank with probable ignition from FQIS-related wiring demonstrated that inadequate wiring condition/segregation can be catastrophic, reinforcing EWIS-focused maintenance instructions and limits.

summary: The logic is simple: make detector wiring robust to fire and keep zone detections independent (or deliberately common) so a fire doesn’t either kill the warning or trigger false alarms in the wrong place.
intent: This rule ensures that the electrical wiring interconnection system (EWIS) serving engine and auxiliary power unit (APU) fire/overheat detectors will still work in a fire and will not create false alarms. APU means Auxiliary Power Unit; a “fire zone” is a designated area (e.g., engine nacelle or APU compartment) where fire protection is required. The wiring for detection must be at least fire‑resistant so it continues to function when exposed to heat/flame. Also, detector wiring for one fire zone must not be routed through another fire zone unless it is specifically protected against false alarms from that other zone’s fire, or both zones are intentionally tied to the same detection and extinguishing system. The objective is reliable, bounded, and survivable fire detection without cross‑talk or nuisance warnings.
events: Swissair 111 (MD‑11, 1998): a wiring‑initiated cockpit fire led to loss of the aircraft and catalyzed the EWIS rulemaking (EAPAS) that emphasized wire robustness, routing, and protection; it demonstrates why detector EWIS must be fire‑resistant and properly segregated.

ATR 42/72 fleet, EASA AD actions around 2010: operators experienced spurious engine fire warnings traced to detector loops heated by bleed‑air leaks, prompting re‑routing/protection of fire‑loop EWIS; this shows the need to protect detector wiring from adjacent hot zones to prevent false warnings.

Qantas QF32 (A380, 2010): an uncontained engine failure damaged systems and produced engine fire warnings managed with bottle discharge; the event illustrates why fire‑detection wiring in nacelles must withstand heat/damage to provide valid alerts when they are most needed.

summary: The logic is simple: decide if the APU is essential or not, then install and bond all APU-related components per the APU maker’s instructions and Subpart J so they operate safely and are maintainable, using system safety analysis for most hazards while treating case burn-through and rotor burst via specific installation protections rather than CS 25.1309(b) probabilities.
intent: This rule defines what is included in an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) installation and how it must be designed and evaluated for safety. It clarifies that the APU installation covers the APU itself plus any components that control it or affect its safety. It distinguishes an “essential” APU (needed for dispatch and/or continued safe flight) from a “non‑essential” APU (convenience only), because safety objectives and dispatch implications differ. Installations must follow the APU manufacturer’s installation instructions, ensure continued safe operation between inspections, be accessible for maintenance, and have proper electrical bonding to the airframe to prevent arcing/static/lightning hazards. A system safety assessment per CS 25.1309 is required, but the probabilistic criteria of CS 25.1309(b) do not apply to two high‑energy APU failure modes (case burn-through/rupture and uncontained rotor failure), which are instead addressed by specific installation protections in Subpart J (e.g., location, shielding, fire protection, separation).
events: JAL Boeing 787-8 JA829J, Boston (7 Jan 2013): an APU lithium‑ion battery experienced thermal runaway and fire on the ground; this highlighted that components affecting APU control/safety (like start batteries) are part of the APU installation and must be rigorously designed, protected, and accessible for inspection and maintenance.

Regulatory actions on Honeywell 131‑9A/131‑9B APUs: FAA/EASA issued airworthiness directives mandating inspections and part life limits after reports of rotor cracking and uncontained failures; this demonstrates why APU rotor burst effects are handled by specific design/maintenance controls and installation protections rather than CS 25.1309(b) probability targets.

ETOPS practice on Boeing 777: ETOPS certification requires the APU to auto‑start and supply power after loss of main generators, treating it as essential; this shows why the rule distinguishes essential APUs and applies stricter installation and safety requirements tied to dispatch and continued safe flight.

summary: The logic is simple: use an appropriately qualified APU, protect the airplane from its fires or rotor failures, give the crew positive shutdown and rotation-stop capability, and prove it can start in flight within a defined (cold-soak included) envelope when needed.
intent: This rule ensures the auxiliary power unit (APU) is the right kind for its job, is controllable, and cannot endanger the aircraft if it fails. The APU (a small turbine that supplies electrical/air power) must comply with the dedicated APU standard (CS-APU) and be classified as essential or non-essential. Pilots must be able to shut the APU down from the cockpit in normal and emergency conditions, and rotation must be stoppable if continued spinning could be hazardous; components in the APU bay must be fire-resistant. The installation must limit the consequences of an APU rotor failure or an internal fire that breaches the casing, and control/instrumentation must prevent overspeed or other limit exceedances that could compromise rotor integrity. If the APU can be started in flight—or is essential—it must have a demonstrated in‑flight start envelope, including cold-soaked conditions for essential APUs.
events: US Airways Flight 1549 (A320, 15 Jan 2009): After dual bird-strike engine flameouts, the captain immediately started the APU, which the NTSB found helped preserve electrical power and controllability during the ditching. This illustrates why an in-flight APU start capability with a defined envelope is vital for essential or in-flight-startable APUs.

Japan Airlines Boeing 787-8 JA829J, Boston (7 Jan 2013): A thermal runaway of the APU lithium-ion battery caused smoke and fire in the aft electronics bay while parked, prompting an NTSB investigation and design changes. This shows the need to minimize hazards from APU-related fires and to ensure cockpit shutdown and fire-resistant installation features.

Delta Air Lines Flight 1288 (MD-88, 6 Jul 1996): An uncontained engine turbine disk failure on takeoff fatally injured passengers when fragments breached the fuselage (NTSB AAR-98/01). Although this was a main engine, it exemplifies uncontained rotor hazards that CS 25J903 addresses for APUs via shielding, containment, and placement per AMC 20-128A.

summary: The logic is simple: prove the APU and its inlet/installation won’t surge, flame out, or hit dangerous vibrations anywhere you’re allowed to operate, including emergencies, and keep it away from resonant frequencies.
intent: This rule ensures the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU — the small engine that provides electrical power and air when main engines are off or unavailable) behaves safely from start to shutdown in every aircraft operating condition, including emergencies. The APU and its installation must not exhibit hazardous engine behaviors (stall, surge, or flameout) within their approved limits, and the airplane’s inlet/ducting must not distort airflow in ways that create damaging vibration. The installation’s vibration environment must be shown to avoid resonance by staying below critical frequencies and amplitudes defined in CS‑APU 120. In plain terms: integrate and test the APU with the airplane so it remains stable, reliable, and free of harmful vibration or power interruptions whenever it is needed, especially during abnormal and emergency operations.
events: US Airways Flight 1549 (A320, 2009, NTSB AAR-10/03): The captain started the APU immediately after dual engine flameout, preserving electrical power and flight control stability, demonstrating why APUs must operate reliably across the emergency envelope without adverse characteristics.

Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 2010, ATSB AO-2010-089): After an uncontained engine failure disabled multiple generators, the crew used the APU to restore power, underscoring the need to validate stable APU operation during abnormal conditions.

British Airways 2276 (B777-200ER, Las Vegas, 2015, NTSB Accident DCA15FA197): During a severe engine fire and evacuation, the APU was started to supply aircraft power, illustrating the safety case for verifying APU operating stability and avoiding hazardous surges or flameouts under high-stress conditions.

summary: The logic is simple: design and demonstrate the APU installation so that, for the worst expected duration of negative g within the flight envelope, it remains safe (it may shut down, but must not become hazardous).
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) and all associated systems (fuel, oil, electrical, pneumatic, mounts, doors, drains, fire detection/suppression) do not create a hazard when the airplane experiences negative acceleration (negative g loads) that are within the certified flight envelope set by CS 25.333. In practice this means the APU must tolerate brief pushovers, turbulence upsets, or unusual attitudes without fuel or oil unporting, flame, surge, fire, structural damage, uncontained failure, or leakage into the fuselage. Compliance must be shown for the worst credible exposure time to that negative g (i.e., not just a momentary blip), including when the APU is running in flight (e.g., ETOPS) or starting.
events: Boeing 777 ETOPS certification program (1995): Boeing demonstrated in‑flight APU start and sustained operation during adverse attitudes/accelerations per FAA/JAA ETOPS criteria (see FAA AC 120‑42 and Boeing Aero magazine coverage). This shows regulators require APUs to remain safe under negative‑g transients, directly reflecting the rule’s purpose.

China Airlines Flight 006 (1985, B747SP): An upset led to large attitude changes with brief negative‑g excursions before recovery (NTSB AAR‑86/03). It illustrates that negative accelerations can occur in service; APU installations must not add hazards if operating during such events.

Qantas Flight 72 (2008, A330‑303): Two abrupt pitch‑downs produced about −0.8 g and numerous injuries (ATSB AO‑2008‑070). This demonstrates negative‑g of several seconds can occur in normal transport operations, so APU fuel/oil pick‑up, mounts, and fire protection must remain safe for that duration.

summary: The logic is simple: keep the APU fueled across all maneuvers and conditions, and if it’s essential, make the fuel system tolerant to air and icing so it won’t flame out when safety depends on it.
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) always gets enough fuel, at the right pressure, to run properly in all conditions the aircraft may see when the APU is allowed to operate. For APUs designated essential (relied on for continued safe flight and landing, e.g., for electrical/bleed power after engine failures or in ETOPS/EDTO), the fuel system must be more robust: it must tolerate air being introduced into the fuel lines without causing a flameout (loss of combustion), and it must keep running with fuel that contains dissolved and free water which may form ice when cooled. In short, the rule forces design and test margins so the APU won’t quit due to maneuvers, transient air ingestion, or fuel-water icing exactly when it is most needed.
events: British Airways Flight 38 (Boeing 777-200ER, 2008, London Heathrow): dual engine rollbacks from ice formed by small amounts of water in cold-soaked fuel restricted fuel flow, leading to a short landing. This demonstrated how minute water contamination can create ice blockages; CS 25J951(c) requires essential APUs to keep running with water-saturated, icing-prone fuel to avoid similar flameouts.

Boeing 777 ETOPS certification program (mid-1990s): the APU had to be shown to start and run at altitude with cold-soaked, water-contaminated fuel and to tolerate transient air ingestion, as documented in public ETOPS guidance and Boeing/FAA materials. These demonstrations drove robust APU fuel filtration, icing protection, and air-ingestion resilience, illustrating the intent of CS 25J951(b)–(c) for essential APUs.

summary: The logic is simple: analyze and, where needed, test the APU fuel system with representative hardware to show it always functions safely, and ensure any likely heat‑exchanger failure cannot create a hazard.
intent: This rule ensures the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) fuel system is proven safe and reliable. It requires applicants to demonstrate, through engineering analysis and any tests the authority deems necessary, that the fuel system works properly in all probable operating conditions (temperatures, attitudes, transients, contamination, icing, etc.). Tests must use the real aircraft system or a representative test article that faithfully reproduces the relevant operating characteristics. It also demands that the plausible failure of any heat exchanger that uses fuel as one of its fluids (e.g., fuel‑oil heat exchanger or fuel‑cooled oil cooler) cannot create a hazardous situation such as fire, loss of required power, uncontrolled fuel release, or contamination of other systems. In plain terms, don’t just design it—prove it works, and prove that likely failures won’t hurt you.
events: British Airways Flight 38 (Boeing 777-236ER, 17 Jan 2008): Ice crystals blocked the Rolls‑Royce Trent 800 fuel‑oil heat exchanger, restricting fuel flow and causing dual engine thrust loss before landing at Heathrow. The FOHE redesign and expanded cold‑soak/ice‑crystal testing that followed illustrate why representative analysis and testing of fuel/heat‑exchanger behavior under all probable conditions is essential.

Honeywell 131‑9A APU on A320 family: Multiple in‑service events of cracked fuel manifolds and leaks led to ground APU fires/smoke and prompted FAA/EASA airworthiness directives mandating inspections and part replacements. These events show how likely fuel system component failures can create hazards, reinforcing the need to demonstrate safe functioning and failure tolerance.

Airbus integrated “iron‑bird/fuel‑rig” programme lessons (e.g., A350/A380): OEMs used full‑scale rigs that replicated fuel system operating characteristics to validate hot‑day/hot‑fuel starts, suction feed, transients, and failure modes before flight tests. This illustrates the rule’s requirement to use the aircraft system or a representative test article to prove proper function and safety.

summary: The logic is simple: feed the APU independently or make its line isolatable so an APU fuel problem can’t endanger engine fuel supply, and the APU remains available when the engines aren’t.
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) can get fuel reliably without creating a single point of failure that could jeopardise the main engines, and that any APU fuel leak or fire can be quickly isolated. In plain terms: either give the APU its own fuel feed, or if it shares the airplane’s fuel supply with the engines, include a positive shutoff valve so the APU line can be cut off. This prevents an APU line failure from starving engines, prevents fuel from feeding a fire, and preserves the APU as a critical backup power source when engines are unavailable. APU = Auxiliary Power Unit.
events: US Airways Flight 1549 (2009, A320): After dual engine thrust loss from bird strike, the captain immediately started the APU, which provided essential electrical power and stability until ditching (NTSB AAR-10/03). This illustrates why the APU must be assured of fuel supply independent of engine feed vulnerabilities and be isolatable if damaged.

Boeing 777 ETOPS program lesson: To meet ETOPS and Part 25 objectives, the 777 uses a dedicated DC-powered APU fuel pump, check valves, and an APU fuel shutoff valve to isolate the APU fuel feed from engine systems (documented in Boeing FCOM/AMM and FAA AC 120-42B). This design shows the rule’s purpose—an APU fuel fault cannot jeopardize engine fuel and the APU can operate when engines cannot.

summary: The logic is simple: design and prove the APU fuel system will always deliver the required, correctly-pressurized fuel—despite low fuel, manoeuvres, component failures, or a tank running dry—without relying on crew intervention.
intent: This rule ensures the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) always gets enough fuel, at the right pressure, under all expected conditions and manoeuvres. An APU is a small turbine that provides electrical power and air (bleed) when engines are not available or are insufficient; an “essential APU” is one relied upon for safe flight/landing (for example, to back up electrical power in flight or support extended operations). The regulation requires demonstrating 100% of the APU’s fuel demand can be met within its specified pressure limits, even with the minimum usable fuel remaining, during extreme attitudes, and with failures simulated (e.g., a blocked fuel flowmeter) by substituting emergency pumps for main pumps. If the APU can draw from multiple tanks, the system must automatically prevent fuel interruption when one tank runs dry, without crew action, to avoid losing the APU when workload is high. Overall, it is about robust, fail-tolerant fuel delivery to keep the APU working when most needed.
events: US Airways Flight 1549 (NTSB AAR-10/03): The captain immediately started the APU after a dual-engine flameout, and it sustained critical electrical power during the ditching sequence. This highlights the APU’s safety-critical role and why its fuel feed must be assured under dynamic conditions without interruption.

ETOPS/EDTO programme criteria (FAA AC 120-42B; EASA AMC 20-6): These require reliable in-flight APU start and continuous operation to support electrical/bleed redundancy during diversions. That drives designs with automatic, non-interruptible APU fuel supply when a feeding tank is depleted, directly reflecting CS 25J955(b).

summary: The logic is simple: prove the APU’s fuel path stays liquid and reliable with hot fuel under worst realistic loads and altitudes, so an essential APU won’t quit when it’s most needed.
intent: Ensure that an essential APU (Auxiliary Power Unit that is required to support safety‑critical electrical/bleed loads) always gets liquid fuel and runs reliably in hot conditions. Hot fuel can boil and form vapour in low‑pressure sections of the fuel path, causing vapour lock (fuel pump cavitation or gas pockets) that starves the APU and leads to malfunction or shutdown. This rule forces applicants to show, under worst cases, that the fuel system from tank outlet to the APU is kept sufficiently pressurised to prevent vapour formation, or that no vapour‑lock symptoms occur during a climb to the APU’s operating altitude limit (CS 25J1527). If the APU shares pumps/supply with the main engines, the engines must be at maximum continuous power to stress the system, and the test must start with hot fuel (≥ 43°C). Tests may be done in flight or on the ground with credible hot‑weather simulation.
events: Airbus A350 XWB hot‑weather campaign in Al Ain, UAE (2014): Airbus publicly reported extreme‑heat tests including APU operation to validate systems with high ambient temperatures; this demonstrates compliance intent to show no vapour lock or malfunctions with hot fuel. (Airbus Newsroom: A350 XWB ‘Hot Weather’ tests in Al Ain).

Boeing 787 Dreamliner hot‑weather testing at Yuma, Arizona (2010–2011): Boeing’s test program included ground and flight evaluations in >40°C conditions with APU operations, evidencing the requirement to verify pressurised fuel delivery and absence of vapour‑induced malfunctions. (Boeing news releases on 787 environmental testing at Yuma).

ETOPS APU demonstrations (e.g., Boeing 777 program per FAA AC 120‑42B/C and ETOPS rulemaking, 2007): Programs document proving APU start/run capability under adverse conditions and essential loads, underscoring the regulatory need for a reliable, vapour‑free fuel supply to an essential APU. (FAA AC 120‑42B/C; Boeing AERO articles on ETOPS APU reliability).

summary: The logic is simple: put a large, easily inspectable screen at the tank outlet so no debris can reach and starve or damage an essential APU, and size it big enough that it can’t itself become a flow restriction.
intent: This rule ensures that an essential APU (Auxiliary Power Unit—an onboard engine that provides electrical power, air, and starting capability) always gets clean, unobstructed fuel. For APUs that are required for safety (e.g., as backup electrical power), the fuel tank outlet must include a coarse strainer (or an equivalent at the booster pump) sized so it won’t choke flow, yet fine enough to stop debris that could block lines or damage pumps and fuel controls. The strainer’s clear area must be large (≥5× the outlet line area) and at least as wide as the outlet to minimise pressure drop and icing/contamination sensitivity. “Finger strainers” must be readily accessible so maintenance can inspect and clean them, preventing latent blockage from tank debris (sealant slivers, desiccant beads, polymer beads, microbial growth) that could otherwise starve the APU or harm components.
events: Cathay Pacific Flight 780 (A330, 13 Apr 2010): Contaminated fuel containing superabsorbent polymer (SAP) from filter monitors led to fuel metering valve seizure and severe engine malfunctions (AAIA Hong Kong report). It demonstrates how solid contaminants can damage fuel components and restrict flow, validating the need for effective, accessible strainers at the tank outlet.

FAA SAIB NM-09-26 (2009) on Fuel Tank Desiccant Bags: The FAA documented multiple events where desiccant beads migrated from maintenance desiccant bags into tanks, clogging pump inlet screens and fuel controls, causing engine/APU issues. This fleet lesson underpins requirements for inlet strainers with ample area and mandated accessibility for inspection and cleaning.

British Airways Flight 38 (B777-200ER, 17 Jan 2008): Fuel icing restricted flow at the fuel-oil heat exchanger, leading to engine rollbacks on approach (AAIB Report 1/2010). While not a tank strainer failure, it shows that any restriction in fuel feed can be catastrophic, reinforcing the design philosophy of large-area, low-loss inlet strainers for essential power units.

summary: The logic is simple: if the APU is essential, a single pump failure must not stop its fuel supply, and any positive-displacement pump in the line must have a bypass so it can’t block flow if it fails.
intent: Ensure that an APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) that is classified as essential to safe flight has a fuel supply that remains available after any single pump failure, and that any positive-displacement fuel injection pump in the APU supply path (unless it is the APU’s own approved pump) cannot block fuel flow if it stops or seizes. In practice, this means identifying which pumps are “main” for essential APU operation, providing an alternate or emergency pump that takes over immediately upon a main pump failure, and incorporating bypass arrangements around positive‑displacement pumps so fuel can still reach the APU without interruption or structural damage.
events: ETOPS/EDTO certification programs (e.g., Boeing 767/777) require demonstration that the APU can start and run in flight with single failures, including loss of a fuel pump; the ETOPS CMP/AC 120‑42-series framework drove dual/alternate APU fuel feed paths with automatic switchover, illustrating why redundancy and immediate feed continuity are required.

Post‑TWA Flight 800 (NTSB AAR‑00/03) fuel system safety actions led to multiple ADs addressing fuel pump failure modes and dry‑run hazards (e.g., Boeing 737 NG center tank pump ADs), underscoring that pump malfunctions can both interrupt fuel flow and create hazards—hence the need for bypass capability and non‑single‑point fuel supply to essential units like the APU.

summary: The logic is simple: build and install APU fuel lines and connections that are strong, flexible, and temperature‑suitable so they won’t leak under vibration, movement, pressure, or heat—especially inside the fuselage.
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) fuel lines and fittings are installed, supported, and constructed so they do not crack, chafe, or leak when exposed to vibration, pressure pulses, structural movement, and high temperatures (including heat soak after APU shutdown). The rule demands flexible connections where components can move relative to each other, approved flexible hose assemblies where pressurized lines see axial loads, materials proven suitable for the specific application and temperature environment, and installation within the fuselage that tolerates reasonable deformation without leakage. The underlying goal is containment of fuel to prevent fires and loss of APU function by selecting the right hose materials, routing, support, and flexibility provisions.
events: Air Transat Flight 236 (A330-243, 24 Aug 2001): A mis-installed hydraulic line chafed through a fuel line, causing a massive fuel leak and dual engine flameout before a glide to Lajes. It shows why lines must be correctly supported/routed, use suitable materials, and include flexibility to avoid chafing and fatigue leaks as required by this rule.

China Airlines Flight 120 (B737-800, 20 Aug 2007, Naha): Post-landing fuel leakage from the right wing, caused by maintenance-induced damage, ignited and led to a fire and explosion. It illustrates how fuel escaping near hot zones can rapidly ignite, underscoring the need for temperature-suitable hoses and leak-resistant installations.

Qantas Flight 32 (A380-842, 4 Nov 2010): An uncontained engine failure severed fuel pipes and created multiple leaks, which were managed by isolation and did not ignite. The event highlights why robust, well-supported lines and flexible connections that tolerate loads and movement—and minimize leak paths—are critical to preventing fires.

summary: The logic is simple: if the airplane must slide on its belly, APU and fuselage fuel components must not dump fuel that could ignite, so you route, shield, and shut off to prevent a hazardous spill.
intent: Ensure that any fuel system parts located in the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) compartment or within the fuselage are designed, located, and protected so they will not be torn open or crushed in a gear‑up (wheels‑up) landing on a paved runway, as defined by CS 25.721(b). The goal is to prevent a spill large enough to create a fire hazard when the aircraft slides on its belly and structures deform. This drives choices like routing lines away from the lower skin, shielding and guards, robust supports, frangible/breakaway and self‑sealing fittings, and positive shutoff near the tank. It is not demanding zero damage; it requires no hazardous fuel release that could feed a post‑landing fire in a survivable event.
events: LOT Polish Airlines Flight 016 (Boeing 767-300ER, 1 Nov 2011, Warsaw) made a full gear‑up landing and slid on its belly with no post‑landing fire; all 231 evacuated. The absence of a fuel‑fed fire highlights how protecting fuselage/APU fuel lines and providing effective shutoff can keep a survivable belly landing from becoming a fire.

Emirates Flight 521 (Boeing 777-300, 3 Aug 2016, Dubai) experienced gear collapse and a runway slide followed by a major post‑crash fire fed by leaking fuel. It demonstrates the fire hazard from fuel spillage during belly contact, underscoring why CS 25J994 seeks to prevent fuselage/APU fuel leaks in such scenarios.

Asiana Airlines Flight 214 (Boeing 777-200ER, 6 Jul 2013, San Francisco) suffered gear collapse and belly contact on impact, with a significant post‑crash fire fueled by leaking fuel. The event shows how sliding and structural deformation can rupture fuel systems and why minimizing fuselage‑area fuel leakage reduces ignition risk and fire growth.

summary: The logic is simple: support and isolate APU fuel valves so their actuation and inertial loads do not get carried by attached fuel lines—unless you can show those lines are strong enough in all conditions.
intent: This rule ensures the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) fuel valves are mounted and supported so their operation or the airplane’s accelerations (e.g., during maneuvers, turbulence, landing, or rejected takeoff) do not push, twist, or bend the attached fuel lines and fittings. In plain terms, don’t hang a heavy, actuated valve off thin tubing. Either isolate the valve’s actuation and inertial loads with proper brackets/flexible connections, or prove the connected lines and joints have sufficient strength for all loads. The aim is to prevent fuel line cracking, loosened joints, or leaks that could spray fuel into the APU bay, creating fire or shutdown hazards. CS-25J995 complements CS 25J1189 (the required fuel shutoff) by making sure that shutoff devices themselves don’t become a load path that damages fuel plumbing.
events: American Airlines Flight 383 (Boeing 767-323ER, Chicago O’Hare, 28 Oct 2016): NTSB found that released fuel fed a severe engine fire after a catastrophic failure, underscoring how any breach of fuel lines in a fire zone rapidly escalates risk—hence the need to prevent mechanical loads from fracturing fuel plumbing.

British Airways Flight 2276 (Boeing 777-236ER, Las Vegas, 8 Sep 2015): The AAIB reported a large, fuel-fed fire following an uncontained engine failure, illustrating the consequence of fuel release in adjacent compartments and why designs must avoid load paths that can damage lines/valves under high accelerations and vibrations.

summary: The logic is simple: put a properly supported, maintainable, high‑capacity fuel strainer/filter as close to the APU feed as practical so contamination is trapped and drained before it can impair APU starting or running.
intent: Ensure an essential APU (auxiliary power unit needed for safe flight/landing) always gets clean, uninterrupted fuel so it can start and run when demanded. The rule mandates a serviceable strainer/filter in the APU feed line between the tank outlet and the nearest fuel metering device (FMU) or positive‑displacement pump. That filter must be easy to access, drain and clean; include a sediment trap or be easily removable for draining; be mounted so its weight is properly supported (not by the pipes); and be sized/certified to keep the APU operating even when fuel contamination (particle size/density) exceeds normal limits defined for the APU in CS‑APU 250. In short, it prevents debris/water from reaching and damaging or blocking pumps and metering hardware, and makes contamination control straightforward in service.
events: 2018–2019 jet fuel contamination with Diesel Exhaust Fluid (DEF) led to multiple turbine engine/APU power‑loss events, prompting FAA SAFO 18014 and EASA SIB 2019‑11; urea crystals clogged fuel filters and restricted fuel flow, proving the need for robust, maintainable filtration sized for off‑spec contamination.

British Airways Flight 38 (B777‑236ER G‑YMMM), Heathrow, 17 Jan 2008; AAIB Report 1/2010 found ice crystals restricted fuel flow within the FOHE causing engine rollback. Though an engine case, it demonstrates how small contaminants can critically impede fuel system components, underscoring why APU fuel flow must be protected and tolerant to abnormal contamination.

EASA SIB 2008‑34 on FAME (Fatty Acid Methyl Ester) contamination warned that biodiesel carryover in jet fuel can block filters and cause engine/APU malfunctions. This program lesson confirms filters must be accessible for inspection/draining and have capacity margins to handle off‑spec fuel.

summary: The logic is simple: give the APU its own oil system that keeps oil cool and plentiful enough to run for the whole mission—plus margin—so it won’t overheat, leak, or shut down when you need it most.
intent: Ensure the auxiliary power unit (APU) is self-sufficient and reliably lubricated under all approved operating conditions. The rule requires the APU to have its own oil system (independent from the engines) that delivers enough oil, at temperatures safe for continuous operation, to avoid overheating, seal distress, or oil starvation. It also requires the usable oil quantity to be sized by calculation: aeroplane endurance multiplied by the APU’s maximum permitted oil consumption, plus extra margin so oil keeps circulating without uncovering pickups. In plain terms, the APU must not depend on any other system for lubrication, must not overheat its oil, and must carry enough usable oil to run for as long as the aircraft might need it (including long diversions), with margin.
events: ETOPS program lesson (e.g., A350-900 ETOPS 370 and 787 ETOPS approvals): certification required demonstrating the APU could operate for the entire diversion time, driving oil capacity/supply and temperature control design to support continuous operation under maximum oil consumption (see FAA AC 120-42B and EASA ETOPS approvals).

EASA SIB 2017-10R1 (Cabin Air Quality—Smoke/Fumes): cites repeated events where APU oil seal failures and oil leakage contaminated bleed air, reinforcing the need to maintain oil within proper temperature/pressure limits and ensure adequate oil quantity to avoid seal distress and leaks.

EASA and FAA Airworthiness Directives addressing Honeywell 131-9A/131-9B APUs (A320/B737 families) for oil system leaks and fire risk (e.g., oil filter/pump-related leaks): these ADs highlight that improper oil containment or inadequate oil system robustness can lead to APU fires, validating the requirement for an independent, properly sized, temperature-controlled oil system.

summary: The logic is simple: build and route APU oil and breather lines so they don’t leak, don’t ignite in fire zones, don’t ice up and overpressurize, and don’t vent into the APU intake.
intent: Ensure the APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) oil system cannot create a fire, contamination, or reliability hazard. All oil lines and fittings must be as robust as fuel lines (strength, vibration/temperature tolerance, leak resistance) and, where they run through any designated fire zone (areas where fires could occur, like engine/APU compartments), they must meet fire-protection standards. Breather lines (vents that equalize tank/compartment pressure) must be routed so water cannot collect and freeze to block them, their discharge cannot ignite on hot surfaces, and any oil mist or vapour cannot be sucked into the APU air intake, which could feed a fire or contaminate bleed air.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 4 Nov 2010): a Rolls‑Royce Trent 900 oil feed stub pipe manufacturing defect led to an internal oil fire and uncontained engine failure; EASA AD 2010-0224 mandated inspections. This shows how oil line/fitting integrity in fire zones is critical because failures can rapidly cause fires and catastrophic damage that the rule aims to prevent and contain.

EASA SIB 2017-10R1 (Cabin Air Quality—Bleed Air Contamination): documents events where engine/APU oil leaks or venting led to oil mist ingestion into intakes/bleed air with resultant cabin fumes/smoke. This illustrates why APU breathers must not discharge into the intake and must be arranged to avoid creating fire or contamination hazards.

summary: The logic is simple: even if the oil filter plugs, the APU must still receive adequate oil via a safe bypass path, and the crew/maintenance must be warned in time to fix the root cause before unfiltered oil circulates.
intent: Ensure an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) keeps getting enough lubricating oil even if its main full‑flow oil filter becomes completely clogged, and make sure the aircraft provides an early warning before the system goes into filter bypass. In plain terms: the oil system must be designed so that a blocked filter cannot starve the APU of oil (a bypass path and acceptable flow must exist), and there must be an “impending filter bypass” indication (a warning based on differential pressure across the filter) so maintenance can remove contamination before unfiltered oil circulates and damages bearings, seals, or creates fire risk. APU = Auxiliary Power Unit.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (Airbus A380, 4 Nov 2010; ATSB AO‑2010‑089): an oil feed pipe manufacturing defect caused an internal oil fire and uncontained engine failure, underscoring how oil system disruptions can escalate rapidly and why robust oil flow paths and timely indications are critical to prevent lubrication shortfalls and damage.

summary: The logic is simple: make it easy to drain the APU oil system when intended, and make it impossible for the drain to open when not intended.
intent: This rule ensures the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) oil system can be drained safely for maintenance without creating hazards, and that any drain point cannot inadvertently open in service. The drain(s) must be reachable so technicians can properly service, sample, or defuel oil without spills into the tailcone or fuselage. A positive locking device (a mechanism that physically prevents movement from the closed position, manual or automatic) is required so vibration, pressure pulses, or human error cannot leave a drain cracked open. This reduces fire risk from oil contacting hot surfaces, prevents loss of lubrication leading to APU failure, avoids environmental contamination, and improves maintenance reliability.
events: Regulatory ADs on Honeywell 131‑9A/131‑9B APUs (widely used on A320 and 737 fleets) have repeatedly addressed lubrication system oil leaks and resultant APU/tailcone fires; these actions show that unintended oil release in the APU bay is a credible fire hazard. They demonstrate why drains must be both accessible for correct maintenance and positively locked closed to prevent leakage and ignition on hot surfaces.

summary: The logic is simple: make the APU oil cooler strong enough to withstand vibration, g-loads, and oil pressure so it won’t crack or burst, preventing leaks, fires, and lubrication loss.
intent: Ensure the APU’s oil cooler (oil radiator) is structurally strong enough to survive all real operating loads—vibration from the rotating machinery, inertia loads from aircraft motion and APU dynamics, and the full range of internal oil pressures—without cracking, bursting, or leaking. The Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) sits in the tail and its oil system runs near hot surfaces; a failed cooler can dump oil onto hot parts, causing smoke or fire, or starve bearings, leading to mechanical failure. This rule forces designers to prove, by test and analysis, that the cooler’s core, headers, manifolds, mounts, and connections won’t fail under combined loads seen across the flight and ground envelope, including start/stop transients and gusts.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 2010): a mis-manufactured oil feed pipe in a Rolls‑Royce Trent 900 failed, causing an internal oil fire that led to an uncontained engine failure (EASA Emergency AD 2010-0242-E followed). This showed how failure of a pressurised oil component can trigger fire and cascade damage, underscoring why oil coolers must withstand operational vibration, inertia, and pressure without failing.

summary: The logic is simple: make sure the APU oil supply can be positively shut off in a fire and design/support the valves so their operation and flight loads don’t strain or misposition the connected oil lines.
intent: This rule ensures the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) oil system can be safely isolated and that its valves are designed and installed to avoid mis-positioning and line damage. First, any oil shut-off function must meet the APU fire-isolation requirements of CS 25J1189 (i.e., the ability to quickly stop flammable fluid flow to a fire area). Second, oil valves must have clear detents or position indexing for ON/OFF to prevent ambiguity, and the valves must be supported so operating them—or aircraft g-forces—do not transfer loads into attached oil lines unless those lines and fittings are proven strong for all such loads. This prevents leaks, ruptures, and fires from valve-induced stresses or mis-rigging, and ensures crews can reliably shut off oil in emergencies.
events: Qantas Flight 32, Airbus A380 (ATSB AO-2010-089, 2010): a Trent 900 oil feed stub pipe manufacturing defect led to an internal oil fire and uncontained engine failure—demonstrating how oil system integrity and the ability to isolate oil flow are critical to preventing and limiting fires.

summary: The logic is simple: design and operate the APU installation so component and fluid temperatures stay within limits during the hottest, least-cooled conditions and through post‑shutdown heat soak, preventing damage, malfunctions, and fires.
intent: This rule ensures the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU)—the small engine that provides electricity, bleed air, and engine start capability—stays within safe temperature limits in all critical situations on the ground and in flight, and even after it is shut down. “Cooling provisions” means the installation’s airflow, ventilation, insulation, heat shields, and operating procedures that keep APU parts and fluids (oil, fuel, hydraulic fluid) from overheating. It targets hot-day, low-airflow ground ops, high bleed/electrical loads, tailwind or blocked inlets, and the post‑shutdown “heat soak” period, when residual heat can cook oil, boil fuel, damage wiring/structure, or trigger fires or hot‑start failures at the next APU start. The intent is reliable APU operation without thermal damage or fire hazards throughout the full operating envelope, including normal shutdown.
events: Programme lesson: Honeywell 131‑9 APU operating manuals require a cooldown period at no or low load before shutdown to prevent oil coking and hot‑section distress, directly illustrating the need to control temperatures during post‑shutdown heat soak (verifiable in Honeywell 131‑9A/D APU AMM/OPS guidance).

Programme lesson: Boeing 737NG FCOM Normal Procedures call for about 1 minute of APU operation with no bleed/electrical load before shutdown, showing a procedural cooling provision to keep APU and fluids within limits after normal shutdown (see Boeing 737NG FCOM, APU Shutdown).

Programme lesson: Airbus A320 family FCOM recommends a no‑bleed APU cooldown (typically ~1–2 minutes, especially after bleed use) before shutdown to avoid heat‑soak‑related oil coking and hot‑restart issues, evidencing the requirement to manage temperatures under critical ground conditions and after shutdown (see Airbus A320 FCOM, APU procedures).

summary: The logic is simple: measure APU component/fluid temperatures under critical conditions, correct them to the specified hottest-day atmosphere if the test day was cooler, and confirm the adjusted temperatures stay within established limits.
intent: This rule ensures the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) and its installation can keep all parts and fluids (like oil, fuel, generators, ducts) within their temperature limits during the hottest plausible operating conditions. Because real tests may be run on days cooler than the worst case, the rule tells you to mathematically correct (adjust) the measured temperatures to a defined maximum ambient temperature profile (sea-level max, with a standard lapse rate to -56.5°C). If the corrected values would exceed any limit, the installation isn’t acceptable. In short, it standardizes how to prove APU cooling is adequate in hot-day, high-heat-soak scenarios without requiring every test to be run in extreme ambient heat.
events: JAL Boeing 787 JA829J APU battery fire at Boston (Jan 7, 2013; NTSB briefs): thermal runaway in the APU start battery highlighted how APU-associated components can overheat if not adequately managed, underscoring the need to demonstrate temperature margins in worst-case conditions.

AAIB Bulletin 6/2010, Airbus A321 G-MEDL, APU fire at stand (Heathrow, 26 Oct 2009): tailcone fire linked to APU area overheating showed that installations must keep temperatures within limits during ground operations, a core aim of standardized hot-day cooling tests and corrections.

FAA AD actions on APU/bleed systems (e.g., Boeing 737 series ADs addressing APU bleed air check valve/duct overheat risks): mandated inspections and parts changes due to hot bleed air leaks demonstrate the safety consequence of inadequate thermal control and the importance of proving cooling margins via corrected-to-hot-day testing.

summary: The logic is simple: test the APU installation in its hottest, least-cooled configurations until temperatures stop rising (or a limit is reached) to prove it stays within safe limits throughout real operations.
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) installation and its components/fluids (e.g., oil, fuel, hydraulic fluids, bleed-air ducts) can be adequately cooled in the worst realistic operating scenarios. The rule demands flight or ground tests be run in configurations and conditions most critical for cooling (high ambient temperature, low airflow on ground, doors/bleed/electrical loads as used operationally), with temperatures allowed to “stabilize” (defined as changing less than 1°C per minute) before assessing each critical condition. Tests must continue long enough to capture slow heat-soak effects and must end only when temperatures stabilize, the flight stage ends, or an operating limit is reached. This prevents premature termination that could miss late-peaking temperatures and ensures the declared operating limits keep the APU and nearby structure safe.
events: NTSB investigation of Japan Airlines Boeing 787-8 JA829J APU battery fire at Boston Logan on 7 January 2013 (widely published NTSB docket and reports). It underscored that components located in/near the APU bay can reach hazardous temperatures without robust worst-case thermal analysis and test validation, reinforcing the need for stabilized, critical-condition cooling tests and hard operating limits for thermal protection.

summary: The logic is simple: make sure the APU only inhales clean air under all conditions, and keep fire, fuel, water/slush, and debris out—using firewall isolation wherever the intake could communicate with other compartments.
intent: This rule ensures the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) always breathes clean, safe air and cannot ingest hazards. The APU is a small turbine that provides electrical power and bleed air (compressed air for systems) on the ground and sometimes in flight. Its intake must reliably supply enough air in all certified conditions, be isolated from any compartment that could contain fire/smoke (via a firewall), and be protected so flammable fluids (fuel from drains/vents), water/slush, or foreign object debris (FOD) cannot be sucked in. The aim is to prevent fire/explosion risks, smoke/fume contamination of bleed/cabin air, flameouts/surges, and mechanical damage to the APU while taxiing, taking off, or landing.
events: NTSB AAR-14/01 (JAL Boeing 787-8, Boston, Jan 7, 2013): An APU battery fire in the APU bay showed that fires can occur in or near the APU compartment; firewall isolation prevents smoke/flame from being drawn into intake/bleed paths, underscoring the need for compartment-air isolation.

FAA AC 120-60 (Ground Deicing and Anti-icing Program): Advises avoiding APU bleed/pack use or shielding intakes during de/anti-icing because glycol/water spray can be ingested and contaminate cabin air or upset the APU, directly aligning with the rule to prevent hazardous fluid and water ingress.

Transport Canada AC 700-059 (Ground Icing Operations): Explicitly warns not to direct de/anti-icing fluids toward APU intakes and to manage APU operation to avoid ingestion, illustrating industry practices derived from the hazards this rule addresses.

summary: The logic is simple: if the airplane may need the APU in icing, prove its intake system prevents ice‑related malfunctions across all modern icing environments (including snow) and for a sustained ground exposure—otherwise restrict its use to non‑icing.
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) air intake and any screens/ice‑protection can cope with all relevant icing environments so the APU does not lose power, surge, stall, over‑temperature, or flame out, and does not create hazardous interactions with the airframe. If an APU is non‑essential (not needed for safe continuation/termination of flight), it may be limited to non‑icing use unless safety in icing is shown. If an APU is essential (e.g., needed for electrical/bleed power for critical systems, engine start, or EDTO/ETOPS), it must be demonstrated to operate across its power range in Appendix C (classical icing), Appendix O (supercooled large droplets), Appendix P (ice crystal/mixed‑phase), and in falling/blowing snow, plus a 30‑minute ground run in critical icing conditions, all without unacceptable effects. The goal is to prevent ice accumulation or ingestion from degrading APU performance or damaging it when the airplane relies on it.
events: FAA AD 2013-24-01 addressed multiple GE90 engine rollback/power‑loss events on Boeing 777 due to ice‑crystal icing in convective weather; those events led to new standards (Appendix P) and show why powerplant intakes must handle ice crystals. Applying the same environment to APUs ensures an essential backup power source won’t fail when most needed.

American Eagle Flight 4184 (ATR 72), Roselawn, 31 Oct 1994, crashed after supercooled large droplet (SLD) icing exceeded the classical envelope, prompting development of SLD provisions now captured in Appendix O. Extending SLD to APU intakes prevents designs that are safe in classical icing but vulnerable to freezing rain/SLD or wet snow, averting stalls/surges and flameouts.

EDTO/ETOPS programs (e.g., Boeing 777) treat the APU as an essential safety power source, requiring demonstrated in‑flight start/operation and ground operation in icing and snow per CS/§25.1093; associated AFM limitations and tests are publicly documented via ETOPS policy (AC 120-42) and certification materials. This program experience underpins CS 25J1093’s requirement for essential APUs to run across their range and for 30 minutes on the ground in icing without adverse effects.

summary: The logic is simple: keep flammable fluids out of the intake, make the duct tough and fireproof where it matters, and ensure it won’t fail when flows reverse or doors/structures move.
intent: Ensure the APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) air intake ducts cannot become a source or pathway for fire or hazardous gases. The rule requires intake ducts to drain away any fuel or moisture so nothing flammable can pool, to be made of materials that don’t soak up or trap fuel, and to be robust against abnormal flow conditions such as reverse flow, APU surges, or an inlet door closing. Duct sections within and just ahead of the APU bay must be fireproof (able to withstand a severe fire without burn-through) so any hot gas blowback cannot burn through the ducting and spread into other compartments. The rest of the intake system must tolerate the highest heat expected. Where parts move relative to each other, the ducting must flex so it doesn’t crack or leak. Overall, it prevents ignition sources and hot gases from turning the intake path into a fire/propagation route.
events: Japan Airlines Boeing 787-8 JA829J, Boston Logan, Jan 7, 2013: an APU battery fire filled the APU bay with heat and smoke; it demonstrates why APU-compartment-adjacent intake ducting must be fireproof and sealed to prevent hot gas/fire propagation into other areas.

Lufthansa Airbus A321-200 at Munich (reported by Aviation Herald): an APU tailpipe fire during start at the gate showed how APUs can produce hot gas blowback; this underscores the need for intake ducts designed for reverse flow without burn-through and for proper drainage to avoid pooled fuel ignition.

Ryanair Boeing 737-800 at Dublin (reported by Aviation Herald): an APU fire on stand led to smoke in the cabin; events like this highlight why intake/plenum design must prevent accumulation of flammable fluids and use non-absorbing materials, limiting the chance and consequences of ignition.

summary: The logic is simple: design APU bleed ducts to fail safely, include flexibility where things move, and prevent backflow in shared manifolds so a single fault cannot turn hot, pressurized air into a fire or system-damaging hazard.
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) bleed air system is inherently safe if something goes wrong. Bleed air is very hot, high-pressure air tapped from the APU or engines and routed through ducts to start engines, run air conditioning packs, or deice systems. The rule’s aims are: (1) a duct failure (rupture, disconnection, or leak) anywhere between the APU and the user unit must not create a hazard (fire, structural damage, critical system loss, or unsafe cockpit conditions); (2) ducts spanning parts that move relative to each other must include flexible joints to avoid cracking or pull-off; and (3) when APU and engine bleeds share a common manifold, design must prevent hazardous reverse flow into the APU if a valve or component malfunctions (e.g., stuck/non‑return valve), which could cause APU surge, overheat, or fire.
events: Boeing 757 pack-bay smoke/fire events from ruptured hot bleed ducts led to FAA corrective action (e.g., AD action around 2000 on 757 bleed/pack area), showing why a bleed duct failure must not become a hazardous condition (CS 25J1106(a)).

Airbus A320-family in-service events of engine/APU pneumatic reverse flow prompted EASA AD action requiring replacement or inspection of APU bleed non‑return/check valves, demonstrating the need to prevent hazardous reverse airflow into the APU when sharing a common manifold (CS 25J1106(c)).

BAe 146/RJ series cabin-smoke occurrences reported by the UK AAIB traced to degraded or failed flexible joints in bleed ducting, leading to mandated inspections—illustrating the requirement for flexibility between components with relative motion to prevent duct failures (CS 25J1106(b)).

summary: The logic is simple: route and cool APU exhaust, shield and separate hot parts from any flammable fluid or structure, and verify no CO or fire hazards exist even if leaks occur.
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) exhaust system cannot create fire or poisoning hazards. It must route exhaust gases safely so carbon monoxide (CO) cannot enter any occupied compartment; position or shield hot parts so a leak of any flammable fluid (fuel, oil, hydraulic fluid) cannot be ignited; make any part that could be hit by hot exhaust or heated by exhaust components fireproof; keep exhaust discharge away from flammable fluid vents and drains; and provide ventilation/insulation so exhaust components and shrouds do not reach ignition temperatures in normal operation. Demonstration may use any acceptable CO detection method. Fireproof separation is required between exhaust components and adjacent airplane structure outside the APU compartment.

summary: The logic is simple: use heat/corrosion‑resistant exhaust pipes, support them against vibration and loads, and include flexible joints for thermal growth and relative motion so the system doesn’t crack, leak, or fail in service.
intent: Ensure the APU exhaust pipes can survive their harsh environment without cracking, leaking hot gas, or breaking loose. That means using materials that resist heat and corrosion, designing joints that allow thermal expansion from high operating temperatures, supporting the pipes to withstand vibration and G-loads in service, and incorporating flexible sections where the APU and airframe can move relative to each other. The aim is to prevent fires, structural heat damage, and hazardous exhaust leaks that could endanger the aircraft.
events: Programme lesson – Boeing 737 Classic: FAA Airworthiness Directives in the 2000s mandated repetitive inspections and repairs of cracked APU exhaust ducts and supports after field reports of hot-gas leaks and tailcone heat damage, underscoring the need for heat‑resistant materials, proper supports, and thermal‑expansion accommodation.

Programme lesson – Airbus A320 Family (Honeywell 131‑9A APU): EASA issued ADs requiring inspection/replacement of cracked APU exhaust mufflers/ducts caused by thermal fatigue and vibration, demonstrating why exhaust piping must be designed for high‑temperature corrosion resistance and expansion.

Programme lesson – Bombardier CRJ series: Regulatory actions and service bulletins addressed failures of APU exhaust bellows/flexible couplings and support brackets that led to leaks and overheat warnings, illustrating the necessity for flexible joints where relative motion exists and robust supports against vibration.

summary: The logic is simple: put robust, unmistakable APU controls where crews can use them without accidental activation, confirm critical valve positions, and make the APU shut itself down and isolate fuel/bleed automatically if anything goes wrong—especially when no one is watching.
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) can be safely controlled and will protect itself when unattended. The rule requires clear, properly placed and marked cockpit controls to start, stop, and emergency‑shut down the APU, designed so they aren’t bumped accidentally and stay where set. APU valves (e.g., fuel and bleed) must have positive stops and, when remotely actuated, provide direct position indication so the crew knows the valve actually moved. For unattended operation (common during ground turns), the APU must automatically shut down on any limit exceedance or hazardous condition, and isolate/shut off flammable fluids if there’s a fire. Any extra controls elsewhere on the aircraft must also be protected against inadvertent operation and resist vibration/loads, and control parts in fire zones must be fire‑resistant. In short, prevent inadvertent activation, confirm valve positions, and ensure automatic containment of fires, leaks, or runaways.
events: Emirates A380 APU fire at Shanghai Pudong (Apr 11, 2011): An APU caught fire on the ramp, prompting evacuation; the event underscores the need for automatic shutdown, fuel isolation, and remote emergency stop during unattended ground operation (Aviation Herald report of Apr 11, 2011).

Japan Airlines Boeing 787-8 JA829J, Boston (Jan 7, 2013): An APU lithium‑ion battery thermal runaway caused fire/smoke while parked, highlighting hazards in the aft bay during unattended periods and the need for autonomous protections and fire‑resistant components in the APU installation (NTSB Report NTSB/AIR-14/01).

summary: The logic is simple: only use approved APU accessories on approved mountings, keep any sparking electrical gear away from flammable fluids or vapours, and for essential APUs provide a disconnect so a failed driven accessory can be stopped without losing the APU.
intent: This rule ensures that any accessories installed on the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) are properly approved, correctly mounted using the APU’s certified provisions, and do not create ignition or safety hazards. It requires that electrical items which may spark or arc be located and shielded so they cannot ignite any flammable fluids or vapours that might be present in the APU bay. For APUs deemed essential (e.g., needed in flight for electrical power on ETOPS aircraft), it requires a means (such as a clutch or shear coupling) to stop a failed, APU‑driven accessory from continuing to rotate if that rotation could compromise aircraft safety—without forcing the APU itself to shut down. In short, it prevents incompatible add‑ons, avoids ignition sources near fuel, and ensures the APU can keep providing essential power even if a driven accessory fails.
events: Japan Airlines Boeing 787-8 JA829J, Boston (7 Jan 2013): The APU lithium‑ion battery underwent thermal runaway and fire while parked; NTSB found internal short and inadequate containment. It showed APU‑related electrical equipment can be a potent ignition source and must be installed/isolated so a fire cannot threaten nearby flammable materials.

TWA Flight 800, Boeing 747-131 (17 Jul 1996): The center wing tank exploded due to ignition of a flammable fuel‑air mixture, likely from electrical arcing, per the NTSB. Though not in the APU bay, it cemented the need to prevent arcing equipment from contacting flammable vapours anywhere on the airplane, including APU compartments.

ETOPS policy lesson (FAA AC 120-42B; EASA ETOPS guidance such as AMC 20-6): Essential APUs must remain available in flight independent of driven accessories, leading industry to use starter‑generator shear couplings/overrunning clutches so a seized generator can be disconnected without shutting down the APU. This directly reflects CS 25J1163(c)’s aim to prevent a failed accessory’s rotation from jeopardizing safe operation.

summary: The logic is simple: keep APU ignition on its own isolated electrical path so other system faults can’t take it out or make it misbehave, while allowing only the control and monitoring connections it needs.
intent: This rule says the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) ignition system—the parts that make the spark to light its fuel—must have its own dedicated electrical circuits, isolated from the aircraft’s other electrical systems. It may only be tied to circuits that directly help it start, control it (e.g., start logic), or monitor/analyse its operation (e.g., health monitoring). The goal is to prevent a single fault elsewhere in the airplane’s electrical system from disabling APU ignition or causing unintended igniter operation, and to ensure reliable starting and safe operation when the APU is needed for power or bleed air, especially in abnormal or emergency conditions.
events: JAL Boeing 787-8, JA829J, Boston (7 Jan 2013): An APU battery thermal runaway led to a fire while parked; the redesign that followed emphasized dedicated, isolated APU start/ignition power paths and enhanced monitoring, underscoring the safety value of keeping APU ignition circuitry independent and limited to assisting/controlling/analysing interfaces (NTSB/AIR-14/01).

summary: The logic is simple: treat every APU compartment as a fire zone so all standard fire detection, suppression, containment, and isolation rules automatically apply.
intent: This rule’s objective is to state plainly that the auxiliary power unit (APU) bay is a fire-hazard area and must be protected accordingly. By declaring any APU compartment a “designated fire zone,” it forces application of the full fire‑protection suite in CS-25 Subpart J—detection, extinguishing, containment/firewalls, ventilation/drainage control, and shutoff/isolation—so a fire originating in the APU or its fuel/oil/bleed-air systems is quickly detected, contained, and extinguished without endangering the aircraft. CS means Certification Specification and APU means Auxiliary Power Unit.
events: Japan Airlines Boeing 787-8, Boston Logan, 7 Jan 2013: an APU lithium‑ion battery fire in the aft electronics bay produced smoke and flames on the ground (NTSB DCA13IA037). It showed APU-related systems can ignite in aft fuselage compartments, underscoring the need for robust detection, isolation, and extinguishing around APU-associated fire zones.

In-service APU-bay fires on aircraft with Honeywell 131‑9A/131‑9B APUs due to fuel leaks prompted FAA/EASA Airworthiness Directives mandating inspections and modifications (public ADs issued in the 2010s). These events illustrate that leaks onto hot APU components can ignite, validating the requirement to treat the APU compartment as a designated fire zone with detection, extinguishing, and containment.

During certification of modern types (e.g., Airbus A350 XWB and Boeing 787), manufacturers were required to demonstrate APU-bay fire detection/extinguishing effectiveness and firewall integrity as a designated fire zone in compliance with CS 25J1185–25J1203. These programme demonstrations exemplify the rule’s purpose: the APU compartment must meet the full fire-protection standard.

summary: The logic is simple: make anything that can feed a fire robust and arranged so leaks can’t ignite, and make anything that could spread fire or disable essential services truly fireproof, so any APU fire stays contained.
intent: This rule aims to keep any fire in the APU area contained, starved of fuel, and unable to disable critical systems. Any line, fitting, or component that carries flammable fluids in APU fire areas (designated fire zones) must at least be fire-resistant; tanks and their supports must be fireproof or shielded, and items must be located or shielded so leaked fluid cannot ignite. Exceptions apply to parts already approved as part of the APU, and to vents/drains whose failure cannot create a fire hazard. Additionally, any component or duct inside a designated fire zone that could let fire spread elsewhere, or that could unintentionally operate or disable essential services if damaged by fire, must be fireproof. Designated fire zone means spaces with both flammable fluids and ignition sources (e.g., the APU compartment). Fire-resistant means it continues to function during a defined short exposure to fire; fireproof means it withstands a much more severe/longer fire without failure.
events: British Airways Flight 2276 (Boeing 777‑200, Las Vegas, 8 Sep 2015): an uncontained engine failure ruptured a main fuel supply line, causing a severe fuel‑fed fire in the nacelle. The event underscored the need for fire‑resistant lines and shielding in designated fire zones to limit ignition/spread and preserve time for evacuation.

British Airtours Flight 28M (Boeing 737‑236, Manchester, 1985): an engine failure led to a fire that penetrated the fuselage through gaps/ducting with catastrophic results. The accident drove stronger fireproofing and sealing to prevent fire spread from a fire zone, illustrating the paragraph (c) intent for components/ducts that could propagate fire.

JAL Boeing 787‑8 JA829J (Boston, 7 Jan 2013): the APU lithium‑ion battery underwent thermal runaway and fire in the aft electronics bay. The redesign added a fireproof enclosure and venting to contain and isolate a fire and protect essential systems, mirroring the rule’s requirement that components that could spread fire or disable services be fireproof.

summary: The logic is simple: keep flammable fluids out of APU fire zones or make them as safe as if they were outside, physically separate them from hot/fire barriers, and stop any nearby materials from soaking up leaked fluid that could sustain a fire.
intent: This rule ensures that any part of the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) area identified as a designated fire zone (a compartment where fires are more likely, such as the APU bay) is designed so flammable fluids or gases (fuel, oil, hydraulic fluid) cannot create or worsen a fire. It requires either keeping tanks/reservoirs out of fire zones, or, if they must be inside, giving them equivalent safety through robust design, materials, shutoff valves, and protected lines/controls. A required 12.7 mm (0.5 inch) air gap from firewalls/shrouds helps reduce heat conduction and wicking, and allows inspection. Absorbent materials near components that can leak must be covered or treated so they cannot soak up and hold flammable fluids. In short, the rule prevents leaks from accumulating or feeding a fire in the APU compartment and ensures quick isolation if a leak occurs.
events: AAIB Report 4/2015 – British Airways Airbus A319-131 (G-EUOE), London Heathrow, 24 May 2013: Unlatched fan cowl doors detached, damaging a fuel pipe and causing a nacelle fire; this underscores why flammable-fluid systems in fire zones need robust design, reliable shutoff, and protection from leakage and pooling.

NTSB HAR-18/01 – American Airlines Flight 383, Boeing 767-323ER (N345AN), Chicago O’Hare, 28 Oct 2016: An uncontained engine failure severed a fuel line, producing a significant fire in the engine zone; it demonstrates the necessity for effective isolation of flammable fluids and designs that minimize fuel accumulation in hot areas.

JTSB AAI07-6 – China Airlines Flight 120, Boeing 737-800 (B-18616), Naha, 20 Aug 2007: A maintenance-induced fuel leak at the wing leading edge ignited on hot surfaces, leading to a rapid post-landing fire; it illustrates how leaked flammable fluids can quickly ignite and why materials and proximity in potential fire zones must prevent absorption and heat transfer.

summary: The logic is simple: don’t let fuel or vapours accumulate in fire zones, don’t let air paths spread fire or dilute the extinguishing agent, and either shut off ventilation during a fire or size the extinguishing system to cope with maximum airflow.
intent: This rule aims to keep any area that could experience an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) fire safe by ensuring flammable liquids (like fuel or oil) cannot pool, flammable vapours cannot build up, and airflow does not spread fire or defeat extinguishing systems. It requires effective drains that work when needed and route any leaked fluid to safe locations, ventilation that prevents vapour accumulation without allowing flames or fluids to pass between zones, and discharge of vapours where they will not create new hazards. Because strong airflow can wash away extinguishing agent, crews must be able to shut off forced ventilation unless the fire-extinguishing system was sized and tested for maximum airflow. In plain terms: remove fuel, control vapours, and manage airflow so a fire is less likely to start, spread, or resist extinguishing.
events: AAIB Special Bulletin S5/2013 – Airbus A319-131 G-EUOE, Heathrow (24 May 2013): unlatched fan cowl doors led to fuel line damage, fuel release, and a nacelle fire; it illustrates how leaked flammable fluid and strong ventilation can drive a fire and why drainage/vent management is critical to limit hazards.

FAA Fire Safety R&D (e.g., DOT/FAA/AR-95/79 and DOT/FAA/AR-00/28) demonstrated that high nacelle/APU ventilation flow rapidly dilutes Halon concentrations and reduces extinguishing effectiveness; this underpins the requirement to either size bottles for maximum airflow or provide a means to shut off forced ventilation.

Boeing transport practice (e.g., 737NG/787 FCOM/QRH): pulling the APU fire switch shuts the APU down and closes the APU air inlet door and bleed air/pack valves; this design lesson shows compliance with the rule’s purpose to stop forced ventilation so extinguishing agent remains effective and to prevent ingestion/egress of flammable vapours.

summary: The logic is simple: if an APU fire starts, immediately and reliably stop any flammable liquid from getting to it—without harming other critical systems—and make sure the shutoff hardware survives and works under fire and structural damage.
intent: This rule ensures that, in an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) fire zone, crews and systems can quickly stop flammable liquids (fuel, oil, hydraulic fluid) from feeding a fire, and that the shutoff hardware itself continues to work during a fire.
