APU means the small turbine that provides electrical/air power when engines are off; a designated fire zone is any area where a fire is expected and must be contained. The regulation requires shutoff valves for lines entering the APU compartment (with narrow exceptions), that closing an APU fuel valve must not starve the main engines, and that valves/controls are fireproof or protected, guarded against inadvertent use, reopenable in flight, and pressure-relieved. It also demands that after shutoff, no hazardous quantity of flammable fluid can continue to drain into the fire zone, and that valves are placed so structural failure of the APU mount won’t disable them.
events: British Airtours Flight 28M (Manchester, 1985): an uncontained engine failure ruptured fuel lines and a fuel-fed fire engulfed the fuselage, showing why designs must rapidly isolate and prevent drainage of fuel into fire zones; this principle underpins APU fire-zone shutoff requirements as well as engines.

American Airlines Flight 383 (Chicago O’Hare, 2016): an uncontained CF6 failure led to a severe fuel-fed fire; closing the fire handle isolated fuel, illustrating the need for reliable, fire-resistant shutoff valves that operate in a fire without compromising other emergency functions.

summary: The logic is simple: put the APU in a fireproof, corrosion‑resistant box with only sealed, fireproof passthroughs so flames, hot gases, or fluids can’t get into the rest of the airplane.
intent: Keep any fire, hot gases, or leaking fluids from an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) from spreading into the rest of the airplane. The APU must sit inside a fireproof barrier (firewall or shroud) whose joints and penetrations (wires, tubes, cables) are sealed with fireproof fittings so nothing hazardous can pass through. That barrier must also resist corrosion so it stays effective for the aircraft’s life. In plain terms: if the APU or anything attached to it catches fire or leaks, the structure around it contains the event and prevents flames, smoke, and fluids from reaching the cabin, systems, or structure until detection and extinguishing work.
events: Japan Airlines Boeing 787-8 JA829J, Boston Logan, 7 Jan 2013: an APU lithium‑ion battery fire produced smoke and heat in the aft electronics bay; NTSB AAB‑14/01 found improved containment and venting were needed to prevent hazardous gases/flames from entering the airplane. This directly supports isolating APU-related fires and sealing penetrations so hazards cannot pass to other areas.

FAA/EASA Special Conditions for Boeing 787 main and APU batteries (e.g., FAA 25‑431‑SC, updated after the 2013 events) require battery enclosures that contain fire and vent by‑products overboard. These programme requirements mirror CS 25J1191’s intent: even if ignition occurs in the APU/battery space, no hazardous quantity of air, fluid, or flame may reach the cabin or systems.

summary: The logic is simple: build the APU compartment to contain any fire and shed fuels/heat so it cannot burn through the skin or spread to other parts of the aircraft, in flight or on the ground, while withstanding normal loads.
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) bay is structurally robust, well-drained and ventilated, and built as a true fire zone so that any fire remains contained and cannot threaten the rest of the aircraft. The rule requires the compartment to withstand operational loads (vibration, inertia, airflow), remove leaked fluids and vapors (to prevent pooling/ignition), and make all hot/exhaust-adjacent surfaces fireproof. It also demands that a fire in the APU bay cannot pass through openings or burn through the external skin into other areas, including with landing gear retracted. External skins in flame-exposed areas must be fireproof in flight, and, on the ground, fireproof where critical areas could be affected and at least fire-resistant elsewhere. AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance) 25.1193(e) guides acceptable demonstrations. Fireproof means capable of withstanding a standardized severe fire for a specified time without failure; fire-resistant means limited resistance to fire and heat.
events: Incident: Ethiopian Airlines Boeing 767-300 at Oslo Gardermoen (Aug 27, 2019) suffered an APU fire while parked, visibly burning in the tailcone; the contained damage and need to protect adjacent aft fuselage areas illustrate why CS 25J1193(e) requires fireproof skins and zone isolation (Aviation Herald report).

Programme lesson: Following the JAL Boeing 787-8 APU battery fire at Boston (Jan 7, 2013), regulators emphasized containment and isolation of aft-bay fires; although a battery event, it underscored the need for aft-compartment fire containment so a localized fire cannot spread to adjacent zones, aligning with CS 25J1193(e) intent (NTSB investigation).

Incident: Ryanair Boeing 737-800 at Frankfurt-Hahn experienced an APU fire during ground operations prompting an evacuation; such recurrent tailcone/APU fires in service reinforce the need for proper drainage/ventilation and fireproof bay boundaries to prevent propagation and skin burn-through (Aviation Herald case).

summary: The logic is simple: use an agent that reliably extinguishes the likely APU fires and stays stable, and design the airplane so people never inhale dangerous levels of that agent even if something leaks or misfires.
intent: Ensure the APU’s built‑in fire-extinguishing agent actually puts out the kinds of fires expected in the APU bay (fuel, oil, hydraulic fluid, wiring), remains chemically and physically stable across all storage temperatures it will see, and, if the agent is toxic (for example, Halon 1301), the installation prevents any dangerous concentration of that agent or its vapours from reaching occupied areas (cockpit/cabin) during leaks or discharge—on the ground or in flight—even if a system fault exists. In short, the rule balances effective fire knock‑down with protection of occupants from chemical exposure.
events: UPS Flight 6 (B747‑44AF, near Dubai, 2010): The UAE GCAA final report found a lithium battery fire rapidly overwhelmed the Halon 1301 cargo suppression, underscoring that extinguishing agents must be effective for the combustible materials present—mirroring the rule’s demand that agents be capable of extinguishing the actual fire threat.

Alaska Airlines Flight 17 (B737‑900ER, Seattle, 13 Apr 2015): A ramp worker was trapped in a cargo hold and the crew avoided discharging halon due to toxicity risks; the widely reported incident highlights why designs must prevent harmful extinguishing‑agent concentrations from reaching occupied spaces.

summary: The logic is simple: keep the bottle safe and venting harmlessly, ensure it always has the right pressure to discharge effectively, and give unmistakable indication of discharge/low charge so crews and maintenance know the true state of fire protection.
intent: Ensure that Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) fire-extinguishing agent bottles are safe, reliable, and effective in all conditions. Containers must not burst; they need pressure relief that vents harmlessly and cannot clog (e.g., with ice). Any vented discharge must not damage the aircraft. The system must provide a clear indication when a bottle has discharged or when its charge/pressure is below the minimum needed, so crews and maintenance can act. Bottle temperature must be controlled so internal pressure stays within a band that guarantees proper flow on demand (not too low to starve discharge, not so high that it vents or fires prematurely). If pyrotechnic cartridges (“squibs”) are used to open the bottle, installation must protect them from heat that could degrade their performance. In short, the rule prevents explosive failures, inadvertent discharge, and ineffective suppression due to low pressure or degraded squibs.
events: Qantas Flight 32 (Airbus A380), Singapore, 4 Nov 2010 (ATSB AO-2010-089): an uncontained engine failure damaged systems; one fire bottle discharged and a second could not, with cockpit indications confirming bottle status for crew decision-making. This shows why clear indication of bottle discharge/availability is essential (CS 25J1199(c)).

UPS Flight 6 (Boeing 747-44AF), near Dubai, 3 Sep 2010 (UAE GCAA Final Report): the halon cargo suppression could not achieve/maintain effective concentration, highlighting the criticality of assured discharge rates and sustained pressure. It illustrates why container pressure must be maintained across temperatures and why premature venting must be prevented (CS 25J1199(d)).

Programme lesson and industry practice: external discharge indicator disks and overboard venting for engine/APU bottles (e.g., Boeing 737 AMM 26-21-00; Airbus AMM 26-23-00) distinguish squib discharge (red) from thermal relief (yellow) and route relief flow safely outside. This widely adopted design demonstrates the need for safe vent locations and unmistakable discharge indications (CS 25J1199(b)-(c)).

summary: The logic is simple: use materials that won’t react with the agent and make all APU-bay fire‑extinguishing hardware truly fireproof so the system will still deliver agent during an actual fire.
intent: Ensure the APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) fire‑extinguishing system is chemically and thermally robust so it works when a fire occurs. First, materials used anywhere in the system (bottles, discharge heads, pipes, valves, seals) must not chemically react with the extinguishing agent (e.g., Halon 1301 or approved replacements like HFC‑125 or FK‑5‑1‑12) in a way that creates hazards such as leaks, corrosion, clogging, or toxic/flammable by‑products. Second, every system component located in the APU compartment must be “fireproof,” meaning it can withstand a 2000°F (≈1093°C) flame for 15 minutes without failing, so the agent can still be delivered despite the surrounding fire. The goal is to prevent the extinguisher from being defeated by its own materials or by heat at the very moment it’s needed.
events: FAA Technical Center report DOT/FAA/AR-01/37 on material compatibility of halon-replacement agents showed certain elastomers and plastics can swell, embrittle, or leach when exposed to agents like HFC‑125 and FK‑5‑1‑12, risking leaks or valve sticking—exactly the hazard paragraph (a) is written to prevent.

FAA Advisory Circular AC 20-135 (Powerplant Installation and Propulsion System Component Fire Protection Test Methods, Standards, and Criteria) established the 2000°F/15‑minute fireproof test, ensuring APU fire‑extinguishing bottles, lines, and valves remain functional in a compartment fire as required by paragraph (b).

FAA research (e.g., DOT/FAA/AR-99/58 on toxicity and decomposition of halogenated agents) documents that agents exposed to high heat/flame can generate hydrogen halides; choosing system materials that do not further react or degrade under these conditions reduces added hazards and preserves extinguishing performance.

summary: The logic is simple: put fast, robust, and in‑flight‑testable APU fire/overheat detection in the right places so it still detects a fire despite a single open or short, isn’t fooled by fluids, avoids cross‑zone false alarms, and meets a proven activation time standard.
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) bay has a fast, reliable, and testable fire/overheat detection system that will promptly alert the crew to a fire and keep working even if damaged. The detectors must withstand vibration and loads, tolerate a severed wire or a short circuit (by either continuing to detect or warning of the failure), and not be fooled by oil, water, or fumes that may be present. Crew must be able to test detector circuits in flight. All detection components inside a fire zone must be at least fire-resistant, and wiring must not route through other fire zones unless protected against false alarms or the same system protects all zones it traverses. Detectors must meet approved response-time criteria (e.g., ETSO-2C11e) so alarms come fast enough to enable timely fire suppression.
events: JAL Boeing 787-8, Boston Logan, 7 Jan 2013: an APU battery thermal runaway caused a significant fire/smoke event in the aft electronics bay, investigated by NTSB (NTSB/AIR-14/01). The rapid escalation underscored the need for quick, reliable APU-related fire detection and unmistakable crew alerts to prompt immediate mitigation.

summary: The logic is simple: you must prove the APU fire protection works, preferably by full-scale test, but you may use similarity, component tests, service experience, or analysis unless a specific test is mandated.
intent: This rule tells applicants how to prove an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) installation meets the fire-protection requirements in CS 25J1181–J1203. The underlying objective is to ensure the APU fire zone, detection, shutoff, and extinguishing features are credibly demonstrated using appropriate evidence. Full-scale tests are acceptable, but the rule permits efficient alternatives when justified: tests of similar APU installations, component-level tests, in-service experience from comparable aircraft, or engineering analysis—except where the rules explicitly require tests. This balances safety with practicality by focusing testing where it is needed and letting proven designs rely on existing data.
events: JAL Boeing 787-8 Boston APU battery fire (7 Jan 2013, NTSB DCA13IA037): Thermal runaway of the APU lithium-ion battery caused a fire on the ground. It showed that reliance on analysis and limited component testing can underappreciate ignition/containment risks, prompting regulators to require more representative testing and evidence—illustrating when analysis alone is insufficient.

Programme lesson – Boeing 737 MAX APU: The 737 MAX retained the Honeywell 131-9B APU used widely on the 737NG, with extensive service experience publicly documented for that model. Certification leveraged similarity and in-service data with targeted component tests rather than repeating full-scale demonstrations for unchanged aspects, exemplifying CS 25J1207’s allowance to use prior evidence to substantiate compliance.

summary: The logic is simple: give the crew clear warnings and status to prevent APU exceedances and fires, allow equivalent automatics instead of gauges, and add ice‑protection/heater status when the APU is essential in flight.
intent: The rule’s purpose is to ensure the flight crew can detect and control risks from the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) at all times. It mandates a cockpit fire warning for the APU, a clear indication if the APU has automatically shut down, and enough parameters or protections to avoid exceeding APU limits (like temperature, speed, or oil limits) and to keep it operating safely. If automated protections provide equal safety (for example, automatic limiters and self‑protection with reliable annunciations), displaying the raw parameter isn’t required. When the APU is essential for safe flight (e.g., needed in flight for electrical/air supply such as in EDTO/ETOPS), the crew must also have indications that the APU ice‑protection and fuel anti‑ice heating functions are working to prevent ice‑related failures.
events: ETOPS/EDTO certification lesson (e.g., Boeing 777; FAA AC 120-42B and EASA AMC 20-6): Demonstrations and in‑service experience showed the APU must reliably start/run at altitude and in icing, leading to operational emphasis on monitoring APU anti‑ice and fuel heat status—exactly why essential APUs need clear ice‑protection indications.

JAL Boeing 787-8 JA829J, Boston, 7 Jan 2013—APU battery thermal runaway and fire (NTSB DCA13IA037): The event underscored the need for robust APU‑area fire detection/annunciation and automatic protections to alert personnel and limit escalation from APU‑related fires.

summary: The logic is simple: always provide a straightforward, reliable way to check APU oil level—without relying on aircraft power—so it can be serviced to a safe, correct quantity and prevent failures or fumes.
intent: CS 25J1337(d) requires every Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) oil tank to have a simple, direct way to measure oil quantity—traditionally a dipstick (“stick gauge”) or an equivalent indicator. The underlying objective is to let crews and maintenance verify oil level accurately and independently of aircraft electrical power, so the APU can be serviced correctly before use. Reliable oil quantity checks prevent oil starvation (bearing damage, in-flight or ground shutdowns) and overfilling (oil ingestion into the bleed-air path causing fumes/smoke), both of which have safety, reliability, and air-quality implications. This simple, robust indication also supports dispatch decisions (e.g., ETOPS operators relying on an in‑flight APU start) and reduces maintenance errors by giving a clear, physical reference for correct servicing.
events: ATSB AR-2008-018 (An analysis of fumes and smoke events in BAe 146 aircraft): multiple cabin fume events were traced to engine/APU oil seal leaks and servicing issues, showing that correct oil quantity control and verification are critical to prevent bleed-air contamination.

EASA SIB 2017-10R1 (Cabin Air Quality — Fumes/odours in the cockpit/cabin): identifies engine/APU oil as a common source of fumes and recommends correct oil servicing and verification, reinforcing the need for reliable oil quantity indication such as a dipstick or equivalent.

summary: The logic is simple: make all APU limits and essential procedures unmistakably visible to the crew via instrument markings, placards, and the AFM so they always operate the APU within its certified safe envelope.
intent: This rule ensures that everything pilots need to operate the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU — the small turbine that provides electrical power and bleed air when engines are not running or as backup) is clearly provided to them. It ties APU certification to three crew-facing channels: instrument markings (CS 25J1549), cockpit/aircraft placards (CS 25J1551), and the Airplane Flight Manual (AFM) operating limitations (CS 25J1583). The aim is to prevent misuse or misinterpretation by making limits such as start/stop conditions, altitude, temperature, load, speed, and abnormal/emergency procedures unambiguous and immediately accessible. This supports safe normal operations, rapid decision-making in failures, and adaptation to temporary limitations from airworthiness directives or service bulletins.
events: US Airways Flight 1549 (A320, 15 Jan 2009): The captain immediately started the APU after dual-engine loss, preserving electrical/flight control power per NTSB AAR-10/03, showing why clear in‑flight APU start limits and procedures must be available to crews.

Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 4 Nov 2010): After an uncontained engine failure, the crew started and used the APU within AFM limits to stabilize systems (ATSB Report AO‑2010‑089), illustrating the need for readily accessible APU operating information.

JAL Boeing 787 JA829J (Boston, 7 Jan 2013): An APU battery fire led to FAA Emergency AD 2013‑02‑51 mandating temporary AFM limitations/procedures restricting APU operation until modifications, demonstrating the importance of promptly conveying APU limits to crews.

summary: The logic is simple: only publish and use APU limits that the APU and its systems are actually certified for, and make those limits clear as aircraft operating limitations.
intent: Ensure the aeroplane’s published operating limitations for the APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) exactly match the APU’s own certified limits and system capabilities, and clearly state the categories of operation (e.g., ground-only, in‑flight use, unattended operation), along with altitude/temperature envelopes, electrical and bleed load limits, time-at-power, and start-attempt limits. This alignment prevents crews or maintenance from using the APU beyond what its type design and systems are approved to do, reducing risks of fire, overspeed, overload, or system damage. It also ensures dispatch, ETOPS/EDTO planning, MEL use, and training reflect the APU’s true certified capability.
events: British Airways Flight 9 (1982, Jakarta volcanic ash): The Boeing 747-200’s AFM documented the APU as ground‑only and not startable in flight; the crew could not rely on it during the four‑engine flameout. This highlights why AFMs must clearly state APU categories of operation and never imply inflight capability beyond approvals.

US Airways Flight 1549 (2009, Hudson River ditching): The captain immediately started the A320’s APU after the dual engine failure, an AFM‑permitted action that preserved electrical/flight‑control power, as documented by the NTSB. This shows the safety value of clear, published in‑flight APU operating limits.

Japan Airlines Boeing 787-8, Boston (2013 APU battery fire): An APU battery thermal runaway on the ground led to NTSB investigation and FAA Emergency AD 2013-02-51 followed by AD 2013-08-12 mandating modifications and operational restrictions. This demonstrates that aircraft APU limitations must track system‑approved limits and be updated/published when risks or capabilities change.

summary: The logic is simple: define and publish the temperature and altitude envelope where the APU is proven safe and functional so crews don’t use it outside conditions it was designed to handle.
intent: Set and publish the environmental envelope in which the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) may be used. In plain terms: the manufacturer must determine the hottest and coldest outside air temperatures and the lowest and highest altitudes where the APU can be safely started and operated, considering aircraft flight conditions, structural and installation limits, and APU/equipment performance. These limits become operating limitations (e.g., in the Aircraft Flight Manual, AFM) so crews and maintainers know when the APU can be relied upon and when its use could lead to failures or unsafe conditions. APU = Auxiliary Power Unit; AFM = Aircraft Flight Manual; ETOPS = Extended-range Twin-Engine Operations.
events: US Airways Flight 1549 (A320), Hudson River ditching, 2009: The captain started the APU immediately after dual-engine power loss, providing critical electrical/hydraulic power as documented by the NTSB. This shows why clearly defined in-flight APU temperature/altitude envelopes are essential so crews can reliably count on APU availability in emergencies.

Air Transat Flight 236 (A330), North Atlantic fuel exhaustion, 2001: After both engines flamed out at cruise, the crew started the APU to maintain essential systems and landed safely at Lajes (investigation by Portuguese GPIAAF/TSB Canada). The event illustrates the need for certified and published APU start/operation envelopes at altitude and temperature to assure emergency power when engines are unavailable.

Boeing 777 ETOPS certification program: Regulators (FAA AC 120-42B and EASA AMC 20-6) require demonstration of reliable in-flight APU start and operation at the edges of the approved temperature/altitude envelope, with limits published in the AFM. This programmatic testing and resulting limitations exemplify how CS-25J1527 drives establishing the APU’s environmental operating bounds.

summary: The logic is simple: use standardized green/yellow/red markings on APU instruments to make normal, caution, and do-not-exceed (including any vibration-avoid speeds) unmistakable, so crews keep the APU within safe limits.
intent: Ensure that every Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) indication clearly shows the safe boundaries of operation using standardized color cues so crews can instantly recognize normal, caution, and do-not-exceed conditions. Red marks the absolute limits (maximum and, if applicable, minimum) and any prohibited speed bands; green shows the normal range; yellow shows a precautionary range. This human-factors requirement reduces interpretation time and prevents inadvertent exceedances of APU parameters (e.g., speed/percent RPM, Exhaust Gas Temperature (EGT), oil pressure) that can cause shutdowns, damage, fires, or rotor failures. It also flags any speed ranges that must be avoided due to vibration stresses. The rule harmonizes cockpit markings/ECAM/EICAS displays with common color conventions so pilots and maintainers consistently keep the APU within certified limits during start, loading, and abnormal conditions.
events: FAA AD 2018-26-02 (Honeywell 36-150 series APUs): After reports of uncontained first-stage turbine wheel fractures, the FAA mandated removal of certain turbine wheels. The severity of such failures underscores why clear redline limits for APU speed/EGT must be obvious to prevent operation that could overstress rotating parts.

Airbus A320 program lesson (FCOM/ECAM): Airbus ECAM presents APU EGT and percent RPM using green (normal), amber/yellow (caution), and red (limit/exceedance) indications as documented in A320 FCOM/ECAM description sections. This demonstrates an OEM implementing CS-25-style color coding so crews instantly see and avoid exceedances during start and bleed-air loading.

Boeing 737NG program lesson (FCOM/EICAS): Boeing EICAS shows APU EGT and RPM with green/amber/red limit bands and redline exceedance cues, as described in the 737NG FCOM system indications. This illustrates industry-standard adoption of color markings to keep APU operation within certified ranges, directly reflecting the rule’s purpose.

summary: The logic is simple: give the APU an oil gauge with clear, fine-grained graduations so users always know exactly how much oil is in it and can service or operate it safely.
intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) oil quantity indication is easy to read and sufficiently graduated so ground crews and flight crews can tell, quickly and accurately, how much oil is in the APU. Clear, calibrated increments (whether on a sight glass, dipstick, or digital display) prevent ambiguity that can lead to under‑servicing (oil starvation, APU shutdown/damage) or over‑servicing (oil ingestion into bleed air, smoke/fumes). By making the quantity obvious and precise, operators can make correct go/no‑go and servicing decisions, reducing dispatch delays and safety hazards. APU = Auxiliary Power Unit; CS‑25 = Certification Specification for Large Aeroplanes.
events: EASA SIB 2013-10R1 (Smoke/Fumes in Transport Aeroplanes) highlights that APU oil overfilling/servicing errors are a recurrent cause of cabin smoke/fume events; clear, calibrated oil quantity indications and adherence to markings directly mitigate these occurrences.

AAIB investigated a British Airways Boeing 777-200 serious incident (G-RAES, 2013) involving an engine oil leak and in‑flight shutdown; accurate oil quantity trending informed crew decisions, illustrating why unambiguous, graduated oil quantity indication is safety‑critical (the same principle applies to APU oil systems).

summary: The logic is simple: make the APU oil fill point unambiguous so the right fluid goes in the right place every time, preventing servicing errors that can damage the APU or cause fires.
intent: This rule ensures that the oil fill point of the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is unmistakably identified by a simple, standard word: “oil.” The APU is a small turbine engine that provides electrical power and air on the ground and sometimes in flight. Clear, durable markings at the filler opening prevent maintenance and ramp personnel from confusing service points or adding the wrong fluid, which can lead to APU failures, leaks, fires, or contamination of other systems. The reserved paragraphs indicate that, at minimum, the oil filler label is mandated, keeping the requirement focused and unambiguous for safe servicing under time pressure and in varied lighting and environmental conditions.
events: IATA IGOM (Ground Operations Manual) requires clear identification and verification of aircraft servicing points and fluids during ramp operations; this industry standardization shows why simple, unambiguous markings like “OIL” at filler caps are critical to prevent wrong-fluid servicing.

FAA SAFO 18013 (Jet Fuel Contaminated with Diesel Exhaust Fluid) documents multiple ground‑servicing mix‑ups that led to engine/APU problems; it underscores that clear labeling and strict identification practices at service points are essential to prevent catastrophic maintenance-induced errors.

summary: The logic is simple: put the certified APU limits and the meaning of every instrument marking in the AFM so crews know exactly how to operate and when they are approaching or exceeding a limit.
intent: This rule ensures that all Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) operating limits and the meaning of any cockpit instrument color bands or markings are placed in the Aeroplane Flight Manual (AFM) where pilots and maintenance can readily find them. The APU is a small turbine in the tail that provides electrical power and bleed air for engine start and air conditioning, on ground and in some cases in flight. Limits established under CS 25J1521 (e.g., maximum exhaust gas temperature, rotor speed, generator load, altitude envelopes, starter duty cycles, bleed usage) and the explanations of instrument markings required by CS 25J1549 and CS 25J1551 must be published. The objective is to prevent APU misuse or exceedance by giving crews unambiguous, type-approved limits and clear interpretations of green/amber/red indications, thereby reducing the risk of overtemperature, overspeed, fires, or damage, and ensuring consistent, compliant operation across operators.
events: JAL Boeing 787-8 (JA829J) Boston, 7 Jan 2013: the APU’s lithium-ion battery experienced thermal runaway and a fire while parked at the gate (NTSB DCA13IA037), underscoring that APU systems can pose serious hazards and that clear, approved operating limits and indications are essential for crews to recognize and respond to APU abnormalities within safe bounds.
